When Coffee and Kale Compete

当咖啡和甘蓝竞争

Become Great at Making Products People Will Buy Second Edition

成为伟大的制造产品人们将购买第二版


Alan Klement

Foreword

前言

by Rick Pedi and John Palmer

作者: Rick Pedi 和 John Palmer


Origin of Customer Jobs Theory

顾客工作理论的起源

Back in the days of the quality management movement (mid 1980s), the foundational tenet was that customers define quality. And so, deploying the Voice of the Customer (the VOC) throughout work processes became the central theme for improving business performance. This was especially true in product development, where design teams obsessed about gathering the VOC. In concept, properly researching the VOC would keep developers on track – not over-investing in features customers did not value, and thus, lose money, while not under-investing in features customers did value, and thus, lose customers. It was from this quality management perspective and the high business hopes of deploying the VOC that we created Customer Job Theory (JTBD) - together with Bob Moesta, Pam Murtaugh, and Julia Wesson.

追溯到质量管理运动的时代(20世纪80年代中期) ，其基本原则是客户定义质量。因此，在整个工作过程中部署客户之声(VOC)成为提高业务绩效的中心主题。在产品开发领域尤其如此，设计团队一门心思地收集挥发性有机化合物。从概念上讲，正确研究 VOC 可以让开发人员保持在正确的轨道上——不要过度投资于客户不重视的功能，这样就会亏钱，而不要过度投资于客户确实重视的功能，这样就会失去客户。正是从这种质量管理的角度，以及部署 VOC 的高度商业期望，我们与 Bob Moesta、 Pam Murtaugh 和 Julia Wesson 一起创建了客户工作理论(Customer Job Theory，JTBD)。


Because we are the original source of Customer Jobs, Alan Klement has reached out to us to share his JTBD thinking and to ask our point-of-view on the evolution of JTBD Theory in light of its actual foundational roots. With that in mind, he asked us to write this foreword for his book.

因为我们是客户工作的原始来源，Alan Klement 向我们分享他的 JTBD 思想，并根据 JTBD 理论的实际基础来询问我们对其演变的观点。考虑到这一点，他要求我们为他的书写前言。


Beyond Product Attribute Quality as Value

超越产品属性质量作为价值

JTBD Theory represented a major shift in the focus of product developers and the kind of market research used to support product development. The thinking behind Customer Jobs was the hard-learned understanding that developers and marketers needed to adopt a new paradigm about the meaning of value-for-customers. Instead of attaching value to what products are, value should attach to what products do for customers. In other words, stop trying to communicate value with new and improved product features, and start designing more integrated product experiences that are valuable because of what they enable customers to get done in particular contexts of use.

JTBD 理论代表了产品开发者关注焦点的重大转变，以及用于支持产品开发的市场研究类型。“客户工作”背后的思想是来之不易的理解，即开发人员和营销人员需要采用一种新的范式来理解“为客户创造价值”的含义。价值应该附加在产品为顾客所做的事情上，而不是附加在产品是什么上。换句话说，停止尝试用新的和改进的产品特性来传达价值，开始设计更有价值的集成产品体验，因为它们使客户能够在特定的使用环境中完成。


Our thinking called for new market research techniques that got beyond the prevailing methods that had customers evaluating products and describing lifestyle personas. Instead, we grounded customer interviews in recent real-life purchasing

我们的想法呼吁新的市场调查技术，超越了流行的方法，让客户评估产品和描述生活方式的角色。相反，我们在最近的实际采购中对客户进行了采访


and use situations. We learned how customer behavior derives directly from how customers perceive their market-use situation. No one else can know their situations better than customers do. And we would disguise our research purposes to enable customers to tell us what they actually did and why they did it - openly, expressively, and with emotion.

和使用情况。我们了解了客户行为如何直接来源于客户如何感知他们的市场使用情况。没有人比顾客更了解他们的处境。而且我们会掩饰我们的研究目的，使客户能够告诉我们他们实际上做了什么，为什么他们这样做-公开，表达，并与情感。


Our early Jobs research work never failed to generate amazing gaps between the reasons producers believed customers purchased products in the category (e.g., products were healthy, indulgent, or more convenient) and actual Job purposes customers had for “hiring a product”.

我们早期的乔布斯研究工作总能在生产者认为消费者购买该类产品的原因(例如，产品是健康的、放纵的或者更方便的)和消费者实际的“雇用产品”的工作目的之间产生惊人的差距。


Business growth opportunities could be found in the degree to which the Job that heavy users were hiring the product category to do had not yet been discovered by light or non-users of the category. And optimizing the product design to do the Job better and then communicating the Job value became a good strategy for growing sales.

业务增长的机会可以在某种程度上发现，重度使用者雇用产品类别所做的工作还没有被轻度使用者或非该类别的用户发现。优化产品设计，更好地完成作业，进而传达作业价值，成为促进销售增长的良好策略。


An Early Example

一个早期的例子

The early JTBD evangelists that we taught and inspired began using Snickers as the de facto standard-bearer for communicating the idea that customers hire products to do Jobs. Ever since 1930, consumers experienced the typical candy bar ingredients of chocolate and nougat combined with whole peanuts more as real food than a candy treat. And yet, it wasn’t until 1979 - when Mars introduced the tag “Snickers really satisfies” – that Snickers reflected “new thinking”. Much more than a quality cue, “packed with peanuts” gave customers a reason to connect Snickers use with every day hunger situations.

早期的 JTBD 传道者，我们教导和启发开始使用士力架作为事实上的标准，传达消费者雇用产品做乔布斯的想法。自1930年以来，消费者经历了典型的巧克力和牛轧糖糖果成分与整个花生更作为真正的食物比糖果治疗。然而，直到1979年，当火星推出的标签“士力架真的令人满意”，士力架反映了“新思维”。不仅仅是一个优质的提示，“装满花生”给了消费者一个理由将士力架的使用与每天的饥饿情况联系起来。


The Snickers example easily demonstrated several fundamentals of JTBD Theory that are now commonplace:

Snickers 的例子很容易地证明了 JTBD 理论的几个基本原理，这些原理现在已经司空见惯:


There are often wide gaps between the value producers think customers assign to their products and the real reasons customers have for using the category.

生产者认为客户赋予其产品的价值与客户使用该类别的真正原因之间往往存在很大的差距。


Marketing communications should focus on what a product does for (and to) the customer, not on what it is. A Snickers satisfies hunger –i.e., what it does. It is chocolate and nougat combined with whole peanuts.

营销传播应该关注产品为顾客做了什么，而不是它是什么。士力架可以满足饥饿感——也就是说，它可以做什么。它是巧克力和牛轧糖与整颗花生的混合物。


How the design of products can be perfected against the customer’s hiring criteria. The food-like qualities of peanuts, Snickers’ first bite and chew characteristics, its shape, and its weight in the hand all combine to signal and deliver against the requirements of satisfying hunger in certain customer Job situations.

如何根据客户的聘用标准完善产品设计。类似食物的花生的品质，士力架的第一咬和咀嚼的特点，它的形状，它的重量在手都结合起来，以信号和传递满足饥饿的要求在某些客户的工作情况。


The pitfalls and limitations of defining markets and competition in terms of product categories, versus, seeing markets from the customer’s perspective. Mars came to understand that Snickers and Milky Way, which were thought of as “candy bars, chocolate confections, etc.” were actually hired by customers for very different reasons. The slogan “Milky Way, comfort in every bar” recognized the differences between customers hiring Milky Way to do a “comfort me” Job and the same customers hiring Snickers to do a “satisfy my hunger” Job.

根据产品类别来定义市场和竞争的缺陷和局限性，与从客户的角度来看待市场相比。玛斯开始了解到，被认为是“糖果棒，巧克力糖果等”的士力架和银河系实际上是由顾客出于完全不同的原因雇佣的。标语“银河，每个酒吧都有安慰”认识到了雇佣银河做“安慰我”工作的顾客和雇佣士力架做“满足我的饥饿”工作的顾客之间的区别。


JTBD Theory and Innovation Success

JTBD 理论与创新成功

Over the last 15 years, we’ve continued to advance the thinking we pioneered with JTBD Theory. Our focus has gone beyond using Jobs to explain customer choices. Instead, we have advanced core JTBD principles in order to understand how to develop new product concepts able to carve out new growth footholds in established, fiercely-competitive markets.

在过去的15年里，我们继续推进我们开创的 JTBD 理论的思想。我们的重点已经超越了使用乔布斯来解释客户的选择。相反，我们有先进的核心 JTBD 原则，以了解如何开发新的产品概念，能够开拓新的增长立足点，在成熟的，激烈的竞争市场。


We also have followed closely Clayton Christensen’s popularization of JTBD Theory and the connections to innovation he and his followers have made. In paraphrasing Clay:

我们还密切关注克莱顿 · 克里斯滕森对 JTBD 理论的推广，以及他和他的追随者们与创新之间的联系。用克莱的话来说:


A Job is the progress that an individual is trying to make in a particular circumstance. And for innovators, understanding the Job is to understand what customers care most about in that moment of trying to make progress … i.e., the causal mechanism of customer behavior. Therefore, JTBD Theory provides a way of understanding the foundational question of innovation success: what causes a customer to purchase and use a particular product or service.

工作是一个人在特定环境下努力取得的进步。而对于创新者来说，理解工作就是理解客户在努力取得进展的那一刻最关心什么... ... 也就是说，客户行为的因果机制。因此，JTBD 理论提供了一种理解创新成功的基本问题的方法: 什么导致顾客购买和使用特定的产品或服务。


We respectfully disagree with the assertion that answering that question is the key to innovation success (of course that depends on your definition of innovation). How can you expect to invent new value propositions that will create tomorrow’s

我们不同意这样的说法，即回答这个问题是创新成功的关键(当然这取决于你对创新的定义)。你怎么能期望发明新的价值主张来创造明天的价值主张呢


markets … with an understanding of customer progress that only explains why customers buy products today?

市场... 了解客户的进展，这只能解释为什么客户购买产品今天？


Moreover, understanding what customers care most about in that moment of trying to make progress, brings us back to the very beginning - JTBD Theory as way for businesses to grow sales by improving performance against the customer’s definition of quality – essentially aligning today’s products and services with the real reasons customers are buying them.

此外，在试图取得进展的那一刻，理解客户最关心的是什么，让我们回到最初—— JTBD 理论，作为企业通过提高业绩来增加销售额的方式，而不是客户对质量的定义——本质上是将当今的产品和服务与客户购买它们的真正原因联系起来。


Our work, on the other hand, has led to asking and answering a very different question as the foundational question of innovation success: how do individuals develop themselves by using the marketplace to advance towards the values, norms, and ideals that enrich the meaning of their lives. After all, innovation is relevant only if it creates or leads customers to substantial new meaning in how they lead their lives. And by focusing on creating new market behavior versus explaining current behavior, we shift the innovator’s work from explaining historical choices based on what a product does and is … to understanding why and how customers would develop new market knowledge and behavior tomorrow.

另一方面，我们的工作提出并回答了一个截然不同的问题，这个问题是关于创新成功的基本问题: 个人如何通过利用市场来发展自己，以达到丰富他们生活意义的价值观、规范和理想。毕竟，只有当创新创造或引导客户在他们如何生活中获得重大新意义时，创新才有意义。通过专注于创造新的市场行为，而不是解释当前的行为，我们将创新者的工作从解释基于产品的历史选择转移到理解为什么以及如何客户明天会发展新的市场知识和行为。


Alan’s Work and What’s Next

艾伦的工作和下一步

In light of our work, we find Alan’s thinking to be a breath of fresh air. Through determination and perseverance, he has developed the forward-looking “Self-Betterment” concept to explain the demand side of innovation. He makes a compelling case for Self-Betterment as a basis for innovators to work out what should be next. His case stands in stark contrast to prevailing JTBD Theory that can only explain today’s customer choices.

根据我们的工作，我们发现艾伦的思想是一股清新的空气。通过决心和毅力，他发展了前瞻性的“自我完善”的概念来解释创新的需求面。他提出了一个令人信服的案例，自我改善作为基础，创新者应该找出下一个什么。他的案例与流行的 JTBD 理论形成鲜明对比，后者只能解释当今的客户选择。


Alan’s work recognizes that humans have a compelling imperative to improve themselves. His thinking echoes the work we have been doing to explain why people, whose needs are already well met, still hunt the market for new ideas.

艾伦的工作认识到，人类迫切需要提高自己。他的想法与我们的工作相呼应，我们一直在努力解释，为什么那些需求已经得到很好满足的人，仍然在市场上寻找新想法。


In our view, the Self-Betterment idea is on track and Alan is poised to develop it further in this direction: Human beings don’t stand still. And in living their lives, they are restless innovators who use their environment - in this case the ecosystem of market information - to imagine better scenarios to their status quo … to change existing situations to preferred ones … to imagine what ought to be next in living their lives.

在我们看来，自我改善的理念正在走上正轨，艾伦准备朝着这个方向进一步发展: 人类不会停滞不前。在生活中，他们是不知疲倦的创新者，他们利用自己的环境——在这种情况下是市场信息的生态系统——想象更好的情景来改变他们的现状... 把现有的情况改变成喜欢的情况... 想象他们生活中的下一步应该是什么。


Step-change business growth demands that new product concepts reflect the improvement imperative that keeps customers looking to the market for ideas, devices, and knowledge that break from the past. The “next book” should fill in a picture of work we are now doing with causal models that explain how customers actually use the market to transform themselves and lift their capabilities for living the lives they imagine.

逐步变化的业务增长要求新的产品概念反映出改进的必要性，这种必要性使得客户不断向市场寻找突破过去的想法、设备和知识。“下一本书”应该填补我们现在正在做的工作的图景，用因果模型来解释客户实际上如何利用市场来改变自己，提高他们过自己想象的生活的能力。


This book does not represent insights from one person, but from many. Those listed here—as well as those whose names I have mistakenly omitted—have helped me understand JTBD and thereby helped me write this book. I am indebted to them and the entire JTBD community.

这本书并不代表一个人的见解，而是来自许多人的。这里列出的那些人ーー以及那些我错漏了名字的人ーー帮助我理解了 JTBD，从而帮助我撰写了这本书。我感激他们和整个 JTBD 社区。


Tim Zenderman, Samuel Hulick, Leslie Owensby, Michael Sacca, Willis Jackson III, Morgan Ranieri, Andrej Balaz, Daphne Lin, Matthew Woo, Matt Brooks, Mat Budelman, Eric White, David Wu, Bob Moesta, John Palmer, Rick Pedi, Chris Spiek, Ervin Fowlkes, Timur Kunayev, Matthew Gunson, Alex Yang, Ryan D. Hmesatch, Leslie Owensby, Marc Galbraith, Daryl Choy, James Ramsay, Joshua Porter, Tor L. Bollingmo, Martin Jordan, Ryan Singer, Laura Roeder, Justin Jackson, Vincent van der Lubbe, Ash Maurya, Benedict Evans, Esteban Mancuso, Des Traynor, Paul Adams, Sian Townsend, and the rest of the Intercom team, Daniel Ritzenthaler, Dan Martell, Anthony Francavilla, Omer Yariv, Justin Sinclair, Joanna Wiebe, Paulo Peres, Alexander Horré, Bleau Alexandru, Tom Masiero, Jose

Tim Zenderman，Samuel Hulick，Leslie Owensby，Michael Sacca，Willis Jackson III，Morgan Ranieri，Andrej Balaz，Daphne Lin，Matthew Woo，Matt Brooks，Mat Budelman，Eric White，David Wu，Bob Moesta，John Palmer，Rick Pedi，Chris Spiek，Ervin Fowlkes，Timur Kunayev，Matthew Gunson，Alex Yang，Ryan D. Hmesatch，Leslie Owensby，Marc Galbraith,daryl Choy，James Ramsay，Joshua Porter，Tor L. Bollingmo，Martin Jordan，Ryan Singer，Laura Roeder，Justin Jackson，Vincent van der Lubbe，Ash Maurya，Benedict Evans，Esteban Mancuso，Des Traynor,保罗 · 亚当斯、西安 · 汤森德和对讲机团队的其他成员，丹尼尔 · 里森塔勒、丹 · 马特尔、安东尼 · 弗兰卡维拉、奥马尔 · 亚里夫、贾斯汀 · 辛克莱尔、乔安娜 · 韦伯、保罗 · 佩雷斯、亚历山大 · 霍雷、布劳 · 亚历山德鲁、汤姆 · 马西埃罗、何塞

A. de Miguel, Dimitri Nassis, Roman Meliška, Paul Gonzalez, Lee Yanco, Thomas Fröhlich, Lou Franco, David Emmett, Thomas Huetter, Nir Benita, Kyle Fiedler and Trace Wax and the thoughtbot team, everyone at the NYC JTBD Meetup, Amrita Chandra, Jeremy Horn, David Lee, Barry Clark, Ryan Witt, Boris Grinkot, Alex Lumley, Claudio Perrone, Omar Gonzalez, Ain Tohvri, Amit Vemuri, Sri Vemuri, Hiten Shah, Paul Sullivan, Matthew Woo, Joanna Wiebe, George White, Dave Rothschild, Elvin Turner, Mike Rivera, Jason Evanish, Levi Kovacs, and Debbie Szumylo.

A.De Miguel，Dimitri Nassis，Roman Meli ka，Paul Gonzalez，Lee Yanco，Thomas Fröhlich，Lou Franco，David Emmett，Thomas Huetter，Nir Benita，Kyle Fiedler and Trace Wax 和思想机器人团队，纽约 JTBD 聚会上的每个人，Amrita Chandra，Jeremy Horn，David Lee，Barry Clark，Ryan Witt，Boris Grinkot，Alex Lumley，Claudio Perrone,omar Gonzalez，Ain Tohvri，Amit Vemuri，Sri Vemuri，Hiten Shah，Paul Sullivan，Matthew Woo，Joanna Wiebe，George White，Dave Rothschild，Elvin Turner，Mike Rivera，Jason Evanish，Levi Kovacs，and Debbie Szumylo.


Alan Klement October 2, 2016

Alan Klement 2016年10月2日


Challenges Hope About me

关于我的挑战希望

How to be successful with JTBD and this book Abandon every MBA, all you who enter

如何成功与 JTBD 和这本书放弃每一个 MBA，所有你进入


This book will help you become great at creating and selling products that people will buy. Your joy at work will grow. You will know how to help companies increase revenue, reduce waste, remain competitive, and make innovation more predictable and profitable. In doing so, you will help economies prosper and help provide stable jobs for employees and the families who depend on them.

这本书将帮助你成为伟大的创造和销售产品，人们会买。你在工作中的快乐会增长。你将知道如何帮助公司增加收入，减少浪费，保持竞争力，使创新更加可预测和有利可图。通过这样做，你们将帮助经济繁荣，并帮助为雇员和依赖他们的家庭提供稳定的工作。


I struggled with innovation for many years. I finally made progress when I focused on two things:

我与创新斗争了很多年，最终我在两件事情上取得了进步:


The desire every customer has to improve themselves and their life-situations.

每个顾客都有改善自己和生活状况的愿望。


How customers imagine their lives being better when they have the right solution.

客户如何想象当他们有正确的解决方案时他们的生活会变得更好。


This understanding has helped me become a better innovator. I believe it will do the same for you. Yet, challenges stand in your way. This chapter introduces these challenges. The rest of this book will equip you with the understanding of how your focus on the customer’s desire for self-betterment as a Job to be Done (JTBD) will help you overcome these challenges.

这种理解帮助我成为一个更好的创新者。我相信对你也一样。然而，挑战阻碍着你。本章将介绍这些挑战。本书的其余部分将帮助你理解，如何将重点放在客户的自我完善欲望上，将其作为一项待完成的工作(JTBD) ，这将有助于你克服这些挑战。


Challenges

挑战

Creative destruction is accelerating. The average time a company spends on the S&P 500 continues to drop. In 1960, it was fifty-five years; in 2015, it was about twenty (figure 1). This happened for numerous reasons. A big one is that it has never been easier to create a product and get it to customers. This increases the pace at which new innovations disrupt the sales of incumbent ones and then go on to replace them. This process is known as creative destruction.1

创造性破坏正在加速。一家公司在标准普尔500指数上花费的平均时间继续下降。1960年是55年，2015年大约是20年(图1)。这种情况发生的原因有很多。一个重要的原因是，创造一种产品并将其推向消费者从未像现在这样容易。这加快了新创新扰乱现有产品销售，然后继续替代它们的步伐。这个过程被称为创造性破坏。1



Figure 1. Creative destruction in action. The average company life span on the S&P 500 index has declined over time (rolling seven-year average).

图1。行动中的创造性破坏。标准普尔500指数成分股公司的平均寿命随着时间的推移有所下降(连续7年平均)



When one innovation wins, another loses. Why? Because a day has only so many minutes, and a customer can use only one product at a time. For example, every day I used to get an espresso from a coffee shop down the street. Two months ago, I bought a Nespresso machine. Now I make my own espressos. The coffee shop has lost my business.

当一项创新获胜时，另一项就会失败。为什么？因为一天只有这么多分钟，而且一个客户一次只能使用一种产品。例如，我过去每天都会去街边的咖啡店买一杯浓缩咖啡。两个月前，我买了一台 Nespresso 咖啡机。现在我自己做浓缩咖啡。咖啡店失去了我的生意。


The theory of Customer Jobs and the idea that customers buy a product to complete a Job to be Done, help us understand all the creative destruction around us. Even though solutions and technologies come and go, the customer’s desire for self-betterment is always there. This focus on everyone’s desire for self-betterment is the key to successful, ongoing innovation and business.

顾客工作的理论和顾客购买产品来完成工作的想法，帮助我们理解我们周围所有的创造性破坏。即使解决方案和技术来来去去，客户对自我完善的渴望始终存在。这种对每个人自我改善愿望的关注是成功、持续创新和商业的关键。


“Sunk costs” keep us from creating new products. In 1975, a Kodak engineer invented the digital camera. What was the management’s response? They shelved it. Management argued that Kodak “could” sell a digital camera, but why would they? They made billions of dollars selling photographic film. A digital camera would cannibalize their film sales. In the end, Kodak’s management decided that the company would skip digital and focus on selling photographic film.2

“沉没成本”使我们无法创造新产品。1975年，一位柯达工程师发明了数码相机。管理层的反应是什么？他们把它搁置了。管理层辩称，柯达“可以”出售数码相机，但他们为什么要这么做呢？他们靠卖胶片赚了数十亿美元。数码相机会蚕食他们的胶卷销售。最后，柯达的管理层决定，公司将跳过数字化，专注于销售胶片


In 2012, Kodak filed for bankruptcy. What happened? Customers no longer needed film for their cameras—they had switched to digital cameras. Kodak’s downfall was due to management’s unwillingness to adapt to a world with digital cameras— something they had invented forty years earlier.

2012年，柯达申请破产。发生什么事了？消费者的相机不再需要胶卷ーー他们已经转而使用数码相机。柯达之所以垮台，是因为管理层不愿适应一个有数码相机的世界ーー这是他们40年前发明的东西。



Figure 2. What data about your product are information? Which are misinformation?

图2。关于您的产品的哪些数据是信息? 哪些是错误信息？



Very often, it’s not legacy technology that stops companies from adapting, but being tied to a legacy business model. And when change is proposed to management, they have unlimited excuses to avoid it: “We make billions of dollars with our current products. Why risk it by selling something different?”; “We’ve spent a hundred years perfecting what we do and building the company we have today. Why should we change?” Excuses like these make it hard for businesses to adapt, but change will always happen. Customer Jobs gives you the confidence to break away from legacy business models and create the products of tomorrow.3

很多时候，阻止公司进行适应的不是遗留技术，而是与遗留业务模型绑定在一起。当向管理层提出变革建议时，他们有无数的借口来避免变革: “我们用现有产品赚了数十亿美元。为什么要冒险出售一些不同的东西呢?”“我们花了一百年的时间来完善我们的工作，建立我们今天的公司。我们为什么要改变?”这样的借口让企业难以适应，但变革总会发生。客户工作让你有信心摆脱传统的商业模式，创造未来的产品。3


It’s a mistake to focus on our customers’ physical characteristics. My father-in-law is sixty-five years old, is from the Bronx, and has never used a computer in his life. I’m thirty-five years old, from Florida, and wrote my first computer program at fifteen. Our behaviors, physical characteristics, life goals, and personal histories couldn’t be more different. Nevertheless, we both own the same model of smartphone. We even use it in almost the same way. Will a study of who we are and how we behave explain why? Which data in figure 2 are information? Which are misinformation?4

关注顾客的身体特征是错误的。我的岳父今年65岁，来自布朗克斯区，一生中从未使用过电脑。我今年35岁，来自佛罗里达州，15岁时编写了我的第一个计算机程序。我们的行为、身体特征、生活目标和个人历史都大相径庭。尽管如此，我们还是拥有同一款智能手机。我们甚至以几乎相同的方式使用它。一项关于我们是谁以及我们如何行为的研究能够解释为什么吗？图2中的哪些数据是信息？哪些是错误的信息？4


JTBD helps you become better at knowing the difference between good data and bad data. This helps you focus on making changes to your product that bring profits instead of increasing your costs of production only.

JTBD 可以帮助您更好地了解好数据和坏数据之间的区别。这样可以帮助你集中精力对产品进行修改，从而带来利润，而不仅仅是增加生产成本。


We don’t take into consideration how customers see competition. In 2006, Indian manufacturer Godrej collaborated with Harvard Business School professor Dr. Clayton Christensen to create the chotuKool—a low-cost, feature-minimal refrigerator. It was hailed as a “disruptive innovation” that would create a new market of refrigerators and create what Christensen calls “inclusive growth” for millions of low-income Indians. Unfortunately, the chotuKool was a costly flop. What happened?

我们不考虑顾客如何看待竞争。2006年，印度制造商 Godrej 与哈佛商学院(Harvard Business School)教授克莱顿•克里斯滕森博士(Dr. Clayton Christensen)合作，创造了一种低成本、功能最少的冰箱 chotuKool。它被誉为“破坏性创新”，将创造一个新的冰箱市场，并为数百万低收入印度人创造克里斯滕森所说的“包容性增长”。不幸的是，ChootuKool 是一个昂贵的失败。发生什么事了？


For far too long, academics and analysts—who have no personal experience with innovation—have created and sold pseudoscientific theories of innovation. Unfortunately, these theories often mislead. The resulting product failures exact terrible costs on our economies. This happens because most, and perhaps all, of these theories don’t take into consideration how customers view competition. Do PCs compete with mainframes because they’re both “computers,” or do PCs compete with typewriters, video game systems, and accountants? Do hard drives compete only with other hard drives, or do they also compete with tape storage, CDs, DVDs, floppy disks, flash drives, and cloud storage?

长期以来，学者和分析师(他们没有创新的个人经验)创造和兜售伪科学的创新理论。不幸的是，这些理论经常误导。由此产生的产品故障给我们的经济造成了可怕的损失。之所以会出现这种情况，是因为这些理论中的大多数(也许是全部)没有考虑到顾客如何看待竞争。PC 与大型机竞争是因为它们都是“计算机”，还是 PC 与打字机、视频游戏系统和会计竞争？硬盘驱动器是仅仅与其他硬盘驱动器竞争，还是也与磁带存储器、 CD、 DVD、软盘、闪存驱动器和云存储器竞争？


JTBD helps you avoid mistakes like the chotuKool and falling victim to invalid theories of markets by giving you the knowledge to create an accurate model of competition before you create a product. It does this by helping you learn how to gain the customer’s perspective on what does and doesn’t count as competition for a JTBD.

JTBD 帮助您避免像 chotuKool 这样的错误，避免成为无效的市场理论的受害者，因为它在您创建产品之前为您提供了创建准确的竞争模型的知识。它通过帮助您了解如何获得客户对于什么算作 JTBD 的竞争，什么不算作竞争的观点来实现这一点。


We myopically study and improve on customers’ “needs” and expectations of today; instead, we should create new systems that help customers make progress. In the 1860s, the Pony Express was created to help customers get letters and messages across the United States as fast as possible. It lasted only nineteen months. What happened? Western Union established the transcontinental telegraph. While the Pony Express was trying to solve the “needs” associated with using physical mail, Western Union thought, what if we could communicate without using physical messages? 5

我们目光短浅地研究和改进当今客户的“需求”和期望; 相反，我们应该创建帮助客户取得进展的新系统。在19世纪60年代，驿马快递被创造出来，以帮助顾客尽可能快地在美国各地收到信件和信息。只持续了19个月。发生什么事了？西联电报公司建立了洲际电报。当驿马快递试图解决与使用实体邮件有关的“需求”时，西联电报公司想，如果我们不使用实体邮件就能交流会怎样？5


Very often, innovators think they are studying customers’ needs – when in fact they are studying what customers don’t like about the products they use today, or what customers currently expect from a product. For many years, manufacturers such as Nokia, Palm, Research in Motion (RIM), and Motorola worked hard to satisfy customers’ stated needs and expectations: make a low-price smartphone with a physical keyboard. Today, those expectations have been reversed. Customers don’t mind shelling out several hundred dollars for a smartphone, and physical keyboards have almost completely disappeared.

很多时候，创新者认为他们是在研究客户的需求——实际上他们是在研究客户对他们今天使用的产品不满意的地方，或者客户当前对产品的期望。多年来，诺基亚、 Palm、 Research in Motion (RIM)和摩托罗拉(Motorola)等制造商一直努力满足客户的既定需求和期望: 生产带有物理键盘的低价智能手机。如今，这些预期已经被逆转。消费者不介意花几百美元买一部智能手机，实体键盘也几乎完全消失了。


We can’t build the products of tomorrow when we limit ourselves to the needs and expectations associated with the products of today. Instead, we should focus on what never changes for customers: their desire for progress. When we focus on delivering customers’ progress—instead of what customers say they want—we are free to imagine a world where many needs and expectations are replaced with new ones. Customer Jobs theory helps us ask, “Customers keep asking for a smartphone with a keyboard, but couldn’t we help customers so much more if we take it away?” Chapters 13 and 14 show you the power of prioritizing customer progress over everything else.

当我们把自己局限于与今天的产品相关的需求和期望时，我们就不能创造明天的产品。相反，我们应该关注那些永远不会改变的客户: 他们对进步的渴望。当我们专注于为客户带来进步时ーー而不是客户说他们想要什么ーー我们可以自由地想象一个世界，许多需求和期望被新的需求和期望所取代。客户工作理论帮助我们提出这样一个问题: “客户一直要求一部带键盘的智能手机，但如果我们把它拿走，难道我们不能为客户提供更多的帮助吗?”第13章和第14章向您展示了将客户进度优先于其他任何事情的能力。


We may think about the upsides of product changes only, ignore the downsides, and fail to embrace new ways of helping customers make progress. In the early 1980s, the Coca-Cola Company was losing market share to Pepsi. In response, Coca-Cola’s management decided to change the formula for Coke, believing that the change would increase market share. They were wrong. Loyal customers went up in arms over it; three months later, Coca-Cola’s original formula was restored. Over time, the company regained its market share, but it was lucky. It had the money and resources to recover from the mistake.6

我们可能只考虑产品变化的好处，忽略不好的方面，而不能接受帮助客户取得进步的新方法。上世纪80年代初，可口可乐公司的市场份额逐渐被百事可乐抢走。作为回应，可口可乐的管理层决定改变可口可乐的配方，认为这一改变将增加市场份额。他们错了。忠实的消费者对此表示强烈反对; 三个月后，可口可乐的原始配方得以恢复。随着时间的推移，该公司重新获得了市场份额，但这是幸运的。它有足够的资金和资源从错误中恢复过来。6


Customer Jobs helps you know when it does and doesn’t make sense to change your product. Your product might be fine the way it is. Any further investment might increase only your costs of production. Customer Jobs also helps you understand the opportunity costs: what happens when you don’t invest in new products, even if it means cannibalizing existing offerings? Kodak knows the cost of not embracing new ways of helping customers evolve: bankruptcy.

客户工作可以帮助你知道什么时候需要改变产品，什么时候改变产品是没有意义的。你的产品可能就是这个样子。任何进一步的投资可能只会增加你的生产成本。客户工作还可以帮助你理解机会成本: 如果你不投资新产品，即使这意味着拆分现有产品，会发生什么情况？柯达知道不接受帮助客户发展的新方法的代价: 破产。


Our decision making can be misled when we manage by visible figures only. Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAT) and Net Promoter Score (NPS) are figures that seems straightforward enough. Ask customers to self-report their satisfaction with your product and record their responses. If CSAT or NPS are high, you’re doing a good job. Easy, right? Yet, such data and figures are incomplete at best and misinformation at worst. In chapter 13, you’ll learn about Spirit Airlines. Customers have consistently rated it as the worst airline in the United States. Nevertheless, it continues to be the fastest-growing and most profitable airline in America. If customers hate it so much, why do they keep flying it?

我们的决策可以被误导，当我们管理只有可见的数字。顾客满意度得分(CSAT)和净促进者得分(NPS)是看起来足够简单的数字。要求客户自我报告他们对你的产品的满意度，并记录他们的反应。如果 CSAT 或 NPS 很高，那么你做得很好。很简单，对吧？然而，这些数据和数字往好里说是不完整的，往坏里说是错误的信息。在第13章，你将了解精神航空公司。客户们一直把它评为美国最差的航空公司。尽管如此，它仍然是美国增长最快、利润最丰厚的航空公司。如果顾客这么讨厌它，他们为什么还要继续飞呢？



Figure 3. A tale of creative destruction. Chasing visible figures often leads to poor decisions about your product.

图3。一个创造性破坏的故事。追求可见的数字往往会导致对你的产品做出错误的决定



Figures can not only be misleading, they can also be misused. We see this today with the number of monthly active users (MAU) for Twitter. It has experienced explosive growth over the last five years—annual revenue was $106 million in 2011 and $2.2 billion in 2015. Yet analysts and journalists continue to write articles titled “The End of Twitter” and “A Eulogy for Twitter.” Why?

数字不仅可以误导，还可能被误用。今天我们看到的是 Twitter 的月活跃用户数(MAU)。在过去五年里，该公司经历了爆炸性的增长，2011年的年收入为1.06亿美元，2015年为22亿美元。然而，分析人士和记者继续撰写题为《推特的终结》和《推特颂词》的文章为什么？


The most common criticism is that growth of Twitter’s MAUs has stalled at “only” 313 million. Is it any surprise when management’s priority then becomes “How can we make MAUs go up?” instead of “How can we continue to make Twitter valuable to users, so they won’t leave?” Yes, adding new features might push up visible figures such as MAU in the short term, but constant changes might upset and drive away loyal users. Instead, we should congratulate Twitter’s employees for their hard work and gently remind them of grandmother’s advice: “When you try and please everyone, you end up pleasing no one.”7

最常见的批评是，Twitter 的 MAU 增长停滞在“仅仅”3.13亿。当管理层的优先权变成“我们怎样才能让 MAU 上升?”而不是“我们如何继续让 Twitter 对用户有价值，这样他们就不会离开了?”是的，增加新的功能可能会在短期内推高像 MAU 这样的可见数字，但是不断的变化可能会让忠实用户感到不安并离开他们。相反，我们应该祝贺 Twitter 的员工们的辛勤工作，并温和地提醒他们记住祖母的建议: “当你试图取悦每一个人时，你最终将无法取悦任何人。”7


Many innovators and managers have been influenced by ideas such as: If you can’t measure it, you can’t manage it.

许多创新者和管理者都受到这样的想法的影响: 如果你不能衡量它，你就不能管理它。

What gets measured gets improved.

被测量的东西得到改进。


However, such opinions do not take into consideration the following:8

然而，这些意见没有考虑到以下几点: 8


All models are wrong, but some are useful.

所有的模型都是错误的，但有些是有用的。


The most important figures are unknown or unknowable, but successful management must nevertheless take account of them.

最重要的数字是未知的或不可知的，但成功的管理必须考虑到他们。


If you torture the data long enough, they will tell you whatever you want.

如果你折磨数据够久，他们会告诉你任何你想知道的。


It is wrong to suppose that if you can’t measure it, you can’t manage it – a costly myth.

认为如果你不能测量它，你就不能管理它，这种想法是错误的——这是一个代价高昂的神话。


These statements were made by some of the most important mathematicians and systems thinkers of the twentieth century. They are warnings for those who subscribe to the idea of being driven by visible figures only, and not taking into consideration figures that are unknown or unknowable. Yes, visible figures can be helpful and are often necessary. We have payroll to meet and should strive to increase long-term profits. But we can let figure based data deceive us.

这些陈述是由二十世纪一些最重要的数学家和系统思想家作出的。对于那些认同只由可见数字驱动、而不考虑未知或不可知数字的人来说，这是一个警告。是的，可见的数字是有帮助的，而且往往是必要的。我们有工资单要支付，应该努力增加长期利润。但是我们可以让基于数字的数据欺骗我们。


We must remember that data are only proxies for some results of a system. Moreover, the most important figures are unknown and unknowable. What figures or data would have told Apple to remove floppy drives from PCs or keyboards from their smartphones? At the time, many dismissed or criticized these ideas. Journalists claimed Apple’s management had lost their minds. Now we regard Apple’s decisions as obvious. And what about Twitter’s MAUs? The number of users who might want a product like Twitter is a figure that is unknown and unknowable. Twitter’s 313 million MAU might represent 100 percent of the market. Analysts, journalists, and even Twitter’s own shareholders might be punishing the company even as it achieves market dominance.

我们必须记住，数据只是系统某些结果的代理。此外，最重要的人物是未知的和不可知的。什么样的数字或数据会让苹果从个人电脑或智能手机的键盘上移除软盘驱动器？当时，许多人对这些想法不屑一顾或提出批评。记者们声称苹果的管理层已经失去了理智。现在我们认为苹果的决定是显而易见的。那推特上的 MAU 呢？可能想要 Twitter 这样的产品的用户数量是一个未知的数字。Twitter 的3.13亿 MAU 可能代表了100% 的市场份额。分析师、记者甚至 Twitter 自己的股东可能正在惩罚这家公司，尽管它已经取得了市场主导地位。


There are a variety of consequences that arise when we abandon intuition and risk taking in favor of management by visible figures only. Perhaps the worst are the unfounded beliefs that a product will last forever, and that products and companies can continuously grow revenue and attract more customers. The reality is that growth for every product will slow and stop. Nothing lasts forever.

当我们放弃直觉和冒险，转而采用只有可见数字的管理方式时，就会产生各种各样的后果。也许最糟糕的是那些毫无根据的信念，认为一种产品将永远存在，而且产品和公司可以不断增加收入，吸引更多的客户。现实情况是，每种产品的增长都将放缓并停止。世事无常 (1979年小说)。


Unfortunately, many managers either don’t know or won’t accept this. Instead, they become worried when growth slows. They start making changes to their product in hopes of attracting more customers and increasing revenue; however, the effect is often the opposite. Management ends up making the product worse for existing customers. With some luck, a competitor won’t notice.9

不幸的是，许多经理要么不知道，要么不愿意接受这一点。相反，当经济增长放缓时，他们会感到担忧。他们开始改变他们的产品，希望吸引更多的客户和增加收入; 然而，结果往往是相反的。管理最终会使现有客户的产品变得更糟。运气好的话，竞争对手不会注意到的。9


But luck will eventually run out. Another innovation will enter the market with a product that customers find more valuable (figure 3). Why? Because the entrant’s innovation cuts off all the baggage the incumbent added during management’s frantic attempt to push up all those visible figures. This is when customers begin to switch from the incumbent to the newcomer. So, goes the cycle of creative destruction.

但运气最终会用完的。另一项创新将通过客户认为更有价值的产品进入市场(图3)。为什么？因为进入者的创新切断了所有的包袱，现任者在管理层的疯狂尝试推高所有这些可见的数字。这就是客户开始从在位者转向新来者的时候。这就是创造性破坏的循环。


Innovation is hard, risky, and nerve-racking. Just ask anyone who has successfully done it. But Customer Jobs can help. With the correct point of view, we can see how visible figures tell us about individual parts of a system only. Once we understand that, we can apply Customer Jobs thinking and understand the relationships around the data. This gives us the ability to assign the proper weight to these figures—or even dismiss them. This helps us become better at knowing if we should continue to improve an existing product or take a risk and develop a new one.

创新是困难的，有风险的，也是令人紧张的。问问任何一个成功做到这一点的人就知道了。但客户工作可以起到帮助作用。有了正确的观点，我们可以看到可见的数字如何告诉我们关于一个系统的个别部分只。一旦我们理解了这一点，我们就可以应用客户工作的思想，并理解数据周围的关系。这使我们能够对这些数字给予适当的权重，甚至可以忽略它们。这有助于我们更好地了解我们是应该继续改进现有产品，还是冒险开发新产品。


Hope

希望

Customer Jobs theory and this book offer you hope whether you are a struggling innovator or just want to become better at understanding, marketing, innovation, product design, or all three. Customer Jobs gives you a collection of principles for understanding why customers buy and use products. This singular attention to customer’s desire for self-betterment—instead of what customers say they want, their demographics, or what they do—is what distinguishes Customer Jobs from other theories. This book aims to explain the theory reliably and consistently.

客户工作理论和这本书给你希望，无论你是一个奋斗的创新者或只是想成为更好的理解，市场营销，创新，产品设计，或所有三个。Customer Jobs 为您提供了一系列原则，帮助您理解客户购买和使用产品的原因。这种对顾客自我完善愿望的独特关注ーー而不是顾客说他们想要什么、他们的人口统计特征或他们做什么ーー正是客户工作区别于其他理论的地方。这本书的目的是可靠和连贯地解释这一理论。


At the time of this writing (2015), no comprehensive book about Customer Jobs theory exists. This is the first. Many others have written interpretations of some of its principles, but almost all of them have created more confusion than clarity.

在撰写本文时(2015年) ，还没有关于客户工作理论的全面著作。这是第一次。许多其他人对其中的一些原则进行了书面解释，但几乎所有这些解释都造成了更多的混乱而不是清晰。


This book stands out from other writings about Customer Jobs because its contributors—including me—are all innovators and entrepreneurs in our own right. We’ve applied the theory to our own businesses and products, rather than merely study and preach it.

这本书之所以脱颖而出，是因为它的贡献者ーー包括我ーー本身就是创新者和企业家。我们已经将这一理论应用于我们自己的企业和产品，而不仅仅是学习和宣传它。


I developed this book and Customer Jobs theory as if I were creating a product. For Customer Jobs to be successful, it must deliver progress to those who plan on using it. This is why I interviewed sixty-three innovators about their struggles with innovation and how Job to be Done helped them design a better product. I

我发展了这本书和客户工作理论，就好像我在创造一个产品。为了让客户工作获得成功，它必须向那些计划使用它的人提供进展。这就是为什么我采访了63位创新者，谈论他们如何与创新斗争，以及如何完成工作帮助他们设计出更好的产品。我


extracted numerous case studies and insights from these interviews. The most comprehensive and useful ones are featured in this book.

从这些访谈中摘录了大量的案例研究和见解，其中最全面、最有用的在本书中。


I had to combine my experiences with those of these innovators to design Customer Jobs into what it should be. I learned something from every practitioner I talked with. I am in their debt. Of course, you benefit the most. With this book, you add the accumulated experience of many successful innovators to your own. This collective knowledge will help you become better at creating and selling products that customers will buy.

我必须将我的经验与这些创新者的经验结合起来，把客户工作设计成它应该成为的样子。我从每个医生那里都学到了一些东西。我欠他们的。当然，你受益最大。通过这本书，你可以把许多成功的创新者的经验积累到你自己身上。这种集体知识将帮助您更好地创造和销售客户将购买的产品。


The Progress You Can Make with Customer Jobs

客户工作的进展

Customer Jobs is attractive to many because it offers you progress in many ways. Here are a few of my favorite.

客户工作对很多人来说很有吸引力，因为它能在很多方面给你带来进步。这里有一些我最喜欢的。


Alignment and distributed decision-making. Insights around a customer’s Jobs to be Done serves as a "true north". Everyone in the business will use the same customer insights to market, design, build, and manage solutions that customers will buy and use to make progress in their lives. This empowers employees throughout the organization to make good decisions that align with the job, be autonomous and innovative.

调整和分布式决策。洞察客户的“工作待完成”是一个“真正的北方”。业务中的每个人都将使用相同的客户洞察力来进行市场营销、设计、构建和管理解决方案，客户将购买并使用这些解决方案在他们的生活中取得进展。这使整个组织的员工能够做出与工作相一致的、自主的、创新的好决定。


Know what data are and are not needed for innovation. Innovators created Customer Jobs theory for themselves. We didn’t create it to sell books, collect speaking fees, sell MBA diplomas, or get a PhD from a business school. We created Customer Jobs because we needed help creating successful products that could support our families. In order to do this, we had to figure out what data were and were not relevant to our innovation efforts.

知道创新需要什么数据，不需要什么数据。创新者为自己创造了客户工作理论。我们创建它不是为了销售书籍、收取演讲费、出售 MBA 文凭或从商学院获得博士学位。我们创造客户工作是因为我们需要帮助来创造成功的产品来支持我们的家庭。为了做到这一点，我们必须弄清楚哪些数据与我们的创新努力有关，哪些数据与我们的创新努力无关。


When we design, we’re faced the countless trade-offs involved in developing a business strategy, crafting advertising, designing, and engineering, from which questions like these arise:

当我们设计的时候，我们面临着无数的权衡，包括制定商业策略，精心制作广告，设计和工程，这些问题就会产生:


We can’t attack every market. Which ones should we focus on?

我们不能攻击每一个市场，我们应该关注哪些市场？


Our video ad must connect with customers in just five seconds. How can we do that?

我们的视频广告必须在5秒钟内与客户建立联系。我们如何做到这一点？


Which shade of white will help customers experience luxurious but not sterile?

哪种白色的色调可以帮助顾客体验奢华而不是无菌的感觉？


Which alloy should the suspension be made of to give customers the “feel the road” experience?

应该用哪种合金制造悬架，让顾客有“感受路况”的体验？


Once you know that you need answers to questions like these, you know which data are and are not important. Not only that, you know what should and should not be measured – as well as what can and cannot be measured.

一旦你知道你需要这些问题的答案，你就知道哪些数据是重要的，哪些是不重要的。不仅如此，你还知道什么应该被衡量，什么不应该被衡量——以及什么可以被衡量，什么不能被衡量。


Not everything that can be counted counts, and not everything that counts can be counted.

不是所有可以计算的东西都算数，也不是所有可以计算的东西都算数。


—William Bruce Cameron

ー威廉 · 布鲁斯 · 卡梅伦


JTBD helps create and sustain a growth culture: What happens when you don’t have a healthy growth mindset? You end up wasting time and money building products and features that don’t increase revenue. I learned that lesson the hard way

JTBD 帮助创建和维持一种成长文化: 当你没有一个健康的成长心态时会发生什么？你最终会浪费时间和金钱去开发那些不会增加收入的产品和特性。我可是吃了不少苦头

– both when I was a Product Manager and as an entrepreneur.

无论是当我是一个产品经理和企业家。


JTBD immunes us with the idea that organizations grow when they offer a growth opportunity to existing and potential customers. No one wants to solve their problems only, we want someone to also give us new and better ways to improve our life-situations in meaningful ways. This thinking helps us answer important growth-related questions such as:

JTBD 免疫我们的想法是，当组织向现有的和潜在的客户提供成长机会时，它们就会成长。没有人希望只解决自己的问题，我们希望有人也给我们新的和更好的方式来改善我们的生活状况有意义的方式。这种想法有助于我们回答一些与成长相关的重要问题，例如:


How can we make sure people continue to buy our existing product?

我们如何确保人们继续购买我们现有的产品？


How can we get more people to buy our product, or get them to buy more of it?

我们怎样才能让更多的人购买我们的产品，或者让他们购买更多的产品？


What additional products and services can we create that existing customers will also buy?

我们可以创造什么额外的产品和服务，现有的客户也将购买？


What additional products and services can we create that can gain us new customers.

我们可以创造什么额外的产品和服务，可以为我们赢得新的客户。


Customer Jobs and its focus on progress gives us a way to think about and answer these questions.

客户工作及其对进步的关注给了我们思考和回答这些问题的方法。


Customer Jobs is a theory evolved over time. The principles of Customer Jobs draw on studies in statistical theory, economics, systems thinking, and psychology. Its principles have slowly evolved over time—at least seventy-five years. It is by no means a flavor of the month.

客户工作是一个随着时间演变的理论。客户工作的原则借鉴了统计理论、经济学、系统思维和心理学的研究成果。它的原则随着时间慢慢演变ーー至少有75年了。这决不是一个月的口味。


As a theory, Customer Jobs persists because it is completely decoupled from describing what kind of product you should make. Instead, it is purely focused on understanding how all customers desire to evolve themselves. You need such a theory to help you become better at innovation.

作为一种理论，Customer Jobs 之所以存在，是因为它与描述应该生产什么样的产品完全脱钩。相反，它纯粹着眼于理解所有客户希望如何发展自己。你需要这样一个理论来帮助你更好地进行创新。


How to Be Successful with Customer Jobs and This Book

如何在客户工作和这本书上取得成功

As to methods there may be a million and then some, but principles are few. The man who grasps principles can successfully select his own methods. The man who tries methods, ignoring principles, is sure to have trouble.

至于方法，可能有一百万个，然后一些，但原则是很少的。掌握原则的人可以成功地选择自己的方法。试图用方法而忽视原则的人肯定会遇到麻烦。

—Harrington Emerson

爱默生


I don’t believe there is any one “right” way to innovate. Life has too many unknown and unknowable variables. Successful entrepreneur Steve Blank illustrates this by saying, “No business plan survives first contact with a customer.”10

我不相信有任何一种“正确”的创新方式。生活中有太多未知和不可知的变数。成功的企业家史蒂夫 · 布兰克(SteveBlank)说过这样一句话: “没有商业计划能够在与客户的第一次接触中存活下来。”10


Customer Jobs prepares us for whatever curveballs are thrown at us because it equips us with principles instead of methods. Why? Methods come and go, whereas principles stick around. In fact, when you’re armed with the right principles, you can plug in any appropriate methods and mental models. You might even create your own methods. And while this idea may cause you some anxiety, over time you will find it empowering. The study and application of principles, instead of methods, is what gives you the confidence to act in a complex world.

客户工作让我们准备好应对任何突如其来的挑战，因为它用原则而不是方法来装备我们。为什么？方法来了又去，而原则却依然存在。事实上，当你用正确的原则武装自己时，你可以插入任何适当的方法和思维模式。您甚至可以创建自己的方法。虽然这个想法可能会让你感到焦虑，但是随着时间的推移，你会发现它会给你力量。学习和应用原则，而不是方法，才能让你有信心在一个复杂的世界中行动。


While it’s easier to teach and learn methods, you become a better designer and innovator when you ground yourself with principles. This is why this book focuses on principles and demonstrates those principles in action through case studies. Most chapters also have a “Put it to work” section that gives ideas on how to apply these principles.

虽然教授和学习方法更容易，但当你把自己建立在原则的基础上时，你会成为一个更好的设计师和创新者。这就是为什么本书侧重于原则，并通过案例研究演示了这些原则在行动中的作用。大多数章节还有“投入工作”部分，提供了如何应用这些原则的想法。


About Me

关于我

I recommend Customer Jobs because I’ve applied its principles as an entrepreneur, product manager, designer, engineer, and salesperson. I’ve applied it to my own businesses and on products whose success I was directly responsible for. I believe it’s wrong to preach a theory unless you’ve applied it yourself and were exposed to the risks in the event the theory failed.

我之所以推荐 Customer Jobs，是因为我作为一名企业家、产品经理、设计师、工程师和销售人员，已经应用了它的原则。我已经把它应用到我自己的企业和我直接负责的成功产品上。我相信传播一个理论是错误的，除非你自己已经应用了它，并且在理论失败的情况下暴露在风险中。


Customer Jobs has helped me. I struggled with innovation for many years. I started my first business in 2003. It offered photographic services, image retouching, and a software platform where customers could create their own websites to showcase their artwork. It was a success. At the time, I didn’t understand why it was successful. But now I do. It was because I offered a collection of products that worked together—as a system—to help customers make progress. What progress did those customers want? “Help me get recognition for myself and my work.”

客户工作帮助了我。我与创新斗争了很多年。我在2003年创办了我的第一家公司。它提供摄影服务，图像修饰，和一个软件平台，客户可以创建自己的网站，以展示他们的艺术作品。很成功。当时，我不明白为什么它会成功。但现在我知道了。这是因为我提供了一系列产品，它们作为一个系统协同工作，帮助客户取得进展。那些客户想要什么进展？“帮助我为我自己和我的工作得到认可。”


As my business grew, I saw myself transition from maker to manager. I didn’t like it. So, I sold the business and went back to making things. I started another business called Vizipres. It failed. Why? I made a product that people would use, but not pay for.

随着业务的增长，我看到了自己从制造者到经理的转变。我不喜欢。所以，我卖掉了公司，回去制造东西。我开了另一家公司，叫 Vizipres。失败了。为什么？我做了一个产品，人们会用，但不付钱。


I thought that perhaps I needed to learn from other entrepreneurs. I began working for others as an engineer and designer. Later, I began leading innovation efforts at various companies. Inspired by all this knowledge, I began a third business called AIM. After a few iterations, it ended up as an advertising marketplace for mortgage brokers and real estate agents. As soon as it gained momentum, I sold it to my cofounder. I learned long ago that I’m a maker, not a manager.

我想也许我需要向其他企业家学习。我开始作为一个工程师和设计师为别人工作。后来，我开始在各个公司领导创新工作。受到所有这些知识的启发，我开始了第三个业务称为 AIM。经过几次迭代，它最终成为抵押贷款经纪人和房地产经纪人的广告市场。一有动力，我就把它卖给了我的联合创始人。我很久以前就知道，我是一个创造者，而不是一个管理者。


That’s also when I realized that Customer Jobs, at the time, was incomplete. Many of the principles and suggested theory of the time were inconsistent and often contradictory. I decided to unpack, refine, and expand its principles to help others and myself.

这也是我意识到客户工作，在当时，是不完整的。当时的许多原则和建议的理论是不一致的，经常是矛盾的。我决定解开它，完善它，扩展它的原则，帮助他人和我自己。


And as of today – as I update the 2nd edition of this book – I’m in the process of applying JTBD theory to create another product. Keep an eye out.

今天，当我更新这本书的第二版时，我正在应用 JTBD 理论创建另一个产品。小心点。


Abandon Every MBA, All You Who Enter

放弃所有 MBA，所有你进入的人

I invite you to explore JTBD with me. I also ask that you—at least for the time being—put aside any preconceived notions of competition, markets, and even Customer Jobs. You can pick them up again when the book is finished, or you may decide you no longer need them.

我邀请你和我一起探索 JTBD。我还要求你们ーー至少在目前ーー把任何先入为主的竞争、市场甚至客户工作的观念放在一边。你可以在书完成后再拿起它们，或者你可以决定不再需要它们。


PART I

第一部

The Job to be Done

待完成的工作

Our journey begins with an introduction to Customer Jobs theory and the idea of a customer having a Job to be Done (JTBD). This section will equip you with a strong foundation to understand what it means to study Customer Jobs and why it is a vital part of innovation.

我们的旅程从介绍客户工作理论和客户有一个工作要做(JTBD)的想法开始。本节将为您打下坚实的基础，让您了解研究客户工作意味着什么，以及为什么它是创新的重要组成部分。

  1. What is a Job to be Done (JTBD)?

    什么是需要完成的工作(JTBD) ？

    My JTBD creates a new me What isn’t a Job to be Done? A Job to be Done defined

    我的 JTBD 创造了一个新的我什么不是一个要完成的工作? 一个要完成的工作定义

    Products enable customers to get a Job Done Where does Customer Jobs theory come from?

    产品让客户完成工作客户工作理论从何而来？


    Upgrade your user, not your product. Don’t build better cameras— build better photographers.

    升级你的用户，而不是你的产品。不要建立更好的相机ーー建立更好的摄影师。


    —Kathy Sierra

    ー Kathy Sierra


    Ten thousand years ago, we were hunter gatherers and used our feet to roam the earth. Today, we have fast food restaurants and autonomous cars. Why did we change? Because we have an intrinsic desire to transform our life-situations into something better. We do this by remaking and adapting to the world around us.

    一万年前，我们是狩猎采集者，用我们的脚在地球上漫步。今天，我们有快餐店和自动驾驶汽车。我们为什么要改变？因为我们有一种内在的欲望，想要把我们的生活状况变得更好。我们通过重塑和适应我们周围的世界来做到这一点。


    The desire to improve ourselves and our life-situations is in our DNA. It’s what makes us human. Moreover, we do these transformations with purpose. We purposefully use the arts to improve ourselves emotionally; the sciences to improve ourselves intellectually; and engineering to improve how we interact with the world. Purposeful transformation is why we are different from animals:

    改善我们自己和我们的生活状况的愿望是在我们的 DNA。这让我们成为人类。此外，我们有目的地进行这些转换。我们有目的地利用艺术来提高自己的情感; 利用科学来提高自己的智力; 利用工程学来改善我们与世界的互动方式。有目的的转变是我们与动物不同的原因:


    A bear trying to catch food by the river may think: I wish fishing could be made better, faster, or easier.

    一只熊试图在河边捕捉食物时可能会想: 我希望捕鱼能做得更好，更快，或者更容易。


    But only a human will think: Fishing is no good. If I could transform that lagoon over there into a place where I can breed fish, then I’d never have to go fishing again.

    但只有人类才会认为: 捕鱼是没有好处的。如果我能把那边的泻湖改造成我可以养鱼的地方那我就再也不用去钓鱼了。


    The bear thinks only about what is. Today, it may come up with a better, faster, or easier way to fish. But tomorrow, it is still a bear that fishes. The human, on the other hand, thinks about what ought to be. Today, she fishes, but tomorrow that can change. If she could figure out a way to no longer do the fishing herself, then she can focus on improving other life-situations—like building a hut so she could move out of that dank cave.

    熊只考虑实际情况。今天，它可能会想出一个更好，更快，或更容易的方法来捕鱼。但是明天，它仍然是一只捕鱼的熊。另一方面，人类思考应该是什么。今天，她在钓鱼，但是明天可以改变。如果她能想办法不再自己钓鱼，那么她就可以专注于改善其他生活状况ーー比如建造一座小屋，这样她就可以搬出那个潮湿的洞穴。


    The bear does not think about transforming itself or its world. It never has a Job to be Done. The human, on the other hand, can desire change. And every time she begins the process of transforming her life-situation, she has a Job to be Done.

    熊从不考虑改变自己或它的世界。它从来没有一个工作要完成。另一方面，人类可以渴望改变。每次她开始改变自己的生活状况时，她都有一项工作要做。


    Improve Your Life-Situation; Become More Than You Are

    改善你的生活环境，超越自我

    Why are you reading this book? I guarantee you’re not reading it for the sake of reading it only. Do you have any social or functional goals you aim to achieve? I doubt it. I’m not sure how a book can be described in terms of “functional” unless you use it as a door-stop. And social? Well, unless your plan is to tell everyone you’ve “read the most amazing book!” (a course of action I highly recommend), I don’t see how there’s any social element to it either. Besides, isn’t every social action really a personal, emotional desire to gain recognition?

    你为什么要读这本书？我保证你不是为了读而读的。你是否有任何社会或功能目标，你的目标是实现？我表示怀疑。我不知道一本书怎样才能用“功能性”来描述，除非你把它当作一个门挡。社交方面呢？除非你的计划是告诉所有人你“读了一本最棒的书!”(我强烈推荐这种做法) ，我也看不出其中有任何社会因素。此外，难道每一个社会行为不都是一种获得认可的个人、情感渴望吗？


    I don’t think there are any social or functional purposes for reading this book. Rather, I believe you are reading this book because you hope to become better at creating and selling products that people will buy and use. And this Job to be Done of yours – make you better at making and selling products that people will buy – is why you are hiring this book. In fact, I bet you don’t even want to read this book. You do so because it is the only way for you to gain the knowledge contained herein. If it were possible to download the knowledge into your brain – like the character Neo from the Matrix – you would probably choose that instead.

    我不认为读这本书有任何社会或功能目的。相反，我相信你正在读这本书，因为你希望在创造和销售人们会购买和使用的产品方面做得更好。你的这份工作——让你更好地制造和销售人们愿意购买的产品——就是你雇佣这本书的原因。事实上，我打赌你根本不想读这本书。你这样做是因为这是你获得这里所包含的知识的唯一途径。如果有可能把这些知识下载到你的大脑中——就像《黑客帝国》中的人物 Neo 一样——你可能会选择那样做。


    Job theory starts with the premise that we, as humans, always want to improve our various life-situations in a variety of ways. This exploration of our core desire to improve ourselves has a long philosophical tradition. The ancient Greek poet Pindar wrote about “becoming who you are”. That is, the exploration and realization of the self is ongoing. This tradition has continued through to recent times. The work of philosopher-psychologist Friedrich Nietzsche’s advocates the humans-seek-self-betterment in various ways. Even Sigmund Freud picked up on this, offering the idea that we attach things to ourselves to become “prosthetic Gods.”11

    工作理论的前提是，作为人类，我们总是希望以各种方式改善我们各种各样的生活状况。这种对我们自我提高的核心愿望的探索有着悠久的哲学传统。古希腊诗人品达写到“成为你自己”。也就是说，自我的探索和实现正在进行中。这一传统一直延续到近代。哲学家兼心理学家弗里德里希·尼采的著作以多种方式倡导人类寻求自我完善。甚至西格蒙德 · 弗洛伊德(Sigmund Freud)也注意到了这一点，他提出了这样一种观点，即我们把东西附着在自己身上，从而成为“假神”11


    It can be shown that every living thing does everything it can not to preserve itself, but to become more.

    可以看出，每个生物都在竭尽全力，不是为了保存自己，而是为了变得更强大。


    —The Will to Power, Friedrich Nietzsche

    ー《权力意志》 ，弗里德里希·尼采



    Figure 4. What is Revlon really selling?

    图4露华浓到底在卖什么？



    Now, I doubt you picked up this book to learn philosophy. My aim is to illustrate the idea that our desire for self-betterment is a core human desire. We should take advantage of this truth and use it in our efforts to create sustainable growth for our businesses. And interestingly, I don’t think I’m the first one to have this idea.

    现在，我怀疑你拿这本书是为了学习哲学。我的目的是说明我们对自我完善的渴望是人类的一个核心愿望。我们应该利用这一事实，并利用它为我们的企业创造可持续增长的努力。有趣的是，我不认为我是第一个有这种想法的人。


    Charles Revson, founder of Revlon, perfectly encapsulates a JTBD when he said:12 In the factory, we make cosmetics. In the drugstore, we sell hope.

    露华浓(Revlon)创始人查尔斯•雷夫森(Charles Revson)说: 12在工厂里，我们生产化妆品。在药店里，我们卖希望。

    With these words, Revson marks the difference between what customers buy, and why they buy it. This thinking was also carried over into Revlon’s advertising. In 1952, Revlon’s breakout advertising campaign was Fire and Ice (figure 4). The advertising campaign makes it clear: Revlon isn’t selling a product, it’s selling transformation – the idea that, with this product in your life, you’ll be able to create a “new me” that is desirable in ways your “existing me” is not. This idea of selling transformation is why there’s barely any mention of any product in the ad. One whole page is a check list of provocative questions; the other features a picture of model Dorian Leigh. Only on further investigation do you notice the lipstick and nail polish at the bottom of the page.

    通过这些话，Revson 标记了顾客买什么和为什么买之间的区别。露华浓的广告也延续了这种思想。1952年，露华浓的突破性广告活动是火与冰(图4)。露华浓的广告活动清楚地表明: 露华浓不是在销售一种产品，而是在销售一种转变——这种观点认为，有了这种产品，你将能够创造一个“全新的我”，这个“全新的我”是你的“现有的我”所不需要的。这种销售变形产品的想法就是为什么在广告中几乎没有提到任何产品的原因。一整页是挑衅性问题的清单，另一页是模特 Dorian Leigh 的照片。只有经过进一步的调查，你才会注意到书页底部的唇膏和指甲油。


    A Job to be Done is neither found nor spontaneously created. Rather, it is designed. The checklist of provocative questions such as, “Have you ever wanted to wear an ankle bracelet?” exists to help customers imagine (i.e., design) what the new me will look and be like when they buy Revlon’s products. Then there’s the picture of Dorian Leigh. Upon seeing that, consumers continue to design a new version of themselves in their mind. For some, the new me looks like her. For others, the new me is with her. Whatever the case, if this new me who experiences new life-situations is something I want, I begin desiring it. In other words, I have a Job to be Done.

    要完成的工作既没有找到，也没有自发创建。相反，它是被设计出来的。一系列挑衅性的问题，比如“你有没有想过戴脚环?”存在帮助客户想象(即，设计)什么样的新的我将看起来是什么样子，当他们购买露华浓的产品。还有 Dorian Leigh 的照片。看到这一点后，消费者继续在脑海中设计自己的新版本。对某些人来说，新的我看起来像她。对其他人来说，新的我和她在一起。无论如何，如果这个体验新生活的全新自我是我想要的，我就会开始渴望它。换句话说，我有工作要做。


    A Job to be Done Defined

    定义待完成的工作

    Customer Jobs theory states that markets grow and transform whenever customers have a Job to be Done, and then buy a product to complete it (get the Job Done). This makes a Job to be Done a transformation process: it starts, it runs, and it ends. The key difference, however, is that a JTBD describes how a customer changes or wishes to change. We define a JTBD as follows:

    客户工作理论认为，只要客户有工作要做，市场就会成长和变革，然后购买产品来完成它(完成工作)。这使得完成工作成为一个转换过程: 它开始，运行，然后结束。但是，关键的区别在于 JTBD 描述了客户如何更改或希望更改。我们对联合待定事项的定义如下:


    A Job to be Done is the process a consumer goes through whenever she aims to transform her existing life-situation into a preferred one, but cannot because there are constraints that stop her.

    待完成的工作是消费者每当想要将现有的生活环境转变为自己喜欢的生活环境时所经历的过程，但是由于受到限制而无法实现。


    Products Enable Customers to Get A Job Done

    让客户完成工作的产品

    Humans are limited in our abilities. We can’t change a life-situation by ourselves. A snap of our fingers cannot create a world where a morning commute is an enjoyable experience. Realizing such a change requires innovation on the part of oneself or someone else. Progress can only happen when we attach and integrate new ideas and new products into our lives.

    人类的能力是有限的。我们不能靠自己改变生活。我们打个响指也不能创造一个早上上下班是一种享受的体验的世界。实现这样的变化需要自己或他人的创新。只有当我们将新思想和新产品融入到我们的生活中，进步才会发生。


    An example of constructing (i.e., designing) a Job to be Done comes from a research project I led to understand what Job or Jobs customers were hoping to get Done (i.e., what new me customers were hoping to create) with a project management

    一个构建(即设计)待完成工作的例子来自于一个研究项目，我领导了一个研究项目，了解了 Job 或 Jobs 的客户希望通过项目管理来完成什么(即，新的我的客户希望创造什么)



    Figure 5. The designers at intercom (intercom.com) use this illustration to show the difference between what customers buy, and what they want.

    图5。Intercom (intercom. com)的设计师用这幅插图来展示顾客购买的商品和他们想要的商品之间的区别


    software. Here is a synopsis of one interview. Notice how the hero of our story comes to realize a new me is possible, and how he must attach a product to himself to attain that new me:

    软件。这里是一个采访的概要。请注意我们故事中的主人公是如何认识到一个新的我是可能的，以及他必须如何将一个产品附加到自己身上以获得那个新的我:


    Andreas began a business around medical tourism. Over time, he grew his business to include five employees. One day, he was out with a friend of his, Jamie, at a coffee shop. During their conversation, Jamie mentioned a product called Basecamp to Andreas. Andreas had never heard of it. He was curious to learn more.

    安德里亚斯开始经营医疗旅游业。随着时间的推移，他的业务扩大到包括5名员工。有一天，他和他的一个朋友杰米出去了，在一家咖啡店。在他们的谈话中，杰米向安德里亚斯提到了一个名为 Basecamp 的产品。安德里亚斯从没听说过。他很好奇想了解更多。


    Jamie explained to Andreas that Basecamp was a project management tool that helped small businesses become better at organizing themselves. Andreas was surprised by this. He knew about complicated project management products like Microsoft Project, but those were for big companies only, not smaller ones like his. Currently, Andreas was using Google Sheets, Google Docs, and email to run his company. He just assumed that, well, that’s how companies his size operated.

    杰米向安德里亚斯解释说，Basecamp 是一个项目管理工具，可以帮助小企业更好地组织自己。安德里亚斯对此感到惊讶。他知道像微软项目这样复杂的项目管理产品，但是这些只适用于大公司，而不适用于像他这样的小公司。目前，安德里亚斯正在使用谷歌表格、谷歌文档和电子邮件来运营他的公司。他只是假设，这就是他那种规模的公司的运作方式。


    Jamie further explained that Basecamp was made specifically to help companies his size. As Jamie spoke, Andreas’s mind began racing: Basecamp could help my company stay organized as it adds more customers and employees. Up until this point, he had just assumed that his company had hit its growth limit.

    杰米进一步解释说，制造 Basecamp 是为了帮助他所在规模的公司。当杰米说话的时候，安德里亚斯的脑子开始转动: Basecamp 可以帮助我的公司保持组织性，因为它增加了更多的客户和员工。在此之前，他一直认为他的公司已经达到了增长极限。



    Figure 6. Samuel Hulick uses this illustration to show how customers use products to design a "new me".

    图6 Samuel Hulick 使用这个插图来展示客户如何使用产品来设计一个“全新的我”



    Andreas and Jamie enjoyed their coffee and parted ways. During his train ride home, Andreas looked up Basecamp on his mobile device. He also learned about and investigated similar products to Basecamp. In the end, he decided to go with Basecamp. He signed up or it, began using it, and grew his company beyond five employees for the first time.

    安德里亚斯和杰米很享受他们的咖啡，然后分道扬镳。在回家的火车上，安德烈亚斯用他的移动设备查找 Basecamp。他还了解并调查了类似于 Basecamp 的产品。最后，他决定加入大本营。他注册了公司，开始使用它，并使公司第一次超过了5名员工。


    This is what a Job to be Done looks like. A consumer goes along his life as he’s come to know it. Then things change. He is presented with an opportunity to improve his life-situation—in this case, make changes so he can grow. When or if he finds a product that helps him realize that growth opportunity, he can evolve to that better version of himself he had imagined. In the case of Andreas, Basecamp enabled him to gain control over how his business could be run. This enabled him to grow it beyond a few employees for the first time.

    这就是要完成的工作的样子。当消费者逐渐了解他的生活时，他就开始了他的生活。然后事情就变了。他面临着一个改善自己生活状况的机会ーー在这种情况下，就要做出改变，这样他才能成长。当或者如果他发现一个产品可以帮助他意识到成长的机会，他可以进化到他所想象的更好的自己。在安德里亚斯的案例中，Basecamp 使他能够控制自己的业务如何运营。这使得他第一次超越了几个雇员的范围。


    Besides demonstrating a JTBD well, Andreas’s story also demonstrates that creating a new me (i.e., having a JTBD) is a process. It’s not something that consumers have; it’s something consumers participate in. That’s why it’s called a Job to be Done. A comparable example is falling in love. Falling in love isn’t something you have; it’s something you participate in. And just as you can’t complete the fall-in-love process by yourself, a customer can’t complete a JTBD by himself. He needs a product to help him design, construct, and complete it.

    除了很好地展示了 JTBD 之外，Andreas 的故事还展示了创建一个新的 me (即，拥有一个 JTBD)是一个过程。它不是消费者拥有的东西，而是消费者参与的东西。这就是为什么它被称为工作要完成。一个类似的例子是坠入爱河。坠入爱河不是你拥有的东西，而是你参与的东西。正如您不能独自完成恋爱过程一样，客户也不能独自完成 JTBD。他需要一个产品来帮助他设计、构建和完成它。


    Customers are always beautifully, wonderfully dissatisfied, even when they report being happy and business is great. Even when they don’t yet know it, customers want something better, and your desire to delight customers will drive you to invent on their behalf.

    顾客总是美丽的，奇妙的不满意，即使当他们报告快乐和业务是伟大的。即使他们还不知道，客户想要更好的东西，你取悦客户的欲望将驱使你为他们发明。


    No customer ever asked Amazon to create the Prime membership program, but it sure turns out they wanted it, and I could give you many such examples.

    从来没有客户要求亚马逊创建 Prime 会员计划，但事实证明，他们确实想要它，我可以给你许多这样的例子。


    —Jeff Bezos13

    ー杰夫 · 贝佐斯13


    What Isn’t A Job to be Done

    什么是不需要完成的工作

    While many of us have been applying Customer Jobs for a while—Rick Pedi and John Palmer have been developing Customer Jobs since the 1990s—it has gained popularity only recently. And like so many things that spread quickly, many people have distorted and misinterpreted it.

    虽然我们中的许多人应用“客户工作”已经有一段时间了ーー里克•佩迪(Rick Pedi)和约翰•帕尔默(John Palmer)自上世纪90年代以来一直在开发“客户工作”ーー但它直到最近才变得流行起来。就像许多迅速传播的事物一样，许多人对它进行了扭曲和误解。


    The biggest mistake I see is thinking of a Job to be Done as an activity or task. Examples include store and retrieve music, listen to music, cut a straight line, or make a quarter-inch hole. These are not Jobs; rather, they are tasks and activities –which means they describe how you use a product or what you do with it. For example, music streaming products such as Pandora and Spotify were designed specifically so customers didn’t have to store and retrieve music like when they used CDs or MP3s. As far as listen to music, that is a broad activity that varies wildly depending on the context. Someone listening to music, so he can maintain his motivation during a workout is engaging in a very different activity than someone going to the opera to listen to music.

    我所看到的最大的错误就是把一项工作当作一项活动或任务来完成。例子包括存储和检索音乐，听音乐，削减一条直线，或作出一个四分之一英寸的洞。这些不是乔布斯，相反，它们是任务和活动——这意味着它们描述了你如何使用一个产品或者你如何使用它。例如，像 Pandora 和 Spotify 这样的音乐流媒体产品是专门设计的，这样客户就不必像使用 CD 或 MP3那样存储和检索音乐。至于听音乐，这是一个广泛的活动，根据上下文变化很大。有些人听音乐是为了在锻炼中保持动力，这与去歌剧院听音乐是完全不同的活动。


    The problem with describing customer demand as activities is well articulate by the creator of Activity-Centered Design, Don Norman:14

    将客户需求描述为活动的问题被活动中心设计的创始人 Don Norman 很好地阐述了: 14


    Harvard professor Theodore Levitt once pointed out, “People don’t want to buy a quarter-inch drill. They want a quarter-inch hole!” Levitt’s example of the drill implying that the goal is really a hole is only partially correct, however. When people go to a store to buy a drill, that is not their real goal. But why would anyone want a quarter-

    哈佛大学教授西奥多 · 莱维特(Theodore Levitt)曾经指出: “人们不想买四分之一英寸的钻头。他们想要一个四分之一英寸的洞!”然而，莱维特关于钻孔的例子暗示目标实际上是一个洞，这只是部分正确。当人们去商店买钻头时，那并不是他们真正的目的。但为什么会有人想要25美分





    Figure 7. Don Norman’s 1988 book, the design of everyday things, features activity-centered design and the seven stages of action seen here. This theory formed the basis of ideologies such as task analysis and human-computer interaction.

    图7。唐 · 诺曼1988年出版的《日常用品的设计》一书，主要介绍了以活动为中心的设计以及在这里看到的行动的七个阶段。这一理论构成了任务分析和人机交互等意识形态的基础


    inch hole? Clearly that is an intermediate goal. Perhaps they wanted to hang shelves on the wall. Levitt stopped too soon.

    一英寸的洞？显然，这是一个中间目标。也许他们想把架子挂在墙上。莱维特停得太早了。


    Once you realize that they don’t really want the drill, you realize that perhaps they don’t really want the hole, either: they want to install their bookshelves. Why not develop methods that don’t require holes? Or perhaps books that don’t require bookshelves. (Yes, I know: electronic books, e-books.)

    一旦你意识到他们不是真的想要钻孔机，你就会意识到他们可能也不是真的想要那个洞: 他们想要安装他们的书架。为什么不开发不需要漏洞的方法呢？或者是不需要书架的书。(是的，我知道: 电子书，电子书。)


    Besides, there are already brilliant design methods out there to help you design for tasks and activities. Examples include Activity Theory, Don Norman’s Activity-Centered Design (figure 7), Cognitive Task Analysis, Goal Directed Design, Use Cases, and Human-Computer Interaction (HCI). If you want to learn more about how to design for activities or tasks, go there.

    除此之外，已经有很多出色的设计方法可以帮助你设计任务和活动。例子包括活动理论，唐诺曼的以活动为中心的设计(图7) ，认知任务分析，目标导向设计，用例和人机交互(HCI)。如果你想学习更多关于如何设计活动或任务的知识，去那里。


    There are not different types of Jobs. Another common mistake is to think that there are types of Jobs. In particular, some may think there are emotional, function, and social Jobs. I’ll describe why it’s a bad idea from both a practical and theoretical perspective.

    没有不同类型的工作。另一个常见的错误是认为乔布斯有不同的类型。特别是，有些人可能认为有情感，功能和社会工作。我将从实践和理论的角度来描述为什么这是一个坏主意。


    Practically, you’ll be more successful when you think of every Customer Job as unique. We’ve learned that while many Jobs share the same core emotional desires (e.g., belonging, self-expression, control, etc.), each Job is a unique combination of these desires. That is why each product should deliver on these core emotional desires in its own way. A good example is Facebook. A lot of people use Facebook because it taps into desires such as control, self-expression, and belonging—but it

    实际上，当你认为每个客户工作都是独一无二的时候，你会更加成功。我们已经了解到，尽管许多工作都有相同的核心情感需求(例如归属感、自我表达、控制欲等) ，但每份工作都是这些需求的独特组合。这就是为什么每个产品都应该以自己的方式传递这些核心情感需求。Facebook 就是一个很好的例子。很多人使用 Facebook 是因为它利用了人们的欲望，比如控制欲、自我表达和归属感



    Figure 8. Are you describing a job to be done, or something else?

    图8。您是在描述要完成的工作，还是其他事情？


    does so in its own unique way. So instead of saying that there are types of Jobs, you’ll be much better off thinking that each Job is unique.

    以其独特的方式。因此，与其说有不同类型的工作，不如认为每个工作都是独一无二的。


    Theoretically—that is, from an ontological and epistemological perspective— Customer Jobs are design (artificial) problems, not natural problems. Natural problems are falsifiable. This means they can be objectively measured and determined as either true or false:

    理论上ーー也就是说，从本体论和认识论的角度ーー客户工作是设计(人为的)问题，而不是自然问题。自然问题是可以证伪的。这意味着它们可以被客观地衡量和确定为真或假:


    Q: Is argon (Ar) a noble gas?

    问: 氩(Ar)是惰性气体吗？


    A: If under conditions X it reacts, then yes; otherwise, no.

    答: 如果在 X 条件下它发生反应，那么是的; 否则不是。


    Design problems, on the other hand, are not falsifiable and cannot be measured objectively:

    另一方面，设计问题是不可证伪的，也不能客观地衡量:


    Q: How do we reduce crime? Person 1: “Improve education.”

    问: 我们如何减少犯罪? 第一个人: “改善教育。”

    Person 2: “Hire more police officers.”

    第二个人: “雇佣更多的警察。”


    With respect to Jobs, then, no objective test can be created to say, “This is a social Job. That is not a social Job.” If I buy a Ferrari to impress other people, is it a “social” Job because I want to impress other people? Or should we rephrase it as an insecurity, making it a “personal” or “emotional” Job?

    那么，对于乔布斯来说，没有任何客观的测试可以说: “这是一个社会性的工作。这不是一份社交工作。”如果我买一辆法拉利是为了给别人留下深刻印象，这是一个“社交”工作，因为我想给别人留下深刻印象吗？或者我们应该把它重新定义为一种不安全感，让它成为一种“个人”或“情感”的工作？


    And because there’s no way to objectively define each type of Job, every person on the team will have his or her own opinion of what type of Job it should be. Moreover, even if/when you do get consensus, so what? Isn’t knowing that I bought a Ferrari because I want to “fit in” good enough? What do you gain by labeling it a social or personal Job? I’ll tell you: absolutely nothing.

    因为没有办法客观地定义每一种类型的工作，团队中的每一个人都会有他或她自己的观点，什么类型的工作应该是。此外，即使你达成了共识，那又怎样？难道不知道我买了一辆法拉利是因为我想“适应”得够好吗？给它贴上社交或个人工作的标签，你会得到什么？我告诉你，绝对没有。


    Take it from me, don’t waste your time trying to dissect Jobs into different types. It’s about as productive as trying to answer, “How many angels can dance on the head of a pin?”

    听我一句，别浪费时间把乔布斯分成不同的类型。这就像试图回答“有多少天使能在针尖上跳舞?”


    Is it a Customer Job? Does it describe an improved life-situation or something else? When presented with a possible description of a Customer Job, the best framework of thinking I can offer you is the decision tree in figure 8.

    是顾客工作吗？它是否描述了一个改善的生活状况或其他东西？当提供客户作业的可能描述时，我能提供的最佳思维框架是图8中的决策树。


    Keep in mind that a Job to be Done describes the “better me.” It answers the question, “How are you better since you started using [product]?”and “Now that you have this product, what can you do now that you couldn’t do before?” Renowned psychologist Albert Bandura described humans as “proactive, aspiring organisms”. Customer Jobs carries this idea into markets, making the claim that we buy and use things to improve ourselves, to make progress. If you’re not describing a Customer Job in terms of progress, you’re probably describing something else.

    请记住，待完成的工作描述的是“更好的我”它回答了这样一个问题: “自从你开始使用(产品)以来，你是如何变得更好的?”“现在你有了这个产品，你能做什么以前做不到的事情呢?”著名心理学家阿尔伯特 · 班杜拉(Albert Bandura)将人类描述为“积极主动、有抱负的有机体”。客户工作将这一理念带入市场，声称我们购买和使用东西是为了提高自己，取得进步。如果你不是在描述一个客户工作的进度，你可能是在描述其他的东西。


    Where Does Customer Jobs Theory Come From?

    客户工作理论从何而来？

    The greatest—and most helpful—theories are not created by one person but are the result of many people over a long period (figure 9). This is certainly the case with JTBD. Its principles have emerged from the work of a long lineage of researchers and innovators. Here are the most notable.

    最伟大(也是最有帮助)的理论不是由一个人创造的，而是许多人长期以来的结果(图9)。JTBD 的情况就是如此。它的原则来自于一系列研究人员和创新者的工作。下面是最值得注意的。


    Joseph Schumpeter and creative destruction. The roots of JTBD thinking go back at least seventy-five years to Joseph Schumpeter and his introduction of creative destruction. Schumpeter observed that new innovations steal customers

    约瑟夫·熊彼特和创造性破坏。JtBD 思想的根源至少可以追溯到75年前的约瑟夫·熊彼特和他引入的创造性破坏。熊彼特观察到新的创新会偷走顾客



    Figure 9. Influences of Jobs to be Done.

    图9。待完成工作的影响


    from incumbent offerings and then eventually go on to replace them. At one time, horses and ships were our primary methods of personal transportation. Eventually, trains replaced horses, but then cars and airplanes replaced those trains and ships.

    从现有的产品，然后最终继续取代他们。曾几何时，马匹和船只是我们的主要个人交通工具。最终，火车取代了马，但是汽车和飞机取代了火车和轮船。


    Customer Jobs incorporates Schumpeter’s insights as it seeks to understand why customers pick one way of doing things over another. Yes, innovators create new solutions, but the wheels of creative destruction turn only through the interaction between customers and innovators.

    《客户工作》融合了熊彼特的洞察力，试图理解为什么客户会选择一种做事方式而不是另一种。是的，创新者创造新的解决方案，但创造性破坏的车轮只能通过客户和创新者之间的互动转动。


    Customer Jobs also incorporates another one of Schumpeter’s brilliant insights that is almost always overlooked. Schumpeter argued that competition should not be measured only among products of the same “type.” He insisted that competition can come from anywhere. You might think you’re alone in a market or have market superiority, but some competitor unknown to you could be stealing away your customers. Your only sign that something is wrong is decreasing sales. In chapter 8, we take a close look at Customer Jobs, creative destruction, and competition

    《客户工作》还融入了熊彼特另一个几乎总是被忽视的卓越见解。熊彼特认为，竞争不应该只衡量同一“类型”的产品之间的竞争他坚持认为，竞争可以来自任何地方。你可能认为你在市场上是孤军奋战或者拥有市场优势，但是一些你不知道的竞争对手可能正在抢走你的客户。你唯一不对劲的迹象就是销量下降。在第八章中，我们将仔细研究客户工作、创造性破坏和竞争


    W. Edwards Deming and systems thinking. Schumpeter’s influence on Customer Jobs is restricted mostly to factors of market dynamics and competition; however,

    爱德华兹·戴明和系统思考。熊彼特对客户工作的影响主要局限于市场动态和竞争因素;

    W. Edwards Deming has influenced Customer Jobs the most. Those who are

    爱德华兹·戴明对客户工作的影响最大


    familiar with his nearly sixty years of contribution to theories of management and innovation will recognize his fingerprints throughout this book.

    熟悉他近六十年来对管理和创新理论的贡献，将认识到他的指纹贯穿整本书。


    Deming’s most notable influence comes from his development of systems thinking, which I discuss in chapter 13. Throughout Deming’s career, he frequently reminded businesses that producers and customers are connected by systems:

    戴明最显著的影响来自他的系统思想的发展，我将在第13章讨论。在戴明的整个职业生涯中，他经常提醒企业，生产者和消费者是通过系统连接在一起的:


    The customer and producer must work together as a system. The consumer is the most important part of the production line.

    客户和生产者必须作为一个系统一起工作。消费者是生产线上最重要的部分。

    Deming often challenged companies to remember creative destruction. He impressed on business leadership that simply making a product better and better— improving what already exists—wasn’t enough. Sooner or later, someone will invent something new. He would tell businesses the following:

    戴明经常要求公司记住创造性破坏。他给企业领导留下的印象是，仅仅让产品越来越好ーー改进现有产品ーー是不够的。迟早会有人发明新的东西。他会告诉企业如下:


    Makers of vacuum tubes improved year by year the power of vacuum tubes. Customers were happy. But then transistor radios came along. Happy customers of vacuum tubes deserted vacuum tubes and ran for the pocket radio.

    真空管制造商逐年提高真空管的功率。顾客们很高兴。但后来晶体管收音机出现了。真空管的快乐顾客抛弃了真空管，跑去拿袖珍收音机。


    A dissatisfied customer does not complain; he just switches.

    一个不满意的顾客不会抱怨，他只是换了一个。


    Deming understood that improving products of today continually isn’t enough: “We must keep asking, what new product or service would help our customers more? What will we be making five years from now? Ten years from now?” For Deming, the process of innovation should never stop.15

    戴明明白，不断改进今天的产品是不够的: “我们必须不断地问，什么样的新产品或服务能更好地帮助我们的客户？五年后我们能赚多少？十年后?”对戴明来说，创新的过程永远不应该停止。15


    Psychology. On the psychology front, you’ll run into influences from Gary Klein, Amos Tversky, Daniel Kahneman, George Loewenstein, and Ann Graybiel. These are psychologists and scientists whose work forms the foundations of behavioral economics and naturalistic decision making (NDM). Their work helps us understand how and why customers don’t make rational decisions when buying and using products, are inconsistent in their opinions of products, and don’t always act in their best interest. Customer Jobs understands that if you want to make a great product and to develop a message that connects with customers, you have to understand the emotional forces that shape their motivation.

    心理学。在心理学方面，你会受到 Gary Klein，Amos Tversky，Daniel Kahneman，George Loewenstein 和 Ann Graybiel 的影响。他们是心理学家和科学家，他们的工作构成了行为经济学和自然决策(NDM)的基础。他们的工作帮助我们理解消费者在购买和使用产品时如何以及为什么不能做出理性的决定，他们对产品的看法不一致，并且不总是以他们的最佳利益行事。客户乔布斯明白，如果你想做出一个伟大的产品，并发展一条与客户相关的信息，你必须理解影响他们动机的情感力量。


    Bringing it all together. Then, you arrive at John B. Palmer, Rick Pedi, Bob Moesta, Julia Wesson, and Pam Murtaugh. In the 1990s, they began working together to combine their respective experiences into the first Customer Jobs

    把一切都联系起来。然后，你到达约翰 · B · 帕尔默、里克 · 佩迪、鲍勃 · 莫斯塔、朱莉娅 · 韦森和帕姆 · 默托。在20世纪90年代，他们开始合作，将各自的经验结合到第一份客户工作中


    principles. They are the ones who came up with the idea and language that customers have “Jobs” that they are trying to get “Done.”

    原则。正是他们想出了这个主意和语言，客户有“工作”，他们试图得到“完成”


    Then, you get to me and this book. John, Rick, and Bob have personally influenced me more than I could ever express. Last but certainly not least, the entire JTBD community has had a tremendous influence on me. Without their application of and experience with JTBD, this book would not have been possible.

    然后，你来找我和这本书。约翰，里克和鲍勃对我的影响超出了我的想象。最后但并非最不重要的是，整个 JTBD 社区对我产生了巨大的影响。如果没有他们对 JTBD 的应用和经验，这本书是不可能的。

  2. What Are the Principles of Customer Jobs?

    客户工作的原则是什么？

    Here are a few JTBD principles that you will see demonstrated repeatedly throughout this book. There are others, but the principles below are perhaps the most useful and commonly used in the Customer Jobs community.

    这里有一些 JTBD 原则，您将在本书中反复看到它们的演示。还有其他的原则，但是下面的原则可能是最有用的，也是客户工作社区中最常用的。


    Principles of Customer Jobs

    客户工作原则

    Customers don’t want your product or what it does; they want help making themselves better (i.e., they want to transform a life-situation, make progress). Charles Revson knew that customers didn’t want cosmetics, which are just colored oils. He also knew that customers didn’t want what those cosmetics do, which is simply coloring skin. He understood that his customers wanted hope. This understanding of customer motivation has helped keep Revlon in business for eighty-four years. In 2015, its revenue topped $1.9 billion. It seems that selling hope is a profitable business.16

    客户不想要你的产品或者它能做什么; 他们想要帮助自己变得更好(例如，他们想要改变生活状况，取得进步)。查尔斯雷夫森知道，顾客不想要化妆品，这只是彩色油。他也知道消费者不想要那些化妆品，那只是简单的给皮肤上色。他知道他的顾客需要希望。这种对客户动机的理解帮助露华浓公司在业务上维持了84年。2015年，其收入超过19亿美元。似乎销售希望是一项有利可图的生意。16


    Focusing on the product itself, what it does, or how customers use it closes your mind to innovation opportunities. For example, if you sold drills, you might be tempted to think that people buy drills and bits because they want holes. But then 3M comes along and develops an entire line of damage-free hanging products that are designed specifically to eliminate the need for a drill or for making any holes. Another manufacturer, Erard, also avoided the “customers want holes” trap. It promotes a collection of TV mounts with a simple description: “The first TV wall-mount bracket with no drilling of the wall required.” While you were convinced customers wanted holes, your competitors understood that customers wanted help improving their lives.17

    关注产品本身，它是做什么的，或者客户如何使用它，会让你对创新机会视而不见。例如，如果你卖钻头，你可能会认为人们买钻头和钻头是因为他们想要钻孔。但是后来3M 公司出现了，开发了一系列无损伤的吊挂产品，这些产品是专门为了消除钻孔或打孔的需要而设计的。另一家制造商 Erard 也避免了“顾客想要洞”的陷阱。它促进了一个简单的描述电视安装集合: “第一个电视墙壁安装支架无需钻孔的墙壁要求。”当你确信顾客需要漏洞的时候，你的竞争对手明白顾客需要帮助来改善他们的生活。17


    People have Jobs; things don’t. It doesn’t make sense to ask, “What Job is your product doing?” or say, “The Job of the phone is…” or “The Job of the watch is…” Phones, watches, and dry-cleaning services don’t have Jobs. They are examples of solutions for Job.

    人们有工作，事情没有。问“你的产品是做什么工作的?”是没有意义的或者说，“手机的工作是...”或者“手表的工作是...”手机，手表和干洗服务没有乔布斯。他们是解决约伯问题的例子。


    Products don’t have lives to make better. They also don’t have motivations, aspirations, or struggles. However, people do struggle. They do have lives they want to improve. This is why people—not products—have a JTBD.

    产品没有更好的生活。他们也没有动机、抱负或挣扎。然而，人们确实在挣扎。他们确实有想要改善的生活。这就是为什么人(而不是产品)会有 JTBD。


    Competition is defined in the minds of customers, and they use progress as their criterion. Imagine an entrepreneur who wants to be advised and inspired

    竞争在顾客心目中是有定义的，他们用进步作为他们的标准。想象一下，一位企业家希望得到建议和鼓舞


    by someone whom she respects. She has a variety of options to choose from to achieve this. Examples include reading books, watching videos, attending conferences, or giving advisory shares in exchange for mentorship.

    被她尊敬的人。为了实现这一目标，她有多种选择可供选择。这样的例子包括阅读书籍，观看视频，参加会议，或者提供咨询意见以换取指导。


    The struggling entrepreneur cares little about how she gets advised and inspired. The concern is about making progress. “Are things better for me today than yesterday? Am I getting closer to that picture in my mind of how I want my life to be?” These are some of the criteria customers use to judge which products compete against one another to improve themselves. Customers don’t define or restrict competition based on the functionality or physical appearance of a product. Instead, they use whatever helps them make progress against a JTBD.

    苦苦挣扎的企业家很少关心自己是如何得到建议和鼓舞的。我们关心的是如何取得进展。“今天对我来说比昨天好吗？我是否越来越接近我脑海中想要的生活画面了呢?”这些是客户用来判断哪些产品相互竞争以提高自己的一些标准。客户不会根据产品的功能或外观来定义或限制竞争。相反，他们使用任何帮助他们取得进展的东西来对抗 JTBD。
