    When customers start using a solution for a JTBD, they stop using something else. Many solo entrepreneurs struggle with feelings of isolation and hope to be motivated and inspired. To get this Job Done, some choose to create local get-togethers through Meetup.com and encourage other solo entrepreneurs to join. If that doesn’t work, they may try getting people together in an online chat group. If that doesn’t work, they may decide to join an existing online community, such as Product People Club. If Product People Club, as a product, is something that works to make their lives better, they stop searching for new solutions. Their Job is Done.

    当客户开始使用 JTBD 的解决方案时，他们停止使用其他解决方案。许多个体创业者都在与孤独感作斗争，希望自己能够被激励和鼓舞。为了完成这项工作，一些人选择通过 Meetup 网站创建当地聚会，并鼓励其他个体创业者加入。如果这不起作用，他们可能会尝试把人们聚集在一个在线聊天组。如果这不起作用，他们可能会决定加入一个现有的在线社区，如产品人员俱乐部。如果产品人员俱乐部，作为一个产品，是有效的，使他们的生活更好，他们停止寻找新的解决方案。他们的任务完成了。


    These entrepreneurs were jumping from one solution to another. This makes competition for a JTBD a zero-sum game. For somebody to win, somebody else has got to lose. Just as only one puzzle piece can fit into an empty slot, a customer prefers only one solution at a time for a JTBD.

    这些企业家从一个解决方案跳到另一个解决方案。这使得对 JTBD 的竞争成为一场零和游戏。有人要赢，就得有人输。正如只有一个拼图块可以放入一个空的插槽，客户一次只喜欢一个解决方案。


    Innovation opportunities exist when customers exhibit compensatory behaviors. Baking soda was originally advertised as a baking agent. Over time, customers started using it as a cleaner and deodorizer. Arm & Hammer picked up on this. It now sells a variety of baking soda–based products specialized for various cleaning and deodorizing purposes.18

    当顾客表现出补偿行为时，就存在创新机会。小苏打最初的广告是作为一种发酵剂。随着时间的推移，消费者开始使用它作为清洁剂和除臭剂。Arm & Hammer 公司发现了这个。该公司现在销售各种专门用于各种清洁和除臭目的的小苏打产品


    The Segway was meant to revolutionize personal transportation for the masses. It failed; however, it did find success among members of law enforcement who began using it for their patrols. Tour companies also began using Segways as the ultimate gimmick to attract tourists and for family activities.19

    赛格威意在革新大众的个人交通工具。它失败了，但是，它确实在执法人员中找到了成功，他们开始使用它进行巡逻。旅游公司也开始使用赛格威作为吸引游客和家庭活动的终极噱头。19


    Baking soda and the Segway are examples of customers using products in ways for which they weren’t originally intended. Such situations represent opportunities to innovate a new product or to refit an existing one.

    小苏打和赛格威的例子，客户使用的产品的方式，他们原本没有打算。这种情况是创新新产品或改装现有产品的机会。


    Favor progress over outcomes and goals. Customer goals and outcomes are only the results of an action. The ball went into the net; that is a goal. Did you win the game? Are you becoming better at making goals? No one knows.

    支持取得进展而不是结果和目标。客户的目标和结果只是行动的结果。球进了球网，那是一个进球。你赢了吗？你越来越擅长制定目标了吗？没人知道。


    Measure progress instead. Making a goal today isn’t as important as becoming better at making goals in the future. This philosophy is the same for your customers. They don’t wait until after they’ve finished using a product to determine whether they like it. They measure progress along the way. Do people wait until they lose ten pounds before judging whether a gym membership is successful?

    而是衡量进展。今天制定一个目标不如将来更好地制定目标重要。这种理念对你的客户来说也是一样的。他们不会等到用完产品之后才决定是否喜欢。它们衡量一路上的进展。人们是否会等到减掉10磅之后再判断健身房会员资格是否成功？


    Customers need to feel successful at every touch point between themselves and your business, not just at the very end when the outcome of an action is realized. Design your product to deliver customers an ongoing feeling of progress. Over time, you will notice that you need to change the outcomes and goals you deliver to customers. Why? A successful product and business will continually improve customers’ lives. As customers use your product to make their lives better, they will face new challenges and desire new goals and outcomes.

    客户需要在他们与您的业务之间的每一个接触点都感到成功，而不仅仅是在行动结果实现的最后一刻。设计你的产品，给客户一种持续进步的感觉。随着时间的推移，你会发现你需要改变你交付给客户的结果和目标。为什么？一个成功的产品和业务将不断改善客户的生活。当客户使用你的产品来使他们的生活更美好时，他们将面临新的挑战，并渴望新的目标和结果。


    Progress defines value; contrast reveals value. See how easily you can answer this question: “Which food do you most prefer: steak or pizza?” Many people find this difficult to answer. An easier question might be, “When do you prefer steak, and when do you prefer pizza?”20

    进步定义价值，对比揭示价值。看看你是多么容易回答这个问题: “你最喜欢哪种食物: 牛排还是比萨饼?”许多人觉得这个问题很难回答。一个更简单的问题可能是: “你什么时候喜欢吃牛排，什么时候喜欢吃披萨?”20


    A customer may find it difficult to compare two foods without any context. The last question is easier because the person being asked is thinking about food and context together.

    顾客可能会发现很难在没有任何背景的情况下比较两种食物。最后一个问题更容易回答，因为被问者是在一起思考食物和背景。


    Products have no value in and of themselves. They have value only when customers use them to make progress. The value of steak is easier to assess when it’s matched with a fancy restaurant and a nice bottle of wine. But things can get wacky in that scenario if we swap a slice of pizza for the steak.

    产品本身没有价值。只有当客户使用它们来取得进展时，它们才有价值。当牛排搭配上一家高档餐厅和一瓶上好的葡萄酒时，它的价值就更容易评估了。但是如果我们用一片披萨换一块牛排，情况就会变得很奇怪。


    The same effect, of course, also applies to pizza. A pizza birthday party for an eight-year-old makes perfect sense, but a steak birthday party for kids doesn’t seem quite right. The kids would probably be upset and the party a disaster.

    当然，同样的效果也适用于披萨。给八岁孩子办披萨生日派对很合理，但给孩子办牛排生日派对似乎不太合适。孩子们可能会不高兴，派对可能会搞砸。


    The same steak has more value at the fancy restaurant than at a kid’s birthday party. The steak doesn’t change, but its value does. Why? A steak at a fancy restaurant helps you have a better restaurant experience. It delivers progress. A steak at a child’s birthday party does not make the party better. It does not deliver progress.

    同样的牛排在高档餐厅比在孩子的生日派对上更有价值。牛排不会变，但它的价值会变。为什么？高档餐厅的牛排可以帮助你获得更好的餐厅体验。它带来了进步。在孩子的生日聚会上吃一块牛排并不能使聚会变得更好。它不会带来进步。


    This is why we say progress defines value, and contrast reveals it. You understand the value customers place on a product when you compare and contrast the progress it delivers against the progress other products can deliver. A steak makes a fancy dinner better but a kid’s birthday party worse. A pizza makes a fancy dinner worse but a kid’s birthday party better.

    这就是为什么我们说进步定义了价值，而对比揭示了它。当您比较和对比产品交付的进度和其他产品可以交付的进度时，您了解客户对产品的价值。一块牛排使一顿丰盛的晚餐更好，但是一个孩子的生日聚会更糟糕。披萨让一顿丰盛的晚餐变得更糟，但是给孩子的生日派对更好。


    Solutions for Jobs deliver value beyond the moment of use. Imagine you own a car. When it’s sitting in your garage, is it still delivering value? Doesn’t the satisfaction of owning a car extend beyond when you’re actively using it? What’s more valuable: getting transported from point A to point B or having the peace of mind that you have the ability to go where you want to go, whenever you like?

    乔布斯的解决方案提供超越使用时刻的价值。想象你有一辆车。当它停在你的车库里时，它还能带来价值吗？难道拥有一辆车的满足感不会超出你积极使用它的时候吗？更有价值的是: 从 A 点到 B 点的旅程，还是你能够随时随地去你想去的地方，从而获得内心的平静？


    Our lives are dynamic. They can’t be measured well in static terms. Yes, a solution can provide functionality only in the moment, but its value to the customer is realized in contexts beyond that moment. A product should be designed with an understanding of how it improves customers’ lives, not just how it offers value in the moment.

    我们的生活充满活力。它们不能很好地用静态条件来衡量。是的，解决方案只能在当下提供功能，但它对客户的价值是在当下之后的上下文中实现的。一个产品的设计应该理解它如何改善顾客的生活，而不仅仅是它如何在当下提供价值。


    Producers, consumers, solutions, and Jobs should be thought of as parts of a system that work together to evolve markets. What is a system? A system is a collection of parts that work together to achieve a desired effect. The value is not in any one particular part of the system but in how those parts work together.

    生产者、消费者、解决方案和乔布斯应该被看作是一个系统的一部分，它们共同努力促进市场的发展。什么是系统？系统是一系列部件的集合，它们共同工作以达到预期的效果。价值不在于系统的任何一个特定部分，而在于这些部分如何协同工作。


    A car is an example of a system. Imagine I give you a box that contains all the parts of a car. What I gave you would likely be worthless to you. The parts are valuable to you only when they are assembled in a particular fashion, when they work together in a particular way, and when you can use them to make progress. You become better at helping customers, not by studying the individual parts of the car, but by studying how those parts work together to create something that helps customers make progress.

    汽车就是一个系统的例子。想象一下，我给你一个盒子，里面装着汽车的所有部件。我给你的可能对你毫无价值。只有当它们以特定的方式组装起来，当它们以特定的方式一起工作，并且当你可以使用它们来取得进展时，这些部件才对你有价值。你变得更善于帮助客户，不是通过研究汽车的各个部件，而是通过研究这些部件如何协同工作，创造一些东西，帮助客户取得进展。


    The same is true for producers, consumers, solutions, and Consumer Jobs. You need to understand how these parts work together to evolve customers and renew markets. Such a study will also help you understand why and how customers and markets don’t evolve.

    对于生产者、消费者、解决方案和消费者工作也是如此。您需要了解这些部分是如何协同工作以发展客户和更新市场的。这样的研究也将帮助您理解为什么以及如何客户和市场没有发展。


    Grill manufacturer Weber understands the idea of producers, consumers, products, and Jobs as part of a system. Weber understands that it’s not in the business of making and selling grills. It’s in the business of making people better grillers. That’s why it offers educational materials, recipes, party-planning guides, grilling accessories, and even a free phone hotline for grilling advice. For many grillers, the

    烤架制造商韦伯理解生产者、消费者、产品和乔布斯作为一个系统的一部分的想法。韦伯明白，这不是生产和销售烤架的业务。它的业务是让人们更好的烧烤。这就是为什么它提供教育材料，食谱，聚会策划指南，烧烤配件，甚至一个免费的电话热线烧烤咨询。对很多烧烤店来说


    JTBD is also about entertaining friends and family with cooking theater, as well as tasty food. In this case, it’s about becoming a better host and entertainer. Weber understands that no matter how well its grills function, if customers can’t use them to make progress against their JTBD, the grills are worthless.

    JTBD 还可以用烹饪剧场和美味的食物招待朋友和家人。在这种情况下，它是关于成为一个更好的主持人和表演者。韦伯明白，无论其烤架功能如何良好，如果客户不能使用它们来取得进展，对他们的 JTBD，烤架是毫无价值的。


    The understanding that customers are buying a better version of themselves is why Weber delivers a constellation of products that work together—as parts of a system—to evolve consumers and markets. Weber has been a successful, profitable company since 1893.

    理解消费者正在购买更好版本的自己，正是韦伯提供一系列产品的原因所在，这些产品作为系统的一部分相互协作，共同促进消费者和市场的发展。自1893年以来，韦伯公司一直是一家成功的、盈利的公司。


    Use these to create a mental catalog of examples of what it is like to apply Customer Jobs to innovation efforts. This will help you absorb the concepts in this book and become better at applying the theory to your own innovation efforts.

    使用这些工具创建一个心理目录，列出将客户工作应用于创新工作的例子。这将有助于你吸收本书中的概念，并更好地将理论应用到自己的创新努力中。


    After these case studies, we’ll dig deeper into the forces that shape customer demand, why Customer Jobs practitioners claim that Jobs remain while solutions come and go, and what it is like when an innovation effort fails to account for the forces of progress and how customers see competition.

    在这些案例研究之后，我们将更深入地挖掘影响客户需求的力量，为什么客户工作的实践者声称，解决方案来来去去，工作仍然存在，当创新努力不能解释进步的力量，以及客户如何看待竞争是什么样子。


    Part II

    第二部分

    Demand and Competition

    需求与竞争

    Customer Jobs theory encourages you to understand how demand for a product is generated and how customers view competition. The first three chapters in this part feature case studies of innovators who developed this understanding, and how it helped them create and sell products.

    客户工作理论鼓励你理解产品需求是如何产生的，以及客户如何看待竞争。这一部分的前三章介绍了发展这种认识的创新者的个案研究，以及这种认识如何帮助他们创造和销售产品。

  3. Case Study: Dan and Clarity

    案例研究: Dan 和 Clarity

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    I didn’t know who Dan Martell was when I started writing this book. Another Customer Jobs practitioner told me about Dan’s success as a serial entrepreneur, angel investor, and Customer Jobs practitioner. When I did catch up with him, I learned that he had applied Customer Jobs principles while building a company called Clarity. Customer Jobs thinking helped him:

    当我开始写这本书的时候，我不知道 Dan Martell 是谁。另一位“客户工作”的从业者告诉我丹作为一个连续创业者、天使投资者和“客户工作”的从业者所取得的成功。当我追上他时，我了解到他在创建一家名为 Clarity 的公司时，运用了客户工作的原则。客户乔布斯的想法帮助了他:


    Improve his research efforts.

    改进他的研究工作。


    Understand the company’s profit potential. Understand how Clarity could stand out to customers. Find marketing messages that resonate with customers.

    了解公司的盈利潜力。了解 Clarity 如何能够在客户中脱颖而出。找到能够引起客户共鸣的营销信息。

    Know which features his team should—and shouldn’t—add to his product so that more customers would use it.

    了解他的团队应该(也不应该)在他的产品中添加哪些特性，以便让更多的客户使用它。


    Founded in 2012, Clarity is a marketplace that connects entrepreneurs with experts who can advise, motivate, and inspire. Dan created Clarity to ensure that entrepreneurs get the advice they need to grow their businesses. It helps them find the right experts and then schedules and hosts calls with them. (Three years later, Dan sold it to Fundable, which is a platform that entrepreneurs can use to raise money.)

    成立于2012年，Clarity 是一个连接企业家和专家的市场，他们可以提供建议、激励和启发。丹创建了 Clarity，以确保企业家得到发展企业所需的建议。它帮助他们找到合适的专家，然后安排和主机与他们通话。(三年后，丹把它卖给了 Fundable，这是一个企业家可以用来筹集资金的平台。)


    Dan first heard about Customer Jobs from Eoghan McCabe during Clarity’s early years. Eoghan is CEO of Intercom, one of the companies Dan invests in. Dan, intrigued by Eoghan’s recommendation, believed Customer Jobs could help him grow Clarity faster:

    Dan 第一次听说客户工作是在 Clarity 早期的时候从 Eoghan McCabe 那里听说的。Eoghan 是 Intercom 的 CEO Dan 投资的公司之一。Dan 对 Eoghan 的建议很感兴趣，他相信客户工作可以帮助他更快地发展 Clarity:


    Once I decided I wanted to learn more about Customer Jobs, the first thing I did was to search Clarity’s marketplace. I found some [Customer Jobs] experts and did a few calls. It was really helpful to get real-world experience and advice on how to approach it.

    一旦我决定要更多地了解客户工作，我做的第一件事就是搜索 Clarity 的市场。我找了一些(客户工作)专家，打了几个电话。它真的有助于获得现实世界的经验和建议，如何处理它。


    How can Customer Jobs help you do better research? Dan had already been a strong proponent of customer interviews, even before getting into Customer Jobs.

    客户工作如何帮助你做更好的研究？甚至在进入客户工作领域之前，丹就已经是客户面试的坚定支持者。


    Every week, he would call six customers or so and ask questions such as, “How would you feel if you could no longer use this?” or, “How can we improve Clarity?” But Dan knows that such interviews have limitations. In particular, he understands the difficulties inherent in talking with customers about their habits and that people often want to feel as if they are giving the “correct” answers. “I feel like customers have this really bad habit of lying sometimes,” he said. “They’ll say, ‘Yeah. I love your product. I use it all the time.’ Then, you look at the logs, and you realize they haven’t logged in once since signing up—so you know it’s not true.”

    每周，他都会打电话给六个左右的客户，问一些问题，比如“如果你不再使用这个，你会有什么感觉?”或者“我们如何提高清晰度?”但是丹知道这样的采访是有局限性的。特别是，他明白与客户谈论他们的习惯固有的困难，人们往往希望感觉好像他们给出了“正确”的答案。“我觉得顾客有时候真的有说谎的坏习惯,”他说。“他们会说，‘是的。我喜欢你的产品。我一直在用。然后，你看看这些日志，你会发现自从注册以来，它们一次也没有登录过，所以你知道这不是真的。”


    Calls with JTBD practitioners helped Dan realize the benefits of framing an interview around what Jobs customers are trying to get done. He did this by changing his questions. Instead of “How would you feel if you could no longer use this?” he asked customers, “Can you tell me about the other solutions you’ve tried? What did, or didn’t you like about each one?” In other words, he shifted from asking broad, individual questions to asking questions aimed at understanding customers’ journeys as they searched to find solutions that fit their JTBD. He would then investigate if other customers had similar journeys. Dan said,

    通过与 JTBD 从业者的电话交流，Dan 意识到了围绕乔布斯客户想要完成的工作来安排面试的好处。他通过改变问题来做到这一点。而不是“如果你不再使用这个，你会有什么感觉?”他问客户，“你能告诉我你们尝试过的其他解决方案吗？你喜欢还是不喜欢每一个?”换句话说，他从提出广泛的、单独的问题转变为提出旨在了解客户在寻找适合他们 JTBD 的解决方案时的旅程的问题。然后他会调查其他顾客是否有类似的旅行。丹说,


    What I love about JTBD is that it really helped me to build a framework for those interviews. Before I became familiar with JTBD, I studied interview questions, extracted pain points, customer language, and all these other things. But when you frame it around the question, ‘What is the Job your customer is hiring you to do?’ then it really puts a lot of things into perspective and helps you uncover key insights.

    我喜欢 JTBD 的原因是它真的帮助我为这些面试构建了一个框架。在我熟悉 JTBD 之前，我研究了面试问题、提取痛点、客户语言以及所有这些东西。但是当你围绕着这个问题，‘你的客户雇佣你做什么工作?’？然后，它真的把很多东西放在透视图，并帮助你发现关键的洞察力。


    What do consumers consider as competition? How do you understand what customers do and don’t value in a solution? Dan’s new approach to interviewing customers encouraged him to learn about other ways they had tried to get advice. He also wanted to learn if getting expert advice was really what customers were looking for. “Getting expert advice” is just an activity—a solution for a Job. What was the Job itself? What was the emotional motivation to make the customers’ lives better? Answering these questions would help him continue to improve and promote Clarity.

    消费者认为什么是竞争？如何理解客户在解决方案中做什么和不做什么？丹采访客户的新方法鼓励他了解他们试图获得建议的其他方法。他还想知道顾客是否真的需要得到专家的建议。“寻求专家意见”只是一种活动，一种工作的解决方案。工作本身是什么？使顾客生活得更好的情感动机是什么？回答这些问题将有助于他继续提高和促进清晰度。


    To help guide him through these interviews, Dan kept asking himself a few simple but powerful questions:

    为了指导他完成这些采访，丹不断地问自己一些简单而有力的问题:


    What do customers see as competition to Clarity?

    客户怎么看待 Clarity 的竞争对手？


    What would they spend their money on if they didn’t spend it on Clarity?

    如果他们不把钱花在 Clarity 上，他们会把钱花在什么地方？


    Have customers set aside a budget for using Clarity or some other solution?

    客户是否为使用 Clarity 或其他解决方案预留了预算？


    He then asked customers questions such as the following:

    然后，他向客户提出了以下问题:


    What other solutions did you try before deciding on Clarity? What did, and didn’t you like about other solutions you had tried? If you could no longer use Clarity, what would you use instead?

    在决定使用 Clarity 之前，您还尝试了哪些其他解决方案？你不喜欢你尝试过的其他解决方案吗？如果你不能再使用 Clarity，你会用什么来代替？

    These questions helped Dan learn what his customers considered as competition to Clarity. He learned that before ending up with Clarity, customers had tried solutions such as joining entrepreneur groups, hiring individual advisers (who take equity), using LinkedIn, and attending conferences. “Understanding how people thought about our product and its competition helped us position it to be different,” Dan said. “A lot of people had tried LinkedIn before coming to Clarity. Whereas LinkedIn connects people, it doesn’t let them call in real time. It was also interesting to hear that customers considered Clarity as an alternative to attending a conference.”

    这些问题帮助丹了解他的客户认为什么是对 Clarity 的竞争。他了解到，在最终使用 Clarity 之前，客户曾尝试过各种解决方案，比如加入企业家团体、聘请个人顾问(他们持有股权)、使用 LinkedIn 以及参加会议。“了解人们如何看待我们的产品及其竞争对手，帮助我们定位于与众不同,”丹说。“很多人在来 Clarity 之前都试过 LinkedIn。而 LinkedIn 却不允许人们实时打电话。同样有趣的是，消费者认为 Clarity 可以替代参加会议。”


    How do you learn what pushes customers to make a change? Dan began to learn two important observations as he talked with customers about the solutions they had used: what his customers did and didn’t value in a solution, and what was pushing them to make a change. He found these data by comparing and contrasting all the solutions they had used and asking himself, “What do these solutions have (or what do they not have) in common?” Dan realized that the solutions “use LinkedIn,” “hire an adviser,” and “attend a conference” had an important aspect in common: entrepreneurs were trying to make a connection with a specific person.

    你如何知道是什么促使客户做出改变？当丹与客户讨论他们使用的解决方案时，他开始了解到两个重要的观察结果: 他的客户在解决方案中做了什么和没有做什么，以及什么促使他们做出改变。他通过比较和对比他们使用过的所有解决方案来发现这些数据，并问自己: “这些解决方案有什么共同点(或者没有什么共同点) ?”丹意识到，“使用 LinkedIn”、“聘请顾问”和“参加会议”的解决方案有一个重要的共同点: 企业家试图与某个特定的人建立联系。


    Dan and his team saw that entrepreneurs seeking advice valued the messenger, often more than the message. When it comes to getting advice, it’s not just about the content. It has a lot to do with who’s delivering it. Dan said,

    丹和他的团队发现，寻求建议的企业家更看重信使，而不是信息本身。当涉及到寻求建议时，不仅仅是内容的问题。这跟送货的人有很大关系。丹说,


    There’s real value in going after that person who is going to motivate you to make a change. It’s not just having someone tell you, ‘Go get ten sales tomorrow.’ It is having billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban tell you, ‘Go get ten sales tomorrow.’

    追求那个能够激励你做出改变的人是有真正价值的。这不仅仅是让别人告诉你，‘明天去做十笔生意吧。’。亿万富翁企业家马克•库班(Mark Cuban)告诉你，‘明天去做十笔生意吧。’


    Dan now knew what was pushing customers to seek a solution: entrepreneurs who were in a slump wanted inspiration from a particular person. Getting advice is just an activity. If the seekers merely wanted advice, they could have read a book or watched a video. They wanted more. They were hoping that someone else’s success would rub off on them. This is why they wanted someone they respected to inspire and motivate them to get out of an entrepreneurial slump. That was their emotional motivation to make a change. Making progress with this Job is more valuable to these customers than getting advice. Dan said,

    丹现在知道是什么在推动客户寻求解决方案: 处于经济低迷期的企业家希望从某个特定的人那里获得灵感。寻求建议只是一种活动。如果探索者仅仅想要建议，他们可以读一本书或者看一段视频。他们想要更多。他们希望别人的成功能传染给他们。这就是为什么他们需要一个他们尊敬的人来激励和激励他们走出企业衰退的原因。那是他们改变的情感动机。对这些客户来说，在这项工作上取得进展比得到建议更有价值。丹说,


    I’ve got a list of competitors that tried to build competing solutions. Their marketing and positioning was all about, ‘Oh, if you want to talk to this type of person, we have them.’ But it was never about a person having the knowledge. It was what [you knew] the person you talked with had accomplished.

    我有一个竞争对手的名单，试图建立竞争的解决方案。他们的市场营销和定位都是关于，‘哦，如果你想和这类人交谈，我们有他们。’。但这从来都不是关于一个人有没有知识。这是(你知道的)与你交谈的人已经完成的事情。


    How can understanding the customer’s moment of struggle help you market a solution? These insights helped Dan and his team make two changes to how they advertised Clarity. Each change would differentiate their solution from what customers considered its competition and help customers realize that Clarity was better. The first change was to emphasize that Clarity would serve its customers on demand. As Dan put it:

    如何理解客户的挣扎时刻帮助您推销解决方案？这些见解帮助 Dan 和他的团队对 Clarity 的广告做了两个改变。每一个改变都将使他们的解决方案与客户认为的竞争对手区分开来，并帮助客户认识到 Clarity 更好。第一个变化是强调 Clarity 将根据客户的需求提供服务。正如丹所说:


    We started saying Clarity gave “on-demand business advice.” It was adding the words on demand that differentiated us from LinkedIn— which is an e-mail exchange from which you may or may not get a response. It also differentiated us from attending a conference—you didn’t have to wait until the next one came up. We mentioned all that in the copywriting.

    我们开始说 Clarity 提供“随需应变的商业建议”我们之所以不同于 LinkedIn，是因为我们可以按需添加词语。 LinkedIn 是一种电子邮件交流，你可能会收到回复，也可能收不到回复。它还使我们不同于参加一个会议ーー你不必等到下一个会议来临。我们在文案里都提到了。


    The second change was to highlight the fact that using Clarity was cheaper than attending a conference. Dan said, “Understanding what customers considered as competition also helped us position Clarity against the cost of going to a conference. Why invest thousands of dollars in expenses and the cost of a ticket if you can just talk to the speaker today?”

    第二个变化是强调使用 Clarity 比参加会议更便宜这一事实。丹说: “了解客户对竞争的看法也有助于我们将 Clarity 与参加会议的成本相对照。如果你今天就可以和演讲者交谈，为什么还要花费数千美元来购买门票呢?”


    How did the product attract more users and customers? Clarity is a marketplace for connecting buyers (entrepreneurs looking for advice) with sellers (those offering advice). This means that Clarity needed to attract two different groups of people—each with its own motivation for using Clarity.

    该产品如何吸引更多的用户和顾客？Clarity 是一个连接买家(寻求建议的企业家)和卖家(提供建议的人)的市场。这意味着 Clarity 需要吸引两组不同的人ーー每组人都有自己使用 Clarity 的动机。


    The motivation for advisers is simple: they want to make money by helping people. The entrepreneurs who use Clarity, however, are different. They want to be motivated and inspired, usually by a particular person. This meant that for its marketplace function to work, Clarity had to find experts whom customers recognized and respected. Dan said,

    聘请顾问的动机很简单: 他们想通过帮助别人赚钱。然而，使用 Clarity 的企业家就不同了。他们希望被激励和鼓舞，通常是由一个特定的人。这意味着，为了使其市场功能发挥作用，Clarity 必须找到客户认可和尊重的专家。丹说,


    Understanding what customers were trying to achieve with LinkedIn and conferences helped us with the supply side of the marketplace. We said to ourselves, “OK, if we recruit experts, we need to recruit a certain type of expert.” One of the creative solutions that we came up with was to source experts from SlideShare (a website where conference speakers share their presentations with the public). If you think about it, people who are regarded as inspiring and motivational are those who give creative presentations at conferences. When we wanted to add topics or categories for Clarity, we would source experts who had presentations on SlideShare.

    了解客户试图通过 LinkedIn 和会议达到什么目的，有助于我们解决市场的供应方面的问题。我们对自己说: “好吧，如果我们招聘专家，我们需要招聘一定类型的专家。”我们提出的一个创造性的解决方案是从 SlideShare (一个会议发言人与公众分享演讲的网站)中寻找专家。如果你仔细想想，那些被认为具有启发性和激励性的人就是那些在会议上发表创造性演讲的人。当我们想为 Clarity 添加主题或类别时，我们会为在 SlideShare 上做过演示的专家提供资源。


    How did Clarity realize its revenue potential? It was Dan’s understanding of what customers considered as Clarity’s competition that also helped him realize Clarity’s revenue potential:

    Clarity 是如何实现其收入潜力的？正是丹对 Clarity 竞争对手的理解，帮助他认识到 Clarity 的收入潜力:


    We learned from customers that their budget for Clarity wasn’t coming from the IPO, or from a monthly membership, or from a training budget. It was coming from spending money to go to an event to meet people and to learn.

    我们从客户那里了解到，Clarity 的预算不是来自 IPO、每月的会员资格或培训预算。它来自花钱去参加一个活动，以满足人们和学习。


    Dan realized that Clarity wasn’t taking money away only from lower-cost alternatives, such as LinkedIn, or from the price of a conference ticket. He learned that Clarity was tapping into the budgets for big-ticket items, such as hiring advisers and consultants, as well as entire budgets for attending conferences, which include airfare, hotels, and meals. This explained why his customers were willing to spend thousands of dollars on calls. This insight helped him understand how valuable his product was to customers. It also helped him understand Clarity’s true value in case it was acquired, which it eventually was.

    Dan 意识到 Clarity 并不只是从低成本的替代品，比如 LinkedIn，或者从会议门票的价格中拿走钱。他了解到 Clarity 正在利用大额项目的预算，比如聘请顾问和咨询顾问，以及参加会议的全部预算，包括机票、酒店和餐饮。这就解释了为什么他的客户愿意在电话上花费数千美元。这种洞察力帮助他理解了他的产品对客户的价值。它还帮助他了解 Clarity 的真正价值，以防它被收购，它最终被收购了。


    Clarity discovered a silent competitor: anxiety. Nobody comes to Clarity when he or she is having a great day. Dan and his team learned that entrepreneurs were hoping they could get inspired by someone they respected. Without this inspiration, these entrepreneurs would struggle to put into action any advice they were given. This generated demand for the product. But were there any forces that blocked this demand? Dan said, “The biggest competition for us is when a customer

    澄清发现了一个沉默的竞争对手: 焦虑。没有人会在他或她过得很开心的时候来 Clarity。丹和他的团队了解到，企业家们希望他们能从自己尊敬的人那里得到启发。如果没有这种灵感，这些企业家将很难把他们得到的任何建议付诸行动。这产生了对该产品的需求。但是有没有什么力量阻止了这种需求呢？丹说: “对我们来说，最大的竞争是当一个客户


    chooses to do nothing. I think that’s true for a lot of innovations. In Clarity’s case, entrepreneurs and innovators continue struggling in the dark. They wouldn’t choose to become a self-educator and solve their problem.”

    选择什么都不做。我认为很多创新都是如此。在 Clarity 的案例中，企业家和创新者继续在黑暗中挣扎。他们不会选择成为自我教育者来解决自己的问题。”


    Dan began to learn about the anxiety that blocks people from using the product or keeps them from using it more, even when they do decide to reach out to an expert on Clarity:

    丹开始了解到阻碍人们使用产品或阻止他们使用更多产品的焦虑，即使他们确实决定联系清晰度方面的专家:


    One of the questions that I would ask, which was about Clarity as a solution and not their JTBD, was, “What can we change to better meet your needs?” We found a bunch of anxieties around using Clarity. A majority of them were, “What if the expert doesn’t answer my question? What’s your guarantee? Is the call going to be recorded? What should I do to prep?” That last was one that really threw me off. Both the seekers and experts themselves felt we should teach them how to prepare for a good call.

    我想问的其中一个问题，是关于 Clarity 作为一个解决方案，而不是他们的 JTBD，是，“我们可以改变什么来更好地满足您的需求?”我们在使用 Clarity 时发现了一些焦虑。他们中的大多数人说: “如果专家不回答我的问题怎么办？你能保证什么？电话会被录音吗？我该怎么准备呢?”最后那个真的让我很困惑。探索者和专家们自己都觉得我们应该教他们如何为一个好的呼叫做准备。


    Dan and his team had taken it for granted that people would be prepared for a call. He assumed that both parties would set up the topic and then have a conversation. This was partly true. Customers had specific questions, but they didn’t know how to organize them or what made a question good or bad. Both sides wanted to prep, but they didn’t know how.

    丹和他的团队理所当然地认为，人们会为电话做好准备。他以为双方会先确定话题，然后再进行对话。这在一定程度上是正确的。客户有具体的问题，但他们不知道如何组织这些问题，也不知道问题的好坏。双方都想准备，但不知道如何准备。


    Another anxiety that both parties shared was the fear of sounding stupid or not putting their best foot forward. What if an expert doesn’t have a good answer for a question? What if he or she temporarily forgets the best answer? What if I get nervous and forget my follow-up questions? These anxieties prevented both groups—entrepreneurs and experts—from using Clarity more.

    双方共有的另一个焦虑是害怕听起来很愚蠢或者没有表现出他们最好的一面。如果专家对一个问题没有一个好的答案怎么办？如果他或她暂时忘记了最好的答案怎么办？如果我紧张了，忘了后续问题怎么办？这些担忧阻碍了企业家和专家两方面更多地使用 Clarity。


    How can you reduce the anxiety customers face when using or buying your product? To fix the problem, Dan and his team added some prep questions and guidelines to the e-mail templates they sent out to notify both parties of a call. They also provided notes that outlined what a great call looks like and what expectations the parties should have going into the call. Dan said,

    如何减少顾客在使用或购买你的产品时所面临的焦虑？为了解决这个问题，Dan 和他的团队在他们发送的电子邮件模板中添加了一些准备问题和指导方针，以便通知双方电话。他们还提供了说明，概述了一次伟大的呼吁是什么样子，以及各方在进行这次呼吁时应当抱有什么样的期望。丹说,


    Discovering anxieties like those—that is the interesting part. What I love is thinking, ‘Here is the problem, and here is the anxiety point. How do we solve it in a way that’s elegant, simple, and doesn’t confuse the interface?’ That was always the fun part for me.

    发现这样的焦虑ーー这才是有趣的部分。我喜欢的是思考，‘这里是问题，这里是焦虑点。我们如何以一种优雅、简单且不会混淆界面的方式来解决这个问题呢？这对我来说一直是有趣的部分。


    How can JTBD be used to research new features? As Dan became more familiar with JTBD, he began to develop his own tools and processes that would help him apply JTBD principles to improve Clarity. One such process was aimed at helping his team quickly validate ideas for new features.

    如何使用 JTBD 来研究新特性？随着 Dan 对 JTBD 越来越熟悉，他开始开发自己的工具和过程，这些工具和过程将帮助他应用 JTBD 原则来改进 Clarity。其中一个这样的过程旨在帮助他的团队快速验证新特性的想法。


    Before committing to developing a feature, the Clarity team wanted to make sure the problem they intended to solve was actually one that customers had. The best way to learn this was to find out if customers had tried to solve the problem before. Dan said, “An interview about how customers had tried to solve a problem in the past was more like a feature-usage time line than a purchase decision.”

    在承诺开发一个特性之前，Clarity 团队希望确保他们打算解决的问题实际上是客户的问题。了解这一点的最好方法是查明客户以前是否曾试图解决这一问题。Dan 说: “关于客户过去如何尝试解决一个问题的采访更像是一个功能使用时间表，而不是一个购买决定。”


    An example of a feature the Clarity team chose not to build was one that saved search results when users looked for experts on Clarity’s marketplace.

    Clarity 团队选择不开发的一个特性的例子是，当用户在 Clarity 的市场上寻找专家时，它可以保存搜索结果。


    We asked customers questions like, “Have you ever tried to save results when you searched for an expert?” If they said no, then we’d move on. We then asked, “Do you have a browser bookmarklet? Which ones?” Then, they would say, “Evernote, Buffer…” It would provide so much context outside of the feature. It was more about how the customer had tried to solve their problems in the past.

    我们向客户提出这样的问题: “当你搜索专家时，你是否曾试图保存搜索结果?”如果他们拒绝，我们就继续。然后我们问: “你们有浏览器书签工具吗？哪些?”然后，他们会说，“ Evernote，Buffer...”这将提供很多功能之外的上下文。它更多的是关于客户在过去如何尝试解决他们的问题。


    So, Dan’s team decided not to build the browser bookmarklet. They didn’t think it delivered enough value because the problem it solved wasn’t one their customers had struggled with. Dan said,

    因此，丹的团队决定不开发浏览器书签工具。他们认为它没有提供足够的价值，因为它解决的问题不是他们的客户曾经挣扎过的问题。丹说,


    A lot of people—especially if they’re committed or already invested in a solution—are looking for that confirmation bias that it’s something they should do. It’s a different question to ask customers how they solved the problem in the past. I could ask them, “Hey, what do you think of this?” They might say, “Oh, it’s prettier. It works great.” But that’s not really answering the question we’re asking. We want to know, “Are you going to use it? Are you struggling to make progress? Have you tried to solve this in the past? Do you want to hire someone or something to solve this Job to be Done?” If the answer is no, then cool. We write that down and move on.

    很多人(特别是如果他们致力于或者已经投入到一个解决方案中)正在寻找确认偏见，认为这是他们应该做的事情。这是一个不同的问题，问客户他们是如何解决这个问题在过去。我可以问他们，“嘿，你觉得这个怎么样?”他们可能会说，“哦，它更漂亮。效果很好。”但这并没有真正回答我们的问题。我们想知道，“你会使用它吗？你在努力取得进展吗？你以前试过解决这个问题吗？你是否想雇佣某人或某事来解决这项工作要完成的问题?”如果答案是否定的，那很好。我们写下来，然后继续。


    How does JTBD help innovators? Dan appreciates the focus JTBD puts on exploring customer motivation. He also wishes more companies would do that rather than “spy” on customers.

    JTBD 如何帮助创新者？Dan 欣赏 JTBD 对探索客户激励的关注。他还希望有更多的公司这样做，而不是“监视”客户。


    I think the biggest thing that Jobs [JTBD] encourages people to do, which I’m a big fan of, is to stop spying on customers and start talking with customers. I feel that way especially with software because we have the analytics and the geeks who are building the software; they’re all about tracking and logging and all these data…I always give the analogy of being a retail shop owner and hiding in the back room and trying to learn from your customers by watching the closed-circuit television.

    我认为乔布斯(JTBD)鼓励人们做的最重要的事情，也是我非常喜欢的事情，就是停止监视客户，开始与客户交谈。我对软件有这样的感觉，因为我们有分析师和开发软件的极客，他们都是关于跟踪、记录和所有这些数据... ... 我总是把这类比为一个零售店老板，躲在后面的房间里，试图通过观察闭路电视来向顾客学习。


    You could watch [customers] come in, walk around your store, pick up things, put them down, try things on…or you could just walk out and ask them, “Hey, what brought you in here today? What are you looking for? What other places did you try in the past?” Talking to customers about their motivations is where you’re going to learn the most.

    你可以看着(顾客)进来，在你的店里走来走去，拿起东西，放下，试穿... ... 或者你可以直接走出去问他们，“嘿，今天是什么风把你吹来的？你在找什么？你以前还去过哪些地方?”与客户谈论他们的动机是你学习最多的地方。


    What’s the JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    From the data Dan has given us, I’d say that the desire for progress is as follows:

    根据 Dan 给我们的数据，我认为进步的愿望如下:


    More about: getting out of a rut, making a connection with someone whose accomplishments I respect, being inspired, being motivated to act, feeling like I’m on the right path, having confidence in what I’m doing, having success rub off on me, on demand.

    更多关于: 走出陈规，与我尊敬的人建立联系，受到鼓舞，被激励去行动，感觉自己走在正确的道路上，对自己所做的事情有信心，成功感染了我，随需应变。


    Less about: getting expert advice, talking with an expert, giving away equity, having a video chat with a mentor, e-mailing a mentor, mentoring, meeting other entrepreneurs, seeing a mentor live.

    更少的是: 得到专家的建议，与专家交谈，放弃股权，与导师视频聊天，给导师发电子邮件，指导，与其他企业家会面，看导师的现场表演。


    Here are some possible descriptions of the one or more Jobs to be Done Clarity is hired for:

    以下是一些关于一个或多个需要完成的工作的可能描述:


    Help me get out of an innovation slump with inspirational advice from someone whom I respect.

    帮助我走出创新的低谷，从我尊敬的人那里得到鼓舞人心的建议。


    Give me the motivation to act with a kick in the butt from someone I respect.

    给我动力，让我从我尊敬的人那里得到教训。


    Take away the anxiety of making a big decision with assurance from someone else whose has been in a similar position.

    消除做出重大决定时的焦虑感，从处于类似情况的其他人那里获得保证。


    These work for me because they don’t describe an activity or task. They describe the motivation that comes before engaging in an activity (i.e., using a solution). Also, notice how these descriptions can be used to describe the other solutions customers had tried in the past (e.g., attending a conference, giving away advisory shares, and using LinkedIn). This is important because a JTBD either doesn’t change or does so slowly. If a description of a JTBD works for solutions from one hundred years ago, it’ll probably work for solutions one hundred years into the future.

    这些对我有用，因为它们没有描述一个活动或任务。它们描述了在参与某项活动之前的动机(例如，使用解决方案)。另外，请注意这些描述如何用来描述客户过去尝试过的其他解决方案(例如，参加会议，发放咨询股份，使用 LinkedIn)。这一点很重要，因为 JTBD 要么没有改变，要么改变得很慢。如果 JTBD 的描述适用于一百年前的解决方案，那么它可能适用于一百年后的解决方案。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Dan’s case study is a great introduction to Customer Jobs. Here are some suggestions to help you get started today with applying Customer Jobs thinking.

    Dan 的案例研究是对客户工作的一个很好的介绍。这里有一些建议可以帮助你今天就开始应用客户工作的思想。


    Ask customers about what they’ve done, not just what they want. Confirm it if you can. Customers will often tell us what we want to hear, even if it’s partially (or completely) untrue. Customers may tell you that they use your product “all the time,” but they really use it only intermittently. Also, people build easy-to-remember narratives between themselves and the products they use. Phenomena like this are why it’s tricky to ask customers, “What do you want?” and “How can we make things better?”21

    询问客户他们做了什么，而不仅仅是他们想要什么。如果可以，请确认。客户经常会告诉我们我们想要听到的，即使它部分(或完全)是不真实的。客户可能会告诉你，他们“一直”使用你的产品，但他们实际上只是间歇性地使用。此外，人们在他们自己和他们使用的产品之间建立容易记住的叙述。像这样的现象就是为什么问顾客“你想要什么?”“我们怎样才能让事情变得更好?”21


    The answer for these problems is to talk with customers about what they actually did, not just about what they say they want. What were their revealed preferences, not just their stated preferences? Even the answers about actual action taken won’t be 100 percent accurate, but they will be a great deal more reliable than their answers to what-if questions.22

    解决这些问题的方法是与客户谈论他们实际上做了什么，而不仅仅是他们说他们想要什么。什么是他们显示的偏好，而不仅仅是他们陈述的偏好？即使是关于实际行动的答案也不会100% 准确，但是它们会比他们对假设问题的回答更加可靠。22


    Understanding how customers have solved problems is a crucial part of understanding their JTBD. Not only does it help you understand what customers expect from a product, but it also helps you design features for new products.

    理解客户如何解决问题是理解他们的 JTBD 的关键部分。它不仅帮助您了解客户对产品的期望，而且还帮助您为新产品设计特性。


    Ask the right questions to learn how your customers view competition. Accurate models of competition can come from only customers. Any model of competition that doesn’t come from them is invalid. One way of getting the information you need to build a correct model of competition is through customer interviews and surveys. Ask them questions such as the following:

    提出正确的问题来了解你的客户是如何看待竞争的。准确的竞争模型只能来自顾客。任何不来自他们的竞争模式都是无效的。获得建立正确竞争模型所需信息的一种方法是通过客户访谈和调查。问他们以下问题:


    What other solutions did you consider before trying the product? What other solutions have you actually used?

    在试用该产品之前，您还考虑了哪些其他的解决方案? 您实际上还使用了哪些其他的解决方案？


    If the product wasn’t available to you, what would you have done instead?

    如果你没有这个产品，你会怎么做？


    What solutions have the people you know tried or used?

    你认识的人尝试过或使用过什么解决方案？


    Learn what kind of progress customers are seeking. What’s their emotional motivation (JTBD)? Use that to segment competition. Dan learned that Clarity’s customers saw its competition as attending conferences, using LinkedIn, and hiring advisers. These solutions have vastly different functionality and qualities. However, from the customers’ point of view, they appeal to the same aspiration: “Get me out of an entrepreneurial slump with motivational advice from someone whom I respect.” Discover your customers’ motivation through comparing and contrasting the solutions that they consider as competition:

    了解客户需要什么样的进步。他们的情感动机(JTBD)是什么？用它来分割竞争对手。丹了解到 Clarity 的客户将其竞争对手视为参加会议、使用 LinkedIn 和招聘顾问。这些解决方案具有完全不同的功能和质量。然而，从客户的角度来看，他们呼吁同样的愿望: “让我摆脱企业衰退，从我尊敬的人那里得到激励性的建议。”通过比较和对比你的客户认为是竞争对手的解决方案来发现他们的动机:


    What do the various solutions have in common? What is different about them?

    各种解决方案有什么共同之处? 它们有什么不同之处？


    What did, or didn’t the customers like about each solution?

    客户喜欢或不喜欢每个解决方案的哪些方面？


    What would customers do if they couldn’t use their existing solution for their JTBD?

    如果客户不能使用现有的解决方案进行 JTBD，他们会怎么做？


    What would the consequences be?

    会有什么后果？


    How are they expecting life to be better once they have the right solution for a JTBD?

    一旦他们找到了 JTBD 的正确解决方案，他们怎么能期望生活变得更好呢？


    These types of questions help you understand two things: what customers are struggling with now, and how they hope life will be better when they have the right solution. Put these two together, and you’ll have their JTBD.

    这些类型的问题可以帮助您理解两件事: 客户现在正在苦苦挣扎的是什么，以及当他们有了正确的解决方案时，他们如何希望生活会变得更好。把这两个放在一起，你会得到他们的 JTBD。


    Ask yourself, “From which budget will my product take away money?” Also ask, “When customers start using my product, what will they stop using?” Dan learned that his customers were willing to spend thousands of dollars on Clarity calls. This number didn’t come from looking at how much other “talk to an expert” products cost. He learned this by understanding that his product—from the customers’ point of view—was replacing the entire budget of going to a conference.

    问问你自己，“我的产品会从哪个预算中拿走钱?”还要问，“当客户开始使用我的产品时，他们会停止使用什么?”丹了解到他的客户愿意在 Clarity 电话上花费数千美元。这个数字并不是来自于“与专家交谈”的其他产品的成本。他了解到，他的产品ーー从客户的角度来看ーー正在取代参加会议的全部预算。


    I’ve noted that when it comes to solutions for a JTBD, customers can use only one at a time. When they start using one solution, they have to stop using something else. This helps you understand what the competition is. It also helps you gauge

    我已经注意到，当涉及到 JTBD 的解决方案时，客户一次只能使用一个解决方案。当他们开始使用一种解决方案时，他们必须停止使用其他解决方案。这有助于你了解什么是竞争。它也可以帮助你判断


    how to price your product properly and figure your revenue potential. Should you charge less or more? You have two big factors to consider: the amount customers are already accustomed to spending on a solution for a JTBD, and the intensity of their desire to change. The more they hope to change, the more they are willing to pay.

    如何正确定价你的产品和计算你的收入潜力。你应该少收费还是多收费？您需要考虑两个重要因素: 客户已经习惯于在 JTBD 解决方案上花费的金额，以及他们希望改变的强度。他们越是希望改变，就越愿意付出代价。


    Create better marketing material by speaking to your customers’ JTBD. Dan Martell described Clarity as “on-demand business advice.” He also featured access to experts whom customers would recognize. He also positioned Clarity as an alternative to going to a conference: Why spend the time and money going to a conference? Talk with the speaker today! Both of these messages spoke to customers’ motivations and distinguished Clarity as unique.

    通过与客户的 JTBD 对话来创建更好的营销材料。丹•马特尔(Dan Martell)将 Clarity 描述为“随需应变的商业建议”他还接触了一些客户认识的专家。他还将 Clarity 作为参加会议的替代选择: 为什么要花时间和金钱去参加会议？今天和演讲者谈谈！这两条信息都说明了客户的动机和独特的 Clarity。


    Talk with customers to learn what messages connect with them. It can be as simple as asking them to describe why they like your product. Sometimes, you have to probe deeper and ask them questions such as, “Before you bought our product, how did you know it was right for you?” The best promotional material, however, comes from speaking directly to their desire for progress.

    与客户交谈，了解哪些信息与他们有关。这可以很简单，要求他们描述为什么他们喜欢你的产品。有时候，你必须深入调查，问他们一些问题，比如，“在你购买我们的产品之前，你是怎么知道它适合你的?”然而，最好的宣传材料来自于直接表达他们对进步的渴望。


    Focus on delivering emotional progress (getting a Job Done). Don’t focus solely on functionality. Dan mentioned a list of people who had tried to create solutions similar to Clarity. They failed, and Clarity won because Dan designed and marketed it in a way that spoke to customers’ emotional motivation. The Clarity clones thought of themselves as “talk to an expert” products; they were focusing on functionality, activities, and tasks. But Dan focused on the emotional quality— that is, customers’ JTBD. He knew that customers wanted to be motivated and inspired by someone whom they respect. This made Clarity stand out, and it’s why Fundable acquired it. Clarity’s former competitors, however, have already been forgotten.

    专注于实现情感上的进步(完成工作)。不要只关注功能性。丹提到了一个试图创建类似 Clarity 的解决方案的人的名单。他们失败了，Clarity 赢了，因为 Dan 设计并营销了一种能够激发消费者情感动机的产品。Clarity 的克隆版本认为自己是“与专家交谈”的产品; 他们专注于功能、活动和任务。但丹关注的是情感质量ーー也就是客户的 JTBD。他知道，客户希望受到他们尊敬的人的激励和鼓舞。这让 Clarity 脱颖而出，也是 Fundable 收购它的原因。然而，Clarity 以前的竞争对手已经被遗忘。


    Your guiding star in understanding your customers’ JTBD is their motivation to better their lives. Focus on that. Focusing on functionality will distract you.

    理解客户的 JTBD 的指导方针是他们改善生活的动力。集中注意力。专注于功能会分散你的注意力。

  4. Case Study: Anthony and Form Theatricals

    个案研究: 安东尼与形式戏剧

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    What progress might someone use theater for? I had never asked this question before, but Anthony Francavilla had. For the past few years, Anthony has been applying Customer Jobs principles to figure out the answers to that question. Theater has been around for thousands of years. Shouldn’t we know the reasons why people attend the theater? Maybe. But maybe not.

    有人会利用剧院来达到什么目的呢？我以前从来没有问过这个问题，但是安东尼 · 弗兰卡维拉问过。在过去的几年里，安东尼一直在应用客户工作的原则来找出这个问题的答案。戏剧已经存在了几千年。难道我们不应该知道人们去剧院的原因吗？也许吧。但也许不是。


    Anthony has managed and produced theater for ten years. In 2012, he cofounded Form Theatricals, whose mission is to help productions grow and be successful. This is particularly challenging in the theater world. Many productions are run by actors or writers who often don’t have much business experience. They also have little to no experience innovating around customer motivation. This is where Anthony and Form Theatricals come in.

    安东尼管理和制作戏剧已经十年了。2012年，他与他人共同创立了 FormTheatricals，其使命是帮助制作成长和获得成功。这在戏剧界尤其具有挑战性。许多作品是由演员或作家经营的，他们通常没有太多的商业经验。他们也几乎没有围绕客户激励进行创新的经验。这就是安东尼和格式剧团的用武之地。


    Customer Jobs has helped Anthony figure out how to learn what really matters to theatergoers; what customers do and don’t consider as competition to theater; and how a theater production could improve its shows for patrons, increase profits from ticket sales, develop new types of theater products, and reduce the cost of operating a show.

    客户乔布斯帮助安东尼弄清楚了什么对观众来说是真正重要的; 什么是客户认为可以与剧院竞争的; 以及剧院制作如何可以改善观众的演出，增加门票销售的利润，开发新型的剧院产品，以及降低演出成本。


    Why look into Customer Jobs? Anthony knew that interviewing theater patrons was the key to improving a show. But what’s the best way to interview people about a show they’ve just seen? To find out, he sought advice from someone who specializes in interviewing customers. Anthony said,

    为什么要研究客户工作？安东尼知道采访剧院的赞助人是提高演出质量的关键。但是，采访刚看过节目的人的最佳方式是什么呢？为了找到答案，他向一位专门面试顾客的人寻求建议。安东尼说,


    I got together with this guy, Boris, who specializes in ethnographic interviewing. I said to him, “I have this problem with a client. People don’t like the show, but it’s selling well. I want to interview customers, but I don’t know what I should be asking them about.” He said I could talk to them and try to find out what Job these patrons are trying to get Done. He asked me if I had heard about Customer Jobs. I told him I hadn’t. He explained it to me. Then, he told me about some sources online where I could learn more. I also signed up for the Customer Jobs Meetup that’s run here in New York.

    我和一个叫鲍里斯的人在一起他专门从事人种学采访。我对他说”我和一个客户有点问题。人们不喜欢这个节目，但它卖得很好。我想采访客户，但我不知道应该问他们什么。”他说我可以和他们谈谈，看看这些顾客想干什么。他问我是否听说过客户工作。我告诉他我没有。他跟我解释过了。然后，他告诉我一些网上的资源，我可以学到更多。我还报名参加了在纽约举行的客户工作会议。


    After looking into Customer Jobs, a bit more and learning about some of the tools associated with the principles, it didn’t take long for Anthony to start gathering powerful insights.

    在深入研究了客户工作，了解了一些与原则相关的工具之后，没过多久 Anthony 就开始收集有力的见解。


    Studying what customers consider as competition helps you reveal what pushes them to change. It also helps reveal their JTBD. Anthony applied some Customer Jobs thinking to his next client: a children’s theater company. To begin, he interviewed parents who had taken their children to the company’s show. He wanted to know why they chose this particular show. Did they consider any other activities for their children besides attending the theater? He told me, “We interviewed a bunch of parents. We learned that the options they had considered [as alternatives to attending the theater] ranged from going to The LEGO Movie and buying the LEGO video game to signing their children up to clubs—like the Girl Scouts.”

    研究顾客认为什么是竞争有助于你揭示是什么促使他们改变。这也有助于揭示他们的 JTBD。安东尼把一些客户工作的想法应用到他的下一个客户上: 一家儿童戏剧公司。首先，他采访了那些带孩子去看公司演出的父母。他想知道他们为什么选择这个节目。除了看戏，他们还考虑过为孩子举办其他活动吗？他告诉我，我们采访了一些家长。我们了解到，他们考虑的选择(作为去剧院的替代选择)包括去看《乐高电影》(The LEGO Movie)和购买乐高电子游戏，以及让他们的孩子加入女童子军(Girl Scout)等俱乐部。”


    This was a story Anthony kept hearing. Parents were considering a wide array of options as alternatives to taking their children to this particular theater show. Or, in Customer Jobs terms, he learned exactly what parents considered as competition for their JTBD. These customers surely used the theater for other Jobs in other circumstances. But in this case, what Job were they hoping to get Done by bringing their children to this show?

    这是安东尼一直听到的故事。父母们正在考虑各种各样的选择作为带孩子去看这个特别的戏剧表演的替代方案。或者，用客户工作的术语来说，他确切地学到了父母认为是他们的 JTBD 竞争对手的东西。在其他情况下，这些顾客肯定会把这个剧院用在其他乔布斯身上。但在这种情况下，他们希望通过把孩子带到这个节目来完成什么工作呢？


    To help him answer this question, Anthony applied Customer Jobs’ idea of “contrast reveals value.” He talked with these parents about what they did or didn’t like about the other options they had considered. What can the theater do for them that an alternative solution—such as the Girl Scouts—can’t? He also asked these parents about what they did immediately after the shows. Did they have family discussions about them? What were those discussions like? After talking with numerous parents, he began to see a distinct pattern. “We found out that part of the Job these parents are trying to get done—when it comes to entertainment and activities for their kids—was that they wanted help teaching their kids how to be independent…while also reinforcing that they are a member of a team.”

    为了帮助他回答这个问题，安东尼应用了客户乔布斯的“对比揭示价值”的理念他和这些家长讨论了他们对其他选择的看法。剧院能为他们做些什么是女童子军这样的替代方案所不能做到的呢？他还询问了这些家长在节目结束后做了什么。他们有家人讨论过他们吗？那些讨论是什么样的？在与许多家长交谈之后，他开始看到一种独特的模式。“我们发现，这些家长努力完成的工作的一部分ーー在为孩子提供娱乐和活动方面ーー是他们希望帮助教导孩子如何独立... ... 同时也强调他们是团队的一员。”


    How do you go about making product changes when you understand the customers’ desire for progress? Anthony brought these insights to his client. Together, they decided to rewrite parts of the play. They kept most of the content the same, but they added a story arc wherein the hero works with the characters around him to solve a problem. This would give parents a talking point with their children about the importance of working with others. Anthony said,

    当你了解客户对进步的渴望时，你如何进行产品更改？安东尼把这些见解带给了他的委托人。他们一起决定重写部分剧本。他们保持了大部分的内容相同，但他们增加了一个故事情节，其中英雄与他周围的人物解决一个问题。这会让父母与孩子谈论与他人合作的重要性。安东尼说,


    It’s interesting to me because helping writers understand what Job parents are using their play for is more powerful than saying to them, “Write a movie, or write a play that a nine-year-old will like.” When we know that parents have a Job that involves their desire to teach their children life lessons in an entertaining way, we can work with our clients to help them craft their content better. When we present it as a Job to be Done, the artist has a lot of leeway around what the story should do.

    这对我来说很有意思，因为帮助作家理解父母用他们的剧本来做什么比告诉他们“写一部电影，或者写一部九岁孩子会喜欢的剧本”更有效果当我们知道父母的工作涉及到他们希望以一种有趣的方式教给孩子人生课程时，我们就可以与客户合作，帮助他们更好地制作内容。当我们把它作为一个需要完成的工作来呈现时，艺术家对故事应该做什么有很大的回旋余地。


    For Anthony’s client to sell more tickets to these parents, the performances had to help parents make progress against their JTBD, which included their aspiration to be responsible parents, as well as becoming better at teaching life lessons to their children. This needed to be done in a way that their kids would enjoy. The performance also had to do this better than what parents considered as competition—namely, other plays, movies, video games, and clubs.

    为了让安东尼的客户卖出更多的门票给这些家长，这些表演必须帮助家长在对抗 JTBD 方面取得进展，包括他们渴望成为负责任的家长，以及更好地教导孩子人生课程。这需要以一种他们的孩子会喜欢的方式来完成。这种表演也必须比家长们认为的竞争ーー即其他戏剧、电影、电子游戏和俱乐部ーー做得更好。


    Anthony wouldn’t have got the same depth of insight had he interviewed parents only about what they did and didn’t like about the play. Had he done that, he would have ended up getting a lot of feedback about how to make the play better— but only in comparison with other plays. With a Customer Jobs approach to understanding competition, he was now learning how theater compared with other solutions customers had tried.

    如果安东尼采访的只是家长们对这部戏做了什么和不喜欢什么的话，他就不会有这么深刻的洞察力了。如果他那样做了，他最终会得到很多关于如何让这部戏更好的反馈ーー但这只是与其他剧本相比。通过客户工作的方法来理解竞争，他现在正在学习与客户尝试过的其他解决方案相比是多么的戏剧化。


    What do we gain from digging deeper into the JTBD? Anthony wasn’t satisfied with just the one insight that these parents wanted help teaching their children life lessons. He wanted to dig deeper into their motivation. Were there other ways they were hoping that theater would make their lives better? He said,

    深入调查 JTBD 有什么好处？安东尼并不满足于这些父母想要帮助他们的孩子学习人生课程的一个见解。他想深入挖掘他们的动机。他们还希望通过其他方式让剧院让他们的生活变得更好吗？他说,


    One of the things we figured out was that parents want to have shared experiences with their kids. That’s not necessarily understood by the producers of theater and movies. On the surface, it doesn’t seem like a shared experience. Theater productions often see the dynamic of a play as “Let’s just go sit in a dark room and watch this together.” What we learned—and what a lot people don’t realize—is that the shared experience actually happens after the show. It’s when everyone goes out for dinner and they talk about the movie or the play they just saw.

    我们发现，父母希望与孩子分享经历。戏剧和电影的制片人不一定能理解这一点。从表面上看，这似乎不像是一种共享的经历。戏剧作品通常把戏剧的动态性看作是“让我们坐在一个黑暗的房间里一起看这个”我们所学到的ーー也是很多人没有意识到的ーー是，分享的经历实际上是在节目结束后发生的。就是大家一起出去吃饭谈论他们刚看的电影或者话剧。


    This insight about shared experiences prompted Anthony to ask parents other questions. What were other shared experiences they engaged in with their children? How did theater fit into those?

    这种对共同经历的洞察力促使安东尼向父母提出其他问题。他们和孩子们还有什么共同的经历？剧院是怎么融入其中的？


    I interviewed this father about how he, his wife, and his child would pick what they were going to watch on TV. They were basically engaged in rhetoric; they would each debate what they wanted to watch. They’d go back and forth, to the point that sometimes the debate would end with them all deciding to just go their separate ways and reading their own books. They wanted to have a shared experience—to the point that the debate itself became the shared experience—and they didn’t end up watching anything on TV.

    我采访了这位父亲，问他，他的妻子和孩子如何选择他们将要看的电视节目。他们基本上都在花言巧语; 他们每个人都在争论他们想看什么。他们会来来回回，直到有时辩论结束，他们都决定各走各的路，读自己的书。他们希望有一个共同的经历ーー以至于辩论本身变成了共同的经历ーー他们最终没有在电视上看到任何东西。


    By comparing and contrasting how families had and felt about shared experiences, Anthony could begin to understand what customers did and didn’t like about each solution. What made discussion about what to watch on TV so successful? What things didn’t families like about it? What were family discussions like after the family saw a play together? Were these discussions about life lessons or about other things, such as the performances of the actors? How could a theater show promote better conversations at home?

    通过比较和对比家庭对共享经验的感受，安东尼可以开始了解客户对每个解决方案的喜欢和不喜欢。是什么让关于在电视上看什么的讨论如此成功？有什么是家人不喜欢的？一家人一起看戏之后，家里的讨论是什么样的？这些讨论是关于人生课程还是关于其他事情，比如演员的表演？一场戏剧表演怎么能促进家庭对话呢？


    Answers to these questions helped Anthony understand that these parents wanted to make family life better through engaging and educational discussions with their children. These conversations were a bonding experience. This was exactly the kind of direction his client needed. It helped the children’s theater company make script adjustments, so its plays could act as vehicles for family conversations.

    对这些问题的回答帮助安东尼明白，这些父母希望通过与孩子进行参与性和教育性的讨论来改善家庭生活。这些对话让我们更加亲密。这正是他的委托人需要的方向。它帮助儿童戏剧公司调整剧本，使其剧本成为家庭谈话的媒介。


    How many Jobs might an innovation be used for? Anthony’s interviews with families had been successful. Understanding what Jobs they were using theater for helped him provide guidance for his client. He decided to continue Customer Jobs research with his other clients.

    一项创新可以用于多少个工作岗位？安东尼对受害者家属的采访很成功。了解乔布斯他们使用戏剧的目的帮助他为他的客户提供指导。他决定继续与其他客户一起研究客户工作。


    The next few shows he worked on were drama pieces with more serious subject matter—definitely not for kids. Patrons were usually individuals or small groups of friends. What Job might these people be using theater for? Anthony said,

    接下来他参与的几个节目都是有更严肃主题的戏剧作品ーー绝对不是给孩子们看的。顾客通常是个人或小团体的朋友。这些人利用剧院做什么？安东尼说,


    We interviewed a banker who went to a show by himself. He said, “I love these weird off-off-Broadway plays.” As we dived deeper into what that meant, we began to realize that an important part of the theater experience was who else is in the audience. That’s what one group of customers was looking for. They would say, “I want to hang out with artists more.” Others would say, “It’s just amazing. I don’t normally sit in a room and have an experience with a group of diverse people like that.”

    我们采访了一位独自去看演出的银行家。他说“我喜欢这些奇怪的外外百老汇”随着我们深入研究这意味着什么，我们开始意识到，戏剧体验的一个重要组成部分是观众中还有谁。这就是一群顾客想要的。他们会说“我更想和艺术家们一起玩”其他人会说，“这太神奇了。我通常不会坐在一个房间里，与这样一群形形色色的人打交道。”


    This is how Anthony began to discover another Job that people use theater for: it was about being a part of, or dipping their toes into, a different community. Very often, these customers had careers that weren’t arts related, such as banking or law. He would hear comments such as “I like these productions that are a bit out there,” “I like going because there are artists in the audience. They’re talking about art,” or “I don’t have a job in the arts, but I love the arts. I want to be involved in that kind of scene.” For many of these patrons, going to these shows was their only opportunity to engage with a diverse group of people. They liked the arts. They wanted to be involved in that community. Anthony said,

    这就是安东尼如何开始发现人们使用戏剧的另一个工作: 它是关于成为一个不同的社区的一部分，或者涉足其中。很多时候，这些客户的职业与艺术无关，比如银行或法律。他会听到这样的评论，“我喜欢这些作品，有点在那里,”“我喜欢去，因为有艺术家在观众。他们在谈论艺术,”或者“我没有艺术方面的工作，但是我热爱艺术。我想参与到这样的场景中。”对于这些顾客中的许多人来说，参加这些演出是他们与各种各样的人打交道的唯一机会。他们喜欢艺术。他们想加入那个社区。安东尼说,


    That was a very impactful insight. A lot of times, the theater will try to sell you the idea that it’s like a movie—but on stage. You can’t compete with that. Theater is more expensive. It’s sometimes super-inconvenient to attend a show. I have Netflix. If I want to watch a movie, I can hit a button, and there is a movie.

    这是一个非常有影响力的洞察力。很多时候，电影院会试图向你推销它就像一部电影ーー只不过是在舞台上。你比不过他的。剧院更贵。有时候去看演出真的很不方便。我有网飞。如果我想看电影，我可以点击一个按钮，就有一部电影。


    Figuring out what Job live entertainment solves for people in the twenty-first century is exciting. We’ve learned that, yes, it is entertainment, but it’s also about this idea of community. It’s something that you’re going to enjoy with other people. Maybe there will also be drinks, food, a lively atmosphere—all that kind of stuff. That’s something that a theater can take and use to build up a new business model for the twenty-first century—as opposed to this idea that there’s going to be a celebrity in the show. Tickets for those shows are two hundred and fifty dollars. There’s a very limited audience for that.

    弄清楚二十一世纪工作现场娱乐为人们解决了什么问题是令人兴奋的。我们已经了解到，是的，这是一种娱乐，但它也是关于社区的理念。这是你和其他人一起享受的东西。也许还会有饮料、食物、热闹的气氛ーー诸如此类的东西。剧院可以利用这一点，为21世纪建立一种新的商业模式ーー而不是认为演出中会有一位名人。那些演出的票价是250美元。观众非常有限。


    How can Customer Jobs help you reimagine existing products? With these new insights, Anthony and his clients were able to create a new type of theater experience: a theater subscription product. When people buy these subscriptions, each person is put into a specific cohort of customers. Shows are picked out for these customers. Over several months, this same group of people sees the same shows and engages in social events around the show. Anthony said,

    客户工作如何帮助您重新设想现有产品？有了这些新的见解，安东尼和他的客户能够创造一种新型的戏剧体验: 戏剧订阅产品。当人们购买这些订阅时，每个人都被放入一个特定的客户群中。节目是为这些顾客挑选的。在几个月的时间里，同一群人看同样的节目，参与节目周围的社交活动。安东尼说,


    These patrons valued this idea of inclusiveness. It is important for us to help theater productions understand that patrons are looking for an inclusive experience. This meant making the subscription affordable. It’s easier for a banker to pay five hundred dollars for a few shows than it is for many artists. We solved this problem by offering multiple payment options. You could spread the price over months or pay for the whole subscription up front.

    这些赞助人重视这种包容性的理念。对我们来说，帮助剧院制作了解观众正在寻找一种包容性的体验是很重要的。这意味着让订阅费用变得可承受。对于一个银行家来说，花500美元看几场演出比许多艺术家要容易得多。我们通过提供多种付款方式解决了这个问题。你可以将价格分摊到几个月内，或者预先支付整个订阅费用。


    How can Customer Jobs help you avoid wasting resources by building features that customers don’t care about? Anthony didn’t help his clients by only suggesting to them what they should add to a show. He also made suggestions on what to take out of it.

    客户工作如何通过构建客户不关心的功能来帮助您避免浪费资源？安东尼没有帮助他的客户，只是建议他们应该添加到一个节目。他还提出了从中取出什么的建议。


    One of Anthony’s clients had a production that featured an after-the-show tour of the stage for anyone who attended. It was something the producers of the show were proud of. But did patrons enjoy it? As he interviewed patrons after the show, he learned that most of them hadn’t known about the tour when they bought their tickets. They had simply chosen the show because tickets were being sold at a discount. He said,

    安东尼的一个客户有一个演出，其特色是在演出结束后为所有参加演出的人安排一次巡回演出。这是节目制作人引以为豪的。但是顾客们喜欢吗？当他在演出结束后采访观众时，他发现他们中的大多数人在买票的时候并不知道这次巡演。他们之所以选择这场演出，只是因为门票打折出售。他说,


    The majority of these patrons learned about the show and the discount on the day of the show. For some of them, it had been a last-minute decision. They’d be discussing with friends what to do for the evening. Should they just go to a bar? A comedy club? But when they noticed the discounted theater tickets, they then chose to buy tickets. It could be an hour or two before the show started.

    这些顾客中的大多数在展览当天就了解了展览和折扣。对他们中的一些人来说，这是最后一刻的决定。他们会和朋友讨论晚上做什么。他们应该去酒吧吗？喜剧俱乐部？但是当他们注意到打折的戏票时，他们选择了买票。演出可能还要一两个小时才开始。


    Of all the people he interviewed, only one or two knew that the set tour was going to happen. Anthony’s client had assumed that theater patrons were interested in access to the actors and seeing how the show worked. As it happened, almost no one who bought a ticket knew about the tour. The tour hadn’t been part of these patrons’ purchase criteria, so it didn’t help explain why they were hiring the show. Anthony said,

    在他采访的所有人中，只有一两个人知道布景巡演即将开始。安东尼的当事人认为剧院的顾客对演员的接触和演出的效果很感兴趣。事情发生的时候，几乎没有一个买票的人知道这次旅行。这次巡演并不在这些顾客的购买标准之内，所以这无助于解释他们为什么要雇佣这个节目。安东尼说,


    We learned that people were not hiring the show to get access to the actors and set after the show. Finding that piece of information was very valuable. The after-show tour was expensive to maintain, and it wasn’t something patrons were particularly interested in. The Job for those patrons was about entertainment and having a shared experience with their friends and significant others.

    我们了解到，人们雇用这部剧并不是为了在演出结束后接近演员和布景。找到那条信息非常有价值。演出后的巡回演出费用昂贵，而且观众也不是特别感兴趣。这些顾客的工作是娱乐和与他们的朋友和重要的其他人分享经验。


    In this case, the producers had overengineered the show. They had designed the show based on what they valued—a tour of the set—instead of what their customers valued—having a shared, fun experience with their friends. After gaining these insights, Anthony worked with the producers to discontinue the set tours. While experimentation is good, it has to be within the constraints of the Job that customers are hiring the show for. The new thinking freed up the show’s designers to focus on what they were doing right and make that better.

    在这种情况下，制片人过度设计了节目。他们设计这个节目的依据是他们所看重的东西ーー参观片场ーー而不是顾客所看重的ーー与朋友分享有趣的经历。在获得了这些洞察力之后，安东尼与制片人合作，终止了布景巡演。虽然实验是好的，但它必须在约束的工作，客户正在雇用的节目。新的思维释放了时装秀的设计师，让他们专注于他们正在做的事情，并使之变得更好。


    How does anxiety stop customers from buying your product? Is there really such a thing as an “impulse purchase”? Similar to tickets for airplanes, sporting events, and movies, theater tickets are worthless after the event starts. Seats are perishable inventory. This posed an interesting challenge for Anthony and his clients. To help him figure out how his clients could sell more tickets, he began interviewing customers to learn more about the key events that sped up or slowed down a decision to buy a ticket. Were there any anxieties about attending a particular show? If so, how could a theater production solve this problem? Anthony said,

    焦虑如何阻止顾客购买你的产品？真的有“冲动购物”这回事吗？与飞机票、体育赛事票和电影票类似，剧院票在赛事开始后一文不值。座位是容易腐烂的。这对安东尼和他的客户提出了一个有趣的挑战。为了帮助他弄清楚他的客户如何才能卖出更多的门票，他开始采访客户，以了解更多的关键事件，加快或放慢了决定购买门票。有没有对参加某个演出感到焦虑？如果是这样的话，一部戏剧作品如何解决这个问题呢？安东尼说,


    For each customer, we mapped out a time line of the events that led up to their ticket purchase. We began to hear the same things over and over again. Things like, a husband reads a magazine with his friends at work—that’s where he’ll first find out about a play. He’ll email his wife about it. She’ll respond with a comment like, “Seems interesting. I like that it’s a horror-themed play set in Spanish. I like horror.” But when bad reviews for it come out, they start to doubt if they’ll like it. But they still keep an eye on the show. Then, maybe a week later, they’ll learn about the discount. At that minute, they’re pushed over the edge and buy the tickets.

    对于每个客户，我们为他们购买机票的事件绘制了时间线。我们开始一遍又一遍地听到同样的事情。例如，丈夫在工作时和朋友一起看杂志ーー这是他第一次了解戏剧的地方。他会发邮件告诉他妻子的。她会回复这样的评论，“看起来很有趣。我喜欢这部以西班牙语为背景的恐怖主题剧。我喜欢恐怖”但是当负面评价出现时，他们开始怀疑自己是否会喜欢它。但是他们仍然在关注这个节目。然后，也许一周之后，他们就会知道折扣的事。在那一分钟，他们被推到边缘，买票。


    Anthony discovered two insights here: some anxieties prevent customers from buying tickets to a show, and tickets that seem to be impulse purchases sometimes aren’t.

    安东尼在这里发现了两个见解: 一些焦虑阻止顾客购买演出门票，而看似冲动购买的门票有时却并非如此。


    The majority of customers who bought a ticket through a discount did so on the day of the show, but that doesn’t mean these were impulse purchases. In the backs of their minds, these customers already had specific shows they wanted to see. But what was holding them back from buying the tickets? Anxiety. They’d first be excited about a show’s concept, but if reviews weren’t positive, they’d hold off. The discount, however, could compress the purchase time line. It eased anxiety and caused potential patrons to buy.

    大多数通过打折购票的顾客都是在演出当天购票的，但这并不意味着他们是冲动购票。在他们的内心深处，这些顾客已经有了他们想看的特定节目。但是是什么阻止了他们买票呢？焦虑。他们首先会对节目的概念感到兴奋，但如果评论不是正面的，他们就会推迟。然而，折扣可能会缩短购买时间。它缓解了顾客的焦虑，引起了潜在顾客的购买欲。


    Can Customer Jobs theory gather new insights about a medium that is thousands of years old? As the competition for theater changes with the advance of technology, it’s important to focus on the Jobs that customers hire theater for. Many parents use it as a way to help them have the types of conversations they want with their children and to help them teach life lessons. For those who want to expand and bring diversity to their social circles, community and diversity are critical.

    客户工作理论能否收集关于一个有几千年历史的媒介的新见解？随着科技的进步，剧院的竞争也在发生变化，关注顾客租用剧院的工作岗位显得尤为重要。许多父母用它来帮助他们与孩子进行他们想要的对话类型，并帮助他们教授人生课程。对于那些希望扩大自己的社交圈并为其带来多样性的人来说，社区和多样性至关重要。


    Anthony’s application of JTBD principles and focusing on customer motivation have enabled him to innovate within a medium that is thousands of years old.

    Anthony 对 JTBD 原则的应用和对客户激励的关注使他能够在一个有着几千年历史的媒介中进行创新。


    What’s The JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    This case study reveals different directions of progress that people hope to make using theater. This would explain why there are so many different types of theater shows. Some big themes associated with Jobs to Be Done I heard include using shared experiences to create or strengthen bonds with family and friends, parents teaching their children life lessons, and adding excitement to your social life by getting involved with people whom you normally wouldn’t interact with.

    这个案例研究揭示了人们希望利用戏剧取得的不同进展方向。这就解释了为什么有这么多不同类型的戏剧表演。我听说过一些与工作有关的大主题，包括利用分享经历来建立或加强与家人和朋友的联系，父母给孩子上人生课程，以及通过与那些你通常不会接触的人交往来为你的社交生活增添乐趣。


    The clearest JTBD I heard was related to parents’ desires. They wanted to teach their children how to be independent, while also understanding how to work with others. This works for solutions such as video games, movies, clubs like the Girl Scouts, and attending the theater. This case study had some great data about customer motivation; however, I still have questions about these parents’ motivations:

    我听到的最清晰的 JTBD 与父母的愿望有关。他们希望教会孩子如何独立，同时也要懂得如何与他人合作。这适用于电子游戏、电影、女童子军俱乐部等解决方案，也适用于剧院。这个案例研究有一些关于客户动机的很好的数据; 然而，我仍然对这些父母的动机有疑问:


    What are some of the consequences of not teaching their children life lessons?

    不给孩子上人生课的后果是什么？


    Is there something in these parents’ lives that is pushing them to make a change now, or are they deciding to be proactive and avoid feeling guilty in the future?

    在这些父母的生活中，是否有什么事情促使他们现在就做出改变，或者他们决定采取主动，避免在未来感到内疚？


    Does having conversations about life lessons relate to anything else going on in the lives of these parents or children? What about school or interactions with their friends?

    关于人生课程的对话是否与这些父母或孩子的生活中发生的其他事情有关？那学校和朋友之间的互动呢？


    What other solutions do parents couple with theater to make progress?

    为了取得进步，家长们还有什么其他的解决办法吗？


    How will parents know their Job is Done? That is, when do they know they are making progress and things are getting better?

    父母如何知道他们的工作完成了？也就是说，他们什么时候知道自己正在取得进展，情况正在好转？


    I would have a better idea of what progress parents are trying to make once I had answers to questions such as these.

    一旦我得到了这些问题的答案，我就能更好地了解父母们正在努力取得的进步。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    How do you persuade teammates or management to change a product? Frame design challenges as a JTBD. Innovators like to solve problems; we don’t like being told what to do. I find it’s best to motivate a team by presenting them with problems to solve in the form of a customer’s JTBD.

    如何说服队友或管理层改变产品？框架设计作为 JTBD 面临的挑战。创新者喜欢解决问题，而我们不喜欢别人告诉我们该做什么。我发现最好是通过以客户的 JTBD 的形式向团队提出需要解决的问题来激励他们。


    Dig deeper when you tap into a struggle or aspiration. How have customers tried to solve it before? Anthony discovered that parents had a desire for shared experiences with their kids. But what does shared experiences mean? It turns out that a shared experience is most important after the show. This insight gave Anthony the idea to talk with other patrons about their shared experiences. What made a shared experience successful? How had the patrons tried to have shared experiences?

    当你陷入挣扎或渴望时，再深入挖掘。客户以前是如何尝试解决这个问题的？安东尼发现，父母有与孩子分享经历的愿望。但是共同的经历意味着什么呢？事实证明，在节目结束后，分享经验才是最重要的。这种洞察力让安东尼有了与其他顾客谈论他们共同经历的想法。是什么让分享经历成功？顾客们是如何试图分享他们的经历的？


    When customers describe a struggle or aspiration, don’t make assumptions about what they mean; rather, unpack what they’re saying. Ask for specific examples. If they describe a struggle, how do they imagine life being better once they solve it? If they describe an aspiration, what are the consequences if they can’t achieve it? The answers will help you make design, marketing, and business decisions.

    当客户描述一种挣扎或渴望时，不要对他们的意思做出假设; 相反，要解开他们所说的话。要求具体的例子。如果他们描述一场斗争，他们如何想象一旦他们解决了它，生活会变得更好？如果他们描述一个愿望，如果他们不能实现它的后果是什么？这些答案将帮助您做出设计、营销和业务决策。


    Discover what customers value. Learn their expectations at the moment of purchase and/or first use and avoid overengineering solutions. Anthony had a client who offered a costly after-the-show tour of the set. However, he learned that almost no patrons were aware that the tour was being offered, so it didn’t affect their purchase decisions. This made it safe to remove tours from the show. This reduced costs of production, and it increased profits.

    发现顾客的价值。了解他们在购买和/或首次使用时的期望，避免过度设计解决方案。安东尼有一个客户提供了一个昂贵的演出后巡回演出。然而，他发现几乎没有顾客知道这个旅游项目，所以这并不影响他们的购买决定。这样就可以安全地取消巡回演出。这降低了生产成本，增加了利润。


    A great deal of waste happens when solutions are developed with features that customers don’t value. Customers value the progress a feature may deliver, not the feature itself.

    当解决方案使用客户不重视的特性时，会产生大量的浪费。客户重视特性可能交付的进度，而不是特性本身。


    If you have an existing product, engage in an audit to determine which features don’t help customers make progress toward their JTBD. If you’re about to create a new feature, make sure it delivers progress and, more importantly, helps you increase profits. You might learn just as one of Anthony’s clients did—namely, that you’re spending money to support features that customers don’t find valuable.

    如果您有一个现有的产品，那么进行一次审计，以确定哪些特性不能帮助客户在他们的 JTBD 方面取得进展。如果您打算创建一个新特性，请确保它能带来进步，更重要的是，它能帮助您提高利润。你可能会像安东尼的一位客户那样学到一些东西ーー也就是说，你正在花钱支持那些客户认为没有价值的功能。


    Determine if anxiety is a competitor. If it is, find ways of reducing it. You should attack the anxieties in choosing and using a product with the same fervor as attacking a competing product. If customers have anxiety over the cost-value

    确定焦虑是否是竞争对手。如果是的话，找到减少它的方法。在选择和使用产品时，你应该像攻击竞争产品一样，用同样的热情来攻击这种焦虑。如果顾客对成本价值感到焦虑


    relationship of your product, offer a discount. If customers experience anxiety in using your product, find a way to make your product less intimidating. Anthony attacked the former by offering discounts on the day of the show. He attacked the latter by offering drinks as “liquid courage” for theater patrons to feel more comfortable mingling with one another.

    你的产品的关系，提供折扣。如果客户在使用你的产品时感到焦虑，找到一种方法使你的产品不那么吓人。安东尼攻击前者，在节目当天提供折扣。他攻击后者，提供饮料作为“液体勇气”的剧院顾客感到更舒适的融合在一起。


    Be suspicious of the “impulse purchase” concept. No purchase is random. Anthony discovered that many customers purchased tickets on the day of—or even an hour or two before—the shows. But that doesn’t mean that these were impulse purchases. Many patrons had already decided they wanted to see a show; they had reservations about paying full price for a show that had received mixed reviews. A lowered price helped ease their anxiety about paying for a show that might not be very good.

    对“冲动购物”的概念持怀疑态度。没有购买是随机的。安东尼发现，许多顾客在演出当天(甚至在演出前一两个小时)购买了门票。但这并不意味着这些都是冲动购物。许多观众已经决定他们想要看一场演出; 他们对付全价观看一场评价不一的演出持保留态度。较低的价格有助于缓解他们对支付可能不是很好的节目的焦虑。


    Talk with customers about how they came to choose your product for their JTBD. They might claim that their purchase of a USB charging cable was “just an impulse purchase while I was waiting in line.” However, when you dig deeper, you might learn that they were about to go on a trip and wanted to take an inexpensive charging cable with them in case it got lost during their travels.

    与客户讨论他们是如何为他们的 JTBD 选择您的产品的。他们可能会声称，他们购买 USB 充电线“只是在排队时一时冲动购买的。”然而，当你深入挖掘，你可能会发现他们即将去旅行，并希望随身携带一个便宜的充电电缆，以防在旅行中丢失。

    Case Study: Morgan and YourGrocer

    案例研究: Morgan and YourGrocer

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    Morgan Ranieri was fed up. Getting home from work at seven o’clock at night meant he couldn’t get the groceries he wanted, for the stores he wanted to shop at were closed by then. Instead, he had to settle for the supermarket chains around Melbourne, Australia, where Morgan lives. I say “settle” because the food quality at these supermarkets isn’t very good. Shopping there also meant he wasn’t supporting family businesses, which was something he liked to do.

    摩根 · 拉涅利受够了。晚上七点钟下班回家意味着他买不到他想要的食品杂货，因为他想去的商店那时已经关门了。相反，他不得不满足于摩根居住的澳大利亚墨尔本附近的连锁超市。我说“解决”是因为这些超市的食品质量不是很好。在那里购物也意味着他不会支持家族企业，这是他喜欢做的事情。


    Sensing that he shared this struggle with other people, he teamed up with his colleague Bandith and created YourGrocer. The concept for YourGrocer was simple: have your groceries delivered to you from local, high-quality food shops.

    意识到自己与其他人分享了这种挣扎，他与同事班迪斯(Bandith)合作创建了 YourGrocer。YourGrocer 的概念很简单: 让你的杂货从当地的高质量食品店送到你手中。


    Over the next few months, Morgan and Bandith did some tests to see if the YourGrocer concept could work. They investigated what the competition might be, what logistics would need to be in place, and how many local shops were interested in partnering with them, and they even did some preliminary testing with a few customers to get feedback.

    在接下来的几个月里，摩根和班迪斯做了一些测试，看看 YourGrocer 的概念是否可行。他们调查了竞争可能是什么，什么样的物流需要到位，有多少当地商店有兴趣与他们合作，他们甚至做了一些初步测试，以获得反馈。


    Their tests told them that an opportunity did exist. However, to grow their business, Morgan and Bandith needed someone with more technical expertise to join the team. Morgan met Francisco (Frankie) Trindade at a local Meetup. Morgan said, “Over the next month or so, we began speed dating, in a sense—getting to know one another before deciding to work together.”

    他们的测试告诉他们，机会确实存在。然而，为了发展他们的业务，摩根和班迪斯需要有更多技术专长的人加入团队。摩根在当地的一个聚会上遇到了弗朗西斯科(弗兰基)特林达德。摩根说: “在接下来的一个月左右的时间里，我们开始了快速约会，在某种意义上说，在决定一起工作之前，我们相互了解了一下。”


    In this case study, we learn how Customer Jobs helped Morgan build a consensus among team members, what customers did and didn’t value in a solution, find the right marketing messages, how it helped first-time customers switch to Morgan’s product, and how he could reduce churn.

    在这个案例研究中，我们了解了 Customer Jobs 是如何帮助 Morgan 在团队成员中建立共识的，客户在解决方案中看重什么，不看重什么，找到正确的营销信息，它是如何帮助第一次使用 Morgan 产品的客户，以及他是如何减少流失的。


    Customer Jobs helps you persuade others that an opportunity exists. Frankie wanted to make sure an opportunity existed before he joined YourGrocer as its third cofounder. This is when Frankie introduced Morgan to Customer Jobs. Frankie told Morgan that he wanted to spend more time learning what Job(s) customers would use YourGrocer for. He especially wanted to do this before writing any of the software that would power the business. Morgan said,

    客户工作帮助你说服他人机会的存在。弗兰基希望在加入 YourGrocer 成为第三位联合创始人之前，确保存在一个机会。这时弗兰基把摩根介绍给了客户工作。弗兰基告诉摩根，他想花更多的时间了解 Job (s)的客户会用 YourGrocer 做什么。他特别想在编写任何能够为企业提供动力的软件之前这样做。摩根说,


    It was Frankie who introduced me and Bandith to Jobs (Customer Jobs). Actually, the first thing Frankie did when he joined YourGrocer was to make sure we all understood the principles of Customer Jobs. We spent a week learning about it and figuring out how we would interview customers. All of us learning about Customer Jobs, and then interviewing twenty customers together, was a great way to induct him as YourGrocer’s third cofounder.

    是弗兰基把我和班迪斯介绍给乔布斯(客户工作)的。事实上，弗兰基加入 YourGrocer 的第一件事就是确保我们都理解客户工作的原则。我们花了一个星期的时间来了解这个问题，并考虑如何面试客户。我们所有人都了解了客户工作，然后一起采访了20位客户，这是一个很好的方式来引导他成为 YourGrocer 的第三位联合创始人。


    How does your team benefit from doing Customer Jobs research together? The newly formed YourGrocer team gained an unexpected benefit of doing Customer Jobs research together. As Morgan said,

    你的团队如何从一起做客户工作调查中获益？新成立的 YourGrocer 团队因为一起做客户工作调查而获得了意想不到的好处。正如摩根所说,


    This shared learning experience really helped bring us together. We developed a shared understanding of what the business needed to be— which was missing in the beginning. At the start, we all had very different ideas about what customers were struggling with and how we should solve it. I was the typical visionary cofounder who has the next five years planned out in my head—which is very dangerous. But Frankie didn’t make many assumptions. He wanted to take it one step at a time. His middle name should be “Pragmatic”: Frankie Pragmatic.

    这种分享的学习经验确实有助于我们走到一起。我们对企业需要什么有了共同的理解ーー这在一开始就没有。刚开始的时候，我们对于客户遇到了什么问题以及我们应该如何解决这个问题有着非常不同的想法。我是一个典型的有远见的联合创始人，在我的脑海里规划着未来五年，这是非常危险的。但弗兰基没有做太多假设。他想一步一步来。他的中间名应该是“务实”: 弗兰基务实。


    Interviewing about twenty customers got me, as a business cofounder, and Frankie, as a new technical cofounder, on to the same page.

    采访了大约20个客户，让我作为一个业务联合创始人和弗兰基作为一个新的技术联合创始人，达成了共识。


    Are data about “types” of people information or misinformation? The first aha moment for the YourGrocer team was when they realized that their customers didn’t match the assumed demographic. Morgan said,

    数据是关于“类型”的人的信息还是错误的信息？YourGrocer 团队的第一个顿悟时刻是当他们意识到他们的客户不符合假定的人口统计学。摩根说,


    We had an assumption about what our customer demographic was— or the idea of who our target customer was. The reality turned out to be quite different. We thought we were creating a business for young professionals who wanted to buy groceries online. It turns out, almost every single one of our customers was a young family—typically a young mom with a couple of kids at home.

    我们对我们的客户群有一个假设ーー或者对我们的目标客户是谁有一个想法。事实证明情况完全不同。我们以为我们是在为那些想在网上购物的年轻专业人士创造一个商机。事实证明，我们的几乎每一位客户都是一个年轻的家庭ーー通常是一位年轻的母亲，家里还有几个孩子。


    At first, the YourGrocer team created the business out of their own need—that is, a way for busy young professionals to buy groceries online.
