But because most of the company’s customers were young families, the team needed to adjust. “It just turned out that the type of customers we were targeting at first [young professionals] didn’t really work too well for our product, but this other group of customers [parents] was ripe for it.”

    起初，YourGrocer 团队是根据自己的需要创建这个业务的ーー也就是说，让忙碌的年轻专业人士在网上购买杂货。但是因为公司的大多数客户都是年轻的家庭，团队需要调整。“事实证明，我们最初瞄准的客户类型(年轻专业人士)对我们的产品并不太适用，但另一批客户(父母)对我们的产品来说已经成熟。”


    How do struggling moments arise? What is it like to be pushed to change? Morgan and his team had now picked up on a group of struggling customers. The next step was to learn how and why these people were struggling. What was the struggling moment? This meant that Morgan first needed to talk with these customers about the different ways they had purchased groceries before. Morgan began to uncover the triggering events that would push these customers from one solution to another.

    挣扎的时刻是如何产生的？被迫改变是什么感觉？摩根和他的团队现在发现了一群苦苦挣扎的顾客。下一步就是了解这些人是如何以及为什么挣扎的。挣扎的时刻是什么？这意味着摩根首先需要和这些顾客谈谈他们以前购买食品杂货的不同方式。摩根开始发现触发事件，将这些客户从一个解决方案到另一个解决方案。


    The push that eventually led our customers to YourGrocer often began a couple of years in the past. They’d start off shopping at the shops they liked. Then they’d have their first child. Getting around to these shops with one kid was difficult, but they could deal with it. But once they had their second child, that would really change things. Having a second kid made it almost impossible to get to the local shops they wanted. That’s when they switched from their local shops to buying at the two big suppliers here.

    最终将我们的客户引向 YourGrocer 的努力往往始于过去的几年。他们开始在他们喜欢的商店购物。然后他们就有了第一个孩子。带着一个孩子去这些商店是很困难的，但是他们可以处理好。但是一旦他们有了第二个孩子，事情就真的不一样了。有了第二个孩子，他们几乎不可能去他们想去的当地商店。从那时起，他们从当地的商店转到这里的两家大供应商那里购买。


    As a customer’s family grew, more of his or her time was dedicated to caregiving. It also made traveling to multiple food shops difficult. This would lead these families to consider other ways of getting their groceries, such as at supermarkets.

    随着顾客家庭的成长，他或她更多的时间用于照顾。这也使得前往多家食品店变得困难。这将导致这些家庭考虑其他方式获得他们的杂货，如在超市。


    Discovering these triggering events helped Morgan understand how demand was being generated and how it pushed these parents to seek a solution. This helped him get an idea of how these parents were trying to make their lives better—that is, what Job they were trying to get Done.

    发现这些触发事件有助于摩根了解需求是如何产生的，以及需求是如何促使这些家长寻求解决方案的。这有助于他了解这些父母是如何努力让他们的生活变得更好的ーー也就是说，他们是如何努力完成工作的。


    What is it like to learn what customers do and don’t like about solutions they’ve tried? Next, Morgan had to learn how these parents had already tried to solve their problem—namely, how to get groceries when they had children to take care of. Comparing and contrasting these solutions would help him understand what these customers did and didn’t value in a solution. In particular, these parents complained about cost, poor-quality food, and not being able to choose foods they wanted.

    了解客户对他们所尝试的解决方案做了什么和不喜欢什么是什么感觉？接下来，摩根必须了解这些父母是如何努力解决他们的问题的ーー也就是说，当他们有孩子要照顾时，如何去杂货店买东西。比较和对比这些解决方案可以帮助他理解这些客户在解决方案中做了什么和没有做什么。特别是，这些家长抱怨成本高，食品质量差，不能选择他们想要的食物。


    The big supermarkets do fresh produce badly. The other local delivery suppliers that do fresh produce well are expensive. Some of them even have these subscription models where you get a preselected assortment of groceries. Customers can’t pick and choose what they want, when they want it. Our customers didn’t like that. They were getting a bunch of stuff they didn’t want, not using it, having it all go bad, and getting frustrated by that. Often, all these issues with other services

    大型超市的新鲜农产品做得很差。其他生产新鲜农产品的当地供应商成本高昂。其中一些甚至有这些订阅模式，你得到一个预先选定的杂货品种。顾客不能在他们想要的时候挑选他们想要的东西。我们的顾客不喜欢这样。他们得到了一堆他们不想要的东西，没有使用它，所有的东西都变坏了，并且对此感到沮丧。通常，其他服务的所有这些问题


    had been going on for some time. They were just putting up with it. Then, we came along. It was just what they had been waiting for.

    已经有一段时间了。他们只是在忍受。然后，我们出现了。这正是他们一直在等待的。


    What are examples of things customers value? Before starting YourGrocer, Morgan and his team already had a pretty good idea of what the business would be: home delivery from the quality shops his customers loved. Now they were filling in any blanks and confirming their assumptions of the value that YourGrocer should deliver. Here’s what they were learning:

    客户看重的东西有哪些例子？在创办 YourGrocer 之前，摩根和他的团队已经对这个行业有了一个很好的想法: 从他的顾客喜欢的优质商店送货上门。现在，他们正在填补所有空白，并确认他们对 YourGrocer 应该提供的价值的假设。以下是他们学到的东西:


    Convenience had become these customers’ top priority. They used to value food quality the most, but traveling with their kids to multiple stores proved too difficult for them. This pushed them to trade food quality for convenience.23

    便利已成为这些客户的首要任务。他们过去最看重食品质量，但事实证明，带着孩子去多家商店购物对他们来说太困难了。这促使他们以食品质量换取方便。23


    After convenience, they wanted to be able to choose foods they wanted. This ruled out services that delivered to the home but didn’t allow buyers to choose their own food options.

    方便之后，他们希望能够选择他们想要的食物。这排除了送货上门的服务，但不允许买家选择自己的食物。


    Quality got pushed to the bottom. Ultimately, these customers ended up choosing food from supermarkets. While supermarkets offered the lowest-quality foods, they ranked the highest on convenience and selection.

    质量被推到了谷底。最终，这些顾客只能从超市里挑选食物。超市提供的食品质量最差，但在方便性和选择性方面排名最高。


    How does JTBD help you create a message that connects with customers? The YourGrocer team members were confident that they now understood what the customers valued and that the team could deliver this value. The next step was to figure out a message that would connect with customers. Once again, customer interviews helped Morgan and his team figure this out.

    JTBD 如何帮助您创建与客户连接的消息？YourGrocer 团队成员确信他们现在理解了客户的价值，并且团队能够提供这种价值。下一步是找出一条能够与客户建立联系的消息。客户访谈再次帮助摩根和他的团队解决了这个问题。


    In the beginning, we didn’t know which messages would stick with customers. We would say, “It’s good to shop locally, because it’s good for the environment. It’s better food. It’s better priced. It’s convenient. It’s local shops. It’s good for your community.” We were throwing out half a dozen different messages out there without knowing which ones would persuade customers to try us.

    一开始，我们并不知道哪些信息会留在客户身上。我们会说，“在当地购物很好，因为这对环境有好处。更好的食物。价格更合理。很方便。是当地的商店。这对你的社区有好处。”我们发出了六条不同的信息，却不知道哪些信息能够说服顾客试用我们。


    Morgan solved this problem by asking his customers JTBD-style questions, such as “What stood out to you about us?” As he did so, he began to gain rich details about customers’ motivations.

    Morgan 通过问他的客户 JTBD 风格的问题解决了这个问题，比如“我们的哪些地方让你觉得突出?”在这样做的同时，他开始获得有关客户动机的丰富细节。


    One thing we really like about Customer Jobs is that you want to learn from customers what they’ve done in the past. You’re not just asking customers their opinion at the time you’re talking with them or through a survey. We would ask them, “What did you tell your friends about YourGrocer?” Or, better yet, “Can you show me the text in your phone that you sent your friend about us?”

    我们真正喜欢客户工作的一点是，你想从客户那里学习他们过去所做的事情。你不仅仅是在与客户交谈时或通过调查询问他们的意见。我们会问他们，“关于你的杂货店，你是怎么跟你的朋友们说的?”或者，更好的是，“你能给我看看你手机里发给你朋友的关于我们的短信吗?”


    Morgan’s customers had no problem pulling out their phones and showing him the text messages they had sent to others about YourGrocer, as well as any Facebook posts they had made about shopping with it. In those messages, Morgan saw customers express what they felt was valuable about YourGrocer. He learned that the messages they sent to other people were about getting groceries from a store:

    摩根的客户毫不犹豫地拿出手机，向他展示他们发给其他人的关于 YourGrocer 的短信，以及他们在 Facebook 上发布的关于使用 YourGrocer 购物的帖子。在这些信息中，摩根看到顾客表达了他们认为 YourGrocer 有价值的东西。他了解到，他们发送给其他人的信息是关于从商店购买日用品的:


    We knew that customers wanted quality foods. But just saying we offered quality wasn’t enough. We learned that customers trusted our message of quality only because of the local stores we featured on our site and advertisements. Other messages didn’t stick with them—being good for the environment, our competitive pricing, the ease of use when compared to other delivery services. All that kind of stuff wasn’t really standing out to our customers. It turned out, they were buying from us because they recognized the stores that we featured on our website.

    我们知道顾客想要高质量的食物。但仅仅说我们提供的质量是不够的。我们了解到，客户信任我们的质量信息，只是因为我们的网站和广告特色的当地商店。其他的信息并没有坚持下来ーー对环境有益、我们的定价具有竞争力、与其他快递服务相比使用方便。所有这些东西对我们的顾客来说都不是很突出。事实证明，他们从我们这里买东西是因为他们认出了我们网站上的商店。


    This is when the YourGrocer team honed their advertising message. It combined convenience, variety, and quality into one statement: “Online grocery shopping and same-day home delivery from the local shops you love.”

    这是当 YourGrocer 团队磨练他们的广告信息。它将便利性、多样性和质量结合成一句话: “网上购物和当天从你喜欢的当地商店送货上门。”


    What anxieties do first-time customers experience? What might prevent customers from using your product? So far, Morgan has learned about how important convenience is to his customers. Just how important this was became even more salient when he talked with customers about the first time they tried to use YourGrocer for delivery. He said,

    第一次购物的顾客会有什么样的焦虑感？什么可能会阻止客户使用您的产品？到目前为止，摩根已经认识到方便对他的客户有多么重要。当他与顾客谈到他们第一次尝试使用 YourGrocer 送货时，这一点变得更加重要。他说,


    We learned about this one anxiety: a lot of people came to the site and had trouble trying to figure out how YourGrocer would fit into their lives. We kept hearing comments such as, “I just don’t know when my groceries are going to get delivered.” This struck us as odd because we give really flexible delivery options.

    我们了解到了这样一种焦虑: 许多人来到这个网站，试图弄明白 YourGrocer 将如何融入他们的生活，但却遇到了麻烦。我们不断听到这样的评论，“我只是不知道我的杂货什么时候能送到。”这让我们感到很奇怪，因为我们提供了非常灵活的交货选择。


    This anxiety didn’t make sense to Morgan and his team. They offered flexible delivery hours, so why were customers commenting about not knowing when their

    这种焦虑对摩根和他的团队来说毫无意义。他们提供灵活的送货时间，那么为什么客户评论说不知道他们的


    groceries would be delivered? The answer lay in customers’ shopping habits and expectations. Morgan said, “It turns out that customers had this obstacle in their buying path. They decided what groceries to buy only after they’d figure out when they’d get the delivery. We had it reversed: you would pick your groceries first and then decide when to have them delivered.”

    杂货会被送到吗？答案在于顾客的购物习惯和期望。摩根表示: “事实证明，消费者在购买过程中遇到了这个障碍。他们只有在弄清楚什么时候能收到货之后，才会决定买什么样的食品杂货。我们把它颠倒过来: 你先挑选你的杂货，然后决定什么时候送货上门。”


    First-time customers coming to the site already had an idea of how YourGrocer was going to work. They had a habit or expectation of coming to a site, finding out how soon they could get a delivery, and then deciding what to buy. When this expectation was violated, they became frustrated and anxious. At this point, they would abandon trying out YourGrocer.24

    首次访问该网站的顾客已经对 YourGrocer 的运作方式有了一个想法。他们有一个习惯或期望来到一个网站，找出他们多快可以得到一个交货，然后决定买什么。当这个期望被违背时，他们变得沮丧和焦虑。在这一点上，他们会放弃尝试你的杂货店。24


    To fix this problem, YourGrocer adjusted the checkout process. It asked customers to pick a delivery window first and then walked them through the grocery-selection process. “That helped,” Morgan said. “We saw conversions go up after that.”

    为了解决这个问题，YourGrocer 调整了结帐流程。它要求顾客首先选择一个送货窗口，然后带领他们完成杂货店的挑选过程。“这很有帮助,”摩根说。“在那之后，我们看到转化率上升了。”


    What habits prevent customers from making progress? Can customers’ habits be competition? Anxiety wasn’t the only emotional force the YourGrocer team members would face. They also had to navigate customers’ existing habits. Morgan said,

    什么习惯阻碍了顾客取得进步？顾客的习惯会成为竞争吗？焦虑并不是 YourGrocer 团队成员面对的唯一情绪力量。他们还必须了解客户现有的习惯。摩根说,


    Dealing with customers’ existing habits was definitely a challenge with repeat-purchase customers. They had this habit around being able to duck down to the local store when they ran out of a key ingredient while cooking. Then, while they were at the store, they’d pick up extra groceries. In this case, they wouldn’t need to come back to us for another two weeks. Sometimes they’d fall out of the buying cycle, and we’d lose them as customers. Habits like these are our biggest competition.

    对于重复购买的顾客来说，处理顾客现有的习惯无疑是一个挑战。他们有这样一个习惯，就是当他们做饭的时候一种关键的原料用完了，就可以低头去当地的商店。然后，当他们在商店的时候，他们会多买一些杂货。在这种情况下，他们不需要在两周内回到我们身边。有时他们会掉出购买周期，我们会失去他们作为客户。这样的习惯是我们最大的竞争对手。


    If Morgan wanted to keep customers coming back, he needed to make sure that customers developed new habits around using YourGrocer. He couldn’t focus on only the outcomes customers were looking for. He had to think holistically about the customers’ JTBD. Customers didn’t just want their groceries delivered; they wanted a solution they could use to make their lives better.

    如果摩根想保持客户的回头率，他需要确保客户在使用 YourGrocer 时养成新的习惯。他不能只关注顾客想要的结果。他必须全面考虑客户的 JTBD。顾客不仅仅想要他们的食品杂货被送达，他们还想要一个可以使他们的生活变得更好的解决方案。


    So, how did Morgan and his team solve it? They focused on helping customers become more successful at using their product.

    Morgan 和他的团队是怎么解决的？他们专注于帮助客户更成功地使用他们的产品。


    We get people to set up regular orders with us. We set up e-mail triggers to help remind them that they might need something. The first one goes out three days after getting your first delivery. We send you an e-mail saying, “Hey, do you need a top-up on anything? Here’s a free delivery of any size so that you can top up with us.” Seven days after your last purchase, we e-mail you again and ask, “Do you know how easy it is to repeat last week’s order? You can just click this button and get everything delivered again.”

    我们让人们和我们一起建立定期订单。我们设置了电子邮件触发器来提醒他们可能需要什么东西。第一个在你收到第一批货三天后就发出去了。我们给你发邮件说“嘿，你需要补充点什么吗?”？这是任何尺寸的免费送货服务，你可以和我们一起补货。”在您最后一次购买的七天后，我们再次给您发电子邮件，问您: “您知道重复上周的订单有多容易吗?”？你只要按一下这个按钮，所有东西就会再次送达。”


    These e-mails are part of YourGrocer’s efforts to help customers become better meal planners. This is important to note because customers aren’t consciously joining YourGrocer to become better meal planners. It wasn’t an outcome that customers were seeking; however, meal planning is what customers have to be able to do if they want to use YourGrocer for their JTBD.

    这些电子邮件是 YourGrocer 努力帮助客户成为更好的膳食计划者的一部分。这一点很重要，因为顾客并不是有意识地加入 YourGrocer，成为更好的膳食计划者。这并不是顾客想要的结果; 然而，如果顾客想要在 JTBD 中使用 YourGrocer，他们必须能够做到膳食计划。


    What progress are customers trying to make? Morgan and his team came to understand their customers’ JTBD by combining their own intuition with what they learned through customer interviews.

    客户想要取得什么样的进步？摩根和他的团队通过把他们自己的直觉和他们通过客户访谈所学到的东西结合起来来理解他们客户的 JTBD。


    An important part of our customers’ Job to be Done is, “Give me a way to provide quality food for my family without the stress of running around.” The phrase “YourGrocer does the running around for me” came up quite a bit during the interviews. Before YourGrocer was available to them, if they wanted to go to these local shops, they had to be willing to deal with running around to these different stores—and deal with the hassle of having their kids in tow.

    我们客户工作的一个重要部分是，“给我一种方法，为我的家人提供高质量的食物，而不是跑来跑去的压力。”“你的杂货商为我跑来跑去”这句话在采访中出现了不少。在 YourGrocer 面世之前，如果他们想去这些当地的商店，他们必须愿意跑到这些不同的商店ーー还要处理带着孩子的麻烦。


    Morgan had the first part of the JTBD: his customers were struggling to get quality groceries without all the stress. Next, it was time for him to understand how customers were expecting their lives to be better when they had the right solution. What would it be like when this Job was Done?

    摩根拥有 JTBD 的第一部分: 他的客户在没有所有压力的情况下很难买到高质量的食品。接下来，是时候让他明白，当客户有了正确的解决方案时，他们是如何期望自己的生活变得更好的。这项工作完成后会是什么样子？


    YourGrocer helps families get back their Saturday mornings and weekends. With us, they can now buy good food for their family without having to sacrifice their Saturday mornings or weekends visiting all these different stores. That’s the trade-off they were struggling with before. If they wanted quality food for their family, they’d have to give up some family time so they could go shopping. If they didn’t want to give up family time, then they’d have to deal with poor-quality food from the supermarkets.

    你的杂货店帮助家庭在周六早上和周末回来。有了我们，他们现在可以为家人买到好吃的食物，而不用牺牲他们周六早上或周末光顾所有这些不同的商店。这就是他们之前苦苦挣扎的权衡。如果他们想为家人提供高质量的食物，他们就不得不放弃一些家庭时间去购物。如果他们不想放弃家庭时间，那么他们就不得不处理超市里的劣质食品。


    How can you beat the competition? Eliminate the need for the customer to make a trade-off. YourGrocer wins because it does what every great innovation does—that is, it helps customers break a constraint. Using YourGrocer means no longer choosing between quality food for the family and quality time with the family. Morgan said,

    你怎样才能打败竞争对手？消除客户进行权衡的需要。YourGrocer 之所以胜出，是因为它做到了每一项伟大创新所做的事情ーー也就是说，它帮助客户打破了限制。使用 YourGrocer 意味着不再在为家人提供优质食物和与家人共度美好时光之间做出选择。摩根说,


    Once the convenience trade-off was equalized—YourGrocer makes local shopping just as convenient as using a supermarket—then other trade-offs, such as quality and supporting the community, became the differentiators. That’s what sets us above the supermarkets. That’s the real progress that people are able to make with us.

    一旦方便性的权衡被平衡ーー YourGrocer 使当地购物就像使用超市一样方便ーー那么其他的权衡，例如质量和支持社区，就成了差异化的因素。这让我们凌驾于超市之上。这才是人们与我们共同取得的真正进步。


    What’s The JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    From the data Morgan has given us, I’d say that the struggle for progress is as follows:

    根据摩根提供的数据，我认为进步的斗争如下:


    More about: My family having quality food, taking away the stress from grocery shopping, more family time, convenience.

    更多关于: 我的家庭有高质量的食物，带走从杂货店购物的压力，更多的家庭时间，方便。


    Less about: Grocery shopping online/supermarket /local shop, supporting the local community.

    网上购物/超市/当地商店，支持当地社区。


    Again, any kind of task or activity associated with grocery shopping is just a solution for a JTBD—it’s not part of the JTBD itself. I know people who employ housemaids to keep the household fridge stocked with food and groceries. That entails no shopping at all—you pay someone else to take care of it. For those who can’t afford or don’t like that solution, grocery-delivery service is a nice alternative.

    同样，任何与食品杂货店购物相关的任务或活动都只是 JTBD 的解决方案ーー它不是 JTBD 本身的一部分。我认识一些雇佣女佣的人，她们会在家里的冰箱里放满食物和杂货。这根本不需要购物ーー你付钱让别人来照顾它。对于那些负担不起或不喜欢这种解决方案的人来说，食品杂货配送服务是一个不错的选择。


    The progression of solutions in this case study helps us understand what customers do and don’t value. In the beginning, parents were fine visiting multiple shops. They were willing to trade convenience for food quality. But when their family grew, saving time and reducing stress became more important to them. This is how we know that their desire to evolve, their JTBD, is heavily related to finding a way to solve that stress and to save time.

    在这个案例研究中，解决方案的进展有助于我们理解客户做什么和不做什么。一开始，家长们可以参观多家商店。他们愿意用方便来换取食品的质量。但是当他们的家庭成员增加时，节省时间和减少压力对他们来说变得更加重要。这就是我们如何知道他们进化的欲望，他们的 JTBD，与找到一种方法来解决压力和节省时间密切相关。


    This case study also demonstrates how customer needs or wants change over time and don’t belong to the customer. We may think we’re measuring a need, but we’re really just measuring what a customer does or doesn’t like about a particular solution. We must keep in mind that a “need” represents an interaction between the customer, their desire for progress, and whatever product they’ve hired for their

    这个案例研究还演示了客户的需求或需求如何随着时间的推移而变化，并且不属于客户。我们可能认为我们在测量一个需求，但实际上我们只是在测量一个特定解决方案的客户喜欢或不喜欢什么。我们必须记住，“需求”代表了客户、他们对进步的渴望以及他们为他们的产品所雇佣的任何产品之间的互动


    JTBD. If one of those parts changes, then customers’ needs will change along with it.

    如果其中一个部件发生变化，那么客户的需求也会随之变化。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Don’t depend on demographics. At first, Morgan thought he was making a product for young, urban professionals. This demographic certainly did represent some of his customers; however, it turned out that his most dedicated customers were families. Not only that, they almost always had two or more young children.

    不要依赖人口统计学。起初，摩根以为他是在为年轻的都市专业人士制造产品。这个人群确实代表了他的一些客户; 然而，事实证明，他最忠实的客户是家庭。不仅如此，他们几乎总是有两个或两个以上的孩子。


    We can learn from this that demographic thinking can be misleading. It was the customers’ situation—not personal characteristics—that determined why they bought. Sometimes, you do have to collect and use demographic data. They can help you when you buy ads and develop promotional material. If you need to develop an ad for video or print, you’ll have to cast actors and set a scene. That means making concrete decisions on what those people should look like, what they do, and where they are. However, these data shouldn’t be used as a basis for product and marketing decisions. They are corollary data, not causal data. Use demographic data only as a guide or hint to help you find JTBD data.

    我们可以从中学到，人口统计学思维可能会产生误导。决定他们为什么购买的是顾客的情况，而不是个人特征。有时，你不得不收集和使用人口统计数据。他们可以帮助你购买广告和开发促销材料。如果你需要制作一个视频或印刷品的广告，你必须选择演员并设置一个场景。这意味着要对这些人应该是什么样子，他们做什么，他们在哪里做出具体的决定。然而，这些数据不应该用作产品和营销决策的基础。它们是推论数据，不是因果数据。仅将人口统计数据用作指南或提示，以帮助您查找 JTBD 数据。


    Know the difference between customers who switch because they are unhappy with your solution and those who switch because changing life circumstances prompt a redefinition of progress. In Morgan’s case study, the local food shops may or may not have known why their customers stopped shopping with them. Was it because supermarkets offered more selection? Was it about quality? Was it about price? As it happens, none of these applied. These customers switched because they needed more convenience.

    了解那些因为对你的解决方案不满而转换的客户和那些因为生活环境的改变而促进进步的重新定义而转换的客户之间的区别。在摩根的案例研究中，当地的食品商店可能知道也可能不知道为什么他们的顾客不再和他们一起购物。是因为超市提供了更多的选择吗？是因为质量吗？是因为价格吗？碰巧，这些都不适用。这些客户转换是因为他们需要更多的便利。


    Let’s slow down and think about this. Notice something important and subtle here. By only observing customers, these businesses would have deduced that some switched to supermarkets. In response, these shops might have been tempted to change their businesses to be more like supermarkets. A butcher shop might think it should offer a wider selection of foods or lower its prices. Yet these things were not why the shops were losing customers. It was about convenience.

    我们慢慢来，好好想想。注意这里一些重要而微妙的东西。这些企业只要观察顾客，就会推断出其中一些人转向了超市。作为回应，这些商店可能受到诱惑，改变他们的业务，更像超市。肉店可能会认为它应该提供更多的食品选择或降低其价格。然而，这些并不是商店失去顾客的原因。只是为了方便。


    Next, imagine that these shops did learn that they were losing customers because of convenience. What should they do about it? This is a turning point where many businesses go terribly wrong. The knee-jerk reaction for many businesses in this position would be to figure out ways to offer more convenience themselves. They might be tempted to develop their own delivery services. This could be risky;

    接下来，想象一下这些商店确实知道他们因为方便而失去了顾客。他们该怎么办？这是一个转折点，许多企业在这个转折点上都出现了严重问题。对于许多处于这种情况的企业来说，下意识的反应是自己想办法提供更多的便利。他们可能会受到诱惑，开发自己的快递服务。这可能有风险;


    delivery might just add to their costs without a significant return in profit. Instead, the way to win back customers and keep existing customers was to coordinate with YourGrocer—a partner who would deliver groceries on their behalf. They didn’t have to change their product at all.

    交货可能只会增加他们的成本，而不会带来显著的利润回报。相反，赢回客户和留住现有客户的方法是与 YourGrocer 合作—— YourGrocer 是一家代表 YourGrocer 送货的合作伙伴。他们根本不需要改变他们的产品。


    Too often, businesses try to increase revenue by developing new products and features that are beyond their expertise. While they may capture more revenue, the endeavor ends up being a drain on time and money. This results in increased costs, minimal revenue gain, and likely a decrease in profits. Avoid this scenario by understanding why customers are switching away from your product. It could be that you can win back customers with little or no change to your product, as these small grocery stores did.

    通常，企业试图通过开发超出其专业知识范围的新产品和特性来增加收入。虽然他们可以获得更多的收入，但这种努力最终会耗费时间和金钱。这导致成本增加，收入增加最小，利润可能下降。通过理解为什么客户正在远离你的产品来避免这种情况。这可能是你可以赢回客户很少或没有改变你的产品，因为这些小杂货店做了。


    Create better advertising and promotional material by speaking to what customers value. Talk with customers to learn what messages connect with them. Don’t simply show them a bunch of ads and ask what they like. Instead, learn what made them think that one solution was better than another. How did they describe using a product to their friends and family?

    通过谈论客户的价值来创造更好的广告和促销材料。与客户交谈，了解哪些信息与他们有关。不要简单地给他们看一堆广告，然后问他们喜欢什么。相反，要了解是什么让他们认为一种解决方案比另一种更好。他们如何向他们的朋友和家人描述使用一种产品？


    Morgan learned that just using the word quality didn’t convey quality to customers. He needed to show pictures of the shops where the food came from. The shop logos did convey quality to customers.

    摩根认识到，仅仅使用质量这个词并不能向客户传达质量。他需要展示食物来源地的商店照片。商店的标志确实向顾客传达了质量。


    Teams become more motivated, build consensus, and share a vision when they do Customer Jobs research together. Morgan’s third cofounder, Frankie “Pragmatic,” wanted to do JTBD research before joining YourGrocer. He also wanted to do it before he built anything. The benefits of this approach cannot be understated. First, the YourGrocer team immediately built consensus about what kind of product they needed to offer. Second, the team got the design of YourGrocer pretty spot-on the first time. They made a few adjustments along the way but never needed to make any significant pivots to the business model or how the company was going to solve its customers’ JTBD.

    当团队一起做客户工作调查时，他们会变得更有动力，建立共识，分享愿景。摩根的第三位联合创始人，弗兰基“务实”，想在加入 YourGrocer 之前做 JTBD 研究。他也想在他建造任何东西之前就这么做。这种方法的好处不可低估。首先，YourGrocer 团队立即就他们需要提供什么样的产品达成了共识。其次，这个团队第一次就设计出了 YourGrocer。在这个过程中，他们做了一些调整，但从来不需要对业务模式或公司将如何解决客户的 JTBD 做出任何重大转变。

  5. The Forces of Progress

    进步的力量

    Forces that oppose each other Unpacking demand generation Push and pull shape the JTBD Unpacking demand reduction Put it to work

    相互对抗的力量拆箱需求产生推拉形状 JTBD 拆箱需求减少放到工作


    The last few case studies made frequent references to pushes, pulls, inertia, and anxieties. These four forces work together to generate and shape customer demand. This singular focus on customer motivation, and how forces shape customer demand, is what distinguishes JTBD from theories of innovation and design processes.

    最后几个案例研究频繁提到推、拉、惰性和焦虑。这四种力量共同作用，产生和形成客户需求。这种对客户激励的单一关注，以及力量如何塑造客户需求，是 JTBD 与创新理论和设计过程的区别所在。


    This chapter will introduce you to Customer Jobs thinking by unpacking the forces of progress. Understanding these forces will make you better at communicating customer motivation within your organization, understanding why customers are or are not attracted to your product, helping more customers buy your product, and creating advertising that connects with customers.

    本章将通过展示进步的力量，向你介绍客户工作的思想。理解这些力量将使你在组织内部更好地沟通客户动机，理解为什么客户会被你的产品吸引或者不会被吸引，帮助更多的客户购买你的产品，以及创建与客户联系的广告。


    Forces That Oppose Each Other

    相互对立的力量

    The forces of progress are the emotional forces that generate and shape customers’ demand for a product. They can be used to describe a high-level demand for any solution for the customers’ JTBD or the demand for a specific product.

    进步的力量是产生和形成消费者对产品需求的情感力量。它们可以用来描述对客户 JTBD 的任何解决方案的高级需求或对特定产品的需求。


    Two groups of forces work against each other to shape customer demand (figure 10). The first group is push and pull, or the forces that work together to generate demand. The other group is inertia and anxiety, or the forces that work together to reduce demand. In the middle, you have the customer, who experiences all these emotions at once.

    两组力量相互作用以形成客户需求(图10)。第一类是推拉作用，即共同产生需求的力量。另一个群体是惰性和焦虑，或者是共同作用以减少需求的力量。在中间，你有客户，谁经历所有这些情绪一次。


    Customers experience some combination of these forces before they buy a product, as they search for and choose a product, when they use a product, and when they use that product to make their lives better. Most innovators focus on the top two forces. They want to know “what customers want” and how demand is generated. They overlook the bottom two forces—that is, the forces that reduce and block that demand.

    消费者在购买产品之前，在搜索和选择产品时，在使用产品时，以及在使用产品使生活更美好时，都会体验到这些力量的某种组合。大多数创新者专注于前两种力量。他们想知道“顾客想要什么”以及需求是如何产生的。他们忽视了最底层的两种力量，即减少和阻碍需求的力量。



    Figure 10. The forces of progress that create and reduce demand.

    图10. 创造和减少需求的进步力量



    The innovators featured in this book are successful because they think about all four of these forces. Moreover, they think about how the forces contribute to the larger system that includes customers, producers, demand, and products. We’ll study this larger system later in the book. For now, we’ll unpack the four forces and understand how they generate and reduce demand.

    本书中的创新者之所以成功，是因为他们考虑到了所有这四种力量。此外，他们考虑的力量如何贡献更大的系统，包括客户，生产商，需求和产品。我们将在本书后面研究这个更大的系统。现在，我们将分析这四种力量，并了解它们是如何产生和减少需求的。


    Unpacking Demand Generation

    打开需求生成

    Demand isn’t spontaneously generated. No one wakes up in the morning and suddenly thinks, Today, I’m going to buy a new car. Some combination of events always comes together to generate that demand. We call those forces push and pull.

    需求不是自发产生的。没有人早上醒来突然想到，今天，我要买一辆新车。一些事件的组合总是一起产生这种需求。我们称之为推拉力。


    Push. People won’t change when they are happy with the way things are. Why would they? People change only when circumstances push them to be unhappy with the way things are. These pushes can be external or internal.

    用力。当人们对现状感到满意时，他们是不会改变的。为什么？人们只有在环境迫使他们对现状不满时才会改变。这些推力可以是外部的，也可以是内部的。


    External pushes. Morgan learned that parents had no problem shopping at multiple food shops with one child. But when they had two or more children to haul around to all these food shops, you can imagine all the stress and effort involved in that (or you may have experienced it yourself). Each child has to be put into and taken out of a car seat, parents need to navigate shops with strollers and shopping carts, and they need to carry all their groceries back to their car with their children in tow. Finally, they have to do all this all over again at the next shop they visit.

    外部推力。摩根了解到，父母带着一个孩子在多家食品店购物没有问题。但是当他们有两个或者更多的孩子要带到所有这些食品店的时候，你可以想象所有的压力和努力(或者你自己也经历过)。每个孩子都必须被放进和放出汽车安全座椅，父母需要用婴儿车和购物车在商店里导航，他们需要带着孩子把所有的杂货搬回他们的汽车。最后，他们不得不在下一家商店重新做这一切。


    Having a second child who makes grocery shopping unbearable is an example of a push. These parents have realized that their lives have changed, and the old way of solving their problems needs to change along with that.

    第二个孩子让人无法忍受在杂货店购物，这就是一个推动的例子。这些父母已经意识到他们的生活已经改变了，解决他们问题的旧方法需要随之改变。


    Internal pushes. The Clarity and Form Theatricals case studies show examples of internal pushes. Clarity’s customers were entrepreneurs who thought they were in a slump and struggled with motivation. Form Theatricals discovered various internal motivations that pushed customers to seek a solution for their struggle. These pushes ranged from frustration with the homogeneity of a peer group to parents who wanted experiences for their children that would teach life lessons.

    内推。清晰和形式戏剧的案例研究显示内部推动的例子。Clarity 的客户都是企业家，他们认为自己正处于经济衰退期，动力不足。FormTheatricals 发现了各种内部动机，推动客户寻求解决他们的斗争。这些推动力包括对同龄人群体同质性的失望，以及父母希望孩子获得能够教给他们人生经验的体验。


    In these examples, the outside world wasn’t forcing customers to change. Rather, they experienced a combination of circumstances that made them think, I don’t like how things are; I want to make a change.

    在这些例子中，外部世界并没有强迫客户改变。相反，他们经历了一系列的环境，使他们认为，“我不喜欢现在的状况; 我想做出改变。”。


    Pull. If a push is the engine that powers customer motivation, the pull is the steering wheel that directs motivation. Customers experience two kinds of pulls: (1) an idea of a better life and (2) a preference for a particular product.

    拉。如果说推力是驱动客户动力的引擎，那么拉力就是引导动力的方向盘。顾客经历两种拉力: (1)对更好生活的想法和(2)对特定产品的偏好。


    The pull for a better life. People don’t buy products just to have or use them; they buy products to help make their lives better (i.e., make progress). When they have the right product for their problem, they are able to do things they couldn’t before. The idea of this better life is what pulls them to act.

    为了更好的生活。人们购买产品不仅仅是为了拥有或者使用它们; 他们购买产品是为了让他们的生活变得更好(例如，取得进步)。当他们有了解决问题的正确产品时，他们就能够做以前做不到的事情。这种美好生活的想法是他们行动的动力。


    It’s important to be able to answer the question “How will customers evolve when they have the right solution?” One way of thinking about this type of pull is to see what happens when customers don’t recognize how life can be better (or refuse to act to improve it).

    能够回答这样一个问题很重要: “当客户拥有正确的解决方案时，他们将如何发展?”考虑这种拉动的一种方式是，看看当顾客不认识到生活可以变得更好(或拒绝采取行动改善生活)时会发生什么。


    For example, Dan described how some entrepreneurs would sit in the dark and choose not to self-educate. It is important to note that these customers are aware of their desire to change but choose to do nothing about it.

    例如，丹描述了一些企业家如何坐在黑暗中，选择不自我教育。值得注意的是，这些客户意识到他们想要改变，但却选择什么也不做。


    People choose not to improve their lives for many reasons. Psychologist Gary Klein posits that customers must engage in various mental simulations before they take any kind of action. They need to make sense of their desire to evolve, and they need to create expectations of how life will be better when their struggle is resolved. A customer who fails to do either of those mental simulations will not be motivated to make a change.

    人们选择不改善他们的生活有很多原因。心理学家加里 · 克莱因认为，顾客在采取任何行动之前必须进行各种心理模拟。他们需要理解自己进化的愿望，他们需要创造期望，当他们的斗争得到解决时，生活将如何变得更好。一个顾客如果不能做这些心理模拟中的任何一个，就不会被激励去做出改变。


    For example, an entrepreneur who struggles with running her business might simply assume that such a struggle is an unavoidable aspect of entrepreneurship. She thinks, that’s just the way things are. Another entrepreneur might recognize that the struggle is due to his inability to create a proper business model and assume that creating a business model is inherently hard.

    例如，一个企业家在经营自己的企业时遇到了困难，他可能会简单地认为这种困难是企业家精神中不可避免的一个方面。她认为，事情就是这样的。另一位企业家可能会认识到，困难是由于他无法创建一个适当的商业模式，并假定创建一个商业模式本身就很困难。


    The pull toward a solution. The pull for self-improvement is what motivates customers to begin searching for and using a solution. But what about their motivation to choose one solution over another? Dan learned that Clarity’s customers thought about and evaluated solutions such as using LinkedIn, giving away adviser shares, and attending a conference. Why choose one over another?

    解决问题的方法。自我改进的吸引力是激励客户开始寻找和使用解决方案的动力。但是，他们选择一种解决方案而不是另一种解决方案的动机是什么呢？丹了解到 Clarity 的客户考虑并评估了一些解决方案，比如使用 LinkedIn、分发顾问股票以及参加一个会议。为什么要选择一个而不是另一个？


    There are many known and unknown factors to consider about why customers choose one solution over another. However, when we focus on the forces that generate demand, we see that the context of the customer’s push shapes his or her desire to change. This affects the criteria used to choose one solution over another.

    有许多已知和未知的因素要考虑为什么客户选择一个解决方案而不是另一个。然而，当我们把注意力集中在产生需求的力量上时，我们看到客户推动的环境塑造了他或她改变的愿望。这将影响用于选择一种解决方案而不是另一种解决方案的标准。


    For example, attending a conference and using Clarity each compete for the same JTBD; however, one is not universally better than the other. If Clarity was universally better than attending a conference, then no one would attend conferences.

    例如，参加一个会议并使用 Clarity 每个人都在争夺同一个 JTBD; 然而，其中一个并不总是优于另一个。如果 Clarity 比参加会议更好，那么没有人会参加会议。


    The reason that many options coexist is that the pushes that shape a desire for change contain many variations. Someone may want advice from successful entrepreneur Mark Cuban; however, that person may not be in a rush or may not even be sure exactly what his problem is. For these reasons, this person is willing to wait for the next time Mark Cuban speaks at a conference. Conversely, another entrepreneur might urgently need help with a specific problem that she knows Mark Cuban has solved and so is willing to pay a premium to have Cuban talk directly with her.

    许多选择并存的原因是，形成改变愿望的推动力包含许多变化。有些人可能需要成功企业家马克 · 库班的建议; 然而，这个人可能并不着急，或者甚至不确定他的问题到底是什么。由于这些原因，这个人愿意等待下一次马克库班在会议上发言。相反，另一位企业家可能迫切需要帮助解决一个具体问题，她知道马克•库班已经解决了这个问题，因此愿意支付额外费用，让库班与她直接对话。


    Variations in the pushes that customers experience also explain why the same customer might go back and forth between different products for the same JTBD. Sometimes, Clarity might be better; sometimes, attending a conference might be better. It all depends on the context of the struggle.

    客户体验到的推送中的变化也解释了为什么同一个客户可能为同一个 JTBD 在不同的产品之间来回移动。有时，清晰可能更好; 有时，参加会议可能更好。这完全取决于斗争的背景。



    Figure 11. A breakdown of the forces that generate demand.

    图11. 产生需求的各种力量的细分



    Push and Pull Shape The JTBD

    推拉塑形 JTBD

    There is no demand—and therefore no JTBD—unless push and pull work together. A powerful step in understanding customer motivation is to study and appreciate the interdependencies between push and pull. They need each other. I might be attracted to the idea of owning an electric car from Tesla, but I won’t buy one unless I need a car. I have no push. Likewise, unless an electric car comes along that is attractive to me—it generates pull—I will accept that owning a car with an internal combustion engine is “just the way things are.”

    没有需求，因此也就没有 JTBD，除非双方共同努力。了解客户动机的一个有力的步骤是研究和理解推与拉之间的相互依赖关系。他们需要彼此。我可能会被拥有一辆特斯拉电动车的想法所吸引，但除非我需要一辆车，否则我不会买。我没有动力。同样，除非出现一辆对我有吸引力的电动车ーー它能产生吸引力ーー否则我会接受拥有一辆带内燃机的汽车“就是这样”


    Generating demand. Appreciating the interdependency between push and pull is why Elon Musk decided that Tesla’s first electric car would be a premium, high-end model. Musk believed he needed first to persuade customers that an electric car could be attractive, perform well, and be practical. He knew he needed to create pull to begin changing people’s minds. Once he did that, he could begin producing less expensive cars with the manufacturing know-how gained through production experience while maintaining the company with the profits from selling high-margin cars. How’s it working out? In 2016, about thirteen years after the company started, Tesla introduced its first low-end electric car. In the first week, it received an unprecedented 325,000 preorders for a car that customers had neither driven nor seen in person.25

    产生需求。了解推拉之间的相互依赖性是为什么埃隆 · 马斯克决定特斯拉的第一辆电动汽车将是一个优质的，高端的模式。马斯克认为，他首先需要说服消费者，电动汽车可以是有吸引力的，性能良好，并实用。他知道他需要创造吸引力，开始改变人们的想法。一旦他做到了这一点，他就可以利用生产经验中获得的制造技术，开始生产更便宜的汽车，同时利用销售高利润汽车的利润维持公司的运营。效果怎么样？2016年，也就是公司成立13年后，特斯拉推出了第一款低端电动汽车。在第一周，该公司收到了前所未有的325,000份订单，这些订单中的汽车客户既没有开过，也没有亲眼见过


    Failing to generate demand. When you fail to appreciate the forces of progress generation and the interdependencies between them, you get an innovation like the Tata Nano. In 2008, Tata Motors believed it could offer a low-end, feature-minimal car that would shake up the automobile market. Various Harvard professors wrote books and case studies about its success, claiming that it was “a runaway best

    无法产生需求。当你不能欣赏进步生成的力量以及它们之间的相互依赖性时，你就会得到像塔塔 Nano 这样的创新。2008年，塔塔汽车认为它可以提供一种低端、功能最少的汽车，这将撼动汽车市场。哈佛大学的许多教授都写过关于它的成功的书籍和案例研究，声称它是“一个失控的最好的


    seller,” a “disruptive innovation,” and that it “may disrupt the entire automobile distribution system in India.”26

    卖方是一个“破坏性创新”，而且它“可能会扰乱整个印度的汽车销售系统。”


    However, the reality proved quite different. Nano sales have been abysmal. After six years of production, annual sales in 2015 were only 18,531. In the end, Tata spent $400 million developing a flop. The blunder has forced Tata Motors to lay off workers and engage in costly redesigns.27

    然而，事实证明情况完全不同。纳米销售一直糟糕透顶。经过6年的生产，2015年的年销售量仅为18531辆。最终，塔塔花费了4亿美元开发了一个失败的产品。这一失误迫使塔塔汽车公司裁员，并进行昂贵的重新设计。27


    Why did the Nano fail? It didn’t have enough pull. In its cost-cutting frenzy, Tata didn’t offer a stereo and air-conditioning—features that customers expected from a car. Poor design made it roll over easily and prone to fire, and its weak engine made it underpowered for mountain driving. As a result, many customers decided to stick with their motorcycles or to spend the same amount of money on a used car that offered more features.28

    为什么 Nano 会失败？它没有足够的吸引力。在疯狂削减成本的过程中，塔塔没有提供消费者所期待的立体声音响和空调功能。糟糕的设计使它很容易翻滚，容易着火，而且它的发动机很弱，使它在山地驾驶时动力不足。因此，许多消费者决定继续使用他们的摩托车，或者花同样的钱买一辆功能更多的二手车。28


    As of 2016, Tata has abandoned the idea of finding profit at the low end of the market. Instead, the company is trying to find profit by marching up market with the redesigned Nano GenX. The company is adding more pull to the Nano, so it competes with traditional cars from other manufacturers, such as Smart.29

    截至2016年，塔塔已经放弃了在低端市场寻找利润的想法。相反，该公司正试图通过重新设计的 Nano GenX 向市场进军来获取利润。该公司正在增加更多的拉力纳米，所以它的竞争对手是来自其他制造商的传统汽车，如智能。29


    If your product doesn’t help customers make progress, price doesn’t matter. Both Tesla and Tata understood the push(es) to own a car, but only Tesla appreciated the role pull played.

    如果你的产品不能帮助客户取得进步，价格就不重要了。特斯拉和塔塔都理解拥有一辆汽车的推动力，但只有特斯拉欣赏拉的作用。


    As you’ll learn in a later chapter, it’s naïve to assume that customers will buy a product just because it’s a low-cost, feature-minimal version of an existing product. If that were true, netbooks would have displaced PCs and laptops, and everything inside the dollar store would be stealing away customers from the high-end products they copy.

    正如您将在后面的章节中了解到的那样，假设消费者仅仅因为某个产品是现有产品的低成本、功能最少的版本就会购买该产品，这种想法是天真的。如果这是真的，那么上网本将取代个人电脑和笔记本电脑，美元商店里的一切将从他们复制的高端产品那里抢走顾客。


    My colleague Ryan D. Hatch once said, “High price may actually draw in customers rather than push them away. It implies quality.” He’s absolutely right. Lower price as a differentiator sounds nice in a PowerPoint presentation, in an MBA program, or on a spreadsheet, but innovators know better. They understand that customers value progress above everything else. What good is low price if the product cannot help you get the Job Done?

    我的同事瑞安• D •哈奇(Ryan D. Hatch)曾经说过: “高价格实际上可能会吸引顾客，而不是把他们推开。这意味着质量。”他完全正确。在 PowerPoint 演示文稿、 MBA 课程或电子表格中，以较低的价格作为区分标准听起来不错，但创新者更清楚这一点。他们明白顾客重视进步高于一切。如果产品不能帮助你完成工作，那么低价格有什么好处呢？



    Figure 12. All the forces, broken down.

    图12所有的力都被破坏了



    Unpacking Demand Reduction

    减少需求

    Demand-reduction forces are just as important to understand as demand-generating forces. Most innovators and businesses focus on the latter and ignore the former. They shouldn’t, though. Forces that reduce or block demand should be investigated and managed with the same enthusiasm as demand generation. Why? These forces are just as much competitors as any product produced by a competing business.

    理解减少需求的力量与产生需求的力量同样重要。大多数创新者和企业关注的是后者，而忽视了前者。但他们不应该。减少或阻碍需求的力量应该像创造需求一样积极地进行调查和管理。为什么？这些力量与竞争企业生产的任何产品一样，都是竞争对手。


    For example, a struggling customer may be willing to buy your product but doesn’t because he fears that it’s too hard to use. Instead, he sticks to an old way of doing things, even though he’s unhappy with it. In this example, the result for you is the same, regardless of whether the customer stays with the current way of solving problems or buys a competitor’s solution: you miss out on a paying customer.

    例如，一个苦苦挣扎的客户可能会愿意购买你的产品，但不是因为他担心它太难使用。相反，他坚持一种古老的做事方式，即使他对此感到不快。在这个例子中，无论客户是继续使用当前解决问题的方法，还是购买竞争对手的解决方案，您都会得到相同的结果: 您错过了付费客户。


    Anxiety. In 2001, a collection of researchers lead by George Loewenstein identified two types of emotions that create anxiety: anticipatory emotions and anticipated emotions. The former are the feelings experienced only at the moment of decision, while the latter are what we expect to feel in the future. Within the context of JTBD and the forces of progress, I respectively call them anxiety-in-choice and anxiety-in-use.30

    焦虑。2001年，由 George Loewenstein 领导的一组研究人员发现了产生焦虑的两种情绪: 预期情绪和预期情绪。前者是只有在做决定的时候才会体验到的感觉，而后者是我们期待在未来体验到的感觉。在 JTBD 和进步力量的背景下，我分别称之为“选择中的焦虑”和“使用中的焦虑”


    Anxiety-in-choice. We experience anxiety-in-choice when we don’t know if a product can help us get a Job Done. It exists only when we’ve never used a particular product before. For example, “I’ve never taken the bus to work. Is it ever on time? Where do I buy a ticket?” We do our best to simulate mentally how things will be when we match a particular solution with a JTBD. However, the more

    选择中的焦虑。当我们不知道一个产品是否能帮助我们完成一项工作时，我们会感到选择中的焦虑。只有在我们从未使用过某种特定产品的情况下，它才会存在。例如，“我从来没有坐过公共汽车去上班。准时吗？我在哪里买票?”当我们将一个特定的解决方案与一个 JTBD 匹配时，我们尽最大努力在心理上模拟事情将如何发展。然而，更多


    unknowns we face, the more worried we become. Some examples of anxiety-in-choice from our case studies include the following:

    我们面对的未知越多，我们就越担心。我们的个案研究中有关选择焦虑的例子包括:


    If I use Clarity, will I sound stupid? Is the call going to be recorded? How is payment handled?

    如果我使用 Clarity，我会听起来很傻吗? 电话会被录音吗? 付款是如何处理的？


    This show seems interesting, but it got bad reviews. Maybe it’s not worth getting tickets for.

    这个节目看起来很有趣，但是评价很差。也许不值得买票。


    How does YourGrocer work? Are there flexible delivery options? Can I get my order today?

    你的杂货店是怎么运作的? 有没有灵活的送货方式? 我今天能拿到订单吗？


    These anxiety-induced unknowns are associated with how—or if—a product can deliver progress. These are the anxieties that drive away first-time customers.

    这些由焦虑引起的未知因素与产品如何(或是否)能够带来进步有关。正是这些焦虑情绪驱赶着第一次购买的顾客。


    Anxiety-in-use. After customers use a product for a JTBD, the anxiety-in-choice largely disappears. Now their concerns are related to anxiety-in-use. For example, “I’ve taken the bus to work several times. But sometimes it’s late, and other times it’s early. I wish I knew its arrival time in advance.” In this case, we know a product can deliver progress, but certain qualities about it make us nervous about using it.

    使用中的焦虑。当客户将产品用于 JTBD 之后，选择中的焦虑很大程度上就消失了。现在他们的担忧与使用中的焦虑有关。例如，“我曾多次乘坐公共汽车去上班。但有时很晚，有时很早。我希望我能提前知道它到达的时间。”在这种情况下，我们知道一个产品可以带来进步，但它的某些特性使我们对使用它感到紧张。


    Dan also discovered anxiety-in-use among his customers. He learned that customers wanted to use Clarity more but were held back because they were not sure how to prep for calls. They know a Clarity call can deliver them progress, but will they be satisfied with the next call? These are the anxieties that drive away repeat customers.

    丹还发现，他的客户中存在使用焦虑。他了解到，客户希望更多地使用 Clarity，但由于不确定如何准备电话服务而受到了阻碍。他们知道一个 Clarity 电话可以给他们带来进步，但是他们会对下一个电话感到满意吗？这些都是让老客户望而却步的焦虑。


    Inertia. Just as customers experience different types of anxieties, customers experience different types of inertia. Think of inertia as “a tendency to do nothing or to remain unchanged.” Inertia can manifest in different ways. Mostly, inertia forces are habits: habits-in-choice and habits-in-use. Understanding customers’ habits plays an important part in your ability to offer innovations.

    惯性。正如客户体验不同类型的焦虑，客户体验不同类型的惰性。把惰性想象成“什么都不做或保持不变的倾向”惯性可以以不同的方式表现出来。大多数情况下，惯性力量是习惯: 选择中的习惯和使用中的习惯。了解客户的习惯在你提供创新的能力中起着重要的作用。


    Habits-in-choice. These are the forces that exist at the moment of decision and prevent a customer from switching from one product to another. My favorite example of this is how the spreadsheet software Excel finally overtook its competitor, Lotus 1-2-3. In the 1980s, Lotus 1-2-3 was the go-to choice for spreadsheet software. Then, Excel came on the scene. At first, many people wanted to use it. But because they already had all their data stored in Lotus 1-2-3 files, they couldn’t switch. Microsoft solved this problem by giving Excel the ability to import and export Lotus 1-2-3 files. This eliminated the force that was holding customers back from switching to Excel.

    选择中的习惯。这些力量存在于做出决定的时刻，并阻止客户从一种产品转换到另一种产品。我最喜欢的一个例子是，电子试算表的 Excel 如何最终超越了它的竞争对手 Lotus 1-2-3。上世纪80年代，莲花1-2-3是电子试算表的首选。然后，Excel 出现了。起初，很多人想用它。但是因为他们已经将所有数据存储在 Lotus1-2-3文件中，所以他们无法切换。微软通过给 Excel 导入和导出 Lotus1-2-3文件的能力解决了这个问题。这消除了阻碍客户切换到 Excel 的因素。


    Habits-in-use. When Morgan and his YourGrocer team started their research, they didn’t explicitly search for problems around habit. But they quickly discovered a behavioral pattern: customers switched from using YourGrocer regularly to using it irregularly. This transition was an early indicator that a customer was about to fall out of the online-grocery buying cycle and switch back to shopping at the supermarket.

    使用中的习惯。当摩根和他的 YourGrocer 团队开始他们的研究时，他们并没有明确地寻找与习惯有关的问题。但他们很快发现了一种行为模式: 顾客从经常使用 YourGrocer 转变为不经常使用它。这种转变是一个早期指标，表明消费者即将脱离在线杂货购买周期，回到超市购物。


    What was going on? Morgan learned that these disruptions in buying patterns were the consequences of a habit. Many customers had developed the habit of not planning for future grocery needs. They got it because they had been shopping at supermarkets—that is, their previous solution for their JTBD. Having a supermarket less than five minutes away meant that customers didn’t need to plan their meals very much. They had gotten used to this and so formed a habit.

    发生什么事了？摩根了解到，这些购买模式的中断是一种习惯的结果。许多顾客已经养成了不为将来的食品杂货需求做计划的习惯。他们之所以能得到这个机会，是因为他们一直在超市购物ーー也就是说，他们之前针对 JTBD 的解决方案。距离超市不到五分钟的路程意味着顾客不需要为他们的食物做太多的计划。他们已经习惯了这一点，因此形成了一种习惯。


    Morgan had discovered an instance where a habit-in-use reduced customer demand for his product. We know that these customers wanted to use YourGrocer because if they hadn’t, they wouldn’t have used it in the first place. However, old habits-in-use were blocking them from continuing to use YourGrocer. Over time, they would regress to using a previous solution. They regressed not because the other solution was better but because customers found that keeping their old habits was easier. If Morgan wanted to keep as many of his customers as possible, he needed to help them drop old habits-in-use and develop new ones.

    摩根发现了一个例子，使用习惯降低了客户对他的产品的需求。我们知道这些顾客想要使用 YourGrocer，因为如果他们没有，他们一开始就不会使用它。然而，正在使用的旧习惯阻碍了他们继续使用 YourGrocer。随着时间的推移，他们会倒退到使用以前的解决方案。他们倒退不是因为另一个解决方案更好，而是因为客户发现保持旧习惯更容易。如果摩根想留住尽可能多的客户，他需要帮助他们改掉旧习惯，培养新习惯。


    Inertia and anxiety are your silent competitors. At its core, innovation is about helping customers make progress. Get them to that better version of life that they aspire to. It’s not just about helping customers break constraints by pulling them with flashy, new features. A lot of not-so-sexy work is involved. YourGrocer is an example of these forces at work. If Morgan wanted to maintain his customers, he had to help them become better at planning their meals and grocery needs.

    惰性和焦虑是你沉默的竞争对手。创新的核心是帮助客户取得进步。让他们过上他们向往的更好的生活。这不仅仅是帮助客户打破限制，通过拉动他们与华丽，新的功能。有很多不那么性感的工作。你的杂货店就是这些力量的一个例子。如果摩根想留住他的顾客，他就必须帮助他们更好地规划饮食和食品需求。


    Samuel Hulick once told me that designing an innovation was similar to conducting an organ transplant. It’s a wonderful analogy. The customer wants your product and hopes it will make life better, but for some reason, the switch doesn’t happen. Customers get hung up on one little thing that blocks them from using your solution for their JTBD.

    Samuel Hulick 曾经告诉我，设计一项创新就像进行器官移植一样。这是个很好的类比。客户想要你的产品，并希望它将使生活更美好，但由于某些原因，转变没有发生。客户被一个小东西所困扰，这个小东西阻碍了他们将您的解决方案用于他们的 JTBD。


    I ferociously attack inertia forces - like habit - as I would any competing product. I recommend you do the same. You can lose revenue because you haven’t accounted for people’s habits, or you can lose revenue because your product is inferior to a competing one. In both cases, the result is the same: you lose revenue.

    我像对待任何竞争产品一样，猛烈地攻击惯性力量——就像对待习惯一样。我建议你也这么做。你可能因为没有考虑到人们的习惯而失去收入，或者因为你的产品不如竞争对手而失去收入。在这两种情况下，结果都是一样的: 你失去了收入。


    Solving for customers’ habits is often an easy win. Your prospective customer already knows about your product and wants to buy it but can’t switch because of some small habit holding him or her back. All you have to do is figure out what’s holding your customer back and solve it.

    解决客户的习惯问题往往是一个容易的胜利。你的潜在客户已经知道你的产品，并且想要购买它，但是由于一些小的习惯阻碍了他或她的购买，他们无法改变。你所要做的就是找出是什么阻碍了你的客户并解决它。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    First, study the push and pull. The easiest way to begin gathering data about the forces of progress is to identify pushes and pulls. These forces are largely experienced outside any product. You should check off these forces first and then dig into the exploration of any product. Push and pull help you understand how demand is generated and help you set some boundaries when exploring customer motivation.

    首先，学习推拉。开始收集关于进步力量的数据的最简单的方法是识别推力和拉力。这些力量在很大程度上是在任何产品之外经历的。你应该首先核对这些力量，然后深入探索任何产品。推和拉帮助你理解需求是如何产生的，并帮助你在探索客户动机时设定一些界限。


    Find pushes by first asking about the solutions that customers have used. At what point did they realize that their particular solution wasn’t working anymore? What was going on in their lives?

    查找推首先询问客户使用的解决方案。他们是在什么时候意识到他们的特殊解决方案不再起作用的？他们的生活发生了什么？


    Find pulls by asking about their opinions about other products they investigated. Why did they choose product X or product Y? What was wrong with product Y? What did X have that Y didn’t?

    通过询问他们对他们调查的其他产品的看法来寻找拉力。他们为什么选择产品 X 或产品 Y？Y 产品有什么问题？X 有什么是 Y 没有的？


    Dig into inertia and anxiety after identifying push and pull. After you understand the forces that generate demand, study the demand-reducing forces. These arise when customer demand meets a product. They can also describe demand reduction for any given product.

    在分辨推拉之后深入研究惰性和焦虑。在了解了产生需求的力量之后，研究减少需求的力量。当客户需求满足产品时，就会出现这些问题。它们还可以描述任何给定产品的需求减少情况。


    For example, customers who hire attending a conference experience a different set of demand-reducing forces (i.e., inertia and anxieties) compared with if they choose Clarity. A customer who is shy may choose attending a conference because the idea of talking directly to an expert makes him or her nervous.

    例如，与选择 Clarity 相比，雇佣参加会议的客户体验到了一系列不同的减少需求的力量(即惰性和焦虑)。害羞的客户可能会选择参加会议，因为直接与专家交谈的想法使他或她感到紧张。


    Fight anxiety and generate pull by helping customers visualize the progress they will make by using your product. Show them how their lives will be better. You could show customers how your company’s outdoor grill is made of the latest and greatest advances in cooking technology. Or you could show customers how great of a cook they will become—and how their family and friends will be impressed—when they use your outdoor grill.

    通过帮助客户想象他们使用你的产品所取得的进步来战胜焦虑并产生吸引力。让他们知道他们的生活会变得更好。你可以向客户展示你们公司的户外烧烤架是如何利用最新最先进的烹饪技术制成的。或者，你可以向顾客展示，当他们使用你的户外烧烤架时，他们将成为一个多么出色的厨师，以及他们的家人和朋友将如何被打动。


    Earlier, we introduced the idea that customers engage in various mental processes: they make sense of their current problem, they try to envision how life will be

    早些时候，我们介绍了顾客参与各种心理过程的想法: 他们理解他们当前的问题，他们试图想象生活将会是什么样子


    better when they overcome that problem, and they simulate what it is like to use a product and its effect on their desire to evolve. This process takes a lot of work on the customers’ part.31

    当他们克服了这个问题，他们模拟使用一个产品是什么样子，以及它对他们的愿望发展的影响。这个过程需要客户做大量的工作。31


    Do customers a favor: help them visualize making progress. Create marketing and advertising materials that tell customers that you understand their struggle for progress, that help them visualize how life will be better when they have the right solution, and that explain why your product is the right solution.

    帮客户一个忙: 帮助他们想象取得的进展。创建营销和广告材料，告诉客户你理解他们为进步而奋斗，帮助他们想象如果他们有正确的解决方案，生活会变得更好，并解释为什么你的产品是正确的解决方案。


    Reduce anxiety-in-choice with trials, refunds, and discounts. “Buy one, get one free!” “Lifetime guarantee!” “Free shipping!” “Thirty-day refund!” These are probably the most obvious and widely practiced techniques of managing cost/value expectation. We’re all familiar with them and have heard enough about discounts in Anthony’s case study on theater tickets. We don’t need to go into the subject further.

    通过试用、退款和折扣减少选择中的焦虑。“买一送一”“终身保证!”“免费送货!”“30天退款!”这些可能是管理成本/价值期望的最明显和最广泛实践的技术。我们对它们都很熟悉，而且在安东尼的戏票折扣案例研究中，我们已经听到了足够多的关于折扣的内容。我们不需要进一步讨论这个话题。


    Identify any habits-in-use that keep customers from using your product. Adjust your product to help them along. Morgan learned that after using YourGrocer, many customers reverted to shopping at supermarkets, even though they preferred the food from YourGrocer. How did he help them? You’ll remember that he created automated e-mail notifications encouraging customers to “reorder an entire box with one click” and asking, “Need anything? Get a free refill.” The idea was to help these customers think ahead and make it easier for them to plan meals.

    识别任何阻止客户使用你的产品的使用习惯。调整你的产品来帮助他们。摩根了解到，在使用 YourGrocer 之后，许多顾客重新开始在超市购物，尽管他们更喜欢 YourGrocer 的食物。他是怎么帮他们的？您还记得他创建了自动电子邮件通知，鼓励客户“一键重新订购整个盒子”，并询问，“需要什么吗？免费续杯”这个想法是为了帮助这些顾客提前考虑，使他们更容易计划膳食。


    Comparing the habits of your best customers with the habits of those who recently quit is a great way to figure out how to turn switchers (i.e., those who have stopped using your product and started using another) into loyal customers. The first group have adapted and developed the necessary skills to get their Jobs Done (change their life-situation). Learn from them and use those data to help customers who are struggling get their Jobs Done.

    将你最好的客户的习惯与那些最近退出的客户的习惯进行比较，是一个很好的方法来弄清楚如何将转换者(即那些已经停止使用你的产品并开始使用另一个产品的人)转变为忠诚的客户。第一组已经适应和发展了必要的技能，以完成他们的工作(改变他们的生活状况)。向他们学习，并利用这些数据来帮助那些正在努力完成工作的客户。

  6. When You Define Competition Wrong

    当你错误地定义了竞争

    Too “kool” for school?

    太“酷”了，不适合上学？

    Why did the chotuKool flop? The mainframe versus the PC Don’t be fooled by randomness Put it to work

    为什么 chotkool 会失败? 主机对 PC 不要被随机性所愚弄，让它工作


    The forces of progress we spoke of earlier can help you understand how demand is generated and reduced. Creative destruction helps you understand the zero-sum nature of competition and how the definition of competition should not be restricted to products that look or function similarly.

    我们前面谈到的进步的力量可以帮助您理解需求是如何产生和减少的。创造性破坏有助于你理解竞争的零和本质，以及竞争的定义不应该局限于外观或功能相似的产品。


    But what happens when you ignore the forces of progress, creative destruction, and a constancy of purpose to solve a customer’s JTBD? What happens when you insist on selling a particular type of product? What happens when you blindly apply a theory to innovation?

    但是，如果忽略了进步、创造性破坏和解决客户 JTBD 的恒定目标的力量，会发生什么情况呢？当你坚持销售某种特定类型的产品时会发生什么？当你盲目地将一个理论应用于创新时会发生什么？


    This chapter will answer those questions. With this knowledge, you can avoid the costly mistakes that others have made.

    本章将回答这些问题。有了这些知识，你就可以避免别人所犯的代价高昂的错误。


    Too “Kool” For School?

    太“酷”不适合上学吗？

    In 2006, Indian manufacturer Godrej believed it had found a vast, untapped market for household appliances: the hundreds of millions of low-income Indians. Could Godrej create a suitably affordable appliance? Godrej believed that it could succeed in a market that other companies overlooked.

    2006年，印度制造商 Godrej 认为他们已经找到了一个巨大的、尚未开发的家用电器市场: 数亿低收入印度人。Godrej 能否创造出一种价格合适的设备？戈德雷吉认为，它可以在一个其他公司忽视的市场取得成功。


    But there were unanswered questions: Did an innovation opportunity really exist? What kind of product should the company create? How should it design the product? How would the product be sold? Godrej decided that it needed some help.

    但是还有一些问题没有得到解答: 创新机会真的存在吗？公司应该创造什么样的产品？如何设计产品？该产品将如何销售？Godrej 认为它需要一些帮助。


    A Harvard professor’s theory. Godrej hired economist and Harvard Business School professor Dr. Clayton Christensen and his consulting firm, Innosight. At Godrej’s headquarters, Christensen presented some of his innovation theories to its management teams, and they discussed the market opportunity that millions of low-income Indians represented. Christensen agreed that it was a great opportunity, and he suggested that Godrej begin with a low-cost, feature-minimal refrigerator. It

    哈佛教授的理论。Godrej 聘请了经济学家兼哈佛商学院教授 Clayton Christensen 博士和他的咨询公司 Innosight。在 Godrej 总部，克里斯滕森向其管理团队介绍了他的一些创新理论，他们讨论了数百万低收入印度人所代表的市场机遇。Christensen 同意这是一个很好的机会，他建议 Godrej 从低成本、功能最少的冰箱开始。它



    Figure 13. The original chotuKool was positioned as a "disruptive innovation".

    图13原来的 chootukool 被定位为一个“破坏性创新”


    would be—as Christensen calls it—a “disruptive innovation.” Godrej took Christensen’s advice and hired his consulting firm to aid them in creating what would become the chotuKool.32

    克里斯坦森称之为“破坏性创新”Godrej 接受了 Christensen 的建议，雇佣了他的咨询公司来帮助他们创造后来的 chotuKool。32


    About a year later, in 2008, the chotuKool was publicly released to great fanfare. George Menezes, COO of Godrej Appliances, said, “In three years [we will sell] probably millions.” It even won the Edison Award for Social Impact. Harvard and other business schools wrote case studies praising its innovation success and benefits to society. Dr. Christensen even created a video describing how the chotuKool would create “inclusive growth” that would improve India’s economy and standards of living. Godrej exuberantly planned a platform of similar products, such as the chotuWash washing machine and a low-cost water purifier.33

    大约一年后，也就是2008年，chotuKool 被大张旗鼓地公开发布。Godrej 电器公司的首席运营官乔治 · 梅内塞斯说: “三年内我们可能会卖出几百万台。”它甚至赢得了爱迪生社会影响奖。哈佛大学和其他商学院撰写了案例研究，称赞其创新的成功和对社会的益处。Christensen 博士甚至制作了一段视频，描述 chotuKool 将如何创造“包容性增长”，从而改善印度的经济和生活水平。Godrej 兴高采烈地计划开发一个类似产品的平台，例如 ChutuWash 洗衣机和一个低成本的净水器


    However, reality was quite different. Using a test market of about 114.2 million people, Godrej had sold fifteen thousand units after two years. The chotuKool was an utter disaster. Godrej quietly abandoned plans for the chotuWash as well as any plans to create further “disruptive innovations.”34

    然而，现实却截然不同。通过1.142亿人的测试市场，Godrej 在两年后卖出了15000台。ChootuKool 是个彻头彻尾的灾难。Godrej 悄悄地放弃了 ChotuWash 的计划，以及任何创造更多“颠覆性创新”的计划34


    Redesign, reposition, and relaunch. Recognizing it was a flop, Godrej engaged in a costly redesign of the chotuKool. As of 2016, it’s still being sold, but it’s no longer targeted at low-income Indians. Instead, it’s being advertised to middle-class Indians as a high-end, feature-rich portable cooler. Navroze Godrej, director of

    重新设计，重新定位，重新启动。认识到这是一个失败，Godrej 参与了一个昂贵的重新设计 chtuKool。截至2016年，它仍在出售，但不再针对低收入的印度人。相反，它正在向中产阶级印度人作为一个高端，功能丰富的便携式冷却器的广告。Navroze Godrej



    Figure 14. The chotuKool was repositioned to serve a mid-level buyer.

    图14. chotuKool 被重新定位以服务于一个中层买家


    innovation and strategy, described the new chotuKool as “a lifestyle product that people use in cars.” G. Sunderraman, a Godrej vice president, commented on the repositioning: “How can you expect poor consumers with a minimum sustenance to be your pot of gold?” He also said, “We are now targeting a midlevel buyer.”35

    创新和战略，形容新的 chootuKool 是“一种生活方式的产品，人们在汽车中使用。”Godrej 公司副总裁 G · 桑德拉曼(G. Sunderraman)对这种重新定位发表了评论: “你怎么能指望最低生活保障的贫穷消费者成为你的黄金储备呢?”他还说，“我们现在的目标是一个中层买家。”35


    To add insult to injury, this new strategy is directly opposite from the one Godrej had started with. It had wanted a disruptive innovation that offered millions of Indians an inexpensive alternative to the household refrigerator, but the company now makes a luxury alternative to the inexpensive Styrofoam cooler.

    雪上加霜的是，这个新策略与戈德雷开始采用的策略正好相反。该公司曾希望推出一款破坏性创新，为数百万印度人提供一种廉价的家用冰箱替代品，但现在该公司推出了一款豪华的替代品，取代了廉价的聚苯乙烯泡沫制冷机。


    Why Did The chotuKool Flop?

    ChootuKool 为什么会失败？

    Godrej made numerous mistakes leading up to the chotuKool. We can learn a lot about Customer Jobs and innovation when we compare and contrast its approach to a Customer Jobs approach.

    Godrej 犯了很多错误。当我们将其方法与客户工作方法进行比较和对比时，我们可以学到很多关于客户工作和创新的东西。


    Godrej began with a solution instead of a JTBD. The first thing Godrej and Christensen did was to consider which solution to make. Oddly, they came to the decision to create a refrigerator before talking with any potential customers. They jumped to this conclusion because they were following the theory of disruptive innovation, which restricts innovation efforts to a group of specific solutions and

    Godrej 从一个解决方案开始，而不是 JTBD。戈德雷和克里斯滕森做的第一件事就是考虑制定哪种解决方案。奇怪的是，他们在与任何潜在客户交谈之前就决定制造一台冰箱。他们之所以得出这个结论，是因为他们遵循的是破坏性创新理论，这种理论将创新努力限制在一组特定的解决方案和


    technologies. Godrej and Christensen assumed that consumers wanted a low-cost refrigerator, and that this would make the chotuKool successful.

    Godrej 和 Christensen 假设消费者想要一个低成本的冰箱，这将使 chotuKool 成功。


    Customer Jobs rejects solution-first approaches and rejects the idea that products of only the same type can be competitors. Customer Jobs argues that you must begin by understanding the customers’ JTBD and how they see competition. Remember the forces of progress: what is pushing and pulling customers to make a change? Don’t assume that customers will buy a particular product just because it’s a cheaper version of another or that they are unhappy with whatever solution they are currently using for a JTBD.

    客户乔布斯反对解决方案优先的方法，反对只有同一类型的产品才能成为竞争对手的观点。Customer Jobs 认为，您必须首先了解客户的 JTBD 以及他们如何看待竞争。记住进步的力量: 是什么在推动和拉动客户做出改变？不要以为消费者会仅仅因为某个产品是另一个产品的便宜版本而购买它，或者他们不满意他们目前用于 JTBD 的任何解决方案。


    Godrej followed its own prejudices and discounted customer motivation. The company did a great deal of research before it designed the chotuKool. Its research team visited people’s homes, observed how they lived, and conducted interviews. Here are some excerpts from them:

    Godrej 遵循自己的偏见和折扣客户动机。这家公司在设计 chotuKool 之前做了大量的研究。它的研究小组走访了人们的家，观察了他们的生活方式，并进行了采访。以下是其中的一些节选:


    “I don’t feel the need for a refrigerator. I use an earthen pot to cool water. I buy vegetables for immediate consumption and boil milk to avoid it from getting spoilt.”

    “我觉得不需要冰箱。我用一个陶壶来冷却水。我买蔬菜立即食用，并煮牛奶，以免变质。”


    “In India, a refrigerator costs around eight thousand to ten thousand rupees. In addition, it has a running expense, which will upset my monthly budget. I don’t have the space to keep it in my tiny house.”

    “在印度，一台冰箱的价格在8000到10000卢比左右。此外，它有一个运行费用，这将打乱我的每月预算。我没地方把它放在我的小房子里。”


    “To me, a refrigerator should cost around twenty-five hundred rupees, and running it should be affordable. How will I service it if needed? My neighbor had to shell out twenty-five hundred rupees for servicing it and an additional three hundred rupees to transport it to a service center. I face load-shedding of six to eight hours every day. How will the product work?”

    “对我来说，一台冰箱的价格应该在2500卢比左右，运行它应该是负担得起的。如果需要，我将如何维修它？我的邻居不得不支付2500卢比来维修它，另外还要支付300卢比来把它运到一个服务中心。我每天要面对六到八个小时的负荷减少。产品将如何运作?”


    Godrej actually got valuable information about customer motivation, but it seems that it chose to ignore the most important parts. Instead of digging deeper into “I don’t feel the need for a refrigerator,” it focused on “a refrigerator should cost around twenty-five hundred rupees and running it should be affordable.”

    Godrej 实际上得到了关于客户动机的有价值的信息，但是它似乎选择忽略了最重要的部分。而不是深入挖掘“我不觉得需要一个冰箱,”它集中在“一个冰箱应该成本约2500卢比和运行它应该是负担得起的。”


    Why did Godrej do this? Well, it had already decided to create a low-end refrigerator, so it listened to data that confirmed only its prejudices and ignored all the warning signs that consumers had little or no interest in any kind of electric refrigerator.36

    戈德雷为什么要这么做？好吧，它已经决定创造一个低端的冰箱，所以它听取的数据只证实了它的偏见，忽略了所有的警告信号，即消费者对任何种类的电冰箱都没有兴趣


    What was the biggest mistake that Christensen and Godrej made? Christensen and Godrej created the chotuKool based on the theory of disruptive innovation. This theory has critical flaws. The biggest? It relies on an oversimplified model of competition that does not take into account how customers see competition. In this case, the theory limits the competition for electric refrigerators to only other electric refrigerators. This is why Christensen and Godrej completely misunderstood the competitive landscape. They did not consider Schumpeter’s warning that competition should not be restricted to products of the same type. Competition can come from anywhere.

    Christensen 和 Godrej 犯的最大的错误是什么？Christensen 和 Godrej 根据破坏性创新理论创造了 chotuKool。这个理论有严重的缺陷。最大的？它依赖于一种过于简化的竞争模型，没有考虑到客户如何看待竞争。在这种情况下，该理论限制了电冰箱的竞争，只有其他电冰箱。这就是为什么 Christensen 和 Godrej 完全误解了竞争格局。他们没有考虑熊彼特的警告，即竞争不应局限于同类产品。竞争可能来自任何地方。


    Customer Jobs invalidates many theories—like disruptive innovation—that try to model and predict the dynamics of a market. Here are a few reasons why:

    客户乔布斯否定了许多试图建模和预测市场动态的理论，比如颠覆性创新。以下是一些原因:


    They oversimplify the competitive landscape. JTBD shows us that competition can rarely be restricted to just one type of technology or innovation. Think about all the different types of innovations that compete with Clarity, theater, or YourGrocer.

    他们过分简化了竞争格局。JTBD 告诉我们，竞争很少仅限于一种技术或创新。想想所有与 Clarity、剧院或者你的杂货店竞争的不同类型的创新。


    These theories don’t take into consideration that customers often combine multiple products together to form one solution for a JTBD. This is something we’ll see shortly.

    这些理论没有考虑到客户经常将多个产品组合在一起以形成一个 JTBD 解决方案。这是我们很快就会看到的。


    They don’t take into consideration how customers view competition. People who create these models rarely, if ever, talk with customers and learn how they see competition. A competitive model that doesn’t come from customers will be invalid. The chotuKool is such an example.

    他们没有考虑顾客如何看待竞争。创建这些模型的人很少(如果有的话)与客户交谈，并了解他们是如何看待竞争的。不来自客户的竞争模式将是无效的。ChootuKool 就是这样一个例子。


    These theories assume that the competitive landscape won’t change in the future. Competition for a product changes continually. Moreover, often what renders an innovation obsolete isn’t a cheaper or simpler version of itself; rather, it’s when the system around an innovation changes so much that it doesn’t fit anymore. Apple’s iPod wasn’t made obsolete by another type of MP3 player; it was made obsolete by an app on a smartphone. While the fuel injector made the carburetor obsolete, what will make the fuel injector obsolete won’t be a new way of mixing gas and air—it will be electric cars that don’t even use engines or gas!

    这些理论假设竞争格局在未来不会改变。产品的竞争不断变化。此外，通常使一项创新过时的并不是它本身的更便宜或更简单的版本; 而是当一项创新周围的系统变化如此之大，以至于它不再适合它的时候。苹果的 iPod 不是被另一种 MP3播放器淘汰的，而是被智能手机上的一个应用程序淘汰的。虽然燃油喷射器使化油器过时了，但使燃油喷射器过时的并不是一种混合气体和空气的新方法ーー而是甚至不使用发动机或气体的电动汽车！


    When we acknowledge the complex nature of competition for a JTBD, we can see why rural Indians in Godrej’s target market saw competition to an electric refrigerator as follows:

    当我们承认日本电冰箱竞争的复杂性时，我们就能明白为什么 Godrej 目标市场上的印度农村人看到了电冰箱竞争的情况如下:


    Buying vegetables every day for immediate consumption. Boiling milk to prevent it from spoiling.

    每天购买即时食用的蔬菜。煮牛奶以防变质。

    Keeping water in clay pots at home.

    在家里把水放在陶罐里。


    Using a more than three-thousand-year-old innovation called a pot-in-pot to keep food and water cold.

    使用一种有三千多年历史的发明——锅中锅——来保持食物和水的冷却。


    Using other clay-based cooling innovations, such as the MittiCool.

    使用其他基于粘土的冷却创新，如 MittiCool。


    Godrej’s own research had revealed that customers were already hiring these solutions for their JTBD. However, because Godrej had a bias to follow the theory of disruptive innovation, the company chose to ignore these data.

    Godrej 自己的研究显示，客户已经为他们的 JTBD 雇佣了这些解决方案。然而，由于戈德雷吉倾向于遵循破坏性创新理论，该公司选择忽视这些数据。


    Godrej believed in an idea called “nonconsumption” or “nonusers.” Navroze Godrej describes how “Clayton and the Innosight team were insistent on focusing on nonusers.” In other words, the company was led to believe these Indians lacked the money or skill to buy and use any product for their JTBD. That’s what Christensen and his team meant by “nonusers” or that “nonconsumption” was taking place. What do you think? Would you consider these Indians as nonconsumers or nonusers? Unfortunately for Godrej, the company learned the answer to this question the hard way: these Indians were consumers, but they just weren’t consumers of electric refrigerators.37

    Godrej 相信一个叫做“非消费”或者“非使用者”的概念Navroze Godrej 描述了“ Clayton 和 Innosight 团队是如何坚持关注非用户的。”换句话说，该公司被误导，认为这些印度人缺乏资金或技能来购买和使用他们的 JTBD 的任何产品。这就是 Christensen 和他的团队所说的“非使用者”或者“非消费者”正在发生的意思。你觉得怎么样？你认为这些印度人是非消费者还是非使用者？对 Godrej 来说不幸的是，这家公司很不幸地得到了这个问题的答案: 这些印度人是消费者，但他们不是电冰箱的消费者。37


    JTBD rejects the idea of nonusers or nonconsumption. Just because consumers aren’t using your product, or another product of the same type, doesn’t mean they are nonusers. This is another big difference between JTBD and other approaches to markets and innovation. JTBD insists that if consumers have a JTBD, they must be using something for it.

    JTBD 反对非用户或非消费的观点。仅仅因为消费者不使用你的产品，或者其他同类型的产品，并不意味着他们不使用你的产品。这是 JTBD 与其他市场和创新方法的另一个重大区别。JTBD 坚持认为，如果消费者有一个 JTBD，他们必须使用某些东西来实现它。


    Here’s the twist: That “something” that consumers use for their JTBD doesn’t include products that one can only buy. It includes any compensatory behavior, paying someone else for help, making one’s own solution, or combining solutions. Each counts as a solution for a JTBD.

    这里有一个转折: 消费者在 JTBD 中使用的“东西”并不包括只能购买的产品。它包括任何补偿行为，支付其他人的帮助，制定自己的解决方案，或结合解决方案。每种方法都可以作为 JTBD 的解决方案。


    We actually heard about this in Godrej’s own research. One interviewee claimed that she would “buy vegetables for immediate consumption and boil milk to avoid it from getting spoilt.” Combined, those two actions count as a solution for a JTBD. In the customer’s mind, they are competition to the chotuKool.

    我们实际上在 Godrej 自己的研究中听说过这个。一位受访者声称，她会“买蔬菜立即食用，并煮牛奶，以免变质。”结合起来，这两个操作可以作为 JTBD 的解决方案。在顾客的心目中，他们是 ChootuKool 的竞争对手。


    If Godrej wanted consumers to buy a chotuKool, Godrej needed to offer its target buyers a solution that would persuade them to give up the solutions they were currently hiring for their JTBD. Sadly, the people leading this project didn’t think about that.

    如果 Godrej 希望消费者购买 chotuKool，Godrej 需要向目标消费者提供一个解决方案，说服他们放弃目前为 JTBD 雇佣的解决方案。不幸的是，领导这个项目的人没有想到这一点。


    Godrej didn’t understand that the chotuKool had little to no profit potential. The company assessed chotuKool’s potential by applying the theory of disruptive innovation. Instead, it should have applied some simple math. If it had, any plans to create the chotuKool would have been immediately abandoned. Unfortunately, it took the failure of the chotuKool for Godrej to realize that it had been a mistake to create any type of “low-end” innovation for low-income consumers. Recall what Godrej vice president G. Sunderraman said: “How can you expect poor consumers with a minimum sustenance to be your pot of gold?”

    Godrej 不明白 ChotuKool 几乎没有盈利潜力。该公司通过应用破坏性创新理论来评估 chutkool 的潜力。相反，它应该应用一些简单的数学。如果是这样的话，任何创建 chtuKool 的计划都会被立即放弃。不幸的是，直到 chotuKool 的失败，Godrej 才意识到，为低收入消费者创造任何类型的“低端”创新都是错误的。回想一下 Godrej 的副总裁 G。 Sunderraman 说过的话: “你怎么能指望那些只有最低生活保障的贫穷消费者成为你的黄金储备呢?”


    The chotuKool was never going to make much money targeting low-income Indians. Why? In our discussion of creative destruction and profits, we pointed out that competition is a zero-sum game. Profits have to come from somewhere. Whose profits was the chotuKool going to steal? Its target customers were people who lived on only a few dollars a day. How were they going to afford a sixty-dollar to seventy-dollar chotuKool? This price point would have made sense if consumers were spending that kind of money on comparable solutions. Or perhaps they would consider saving up their money if the chotuKool improved their lives dramatically. Neither of these conditions, however, were remotely true. Again, think about the forces of progress. It would have taken a great deal of push and pull to persuade customers to switch from using a free solution for their JTBD to using one they have to pay for. For these consumers, using a clay pot and buying vegetables daily was a good-enough solution for their JTBD.

    针对低收入的印度人 ChootuKool 永远不会赚很多钱。为什么？在我们关于创造性破坏和利润的讨论中，我们指出竞争是一种零和游戏。利润总得有来源。ChootuKool 要偷谁的利润？它的目标客户是那些每天只靠几美元生活的人。他们怎么买得起60到70美元的巧克力？如果消费者在可比较的解决方案上花那么多钱，这个价格点就有意义了。或者也许他们会考虑节省他们的钱，如果 ChotuKool 显著改善他们的生活。然而，这两种情况都远远不是真的。再次，想想进步的力量。要说服客户从使用免费的 JTBD 解决方案转向使用他们必须付费的解决方案，需要付出很大的努力。对于这些消费者来说，每天使用陶罐和购买蔬菜对于他们的 JTBD 来说是一个足够好的解决方案。


    The Mainframe Versus the PC

    大型机 VS 个人电脑

    Innovation is hard and unpredictable. I’ve had my share of innovation mishaps. And admittedly, if I had been in Godrej’s place, I might have made some of the same mistakes. It’s easy to stand on the sidelines and critique what someone else does wrong. But there are two mistakes I sure as heck wouldn’t have made:

    创新是困难和不可预测的。我也经历过创新失误。诚然，如果我是 Godrej，我可能也会犯同样的错误。站在一旁批评别人的错误是很容易的。但有两个错误我绝对不会犯:


    Limiting my definition of competition to products that look and function similarly.

    将我对竞争的定义限制在外观和功能相似的产品上。


    Not making sure a true desire for change was taking place and that customers were willing—and able—to pay for a solution.

    不能确定变革的真正愿望是否正在实现，以及消费者是否愿意(且有能力)为解决方案付费。


    These are common mistakes when you don’t apply a JTBD view to competition. But they aren’t the only ones.

    当你不把 JTBD 的观点应用到竞争中时，这些都是常见的错误，但它们并不是唯一的错误。


    A less common mistake—but just as dangerous—is to believe that products are competitors when they are not. One example of this is the widespread belief that PCs and mainframes are (or were) competitors. Was that ever true? Were or are PCs just a cheaper, simpler version of mainframes? Did the introduction of PCs have any effect on the market for mainframes? Did the PC create a new market or tap into existing ones?

    一个不太常见的错误(但同样危险)是，相信产品是竞争对手，而实际上它们并非竞争对手。这方面的一个例子是，人们普遍认为 PC 和大型机是(或曾经是)竞争对手。那是真的吗？个人电脑是否只是一种更便宜、更简单的大型机版本？个人电脑的引入对大型机市场有什么影响吗？个人电脑是创造了一个新的市场还是进入了现有的市场？


    Understanding the story behind the PC versus the mainframe will help you learn how to think about competition, become better at identifying real threats to your business, create better messaging that properly speaks to what customers consider as competition, and know how you should and shouldn’t design a solution.

    了解个人电脑与大型机背后的故事将帮助你学会如何思考竞争，更好地识别你的业务面临的真正威胁，创造更好的信息，正确地说出客户认为的竞争，并知道你应该如何设计一个解决方案，不应该如何设计一个解决方案。


    Here’s the common narrative about PCs versus mainframes. Mainframe computers are large hardware devices that have been used since the mid-twentieth century for massive calculations. Businesses and universities have used them for tasks such as accounting, payroll, and processing scientific data. Governments have used them for tasks such as processing census, tax, and military data (e.g., predicting the effects of atomic bombs).

    下面是关于 PC 和大型机的一般说法。大型计算机是一种大型硬件设备，自20世纪中叶以来一直被用于进行大规模计算。企业和大学已经使用它们来完成会计、工资单和处理科学数据等任务。政府已经将它们用于处理人口普查、税收和军事数据(例如，预测原子弹的影响)等任务。


    Companies such as IBM sold to these customers, which were the only ones who could afford mainframes and had the skills to operate them. For many years, mainframes were very profitable. To continue grabbing as much profit as possible, makers produced more complicated machines that therefore sold at ever-increasing margins.

    IBM 等公司向这些客户销售产品，而这些客户是唯一能够负担得起大型机并具备操作大型机技能的公司。多年来，大型机一直非常有利可图。为了继续抓住尽可能多的利润，制造商生产了更复杂的机器，因此以不断增长的利润率销售。


    Then, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, PCs appeared. They were nowhere nearly as powerful as mainframes, but they did appeal to customers who couldn’t afford a mainframe or didn’t need so much computing power. PCs created a new market by appealing to these less demanding customers. Mainframe manufacturers were happy to give up the low-end market because the margins in it were so small.

    然后，在20世纪70年代末80年代初，个人电脑出现了。它们远不如大型机强大，但它们确实吸引了那些买不起大型机或不需要那么多计算能力的客户。个人电脑通过吸引这些要求不那么苛刻的消费者，创造了一个新的市场。大型机制造商乐于放弃低端市场，因为它的利润率太小了。


    Unfortunately for the mainframe manufacturers, however, the PC got better and better. Eventually, they were just as good, if not better, than mainframes for doing many computational tasks. As a result, the PC created a huge new market and ultimately eliminated the existing mainframe industry.38

    然而，对于大型机制造商来说，不幸的是，个人电脑变得越来越好了。最终，在执行许多计算任务方面，它们即使不比大型机更好，也和大型机一样好。结果，个人电脑创造了一个巨大的新市场，并最终消灭了现有的大型机行业


    The innovator’s—false—dilemma. That’s certainly an interesting story. Yet it’s totally wrong.

    创新者的ーー错误ーー困境。这当然是一个有趣的故事。但它完全是错误的。


    Before we apply a JTBD perspective here, let’s consider some numbers. Here’s what Toni Sacconaghi of Bernstein Research recently said about IBM:

    在这里应用 JTBD 透视图之前，让我们考虑一些数字。以下是伯恩斯坦研究公司(Bernstein Research)的托尼•萨科纳吉(Toni Sacconaghi)最近对 IBM 的评价:


    The mainframe is a hugely profitable business for IBM. Only around 4 percent of the firm’s revenues come from mainframe sales. But once additional hardware, storage, software, and all kinds of related services have been factored in, the mainframe accounts for a quarter of IBM’s revenue and nearly half of profits.39

    对 IBM 来说，大型机是一项利润丰厚的业务。该公司只有大约4% 的收入来自大型机销售。但是，一旦将额外的硬件、存储、软件和各种相关服务考虑在内，大型机就占到了 IBM 收入的四分之一和利润的近一半


    It seems that the mainframe business is alive and kicking. In fact, in 2012, IBM announced the newest addition to its line of mainframe computers: the z12. It cost

    看起来主机业务正在蓬勃发展。事实上，在2012年，IBM 宣布了其大型机系列中的最新产品: z12。花了不少钱

    $1 billion to develop and had a starting price of around $1 million. The plan worked well: today, approximately 96 percent of the world’s top one hundred banks, 92 percent of the twenty-five top US retailers, and nine of ten of the world’s largest insurance companies run IBM’s System z mainframes. In 2013, IBM’s revenue was

    10亿美元用于开发，起价约为100万美元。这个计划运行良好: 今天，大约96% 的世界顶级100家银行，92% 的25家美国顶级零售商，以及10家世界上最大的保险公司中的9家运行 IBM 的 System z 主机。2013年，IBM 的收入是
