    $99.8 billion. Building on the z12’s success, it launched the z13 in 2015. So, what’s going on? The PC had supposedly disrupted the mainframe business. Let’s put a JTBD lens on this story and see what we can find.40

    998亿美元。在 z12成功的基础上，该公司于2015年推出了 z13。到底怎么回事？据推测，个人电脑已经扰乱了大型机业务。让我们把 JTBD 的镜头放在这个故事上，看看我们能发现什么。40


    To make sense of it all, we need to ask again if mainframes and PCs were ever in competition with each other. And if you recall, if we want to get an accurate model of competition for JTBD, we have to understand how customers see competition. So, let’s take a look at who buys PCs and mainframes, what they are used for, and what each replaced.

    为了搞清楚这一切，我们需要再问一遍，大型机和个人电脑是否曾经相互竞争过。如果你还记得，如果我们想为 JTBD 获得一个准确的竞争模型，我们必须了解客户如何看待竞争。那么，让我们来看看谁购买了 PC 和大型机，它们的用途是什么，以及它们各自被替换了什么。


    Why mainframes? Mainframes have always provided a level and type of computing power that has appealed only to a few. They were first used for intensive

    为什么是大型机？大型机一直以来提供的计算能力水平和类型只吸引少数人。它们最初用于集中治疗



    Figure 15. Creative destruction in action. A mainframe replaced scores of “computers,” the machines they worked on, and the people who supervised them (top). A 1953 picture of “computers” from what would become nasa’s jet propulsion lab (bottom).

    图15。行动中的创造性破坏。一台大型机取代了几十台“计算机”，也就是它们所操作的机器，以及监督它们的人(上图)。1953年美国宇航局喷气推进实验室的“计算机”照片(下图)


    mathematical calculations, such as predicting the effects of the first atomic bomb and processing census data. For scientific or government computations, the alternative was to hire scores of mathematicians (who were usually women in the first decades of computing; they themselves were referred to as “computers”) to do the calculations by hand. For businesses, the alternative to a mainframe was scores of secretaries and clerks who either did payroll and sales data by hand or operated cumbersome, electromechanical calculating machines such as the Friden Electro-Mechanical Calculator.41

    数学计算，如预测第一颗原子弹的影响和处理人口普查数据。对于科学计算或政府计算，另一种选择是雇佣数十名数学家(在计算的最初几十年里，她们通常是女性; 她们自己被称为“计算机”)手工进行计算。对于企业来说，除了大型计算机之外，还有许多秘书和职员，他们要么手工完成工资和销售数据，要么操作笨重的机电式计算机，比如弗里登电子机械计算器。41


    Today, many of the same entities use mainframes for tasks similar to those of sixty years ago. In fact, today, they are used in an ever-increasing number of contexts. A mainframe most likely processes ATM transactions at any major bank. Global

    今天，许多相同的实体使用大型机完成类似于六十年前的任务。事实上，今天，它们在越来越多的情况下被使用。大型机很可能在任何大型银行处理 ATM 交易。全球化


    logistics firms such as DHL run mainframe systems to support their core business processes.42

    像 DHL 这样的物流公司运行主机系统来支持它们的核心业务流程


    The progress that mainframes deliver today is incredibly similar to what they delivered sixty years ago—namely, the confidence that comes with having a computing competitive advantage and the peace of mind that you can securely run mission-critical processes.

    今天大型机所带来的进步与它们60年前所带来的进步惊人地相似ーー也就是说，拥有计算竞争优势所带来的信心，以及能够安全地运行关键任务流程所带来的内心的平静。


    Are PCs competition for mainframes? Here are the real questions: Did purchases of PCs have any impact on the sales of mainframes? Did mainframe manufacturers miss out on a budding market? Is there any relationship between the two types of computer at all?

    个人电脑是大型机的竞争对手吗？真正的问题是: 个人电脑的购买是否会对大型机的销售产生影响？大型机制造商是否错过了一个崭露头角的市场？这两种计算机之间有什么联系吗？


    Today, it is safe to say that there is no competitive relationship between PCs and mainframes. Does anyone ever think, Hmm, do I buy a mainframe, or do I buy a PC? Has a company ever replaced a mainframe with a PC? Of course not. Remember, you can claim that two products are competitors only if you can find a customer who has switched from one to the other.

    今天，可以有把握地说，PC 和大型机之间没有竞争关系。有没有人想过，嗯，我是买主机呢，还是买个人电脑呢？有没有一家公司曾经用个人电脑取代过大型机？当然没有。请记住，只有当您能够找到一个从一个产品转换到另一个产品的客户时，您才能声称两个产品是竞争对手。


    But what about PCs versus mainframes thirty years ago—when PCs first became popular? Well, in 1984, PC Magazine interviewed Dr. Norm Agin of Martin Marietta Data Systems about the company’s recent PC purchases. When asked about PCs replacing mainframes, Agin “scoffs at the notion that putting in PCs reduces the load on the company mainframe.” Agin said, “We picked IBM PCs for compatibility with [our existing IBM] mainframes” and that employees using a PC represented a switch from “having a calculator and typewriter on [their] desk.”

    但是30年前个人电脑首次流行起来的时候，个人电脑与大型机之间的关系又如何呢？1984年，《个人电脑杂志》(PC Magazine)采访了马丁•玛丽埃塔数据系统公司(Martin Marietta Data Systems)的诺姆•阿金(Norm Agin)博士，讨论了该公司最近的个人电脑采购情况。当被问及个人电脑取代大型机的问题时，Agin“嘲笑了把个人电脑放进大型机可以减轻公司大型机负载的说法。”Agin 表示，“我们选择 IBM PC 是为了与(我们现有的 IBM)大型机兼容”，使用 PC 的员工代表着从“办公桌上有计算器和打字机”的转变


    Agin’s comments begs important questions such as: (1) How can PCs and mainframes be competitors if customers use them together? (2) Are these PCs competing with costly mainframes or cheap calculators and typewriters?43

    Agin 的评论回避了一些重要问题，比如: (1)如果消费者一起使用 PC 和大型机，它们怎么能成为竞争对手？(2)这些个人电脑是在与昂贵的大型机还是廉价的计算器和打字机竞争？43


    Agin dismissing the competitive relationship between mainframes and PCs is far from unique. We can get a good idea of how consumers in the 1970s and 1980s saw PCs by turning to YouTube’s nearly endless supply of old PC commercials:44

    再次否认大型机和个人电脑之间的竞争关系远非独一无二。我们可以通过 YouTube 几乎源源不断的旧 PC 广告来了解上世纪七八十年代的消费者是如何看待 PC 的: 44条


    IBM’s 5100 PC, released in 1977, promises to help real estate investors “manage all the difficult decisions.” Avionic designers could “save time and money” by calculating flight expenses in the office.

    IBM 于1977年推出的5100个人电脑承诺帮助房地产投资者“管理所有困难的决策”航空电子设计师可以通过计算办公室的飞行费用来“节省时间和金钱”。


    A 1980 ad has actor William Shatner ask viewers, “Why just buy a video game from Atari? Invest in the wonder computer of the 1980s:

    在1980年的一则广告中，演员威廉•夏特纳(William Shatner)问观众: “为什么只是从雅达利(Atari)购买一款视频游戏？投资20世纪80年代的神奇计算机:


    the Commodore Vic-20.” You can even play “Gorf, the wonder arcade game” with your new Commodore.

    你甚至可以和你的新准将玩“ Gorf，神奇街机游戏”。


    The Apple IIe promises to “teach your children well” and helps baseball managers “manage player stats.” The Apple IIc is also featured as an alternative to the IBM PC Junior.

    Apple IIe 承诺“教好你的孩子”，并帮助棒球经理“管理球员数据”Apple IIc 也是 IBM PC Junior 的替代品。


    The Tandy 1000, released in 1984, would remove all the clutter from your desk by “changing the way you work” with “DeskMate software for easy-to-use word processing, filing, worksheets, scheduling, and communications.”

    1984年发布的 Tandy 1000将通过“改变你的工作方式”来移除你办公桌上的所有杂物，“ DeskMate 软件支持简单易用的文字处理、归档、工作表、日程安排和通信。”


    One thing is clear while watching these TV ads: not once is anyone making any reference whatsoever to mainframes. Moreover, these commercials don’t make any mention of the high-throughput, transactional integrity tasks for which mainframes are used. Instead, we see PCs helping individuals and small businesses become more productive. Even I remember my first PC. It didn’t replace a mainframe; it replaced my (less expensive and simpler to use) Atari game system. In the minds of customers, PCs and mainframes have no association whatsoever.

    在看这些电视广告的时候，有一件事是很清楚的: 没有一个人提到过大型机。此外，这些商业广告没有提到使用大型机的高吞吐量、事务完整性任务。相反，我们看到个人电脑帮助个人和小企业变得更有生产力。连我都记得我的第一台电脑。它没有替换大型机，而是替换了我的(更便宜、更简单的)雅达利(Atari)游戏系统。在消费者心目中，PC 和大型机没有任何联系。


    What was the PC’s competition? Did PCs create a new market? These old TV commercials also make it perfectly clear that the competition for PCs was—and still is, in some cases—typewriters, word-processing machines, personal assistants, calculators, files and file cabinets, interoffice messaging services, graphic design and layout by hand, accounting services or accounting by hand, game systems (e.g., Atari), and tabletop games (e.g., Dungeons & Dragons).

    PC 的竞争对手是谁？个人电脑创造了一个新的市场吗？这些老电视广告也清楚地表明，个人电脑的竞争过去是ーー现在仍然是ーー打字机、文字处理机、个人助理、计算器、文件和文件柜、办公室间信息服务、手工图形设计和布局、会计服务或手工会计、游戏系统(例如雅达利)和桌面游戏(例如龙与地下城)。


    The above alternatives represent solutions whose growth and profits were disrupted by PCs. Think back to our lessons from Schumpeter, competition, and creative destruction. When people began buying and using PCs, what did they stop buying and using? It wasn’t mainframes. They stopped buying and using the various solutions above.

    上述替代方案所代表的解决方案，其增长和利润受到个人电脑的干扰。回想一下我们从熊彼特、竞争和创造性破坏中得到的教训。当人们开始购买和使用个人电脑时，他们停止购买和使用的是什么？不是主机。他们停止购买和使用上述各种解决方案。


    In addition, the invention of the PC represented a new market if you define markets only by products that look or function similarly. However, from a JTBD point of view, PCs didn’t create a new market. Rather, PCs simply added an alternative to the existing markets that the solutions above constituted.

    此外，个人电脑的发明代表了一个新的市场，如果你仅仅通过外观或功能相似的产品来定义市场。然而，从 JTBD 的角度来看，个人电脑并没有创造出一个新的市场。相反，个人电脑只是增加了一个替代现有的市场，上述解决方案构成。




    Figure 16. Changes in revenue from sales of IBM’s mainframes. Dramatic drops and subsequent peaks in revenue are due to product introductions and customer buying patterns, not from customers switching to a competitor.

    图16。IBM 大型机销售收入的变化。收入的急剧下降和随后的高峰是由于产品介绍和客户购买模式，而不是客户转向竞争对手



    Was the PC really cheaper and simpler? The other point to notice is that the PC didn’t necessarily represent a cheaper alternative to the solutions it replaced. This invalidates the idea that the PC was any kind of low-end, “disruptive” product. If you had an accounting firm, you could give one of your accountants a PC, and she would be able to do the work of ten accountants. That is certainly cheaper. However, a PC is neither simpler nor cheaper than a board game, a typewriter, or an Atari game system.

    PC 真的更便宜、更简单吗？需要注意的另一点是，个人电脑并不一定代表着它所取代的解决方案的廉价替代品。这使得个人电脑是任何低端“颠覆性”产品的想法变得站不住脚。如果你有一家会计师事务所，你可以给你的一个会计师一台电脑，她就可以做十个会计师的工作。这样肯定更便宜。然而，PC 既不比棋盘游戏、打字机或雅达利(Atari)游戏系统简单，也不便宜。


    What do mainframes compete against today? Fifty years ago, mainframes competed against hiring scores of mathematicians and clerks, but what do mainframes compete against today? Once again, we have to find evidence of a switch if we want to answer that question. Luckily, such an example comes from Johnson & Johnson (J&J)—an American company that makes medical devices, pharmaceuticals, and consumer packaged goods (CPGs).

    今天大型机的竞争对手是什么？50年前，大型机与雇佣大量数学家和职员竞争，但是今天大型机与什么竞争呢？再说一次，如果我们想回答这个问题，我们必须找到转变的证据。幸运的是，这样的例子来自强生公司(j & j)——一家生产医疗器械、制药和快速消费品的美国公司。


    In 2015, J&J shut down its last mainframe. In place of owning mainframes, it switched to using a combination of cloud services from Amazon.com Inc., Microsoft Corp., and NTT Communications Corp. Stuart McGuigan, J&J’s chief information officer, commented about the switch: “[It was not] something I was sure I’d see in my lifetime: A Fortune 100 company with absolutely no mainframe footprint.” Why did they switch? J&J needed more computing power and using cloud services allows J&J to lower its infrastructure costs. In other words, J&J wanted more for less.45

    2015年，强生关闭了最后一台主机。它不再拥有大型机，而是转而使用亚马逊公司(Amazon.com Inc.)、微软公司(microsoftCorp.)和 NTT通讯公司(corp.)的云服务。强生首席信息官斯图尔特•麦圭根(Stuart McGuigan)对此评论道: “(这不是)我确信在我有生之年会看到的事情: 一家绝对没有大型机足迹的《财富》(Fortune)100强企业。”他们为什么换了？强生公司需要更多的计算能力，使用云服务可以降低其基础设施成本。换句话说，强生希望以更少的成本获得更多。45


    What are the reasons for the mistaken correlation? So, why have people made this mistaken correlation between mainframes and PCs? I can think of two big reasons.

    错误关联的原因是什么？那么，为什么人们会把大型机和个人电脑错误地联系在一起呢？我能想到两大原因。


    Correlation in physical appearance. If you don’t know anything about mainframes or PCs, you’d be tempted to think the latter is simply a smaller version of the former and that they belong to the same market. Just because they are both computers doesn’t mean they are used for the same Jobs.

    外表的相关性。如果你对大型机或个人电脑一无所知，你可能会认为后者只是前者的一个较小的版本，它们属于同一个市场。仅仅因为它们都是计算机并不意味着它们用于同一个工作。


    A misunderstanding of how variation works. Because mainframes are very expensive, customers don’t buy them often. This means mainframes have a sales cycle that can last a decade or more. If you were to focus on sales of mainframes in the middle of their sales cycle, you might think that demand had utterly vanished.

    对变异如何起作用的误解。因为大型机非常昂贵，客户不会经常购买它们。这意味着大型机的销售周期可以持续10年或更长时间。如果你把注意力放在大型机销售周期中期的销售上，你可能会认为需求已经完全消失了。


    People who believe that PCs disrupted mainframe sales are making two common statistical errors. First, they mistake common-cause variation for special-cause variation—something discussed in chapter 19. There was no special decline in mainframe sales in response to the availability of PCs. Rather, mainframes have a very up-and-down sales cycle that is normal for them (figure 16). Second, such people conflate correlation and causation. Just because PC sales were going up at a time when mainframe sales were going down doesn’t mean one caused the other.

    那些认为个人电脑扰乱了大型机销售的人犯了两个常见的统计错误。首先，他们把共因变异误认为是特殊原因变异ーー这一点在第19章中已经讨论过。由于个人电脑的普及，大型机的销售没有出现特别的下降。相反，大型机有一个非常起伏的销售周期，这对它们来说是正常的(图16)。其次，这些人将相关性和因果关系混为一谈。仅仅因为个人电脑的销量在大型机销量下降的时候上升并不意味着一个导致了另一个。


    To this day, IBM continues to make a tremendous amount of money selling both mainframes and supporting services. In 2014, IBM had revenue of $92.8 billion, with $21 billon in operating pretax income. The company has been around for more than one hundred years. It maintains success by continually producing high-margin products for customers who have an insatiable demand for more features and more quality.46

    时至今日，IBM 继续通过销售大型机和支持服务赚取巨额利润。2014年，IBM 的收入为928亿美元，营业税前收入为210亿美元。这家公司已经有一百多年的历史了。它通过不断为那些对更多功能和更高质量有着无法满足的需求的客户生产高利润的产品来保持成功


    Finally, real competition to mainframes has only recently emerged in the form of cloud computing. From the customers’ point of view, competition for the mainframe isn’t owning any kind of computer but outsourcing everything to someone else.

    最后，与大型机的真正竞争是最近才以云计算的形式出现的。从客户的角度来看，对大型机的竞争不是拥有任何类型的计算机，而是将一切外包给别人。


    Don’t Be Fooled by Randomness

    不要被随机性所愚弄

    You will become a better innovator when you recognize that innovation is hard, there are no recipes for success, and there’s no “one right way” to make products

    当你意识到创新是困难的，没有成功的秘诀，也没有制造产品的“唯一正确的方法”，你就会成为一个更好的创新者


    and build businesses. It’s why Steve Blank says, “No business plan survives first contact with customers.” Why is this so? Because life is full of unknown and unknowable variation. Just because a product or business strategy worked once doesn’t mean it work will again.

    建立业务。这就是为什么史蒂夫布兰克说，“没有商业计划生存的第一次接触客户。”为什么会这样？因为生活充满了未知和不可知的变化。仅仅因为一个产品或商业策略曾经奏效，并不意味着它会再次奏效。


    Unfortunately, that doesn’t stop people from trying to sell you recipes for success. The early twentieth century saw Frederick Winslow Taylor sell “scientific management.” Over the last thirty years, countless consultants and academics—who have never innovated themselves—have presumed to tell innovators about the right and wrong ways to innovate. Examples include In Search of Excellence, Built to Last, Good to Great, and The Innovator’s Dilemma.47

    不幸的是，这并不能阻止人们向你推销成功的食谱。二十世纪早期，弗雷德里克·温斯洛·泰勒推销“科学管理”在过去的30年里，无数的咨询师和学者(他们从来没有自己创新过)假定能够告诉创新者创新的正确和错误的方法。例子包括《追求卓越》、《坚持到底》、《从优秀到卓越》和《创新者的困境》。47


    However, history shows that such recipes for innovation and business success fail to live up to their promises. Here are some criticisms of these management and innovation theories, as well as their overall approach to research:48

    然而，历史表明，这些创新和商业成功的秘诀并没有兑现它们的承诺。以下是对这些管理和创新理论的一些批评，以及它们的总体研究方法: 48


    The Halo Effect by Phil Rosenzweig criticizes such formulas and theories as pseudoscientific and falling victim to what he called the “nine delusions”—for example, picking a successful company and making attributions about its culture, leadership, values without offering any objective, experimental data to support it.

    菲尔 · 罗森茨威格(Phil Rosenzweig)的《光环效应》(The Halo Effect)批评了这样的公式和理论，认为它们是伪科学，是他所说的“九种错觉”的受害者ーー例如，选择一家成功的公司，对其文化、领导力和价值观进行归因，却没有提供任何客观的实验数据来支持它。


    Thinking, Fast and Slow by Nobel Prize–winning psychologist Dr. Kahneman explains that we’re drawn to these theories because they are done through entertaining storytelling that is “simple,” “concrete rather than abstract,” and “focus on a few striking events” instead of the myriad, smaller events that did or didn’t happen.

    思考，快与慢诺贝尔奖获得者心理学家卡尼曼博士解释说，我们之所以被这些理论所吸引，是因为它们是通过“简单”、“具体而非抽象”、“关注少数引人注目的事件”而不是那些已经发生或没有发生的无数小事件的有趣的故事来完成的。


    Bongo-playing, Nobel Prize–winning physicist Richard Feynman gave warning of what he called “cargo cult science” and decried these people as selling “science that isn’t science.” He pointed out that too often, people who are good storytellers can fool those of us who aren’t experienced in scientific rigor or statistics. However, many of us who do have these skills recognize that these management and innovation gurus fall victim to what is called “selecting the dependent variable.” For example, suppose I have a theory that wearing red shorts causes shark attacks. To “prove” this theory, I research shark attacks that happen where the victim wore red shorts. Every time I find an instance where that happens, I pat myself on the back and tell everyone how smart I am. However, such an approach ignores instances where someone wore red shorts and was not attacked by a shark. Such data

    打手鼓的诺贝尔物理学奖获得者理查德 · 费曼对他所谓的“草包族科学”发出了警告，并谴责这些人兜售“不是科学的科学”他指出，很多时候，善于讲故事的人可以愚弄我们这些没有科学严谨性或统计经验的人。然而，我们中许多有这些技能的人意识到，这些管理和创新大师成为所谓的“选择因变量”的牺牲品例如，假设我有一个理论，穿红色短裤会导致鲨鱼攻击。为了“证明”这个理论，我研究了鲨鱼袭击受害者穿红色短裤的情况。每次我发现这种情况发生的时候，我都会拍拍自己的背，告诉大家我有多聪明。然而，这种方法忽略了某人穿红色短裤而没有被鲨鱼袭击的情况。这样的数据


    would invalidate my theory; however, I never find them because I never look for them.

    会否定我的理论，但是，我从来没有找到它们，因为我从来没有找过它们。


    Innovation and entrepreneurship is hard, full of self-doubt, and riddles us with anxiety about the future. I know; I’ve been there. Nevertheless, when we do find ourselves struggling, we must do our best to not be taken advantage of by these recipe peddlers and modern-day fortune tellers—no matter how confidently they claim to understand the behavior of markets or where their MBAs come from. If I can’t convince you of the heavy costs these people exact on our economies, perhaps disaster stories such as the chotuKool and the $400-million flop of Tata’s Nano can.

    创新和创业是困难的，充满了自我怀疑，并且让我们对未来充满焦虑。我知道，我也经历过。然而，当我们真的发现自己在苦苦挣扎时，我们必须尽力不被这些菜谱贩子和现代算命师占便宜ーー不管他们声称自己多么自信地理解市场行为，或者他们的 MBA 学位来自哪里。如果我不能让你相信这些人给我们的经济带来的沉重代价，也许像 chotuKool 和塔塔 Nano 4亿美元的失败故事可以。


    Customer Jobs frees us from recipe peddlers. Customer Jobs excites me because it doesn’t try to sell me any plug-in-and-play plan for success. It respects the fact that innovation will always require critical thinking and hard work. That’s what makes its message fundamentally different from what recipe peddlers sell. Customer Jobs doesn’t tell me what kind of innovation I should make or how to build it. Instead, its restricts itself to (1) what customers are struggling with, (2) how they imagine their life being better when they have the right solution, and (3) what they do and don’t value in a solution. Such an approach helps innovators like me find innovation opportunities and to navigate a world that is filled with the unknown and unknowable. I find this knowledge empowering. It’s also why I’ve applied it to my own businesses and products. I believe it will help you become a better innovator as well.

    客户工作让我们摆脱了食谱小贩。客户工作让我感到兴奋，因为它没有试图向我推销任何即插即用的成功计划。它尊重这样一个事实，即创新总是需要批判性思维和努力工作。这就是为什么它所传达的信息与菜谱小贩销售的信息有着根本的不同。客户工作并没有告诉我应该做什么样的创新或者如何创新。相反，它把自己限制在(1)客户在挣扎什么，(2)当他们有正确的解决方案时，他们如何想象他们的生活会变得更好，(3)他们在解决方案中做什么和不做什么。这种方法可以帮助像我这样的创新者找到创新机会，并在充满未知和不可知的世界中前进。我觉得这些知识很有力量。这也是为什么我把它应用到我自己的生意和产品上。我相信它也会帮助你成为一个更好的创新者。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    This chapter is a cautionary tale of what can happen when the principles of Customer Jobs are ignored or unknown. Here are a few things you can do to help you avoid making the same mistakes.

    本章是一个警示故事，说明当顾客工作的原则被忽视或不为人知时会发生什么。这里有一些你可以做的事情来帮助你避免犯同样的错误。


    Don’t restrict competition to products with similar functionality or physical characteristics. Don’t assume two products are competitors because they look or function similarly. There are two related mistakes people make about what is and isn’t competition for a product.

    不要将竞争局限于功能或物理特性相似的产品。不要因为两个产品的外观或功能相似就认为它们是竞争对手。在产品竞争中，人们会犯两个相关的错误: 什么是竞争，什么不是竞争。


    Thinking that two solutions compete against each other because they share similar characteristics. Even though PCs and mainframes are both computers, they don’t compete in the slightest.

    认为两种解决方案相互竞争，因为它们具有相似的特点。尽管个人电脑和大型机都是计算机，但它们丝毫不具有竞争力。


    Restricting the definition of competition to products with similar characteristics. Godrej and Christensen believed that the only competition for their electric refrigerator was other electric refrigerators. They also believed they were creating a new market of refrigerator alternatives. Unfortunately for Godrej, neither of those opinions was true. Consumers were already using several refrigerator alternatives.

    将竞争的定义限制在具有相似特征的产品上。戈德雷吉和克里斯滕森认为，他们的电冰箱唯一的竞争对手是其他电冰箱。他们还相信，他们正在创造一个冰箱替代品的新市场。不幸的是，对于戈德雷吉来说，这两种观点都不是真的。消费者已经在使用多种冰箱替代品。


    Keep your mind open to what counts as competition. I recently talked with a woman who told me about switching from her morning coffee to a kale smoothie with a shot of wheatgrass. Who would’ve thought a cup of coffee and a kale smoothie could be competitors?

    保持你的思想开放，什么才算是竞争。我最近和一位女士交谈过，她告诉我她早上喝的咖啡换成了甘蓝冰沙和小麦草。谁能想到一杯咖啡和一杯甘蓝冰沙会成为竞争对手呢？


    Every innovator, whether creating a new innovation or improving an existing one, should have a clear idea of how his or her customers see competition. When you’re creating a new innovation, you need to answer the question, “What are customers going to stop buying when they start buying our solution?” And if you’re creating a new feature for an existing product, you need to ask, “What behaviors or other products is this feature going to replace?”

    每一个创新者，无论是创造一个新的创新还是改进一个已有的创新，都应该清楚地知道他或她的客户是如何看待竞争的。当你创造一个新的创新时，你需要回答这个问题，“当客户开始购买我们的解决方案时，他们会停止购买什么?”如果您正在为现有产品创建一个新特性，那么您需要问，“这个特性将取代什么行为或其他产品?”


    Talk with your customers! Your competitive model can come only from them. Models of competition and markets that don’t come from customers are almost guaranteed to be wrong.

    和你的顾客谈谈！你的竞争模式只能来自他们。竞争模式和市场并非来自消费者，几乎可以肯定是错误的。


    Don’t study the relationships among customers, products, and competition just from afar. You must actually talk with the customers who use these products. Ask them what else they’ve tried to get the Job Done. Were there other options they wanted to try but didn’t or couldn’t? Did they combine solutions because no single solution worked well? Through questions like these, you can triangulate what customers do or don’t consider as competition.

    不要只是从远处研究客户、产品和竞争之间的关系。您必须与使用这些产品的客户进行实际交流。问问他们还试图完成什么工作。有没有其他选择他们想尝试，但没有或不能？他们组合解决方案是因为没有一个单一的解决方案能够很好地工作吗？通过这样的问题，你可以三角测量出客户认为什么是竞争，什么不是竞争。


    Confirm that competition exists between products by finding customers who switched. At the time of this writing, PC sales have dropped to historic lows; they’ve been on a decline for quite some time. Some people claim that this drop in PC sales is due to the smartphone. But is that true?49

    通过寻找转换的客户来确认产品之间存在竞争。在撰写本文时，个人电脑销量已经跌至历史最低点; 它们已经下降了相当一段时间。一些人声称 PC 销量的下降是由于智能手机。但这是真的吗？49


    Remember, correlation does not equal causation. There’s only one sure way to prove a causal link between smartphone sales and PC sales: find people who stopped using their PCs and started using smartphones. Unless you can find evidence of a switch, the suggestion that any competitive relationship exists between the two is pure conjecture. Yes, some people may have entirely stopped using a PC in favor

    记住，相关性不等于因果关系。要证明智能手机销售和个人电脑销售之间存在因果关系，只有一个可靠的方法: 找到那些不再使用个人电脑而开始使用智能手机的人。除非你能找到转换的证据，否则这两者之间存在任何竞争关系的说法纯属猜测。是的，有些人可能已经完全停止使用个人电脑


    of a smartphone, but a lot of people own and use both. How would you interpret that?

    智能手机，但很多人拥有和使用两者。你如何解释这一点？


    Do you think you’re creating a new market? Think again. For too long, businesses have created, and been encouraged to create, their own definitions of markets—that is, which products do and do not compete against each other. JTBD offers us a way to rethink how we define markets.

    你认为你正在创造一个新的市场吗？再想想。长期以来，企业创造并被鼓励创造自己对市场的定义ーー即哪些产品可以相互竞争，哪些产品不可以相互竞争。JTBD 为我们提供了一种重新思考如何定义市场的方法。


    If you think you’re creating a new market, then you probably haven’t done enough research. Have you explored all the options that customers consider as competition for a JTBD solution? Perhaps customers are solving their problems in ways that don’t require the purchase of a physical product. For example, a lot of people in New York City don’t own a laundry machine. Instead, they drop off their laundry at laundromats for other people to clean and fold.

    如果你认为你正在创造一个新的市场，那么你可能没有做足够的研究。您是否探索了客户认为是 JTBD 解决方案竞争对手的所有选项？也许消费者解决问题的方式不需要购买实物产品。例如，纽约市的许多人没有洗衣机。相反，他们把要洗的衣服放在自助洗衣店，让其他人清洗和折叠。


    Another consideration is how customers often use a combination of solutions for a JTBD—for example, combining (1) boiling milk to make it last, (2) using a pot-in-pot, and (3) buying highly perishable foods only when they can be eaten right away.

    另一个需要考虑的问题是消费者如何经常使用一系列解决 JTBD 问题的方法，例如: (1)用煮沸的牛奶来保持牛奶的持久性; (2)使用锅中的锅; (3)只有在可以马上食用的情况下才购买易腐烂的食品。


    If you don’t have a clear picture of what customers are going to give up when they start using your product, either you haven’t done enough research, or no JTBD exists and you’re creating a solution that no one will buy.

    如果您不清楚客户在开始使用您的产品时会放弃什么，要么您没有做足够的研究，要么 JTBD 不存在，您正在创建一个没有人会购买的解决方案。


    Know what budget you’re taking away from. When commenting on the chotuKool’s initial failure, Godrej vice president G. Sunderraman said that “poor consumers with a minimum sustenance” were probably not a “pot of gold.” He was absolutely correct. The chotuKool had been conceived without a clear picture of what budget it was going to take from.

    知道你在拿什么样的预算。在评论 chotuKool 最初的失败时，Godrej 公司副总裁 G。 Sunderraman 说，“最低限度维持生计的贫穷消费者”可能不是一个“金罐子”他完全正确。ChootuKool 的设计没有明确的预算。


    Dan Martell avoided this problem because he did acquire a clear picture. He knew that Clarity was taking money away from budgets for attending conferences, paying for LinkedIn, hiring consultants, and giving away advisory shares.

    丹 · 马泰尔避免了这个问题，因为他确实获得了一个清晰的图像。他知道 Clarity 正在从预算中拿走钱，用于参加会议、支付领英(LinkedIn)、聘请顾问和发放咨询股份。


    Having a clear picture of what budget you’re going take money away from helps you figure out what the revenue potential for an innovation is—if there’s any at all—and how much money to invest in creating and selling an innovation.

    清楚地知道你将从哪些预算中拿走资金，可以帮助你弄清楚创新的收入潜力是什么(如果有的话) ，以及在创新和销售创新上投入多少资金。


    Continually refresh the competitive landscape with ongoing feedback from customers. What customers count as competition for a JTBD is always changing. Don’t assume that it remains static. Somewhere, unknown to you, your

    不断刷新竞争格局与持续的反馈从客户。对于 JTBD 来说，客户认为是竞争对手的东西总是在不断变化。不要假设它保持静态。某个你不知道的地方


    customers might have come across a new way of getting the Job Done. This is why you need to interact with your customers continually.

    客户可能会遇到一种新的方法来完成工作。这就是为什么你需要不断地与你的客户互动。


    Your best bet is to talk with your customers regularly and keep interviewing new ones. Learn the stories behind their purchases. What solutions have they tried? What other solutions did they consider before buying yours? For existing customers, learn if they’ve heard about or tried other solutions. For customers who’ve stopped using your product, ask them why. Have they switched to a new solution, or does the JTBD no longer exist for them?

    你最好的选择就是定期和你的客户交谈，并不断面试新的客户。了解他们购买背后的故事。他们尝试了什么解决方案？在购买你的产品之前，他们还考虑了其他什么解决方案？对于现有客户，了解他们是否听说过或尝试过其他解决方案。对于那些已经停止使用你的产品的客户，问问他们为什么。他们是否已经转换到新的解决方案，或者 JTBD 对他们来说已经不存在了？


    Remember that not every JTBD needs to be solved with a product that customers buy. Perhaps the most common reason that an innovation fails is that no one wants it. A great many innovators and entrepreneurs get excited about solving people’s problems. This is a good thing. The downside is that most consumers are fine with good-enough solutions for a JTBD, and many of those don’t require a purchase. As Des Traynor, cofounder of Intercom, says, “The popularity of product-first businesses has led to short-sightedness around what’s necessary to create a sustainable business. Some problems persist because they’re quite simply not worth solving.”50

    请记住，并不是每个 JTBD 都需要用客户购买的产品来解决。也许一项创新失败的最常见原因是没有人想要它。许多创新者和企业家对解决人们的问题感到兴奋。这是件好事。不利的一面是，大多数消费者对 JTBD 的足够好的解决方案感到满意，而且其中许多不需要购买。正如 Intercom 的联合创始人德斯•特雷诺(Des Traynor)所言，“产品优先企业的流行导致人们对创建可持续企业所必需的近视产生了分歧。有些问题之所以一直存在，是因为它们根本不值得解决。”50


    The chotuKool case study offers many perfect examples of customers who had good-enough solutions for a JTBD. Rural Indians might like the idea of a small refrigerator, but they were fine using clay pots and shopping for food every day. The chotuKool was a luxury item that didn’t deliver much more progress than their current solutions.

    ChotuKool 案例研究提供了许多客户拥有足够好的 JTBD 解决方案的完美例子。农村的印第安人可能喜欢小冰箱这个主意，但是他们每天使用陶罐和购买食物是可以接受的。ChotuKool 是一个奢侈品，并没有提供更多的进展比他们目前的解决方案。


    PART III

    第 III 部

    THE SYSTEM OF PROGRESS

    进步系统

    As I’ve noted, a study of a customer’s JTBD is fundamentally a study of a system. We are interested in how the system’s parts work together to help customers make progress.

    如前所述，对客户的 JTBD 的研究基本上是对系统的研究。我们感兴趣的是系统各部分如何协同工作，以帮助客户取得进展。


    In our next case study, we’ll see how Omer Yariv was able to discover a JTBD and create a product for it by focusing on the energy behind customers’ struggling moments. Justin Jackson’s and Ash Maurya’s case studies will help you understand better what “customers want progress” and “a JTBD is part of a system” mean. Finally, we’ll look at the system of progress and how the study of it helps create sustainable businesses that make products that customers will buy.

    在我们的下一个案例研究中，我们将看到 Omer Yariv 是如何通过关注客户挣扎时刻背后的能量来发现 JTBD 并为其创建产品的。Justin Jackson 和 Ash Maurya 的案例研究将帮助您更好地理解“客户希望进步”和“ JTBD 是系统的一部分”的含义。最后，我们将探讨进步系统，以及研究如何帮助建立可持续的企业，生产消费者愿意购买的产品。

  7. Case Study: Omer and Transcendent

    个案研究: 奥默与超越

    Endeavors

    努力

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    I met Omer Yariv at the Customer Jobs Meetup I run here in New York City. At the time, he was vice president of engineering and product at a start-up called Simplist—its product helps you search for specific people within your social network. I particularly enjoy talking with Omer. We share a background in writing, engineering, and, of course, Customer Jobs.

    我在纽约市的客户工作会议上认识了 Omer Yariv。当时，他是一家名为 Simplist 的初创公司的工程和产品副总裁，该公司的产品可以帮助你在社交网络中搜索特定的人。我特别喜欢和奥马尔聊天。我们在写作，工程，当然还有客户工作方面有共同的背景。


    Omer joined Transcendent Endeavors (TE) in 2014 and is senior product manager now. Many of TE’s products are about facilitating communication between nurses, doctors, and patients. Omer is in charge of a new-product initiative for helping hospitals improve patient care. He shared with me how he’s using Customer Jobs principles to create a product from scratch.

    奥默于2014年加入卓越奋进公司，现任高级产品经理。TE 的许多产品都是关于促进护士、医生和病人之间的交流。奥马尔负责一项新产品的倡议，以帮助医院改善病人的护理。他与我分享了他是如何利用客户工作原则从零开始创造产品的。


    Omer knew which customers he needed to talk with, how to unpack their desire to evolve, and how to figure out what kind of solution would or wouldn’t help them make progress.

    Omer 知道他需要与哪些客户进行交流，如何打开他们发展的愿望，以及如何弄清楚什么样的解决方案会或不会帮助他们取得进展。


    How Customer Jobs helped Omer get started. Omer’s first task at TE was to develop a solution to prevent adverse events at hospitals—that is, circumstances in which someone’s condition declines because of something other than what brought him or her in for care. Examples are falls, infections, and bedsores.

    客户工作是如何帮助奥马尔起步的。Omer 在 TE 的第一个任务是开发一种解决方案，以防止医院出现不良事件ーー也就是说，在某些情况下，某人的病情会因为其他原因而恶化，而不是因为他或她需要接受治疗。例如跌倒、感染和褥疮。


    When he started, Omer didn’t know very much about the health-care industry, but that didn’t concern him much. He was confident that he could create a successful product; all he had to do was find a group of people who were struggling to get a Job Done. Who struggled the most with adverse events? He looked for answers. Who had the most to lose when adverse events happened? Who had the most to gain by preventing them? Who was putting the most energy—the most effort— into finding a solution that helped prevent adverse events? Omer believes that finding this energy is imperative to discovering a JTBD:

    刚开始的时候，奥马尔对医疗保健行业了解不多，但这并不让他太担心。他有信心创造出一个成功的产品; 他所要做的就是找到一群努力完成工作的人。谁与不良事件斗争最激烈？他在寻找答案。当不良事件发生时，谁的损失最大？谁能从阻止他们中得到最大的好处？谁投入了最大的精力和最大的努力来寻找一种有助于防止不良事件发生的解决方案？奥默认为，发现这种能量对于发现 JTBD 至关重要:


    When I interview potential customers, I look for evidence of a struggle. I’m looking for an energy to tap into. That’s how I know a struggling moment exists and that there’s an opportunity to create

    当我采访潜在客户时，我会寻找挣扎的证据。我在寻找一种可以利用的能量。这就是为什么我知道挣扎的时刻是存在的，并且有机会去创造


    something. If a group of people is not struggling—if I can’t feel that energy—then there’s probably no opportunity there.

    如果一群人没有挣扎ーー如果我感觉不到那种能量ーー那么可能就没有机会了。


    How does Customer Jobs help you create a product that people actually want to use? At this point, Omer didn’t have very much to go on. All he knew was that adverse events happen at hospitals and that nobody wants them to happen. He said,

    客户工作是如何帮助你创造出人们真正想要使用的产品的？在这一点上，奥马尔没有太多的线索。他只知道不良事件发生在医院，没有人希望它们发生。他说,


    Hospitals don’t want adverse events. It costs them money. It costs them time. It costs them reputation. Patients don’t want adverse events. Who wants to get sicker? Nurses don’t want adverse events because they’re there to take care of patients. Nobody in the system wants adverse events to happen. How come they still happen? Where’s the gap there? What’s missing?

    医院不希望出现不良反应。这会花他们的钱。这会浪费他们的时间。这会损害他们的声誉。病人不希望出现不良反应。谁想病得更重？护士不希望出现不良反应，因为他们要照顾病人。系统中没有人希望不利事件发生。为什么还会发生这种事？那个缺口在哪里？少了什么？


    Omer was wrestling with a tough question. Why do adverse events happen, even though so many people don’t want them to? The fact that so many people were affected by adverse events made it hard to know where to start. Omer knew he couldn’t build a solution for everyone. Not only would it be expensive and difficult, but there was no guarantee that all the people would actually use it.

    Omer 正在纠结一个棘手的问题。为什么不良事件会发生，即使有那么多人不希望它们发生？事实上，如此多的人受到不良事件的影响，很难知道从哪里开始。Omer 知道他不可能为所有人提供解决方案。它不仅昂贵而且困难，而且不能保证所有的人都会真正使用它。


    Omer’s experience as an innovator had taught him an important lesson: many products fail simply because no one wants them. Of course, he wanted to make something people would actually use. He narrowed his focus on one group of people who struggled the most (who suffered the greatest consequences at any adverse event) and those who were in a position to prevent adverse events.

    奥马尔作为创新者的经历给了他一个重要的教训: 许多产品失败仅仅是因为没有人想要它们。当然，他想做一些人们真正会用到的东西。他把研究的重点缩小到一组人，他们挣扎得最厉害(在任何不利事件中受到的影响最大) ，以及那些能够预防不利事件发生的人。


    How do you figure out who struggles the most? Omer needed to find out who had the most emotional motivation to prevent adverse events, for they would most likely use whatever product he created. He began by casting a wide net:

    你怎么知道谁挣扎得最厉害？奥马尔需要找出谁有最强烈的情感动机来阻止不良事件的发生，因为他们很可能会使用他创造的任何产品。他开始撒下一张大网:


    I wanted to interview potential users [those who will use it] and potential customers [those who will pay for it]. But I had to find the right ones to interview. I wanted to talk with those who had the most energy—who had the most motivation to solve the problem. So, I started creating surveys for the different people involved in adverse events, such as nurses and medical office managers.

    我想采访潜在用户(那些将使用它的人)和潜在客户(那些将为它付费的人)。但我必须找到合适的人来面试。我想和那些最有精力的人ーー那些最有动力解决问题的人谈谈。因此，我开始为不同的人参与不良事件的调查，如护士和医疗办公室经理。


    Omer asked such employees how long they had worked in the field, how often they saw (and managed) adverse events, and whether they thought adverse events were preventable. He began to see who might be best to interview in more depth:

    奥默询问这些员工在这个领域工作了多长时间，他们看到(和管理)不良事件的频率，以及他们是否认为不良事件是可以预防的。他开始考虑谁最适合进行更深入的采访:


    We learned that we needed to talk with nurses who had a lot of patients—and who had to deal with high turnover of those patients. These two conditions ruled out intensive care units [ICUs] and oncology [cancer treatment]. In ICUs, you have only one or two patients to watch over. There is also a high turnover of those patients. You’re dealing with a limited number of patients, and you’re not in charge of them for very long. In oncology, you might have ten patients, but you work with them over a long period of time. You get to know them. But with nurses involved in med/surg [medical/surgical], there seemed to be an opportunity there.

    我们了解到，我们需要与那些有很多病人的护士交谈ーー他们必须应对这些病人的高流动性。这两种情况排除了重症监护病房[ ICU ]和肿瘤[癌症治疗]。在重症监护室，你只需要照看一两个病人。这些病人的更替率也很高。你面对的病人数量有限而且你不能长时间照顾他们。在肿瘤科，你可能有10个病人，但是你要和他们一起工作很长一段时间。你了解他们。但随着护士参与医疗/外科[内科/外科] ，似乎有一个机会。


    Nurses in medical/surgical face a different challenge compared with other nurses. Medical/surgical nurses watch over at least four or five patients at a time, and these turn over within a few days. It’s a tough situation; patients constantly come and go. Nurses learn about their patients’ conditions and needs and care for them for a few days. But just as nurses get to know patients better, new patients take their place. These working conditions are why nurses in medical/surgical deal with the most adverse events. Omer concluded that medical/surgical nurses desired the most change and would be the most likely to use whatever product his team ended up creating.

    与其他护士相比，内外科护士面临着不同的挑战。内科/外科护士一次至少照看四到五个病人，这些病人在几天内就会转过来。情况很严峻，病人总是来来去去。护士了解他们的病人的情况和需要，并照顾他们几天。但是，正当护士们更好地了解病人时，新的病人取代了他们的位置。这些工作条件是内科/外科护士处理最不良事件的原因。Omer 得出结论，内科/外科护士希望得到最大的改变，并且最有可能使用他的团队最终创造的任何产品。


    Omer’s next step was to dive into the struggle this particular group of nurses faced. In interviews, he would ask what the struggle was like. Were the nurses trying to prevent adverse events? If so, how?

    奥马尔的下一步是深入到这个特殊的护士团体所面临的斗争中。在采访中，他会问挣扎是什么样的。护士们是否试图阻止不良事件的发生？如果是这样，怎么做？


    Discover a customer’s JTBD through an interview by looking for the energy of a desire to evolve. Learn how the customer wants life to be. Omer’s first interviews asked broad questions:

    通过面试发现客户的 JTBD，寻找进化欲望的能量。了解顾客想要怎样的生活。奥默的第一次采访提出了一些宽泛的问题:


    Does your hospital talk about adverse events?

    你们医院提到过不良反应吗？


    Are there incentives if the number of adverse events goes up or down?

    如果不良事件的数量上升或下降，是否有激励措施？


    How would you describe your daily life as a nurse? What are your routines?

    作为一名护士，你如何描述你的日常生活? 你的日常生活是怎样的？


    What is it like when adverse events happen on your watch?

    在你眼皮底下发生不良事件是什么感觉？


    But grabbing just any old data from interviews can make things worse instead of better. To avoid that, Omer looked for signs that these nurses were struggling to make progress:

    但是，仅仅从采访中获取任何旧的数据只会让事情变得更糟，而不是更好。为了避免这种情况，奥默寻找这些护士努力取得进展的迹象:


    All through those questions, I’m always looking for energy. If they describe their struggle using a particular solution, or if they describe having any emotional motivation to make things better, I would know that I needed to dig into it more. I was always looking for energy.

    通过这些问题，我一直在寻找能量。如果他们用一个特定的解决方案来描述他们的挣扎，或者如果他们描述有任何情感动机来使事情变得更好，我就会知道我需要更深入地挖掘它。我一直在寻找能量。


    Omer kept looking for “energy” around a desire for change. Was there any change in body language or how the nurses talked while describing dealing with adverse events? Did some express frustration with procedures or products they used that left them feeling powerless? What was giving them the most anxiety and stress? What were the forces of progress (i.e., push, pull, anxiety, and inertia)? Sure enough, Omer’s persistent search for energy paid off:

    奥默一直在改变的欲望周围寻找“能量”。身体语言或者护士在描述不良事件时说话的方式有没有变化？是否有人对他们使用的让他们感到无能为力的程序或产品表示失望？给他们带来最大焦虑和压力的是什么？进步的力量是什么(例如，推、拉、焦虑和惰性) ？果不其然，奥默对能源的不懈追求得到了回报:


    I finally started to get an idea of the struggle they faced as a nurse— and in particular when dealing with adverse events. For example, I had no idea that nurses don’t always get along; they don’t always like one another. The situation the hospital puts them in leads them to feel that they’re alone against everybody.

    我终于开始了解他们作为护士所面临的困难ーー特别是在处理不良事件时。例如，我不知道护士们并不总是相处融洽; 他们并不总是喜欢彼此。医院让他们陷入的境地让他们觉得自己是孤军奋战。


    The “situation” Omer refers to is how hospitals decide who is liable when an adverse event happens. Nurses generally suffer any consequences, even when an event is not their fault. For example, if a doctor prescribes the wrong medication and the nurse administers it, the nurse is liable, although he or she was not the source of the problem. Such an adverse event goes on a nurse’s permanent record, and he or she could lose a job, lose a license, or be sued. All this can happen because of someone else’s mistake. If all that stress isn’t enough, there’s the social stigma that nurses can face when an adverse event happens on their watch. Omer said,

    Omer 所指的“情况”是指医院在不良事件发生时如何决定谁应承担责任。护士通常承担任何后果，即使事件不是他们的过错。例如，如果医生开错了药方，而护士执行错误的药方，那么护士就要承担责任，尽管他或她并不是问题的根源。这样的不良事件会永久记录在护士的档案上，他或她可能会丢掉工作，丢掉执照，或者被起诉。这一切都可能因为别人的错误而发生。如果所有这些压力还不够的话，当不良事件发生在护士的眼皮底下时，他们就会面临社会的耻辱。奥马尔说,


    There’s a very strong feeling of ‘I don’t want to be that nurse that all the other nurses are talking about.’ That’s another very big motivation to make a change. All these struggles create a lot of energy to change things for the better. It’s a JTBD.

    有一种很强烈的感觉‘我不想成为其他护士都在谈论的那个护士。这是改变的另一个非常大的动机。所有这些努力创造了许多能量，使事情变得更好。是 JTBD。


    You found a struggle for progress. Now what? Learn how customers imagine their lives being better. Omer had found a struggle: nurses were afraid of being held liable for adverse events happening on their watch. But he wanted to learn more. How did these nurses want things to be? What would their lives be like if this struggle were resolved? He said,

    你发现了进步的挣扎。现在怎么办？了解顾客如何想象他们的生活变得更好。奥马尔发现了一种挣扎: 护士们害怕因为在他们看护下发生的不良事件而承担责任。但他想了解更多。这些护士希望事情变成什么样？如果这场斗争得到解决，他们的生活会是什么样子？他说,


    Even with all this struggle they face, you kind of wonder, why do they want to be a nurse? The answer they gave was always the same: They’re there because they feel like they can make a change. They

    即使他们面临这么多困难，你还是会想，他们为什么想当护士？他们给出的答案总是一样的: 他们在那里是因为他们觉得自己可以做出改变。他们


    feel like they’re helping people. That’s the thing that keeps them going—the feeling that you’re helping someone.

    感觉他们在帮助别人。这就是让他们继续下去的东西ーー那种你在帮助别人的感觉。


    These nurses want to help people, and that’s why they became nurses in the first place. This was an important piece of their JTBD puzzle.

    这些护士想要帮助别人，这就是为什么她们一开始成为护士的原因。这是他们 JTBD 拼图中的重要一块。


    Armed with these two insights— (1) the struggle and consequences nurses face regarding adverse events and (2) nurses’ desire to feel as if they are helping other people—Omer now had a pretty good idea of what Job these customers were struggling with and what their lives would be like when it got Done.

    有了这两个见解: (1)护士在不良事件面前的挣扎和后果; (2)护士希望感觉自己是在帮助他人的愿望。现在，奥默已经非常清楚这些客户在挣扎的工作是什么，以及完成工作后他们的生活会是什么样子。


    Omer now needed to learn what these nurses valued in a solution. This would help guide his team in designing one to fit the JTBD.

    奥马尔现在需要了解这些护士在解决方案中重视什么。这将有助于指导他的团队设计一个适合 JTBD。


    How do you learn what customers want in a solution for a JTBD? Even though Omer had a pretty good idea of these nurses’ JTBD, he didn’t know what they would expect in a solution. A JTBD describes the customer’s problem and only hints at what a solution should be. Omer needed to learn the following:

    如何了解客户对 JTBD 解决方案的需求？尽管 Omer 对这些护士的 JTBD 有一个相当好的想法，但他不知道他们在解决方案中会期望什么。JTBD 描述客户的问题，并且只提示解决方案应该是什么。奥马尔需要学习以下内容:


    How nurses currently handled adverse events. What solutions they had tried.

    护士目前如何处理不良事件。他们尝试了什么解决方案。

    What they did and didn’t value in each solution. Whether they were expressing compensatory behaviors.

    他们在每个解决方案中的所作所为和所没有的价值，他们是否表达了补偿行为。

    Whether they were using a combination of solutions because no single solution was good enough.

    他们是否使用了多种解决方案的组合，因为没有一种单一的解决方案是足够好的。


    The answers proved fruitful:

    事实证明，答案是有成效的:


    The story here is that nurses have a lot of things to remember. They want to get them right. There’s a lot at stake if a mistake is made. Nurses take care of people, they run around, they get interrupted, and then they have to put everything into the documentation later.

    这里的故事是，护士有很多事情要记住。他们想把事情做好。如果出了差错，后果很严重。护士照顾病人，他们到处跑，他们被打断，然后他们不得不把所有的事情都记录在案。


    They currently handle all this in two ways. One is memory. Some of them say, “Yeah, I remember.” Other nurses take notes. It can be a little bit on their notes app on their iPhone, or sometimes they just jot down notes on their clipboard and put them in their pockets. But they make notes all the time. They make notes, and then they update the

    他们目前以两种方式处理所有这些问题。一个是记忆。有些人说“是的，我记得”其他护士会记笔记。它可以在他们 iPhone 上的笔记应用程序上显示，或者有时他们只是在剪贴板上草草记下笔记，然后放进口袋里。但他们一直在做笔记。他们做笔记，然后更新


    notes. They cross them out and make more notes. In a few cases, we heard about a product called Rover. It’s an iPhone app that connects to the hospital’s documentation system.

    笔记。他们把它们划掉，做更多的笔记。在一些案例中，我们听说了一种叫做 Rover 的产品。这是一个连接到医院文件系统的 iPhone 应用程序。


    The diversity of these solutions—and how the nurses used them differently—gave Omer an idea of what the nurses wanted in a solution. But his biggest breakthrough came when he interviewed one nurse who had created her own solution.

    这些解决方案的多样性ーー以及护士们如何以不同的方式使用它们ーー让奥马尔了解护士们希望在解决方案中得到什么。但他最大的突破来自于他采访的一位护士，她创造了自己的解决方案。


    One nurse I talked with—she started by taking notes on her hand. She would write everything on her hand with a pen, then she would wash her hands, and the notes would go away. So, then she started writing notes on a pad. But as she wrote down more notes, it became hard to keep track of them all.

    和我交谈过的一位护士ーー她开始在手上记笔记。她会用钢笔把所有的东西都写在手上，然后洗手，笔记就不见了。然后她开始在本子上记笔记。但是当她写下更多的笔记时，就很难记住所有的笔记。


    Then, she came up with her own solution. She created worksheets that used a grid system to track all the beds and patients. She would use that to write what she needs to do. Even more interesting was that the other nurses saw this and liked it. So, she started creating photocopies and giving them to other nurses. That was her evolution of a solution for her Job to be Done. That was great to hear.

    然后，她想出了自己的解决办法。她创建了工作表，使用网格系统来跟踪所有的床位和病人。她会用这个来写她需要做的事。更有趣的是，其他护士看到这一点，并喜欢它。所以，她开始复印照片给其他护士看。这就是她为完成工作而提出的解决方案。很高兴听你这么说。


    Learning about other solutions gave him valuable information about what these nurses did and didn’t like in one. First, he learned about critical pain points that made a nurse realize that the way he or she was doing things wasn’t working. Next, he learned about what would attract nurses to one solution versus another. Finally, he learned how nurses innovated on their own.

    学习其他的解决方案给了他有价值的信息，这些护士做什么和不喜欢在一个。首先，他了解了关键的疼痛点，使护士意识到他或她做事的方式不起作用。接下来，他学习了什么可以吸引护士采用不同的解决方案。最后，他学会了护士如何自主创新。


    It was time to create a solution. Omer first broke down the key moments that would prompt nurses to reach for a solution for their JTBD. He wrote short stories to encapsulate such struggling moments. For example:

    是时候制定一个解决方案了。Omer 首先分析了促使护士为 JTBD 寻找解决方案的关键时刻。他写短篇小说来概括这种挣扎的时刻。例如:


    When I get my handoff, and I need to remember what I need to do, I want to assign beds and interventions quickly, so I can get back to work and not get bogged down.

    当我完成交接后，我需要记住我需要做什么，我想快速分配床位和干预措施，这样我就可以回去工作，而不会陷入困境。


    When I’m done with an emergency and I’ve forgotten what I was last doing, I want to catch up with my scheduled interventions, so I can pick up on what I missed and not worry about skipping any patients.

    当我处理完一个紧急情况，我忘记了我上一次做了什么，我想赶上我预定的干预措施，这样我就可以重拾我错过的东西，而不用担心错过任何病人。


    When I finish an intervention, I want to mark it as done quickly so I can make sure I don’t double-administer treatments.

    当我完成一个干预，我想标记它做得很快，所以我可以确保我不双管治疗。


    Omer described how he got these Job stories and how they helped him innovate: “These struggling moments came after I interviewed nurses and when I started working on a prototype. I wanted those situations documented so that I could make sure I was focusing on the right thing.”

    奥默描述了他是如何得到这些工作故事，以及这些故事是如何帮助他创新的: “这些挣扎的时刻是在我采访护士之后，当我开始做一个原型的时候。我希望把这些情况记录下来，这样我就能确保自己专注于正确的事情。”


    Where’s the project now? At the time of this writing, Omer’s team is still in production. They’ve developed prototypes and are now testing, shooting for a 2016 release date.

    项目现在在哪里？在撰写本文时，Omer 的团队仍在生产中。他们已经开发出了原型机，目前正在测试，计划在2016年发布。


    What’s the JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    Omer described some great data about a JTBD these nurses faced. The struggles for progress these nurses faced seemed to be the following:

    Omer 描述了一些关于这些护士所面临的 JTBD 的重要数据。这些护士面临的进步斗争似乎如下:


    More about: avoiding adverse events, not being the nurse everyone talks about, losing my nursing license, protecting myself from liability, being unfairly blamed, feeling like I’m helping people, pride in my work as a nurse.

    更多关于: 避免不良事件，不做人人都在谈论的护士，丢掉护士执照，保护自己免于责任，被不公平地指责，感觉自己在帮助别人，为自己作为护士的工作感到自豪。


    Less about: protecting the hospital, protecting other nurses.

    少说些: 保护医院，保护其他护士。


    Based on what Omer told us, I would describe the progress, the JTBD, these nurses expressed as follows:

    基于 Omer 告诉我们的，我会描述进展，JTBD，这些护士表达如下:


    Arm me with what I need to manage my interventions, so I can focus on helping my patients.

    用我需要的东西武装我来管理我的干预措施，这样我就可以专注于帮助我的病人。


    There are a few reasons why I like this:

    我喜欢这样做的原因有以下几点:


    This JTBD can be solved with a change in hospital procedures and processes. Nurses don’t have to be buying their own solutions for it. This demonstrates the idea that competition for a JTBD can come from anywhere.

    这个 JTBD 可以通过改变医院的程序和流程来解决。护士不需要自己买解决方案。这证明了 JTBD 的竞争可以来自任何地方。


    It shows how these “needs” are not intrinsic to these nurses. Rather, they are a product of the health-care system these nurses interact with. These nurses wouldn’t face this struggle if management had designed better processes in the first place.

    它显示了这些“需求”是如何不是内在的这些护士。相反，他们是医疗保健系统的产品，这些护士互动。如果管理层一开始就设计了更好的流程，这些护士就不会面临这种困境。


    I get a good sense of what life is like when these nurses’ Job is Done.

    我很清楚这些护士工作完成后的生活是什么样的。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Begin by identifying a struggle. Start wide and get progressively narrow. The first thing Omer did in creating a new product from scratch was to identify a struggling moment. He started by casting a wide net as he sent surveys to doctors, nurses, and hospital administrators. As he learned more, he focused more. Eventually, he ended up doing one-on-one interviews with nurses who worked within a particular department (medical/surgical). These were the people who were struggling the most. These were his potential customers.

    首先确认一下打斗的痕迹。从宽开始，逐渐变窄。奥马尔从零开始创造一个新产品的第一件事就是找出一个挣扎的时刻。他开始撒大网，同时向医生、护士和医院管理人员发送调查问卷。随着他学到的东西越多，他的注意力也越集中。最终，他结束了与在特定部门(内科/外科)工作的护士的一对一面谈。他们是最挣扎的人。这些都是他的潜在客户。


    Understanding the struggling moment is a crucial part of JTBD. In a previous chapter, we saw how the creators of the chotuKool didn’t focus on a struggling moment. They also jumped to a solution—perhaps because they believed they understood their struggling customers. Don’t do what they did. Instead, emulate Omer: start with an open mind and resolve to stop discovery only after you uncover a customer’s struggling moment.

    理解挣扎的时刻是 JTBD 的关键部分。在前一章中，我们看到了 chootuKool 的创造者是如何没有关注一个挣扎的时刻的。他们还急于找到解决方案ーー或许是因为他们相信自己了解苦苦挣扎的客户。别学他们。相反，效仿 Omer: 以开放的心态开始，只有在你发现客户的挣扎时刻之后才决心停止发现。


    Find innovation opportunities when customers exhibit compensatory behaviors. Omer discovered a nurse who shifted between various solutions for her JTBD. She moved from writing on her hand to writing notes on a pad, and then she created her own worksheet system. It was so helpful that other nurses had asked her to make copies of it, so they could use it as well.

    当顾客表现出补偿行为时，寻找创新机会。Omer 发现一个护士为她的 JTBD 在不同的解决方案之间变换。她从在手上写字转变为在便签本上写笔记，然后她创建了自己的工作表系统。这是如此有帮助，以至于其他护士要求她复印一份，这样她们也可以使用它。


    Innovation opportunities exist when customers exhibit compensatory behaviors. The edge cases in which customers use your product might also represent innovation opportunities.

    当顾客表现出补偿行为时，就存在创新机会。客户使用您的产品的边缘案例也可能代表创新的机会。


    Always keep an eye out for customers who use a product in novel ways, combine products into solutions, or create their own solutions for a JTBD. They have all the trade-offs, necessities, struggles, and ways to progress in their minds. Why not take advantage when they choose to express them?

    始终留意那些以新颖方式使用产品、将产品组合成解决方案或为 JTBD 创建自己的解决方案的客户。他们的头脑中有所有的权衡、必需品、挣扎和进步的方式。当他们选择表达时，为什么不利用这一点呢？

  8. Case Study: Justin and Product People Club

    案例研究: Justin 和产品人员俱乐部

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    Justin Jackson is an entrepreneur from Canada. At one time, his Twitter bio simply read: “Professional burrito maker.” In that case, his ten thousand–plus Twitter followers may have made him the most popular burrito maker ever. Never mind his prowess with a burrito tortilla for now. We want to learn more about his experience as a nonstop innovator. The numerous products he has made over the years include the following:

    贾斯汀 · 杰克逊是一位来自加拿大的企业家。有一次，他的推特简介只是写道: “专业的玉米煎饼制造商。”在这种情况下，他的一万多名推特粉丝可能使他成为有史以来最受欢迎的卷饼制作者。先别管他吃玉米煎饼的本事了。我们想更多地了解他作为一个不间断的创新者的经历。他多年来生产的众多产品包括:


    Text Me, Slacker. An app that helps users engage existing customers and acquire new ones through SMS messages.

    发短信给我，一个帮助用户接触现有客户并通过短信获得新客户的应用程序。


    Marketing for Developers. A guidebook for marketing software, apps, and digital products.

    市场营销开发者。市场营销软件，应用程序和数字产品的指南。


    Jolt. A guide that helps users come up with new marketing tactics.

    一个帮助用户想出新的营销策略的指南。


    ProductPress. A plug-in that turns a regular WordPress site into a membership site.

    一个插件，可以把一个普通的 WordPress 站点变成一个会员站点。


    Product People Club. An online community where innovators and entrepreneurs can share their progress, give one another feedback, and track revenue goals.

    产品人员俱乐部。一个在线社区，创新者和企业家可以分享他们的进步，相互反馈，并跟踪收入目标。


    In fact, Justin enjoys innovation so much that he tirelessly encourages others to innovate as well. At the end of 2015, he created the Maker Challenge—a call for others to join him in creating a hundred new products.

    事实上，贾斯汀非常喜欢创新，他不知疲倦地鼓励其他人也去创新。2015年底，他创立了“制造商挑战”(Maker Challenge) ，号召其他人与他一起创造100种新产品。


    I first heard about Justin when I saw his short video about the Jobs for which he hires coffee—you’ll read about that shortly. I contacted Justin to chat about his take on Customer Jobs. How was he using it? Was it helpful to him? Justin told me how he had applied Customer Jobs thinking toward Product People Club and also his book, Marketing for Developers.

    我第一次听说贾斯汀是在我看到他关于他雇佣咖啡的工作的短视频时ーー你们很快就会读到。我联系了贾斯汀，谈谈他对客户工作的看法。他怎么用的？对他有帮助吗？贾斯汀告诉我他是如何将客户工作思维应用到产品人员俱乐部以及他的书《为开发者营销》中的。


    In this case study, you’ll learn how Justin uncovered a struggling moment that his prospective customers faced, as well as how he created a solution for it to help them make their lives better. You’ll learn how he grew his business—not only by adding

    在这个案例研究中，您将了解贾斯汀是如何发现他的潜在客户面临的一个困难时刻，以及他是如何创建一个解决方案，以帮助他们使他们的生活更好。你会了解到他是如何发展他的生意的ーー不仅仅是通过增加


    more features to an existing product but also by creating new products that extend the progress his customers want.

    为现有产品增加更多的功能，同时创建新产品来扩展客户需要的进度。


    Justin learned about Customer Jobs from Ryan Singer and Jason Fried, product designer and cofounder, respectively, of the software company Basecamp. He said, “I saw that they were doing a Customer Jobs seminar at their office. I remember thinking, Oh, that’s weird. They haven’t done seminars like that before. That was the first time I heard about Jobs [JTBD].” Although Justin didn’t actually attend the seminar, it did put Customer Jobs on his radar. He said,

    Justin 分别从软件公司 Basecamp 的产品设计师 Ryan Singer 和联合创始人 Jason Fried 那里了解到了 Customer Jobs。他说: “我看到他们在办公室里举办一个客户工作研讨会。我记得当时在想，哦，这太奇怪了。他们以前从来没有举办过这样的研讨会。那是我第一次听说乔布斯(JTBD)。”虽然贾斯汀并没有真正参加研讨会，但这确实让他注意到了客户工作。他说,


    After that, I began noticing Ryan and Jason tweeting about Customer Jobs. Then, during an interview with Ryan, I heard him say something like, “At 37signals [the former name of Basecamp], we’ve been thinking more about why people hire our product—or what people are hiring our product to do.” I remember at the time thinking, Man, I’ve never thought about it like that before.

    在那之后，我开始注意到 Ryan 和 Jason 在 Twitter 上发布关于客户工作的消息。然后，在接受瑞安采访时，我听到他说了类似这样的话: “在37Signals (Basecamp 的前身) ，我们一直在更多地思考人们为什么雇用我们的产品ーー或者人们雇用我们的产品做什么。”我记得当时我在想，伙计，我从来没有这样想过。


    Their product, Basecamp, is a great example of Customer Jobs thinking. It’s a project management tool. In place of that, you could hire an assistant to manage all your projects for you. Both could do the same Job.

    他们的产品 Basecamp 是客户工作思维的一个很好的例子。这是一个项目管理工具。取而代之的是，你可以雇佣一个助理来管理你所有的项目。两者都可以做同样的工作。


    Customer Jobs differentiates emotional from functional. Justin once thought of Customer Jobs as an exploration of functionality—as a lot of people do: “At first, I was just thinking about Jobs as, literally, utilitarian jobs. For example, I’ve hired people to trim my trees. I’ve hired people to fix my plumbing. I’m hiring this product to manage my schedule. I’m hiring this product to make sure that I don’t miss any more meetings.”

    客户工作区分情感和功能。贾斯汀曾经认为“客户工作”是一种对功能性的探索ーー就像很多人所做的那样: “起初，我只是把乔布斯想象成一种实用性的工作。例如，我雇人修剪我的树木。我雇人修水管。我雇用这个产品来管理我的日程安排。我雇用这个产品是为了确保我不会再错过任何会议。”


    The more he continued digging into Customer Jobs, however, the better he understood the emotional aspect of Jobs. Jobs as an emotional desire for self-betterment are something that stuck out to him. This interested him so much that he created that coffee video. “I love that emotional aspect [of JTBD]. When people go to a coffee shop, they aren’t just buying caffeinated liquid. They’re going for all these other reasons.” Some of his own motivations for going to coffee shops include getting out of the office to clear his head, feeling cool and creative hanging out there, experiencing the ritual of drinking coffee made the way he likes it, and feeling as if he’s part of a community.

    然而，他越是深入挖掘客户工作，就越能理解乔布斯的情感方面。乔布斯对自我完善的情感渴望是他一直坚持的东西。这让他非常感兴趣，所以他制作了那个咖啡视频。“我喜欢(JTBD 的)情感方面。当人们去咖啡店的时候，他们不仅仅是在买含咖啡因的液体。他们去那里还有其它种种原因。”他自己去咖啡店的动机包括走出办公室清理头脑，在那里感到凉爽和有创造力，体验喝咖啡的仪式使他喜欢它的方式，并感觉好像他是一个社区的一部分。


    This focus on emotional motivation and struggle helps Justin create successful products. In particular, it helped him create Product People Club.

    这种对情感动机和斗争的关注有助于贾斯汀创造成功的产品。特别是，它帮助他创建了产品人员俱乐部。


    How do you find a struggling moment when you don’t even have an idea for a product? The inspiration for Justin to create what would become Product People Club came from a moment of frustration: “I was consulting as a product marketing manager at a software company. Things were moving slowly with the team I was working with. I came home one day and wanted a distraction. I [thought], You know what? I’m going to create a new product.” But at that moment, he neither had a concept nor knew what struggle he wanted to solve. However, he did have a few ideas of where to start looking.

    当你甚至没有一个关于产品的想法时，你如何找到一个挣扎的时刻？贾斯汀创建产品人员俱乐部的灵感来自一个沮丧的时刻: “我是一家软件公司的产品营销经理。和我一起工作的团队进展缓慢。有一天我回到家，想分散一下注意力。我想，你知道吗？我要创造一种新产品。”但在那个时候，他既没有一个概念，也不知道他要解决什么样的斗争。不过，他确实有一些从哪里开始寻找的想法。


    For years, he had been active in entrepreneur and innovation communities. He had a successful blog, newsletter, and podcast on the topic of entrepreneurship. His experience of interacting with his community told him that a lot of people were putting a lot of energy into solving a struggle about getting started as an entrepreneur. To begin, Justin simply started observing.

    多年来，他一直活跃在企业家和创新社区。他有一个关于创业主题的成功的博客，时事通讯和播客。他与社区互动的经历告诉他，很多人都投入了大量精力来解决创业这一难题。首先，贾斯汀只是开始观察。


    I decided to take a closer look at the patterns I had been noticing within my audience. I’ve been blogging, sending newsletters, and podcasting for a while. People would frequently write to me with questions or asking for help and advice. I had all this qualitative information, so I began looking through it. Could I find any reoccurring struggling moments that people were experiencing?

    我决定仔细观察一下我在观众中注意到的模式。我一直在写博客，发送时事通讯和播客。人们经常给我写信提问题或寻求帮助和建议。我有所有这些定性的信息，所以我开始浏览它。我能找到人们经历过的任何反复出现的挣扎时刻吗？


    Justin was looking for recurring behaviors that signaled that people were struggling and that they were looking for a better way. All the while, he asked himself questions: “What do people—unprompted—complain about on Twitter?”; “What questions do entrepreneurs and innovators keep asking me over and over again?”; “What topics are talked about during Meetups about entrepreneurship?” He said,

    贾斯汀一直在寻找反复出现的行为表明人们在挣扎，他们在寻找更好的方式。与此同时，他问自己: “人们在 Twitter 上主动抱怨什么?”“企业家和创新者一遍又一遍地问我什么问题?”“聚会期间讨论了哪些关于创业的话题?”他说,


    There were two patterns I noticed. One is that people were lonely. People who are working on products and building apps are usually doing it in their spare time. They’re doing it in their basement, by themselves.

    我注意到有两种模式。一个是人们很孤独。从事产品开发和应用程序开发的人通常在业余时间做这些事情。他们在自己的地下室自己做。


    The other struggling moment I found was this frustration people had when they were just consuming lots of content. They were listening

    我发现的另一个挣扎的时刻是人们在消费大量内容时所感受到的挫折。他们在监听





    Figure 17. A screenshot from productpeople.com.

    图17来自 productpeople.com 的截图


    to all these great interviews on my podcast, listening to other people who are building and launching their own products, but they weren’t doing anything themselves.

    在我的播客上做了很多很棒的采访，倾听其他人创建和发布他们自己的产品，但是他们自己什么都没做。


    Justin was seeing patterns and getting questions seeking advice on two main struggles: (1) loneliness and (2) how to sustain the motivation to finish building a product.

    贾斯汀发现了一些模式，并就两个主要问题寻求建议: (1)孤独感和(2)如何保持完成一个产品的动力。


    The people he was observing were solo entrepreneurs who were passionate about creating something but hit these two barriers. Some were in small towns where they couldn’t talk with anyone else about their struggles. Some exhibited concerns about being seen (or even seeing themselves) as poseurs. These barriers slowed—or stopped—their progress. A lot energy was pent up in these struggles, and something to release it was needed to get them unstuck. Justin said, “They just, they wanted to just fucking do it. They wanted to go out and build their own thing, but they were getting stuck. That’s where I got the idea for Product People Club.”

    他观察到的人都是个体企业家，他们热衷于创造东西，但遇到了这两个障碍。有些人生活在小镇上，在那里他们不能和任何人谈论他们的挣扎。一些人表现出担心被看作(甚至看作自己)装腔作势。这些障碍减缓或阻止了它们的发展。在这些斗争中，人们被压抑了很多精力，需要一些东西来释放这些精力，使他们摆脱困境。贾斯汀说，“他们只是，他们只是想他妈的做到这一点。他们想走出去，建立自己的东西，但他们被卡住了。这就是我创立产品人员俱乐部的灵感来源。”


    Justin had found a desire to change. Next, he wanted to test how many people were struggling and how intense this desire was.

    贾斯汀想要改变。接下来，他想测试有多少人在挣扎，以及这种渴望有多强烈。


    How do you test if an innovation opportunity exists for a struggling moment? Justin believed he had tapped into an emotional struggle. Next, he wanted to come up with a way of measuring it. Was there an opportunity to create a product? As a test, he created a simple product: a chat room, capped at twelve people, that cost ten dollars a month to join. He put up a simple promotional web page that spoke to the frustrations and struggles of solo entrepreneurship and procrastination. The ad copy for the Product People Club stresses these struggling moments (figure 17).

    你如何测试一个创新机会是否存在于一个挣扎的时刻？贾斯汀认为他陷入了一场情感斗争。接下来，他想提出一种测量它的方法。有机会创造一个产品吗？作为一个测试，他创建了一个简单的产品: 一个聊天室，上限为12人，每月花费10美元加入。他建立了一个简单的宣传网页，讲述了个人创业和拖延症带来的挫折和挣扎。产品人员俱乐部的广告文案强调了这些挣扎的时刻(图17)。


    Justin’s simple web page had tapped into the two aspects of a JTBD: (1) the emotional motivation to better your life and (2) how life is better when you have a solution for your Job—that is, what it is like when the Job is Done. How did it work? He told me, “I posted the website to Hacker News, an online discussion group. Thirty minutes later, the product sold out. By the end of the week, I had a waiting list of almost four hundred people. It was clear: I had hit a nerve.”

    贾斯汀简单的网页挖掘了 JTBD 的两个方面: (1)改善生活的情感动机; (2)当你有了工作的解决方案时，生活会变得更好ーー也就是说，当工作完成时，生活会是什么样子。它是怎么工作的？他告诉我，“我把这个网站发给了黑客新闻，一个在线讨论组。30分钟后，产品销售一空。到了周末，我的候补名单上已经有将近400人了。很明显，我触到了他们的痛处。”


    How do you dig deeper into a struggling moment? Justin had confirmed that an opportunity existed. Now it was time to figure out how to make Product People Club (PPC) more successful. He began interviewing his customers to learn more about their struggle: “I started asking my customers questions in a very deliberate way. I talked to people about why they joined.” Justin asked customers questions such as the following:

    你如何更深地挖掘挣扎的时刻？贾斯汀已经确认了机会的存在。现在是时候弄清楚如何使产品人员俱乐部(PPC)更加成功了。他开始采访他的客户，以了解更多关于他们的挣扎: “我开始以一种非常慎重的方式问我的客户问题。我和人们谈论了他们加入的原因。”贾斯汀向客户提出了以下问题:


    How did you first hear about PPC?

    你是如何第一次听说 PPC 的？


    When did you first think about getting involved with PPC? Did you do any research before joining?

    你是什么时候开始考虑加入 PPC 的? 在加入之前你做过调查吗？

    What was going on in your life when you signed up?

    你参军的时候发生了什么？


    Justin was uncovering specific moments of struggle and getting a better idea of what exactly his customers’ struggle was like.

    贾斯汀发现了一些特定的挣扎时刻并且对他的顾客的挣扎有了更好的了解。


    That last question— “What was going on in your life when you signed up?”—is gold. The last customer I interviewed, when I was asking him about what was going on in his life when he signed up, he told me, “Well, I had just quit my job. I had decided I was going to start building products and consulting full time.” He then talked about being alone in his house all day, with no one to talk to. His wife would leave for work, and he felt isolated, which is tough when you’re

    最后一个问题“当你报名参军的时候，你的生活发生了什么?”是金子。我采访的最后一位客户，当我问他注册时，他的生活发生了什么，他告诉我，“嗯，我刚刚辞职。我决定开始全职制造产品和咨询。”然后他说他整天一个人呆在家里，没有人可以说话。他的妻子会去上班，他觉得很孤独，这对你来说很难受


    working to start a business. He was also worried and scared about his future.

    他也为自己的未来感到担心和害怕。


    This is how Justin began to unpack the first part of a JTBD: the push—the struggling moment. The desire for progress for these entrepreneurs was “I want help managing the feelings of isolation as I start my business.” Through his interviews, Justin could qualify what it meant to feel isolated. He learned that these entrepreneurs wanted to interact with other people who shared the same struggle. Talking with their spouses or neighbors wasn’t helpful. In fact, talking with someone who couldn’t relate to their struggle could make them feel more isolated.

    这就是贾斯汀如何开始解开 JTBD 的第一部分: 推力ーー挣扎的时刻。这些企业家对进步的渴望是“我希望在创业时能帮助我克服孤独感。”通过他的采访，贾斯汀可以定义什么是孤立感。他了解到，这些企业家希望与其他有着相同奋斗经历的人进行互动。和他们的配偶或邻居交谈是没有帮助的。事实上，与那些无法理解他们的挣扎的人交谈会让他们感到更加孤立。


    As Justin unpacked their struggle with loneliness, he began to tap into the second part of their JTBD: how life was better when they had a solution for their Job.

    当贾斯汀打开他们与孤独的斗争，他开始进入他们的 JTBD 的第二部分: 如何生活更好，当他们有一个解决他们的工作。


    I learned that, when they joined the club, they would have this feeling of “Oh, finally! These are my people! These are people I can talk to about what it is like to have prelaunch stress!” Having the right people to talk with helped eased their anxiety and raised their confidence. It’s that sense of community, friendship, relationship, and human connectedness.

    我了解到，当他们加入俱乐部时，他们会有这样的感觉: “哦，终于！他们是我的人！我可以和这些人谈谈发射前的压力是什么感觉!”与合适的人交谈有助于缓解他们的焦虑，提高他们的信心。就是那种团结、友谊、关系和人际关系的感觉。


    Now Justin had two important parts of a JTBD: (1) a struggling moment—help me manage feelings of isolation as I start my business—and (2) how things will be better—I’ll have the confidence to persist in being an entrepreneur.

    现在，贾斯汀有了 JTBD 的两个重要组成部分: (1)一个艰难的时刻ーー在我创业时帮助我控制孤独感ーー和(2)事情将如何变得更好ーー我将有信心坚持做一名企业家。


    His next step was to learn more about what these customers had already tried. This would give him more information about their struggle. His exploration of why they moved from one solution to another would also help him understand what customers did—and didn’t—value in a solution.

    他的下一步是了解更多这些客户已经尝试过的东西。这会给他更多关于他们斗争的信息。他对这些解决方案之所以从一个转向另一个的探索，也将有助于他理解客户在解决方案中的所作所为(以及所不为)价值。


    Studying past customer solutions tells you about the JTBD. Justin continued gathering data about his customers through observation, interviews, surveys, and customer e-mails. This uncovered solutions his customers had already tried. Some examples of what he discovered as competition to Product People Club included the following:

    通过研究过去的客户解决方案可以了解 JTBD。贾斯汀继续通过观察、访谈、调查和客户电子邮件收集客户的数据。这揭示了他的客户已经尝试过的解决方案。他发现的与产品人员俱乐部竞争的一些例子包括:


    MicroConf. A conference geared toward self-funded start-ups.

    MicroConf 是一个面向自资创业公司的会议。


    30×500. An online course that guides entrepreneurs from product research through launch.

    30 × 500。在线课程，指导企业家从产品研究到发布。


    Communities formed using an online chat application called Slack. Creating a Meetup or attending one created by someone else.

    使用在线聊天应用程序 Slack 组建的社区。创建一个 Meetup 或参加一个由其他人创建的 Meetup。

    One-on-one coaching from other entrepreneurs. Clarity (which we featured in another case study).

    来自其他企业家的一对一指导。清晰(我们在另一个案例研究中特别提到)。

    Learning about what customers did and didn’t like about the other solutions they had tried helped Justin understand what progress he needed to deliver. In particular, he started to pick up on another struggle taking place:

    了解客户对他们尝试过的其他解决方案做了什么和不喜欢什么，有助于贾斯汀理解他需要交付什么样的进展。特别是，他开始注意到正在发生的另一场斗争:


    [I also learned that] a lot of people in the community have revenue goals for their business. For example, they would say, “I want to do fifty thousand dollars in iOS sales this year.” As I dug down into those things, I began seeing trends. One was a desire to have independent income. The other solutions they tried don’t help with that goal. I felt that Product People Club could help some customers know how to replace, for example, a hundred thousand dollars in income.

    [我还了解到]社区中的很多人都有自己的商业收入目标。例如，他们会说，“我今年想在 iOS 上做五万美元的销售。”当我深入研究这些东西时，我开始看到趋势。其中之一是希望有独立的收入。他们尝试的其他解决方案对实现这一目标没有帮助。我觉得产品人员俱乐部可以帮助一些客户知道如何更换，例如，十万美元的收入。


    Justin’s exploration of other solutions customers had tried gave him ideas on how Product People Club could distinguish itself. This helped him know where to take his product next:

    贾斯汀的探索其他解决方案客户已经尝试给他的想法，产品人俱乐部如何可以区分自己。这帮助他知道下一步该把他的产品带到哪里:


    What if we help you track that income you’re trying to get to? Maybe you are closer than you think or maybe you’re a lot farther and you should not quit your existing job. Right now, we’re working on a feature that will help people track their goals. That’s one thing I think about: how to help people measure their success as they strive to have completely independent income, only from creating and launching products.

    如果我们帮你追踪你想要的收入呢？也许你们之间的距离比你想象的要近，也许你们之间的距离要远得多，你不应该辞掉现有的工作。现在，我们正在开发一个功能，可以帮助人们追踪他们的目标。这是我想到的一件事: 如何帮助人们衡量他们的成功，因为他们努力获得完全独立的收入，只有通过创造和推出产品。


    Can more exploration of the customers’ struggle to change reveal other innovation opportunities? Justin’s awareness of his customers’ struggle for progress led him to uncover related Jobs and therefore more innovation opportunities. For example, what new struggles do customers face once they overcome loneliness? What happens when they have the motivation and confidence to launch their start-up? Justin has some ideas:

    对消费者努力改变的更多探索能否揭示其他创新机遇？贾斯汀意识到他的客户在为进步而奋斗，这使他发现了相关的乔布斯，因此也发现了更多的创新机会。例如，一旦消费者克服了孤独，他们会面临什么新的困难？如果他们有动力和信心来启动他们的初创公司，会发生什么？贾斯汀有一些想法:


    In terms of what’s next for Product People Club, I keep thinking about how we can help more people build and launch successful

    关于产品人员俱乐部的下一步计划，我一直在思考如何帮助更多的人建立和发布成功的产品


    products. A lot of people are looking for help promoting their product after they finally launch it. They have no idea how to get it out to people. That’s an opportunity for another product that I’m exploring right now.

    产品。很多人在他们最终推出产品后都在寻求帮助来推广他们的产品。他们根本不知道怎么传达给别人。这是我正在探索的另一个产品的机会。


    Justin is doing something interesting here; he’s exploring struggles related to the one he started with. He started by developing a product that helps people overcome the isolation of solo entrepreneurship by giving them the support and confidence they need to build their own products. Once his customers have a solution for that problem—once they are able to get that Job Done—they need help launching and promoting their new businesses.

    贾斯汀在这里做了一些有趣的事情，他在探索与他开始做的事情相关的斗争。他首先开发了一种产品，帮助人们克服独立创业的孤立感，为他们提供建立自己产品所需的支持和信心。一旦他的客户有了解决这个问题的办法ーー一旦他们能够完成任务ーー他们就需要帮助来启动和推广他们的新业务。


    Creating a product for related Jobs. Justin knew that his existing Product People Club customers would eventually encounter the struggle of marketing their new products. Could he have something ready for them when the time came? He decided on a combination of instructional and interview videos, a book, worksheets, handbooks, and templates. This combination product is called Marketing for Developers.

    为相关工作创建产品。贾斯汀知道，他现有的产品人员俱乐部客户最终会遇到销售他们的新产品的斗争。到时候他能为他们准备点什么吗？他决定结合教学和面试视频，一本书，工作表，手册和模板。这种组合产品被称为开发商营销。


    Justin delivers his customers’ progress. Justin is the most prolific innovator I know. Who else challenges others with, “I’m going to try to make a hundred things this year. Want to join me?”

    贾斯汀提供他的客户的进度。贾斯汀是我认识的最多产的创新者。还有谁会挑战别人，“今年我要做一百件事情。想和我一起去吗?”


    Many factors contribute to his success. I believe that one of them is his ability to tap into people’s JTBD. He can sense a customer’s struggling moment, qualify it, and discover how he or she imagines life will be better once a solution is in hand.

    许多因素促成了他的成功。我相信其中之一就是他能够利用人们的 JTBD。他可以感觉到客户的挣扎时刻，定性它，并发现他或她如何想象生活会更好，一旦解决方案在手。


    I also admire Justin’s skill in understanding the idea of delivering ongoing progress to customers. He looks ahead and anticipates the struggles his customers will face. He thought, After I help customers maintain their motivation to launch their businesses, what will they struggle with next? This is what it is like to think about delivering progress to customers.

    我也很欣赏贾斯汀在理解向客户提供持续进展的想法方面的技巧。他展望未来，并预期他的客户将面临的困难。他想，在我帮助客户保持他们创业的动力之后，他们接下来还要面对什么呢？这就是为客户提供进步的想法。


    What is even more impressive is that he understood how not to go about solving this downstream Customer Jobs. When he decided to offer a solution for customers to promote new businesses, he didn’t fall into the trap of simply packing more features into Product People Club. Instead, he created an entirely new product. Why? He knew these solutions each solved a different JTBD. Had he done things the other way, he would have risked losing Product People Club’s focus on the Job it should be used for.

    更令人印象深刻的是，他明白如何不着手解决下游的客户工作。当他决定为客户提供一个促进新业务的解决方案时，他并没有落入简单地将更多功能打包到 Product People Club 中的陷阱。相反，他创造了一个全新的产品。为什么？他知道这些解决方案各自解决了一个不同的 JTBD。如果他以另一种方式做事，他可能会失去产品人员俱乐部的工作重点，它应该用来。


    What’s the JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    Here are two quotes from Justin that I find most helpful when trying to understand customers’ JTBD:

    以下是 Justin 的两句话，我发现它们对理解客户的 JTBD 最有帮助:


    Having the right people to talk with helped eased their anxiety and raised their confidence. It’s that sense of community, friendship, relationship, and human connectedness.

    与合适的人交谈有助于缓解他们的焦虑，提高他们的信心。就是那种团结、友谊、关系和人际关系的感觉。


    Oh, finally! These are my people! These are people I can talk to about what it is like to have prelaunch stress!

    终于来了！他们是我的人！我可以和这些人谈谈发射前的压力是什么感觉！


    Justin describes some good JTBD data: he focuses on these solopreneurs’ struggles, and he describes how things will be better when they have the right solution. And when I take quotes like these and match them with the rest of the data Justin gave us, I see the struggle for progress as follows:

    贾斯汀描述了一些很好的 JTBD 数据: 他关注这些独立企业家的挣扎，并描述了如果他们有正确的解决方案，事情会变得更好。当我把这些引语和贾斯汀给我们的其他数据进行对比时，我看到了进步的挣扎:


    More about: loneliness and isolation of solopreneurship, sense of community and human connectedness, keeping your motivation up, not feeling like or being perceived as a poseur, “just do it,” I’ll have the confidence to persist in being an entrepreneur.

    更多关于: 独立创业的孤独和孤立，社区意识和人际关系，保持你的动力，不感觉或被认为是一个装腔作势的人，“只管去做”，我将有信心坚持成为一个企业家。


    Less about: attending a conference, taking a class on entrepreneurship, talking with a mentor.

    减少关于: 参加一个会议，参加一个关于企业家精神的课程，和一个导师交谈。


    With these data and the success of Justin’s Product People Club, I’d phrase one JTBD as follows:

    有了这些数据和 Justin 产品人员俱乐部的成功，我想把一个 JTBD 描述如下:


    Help me overcome the isolation and stress of solopreneurship, so I can have the motivation to finish my product.

    帮助我克服独立创业的孤立感和压力，这样我才有动力完成我的产品。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Justin’s case study is a brilliant example of discovering an innovation opportunity through sniffing out a struggling moment. Let’s see how it reinforces some other important JTBD lessons.

    贾斯汀的案例研究是一个通过嗅出挣扎时刻发现创新机会的绝佳例子。让我们看看它是如何强化其他一些重要的 JTBD 课程的。


    Innovation opportunities are found through looking for specific data. Justin realized he had a treasure trove of data only after he began to investigate innovation opportunities; however, he needed an effective way to filter it. He did

    创新机会是通过寻找具体的数据找到的。贾斯汀只是在开始调查创新机会之后才意识到他拥有一个数据宝库; 然而，他需要一个有效的方法来过滤它。是他干的


    this by asking himself questions: “What do people—unprompted—complain about?”; “What questions do entrepreneurs and innovators keep asking me over and over again?”; “What topics are talked about during Meetups about entrepreneurship?”

    通过问自己一些问题: “人们自发地抱怨什么?”“企业家和创新者一遍又一遍地问我什么问题?”“聚会期间讨论了哪些关于创业的话题?”


    Investigate your data for variations due to special causes. For instance, why are customers using a product other than intended? Or if customers have never complained about it before now, what’s going on? These are the types of questions that help you find innovation opportunities.

    调查你的数据因特殊原因而产生的变化。例如，为什么客户使用的产品不是预期的？或者，如果顾客以前从来没有抱怨过它，这是怎么回事？这些类型的问题可以帮助你找到创新的机会。


    Know the difference between a struggling customer and a merely inconvenienced customer. Don’t look for evidence of just a casual struggle; rather, look for people who were putting a lot of energy into finding a solution. In Justin’s case, the community he was tapped into was reaching out to him and one another for help. These people were actively looking for a solution to a problem.

    了解苦苦挣扎的客户和仅仅是不方便的客户之间的区别。不要只是寻找随意挣扎的证据，而是要找那些投入大量精力寻找解决方案的人。在贾斯汀的案例中，他所接触到的社区正在向他和其他人寻求帮助。这些人积极地寻找解决问题的方法。


    Perhaps the biggest challenge for an innovator is knowing how to determine if an innovation opportunity exists. It is critical to know the difference between a struggling customer and one who is merely inconvenienced. Aspiring entrepreneurs and innovators often move too quickly from observing a problem to hypothesizing a solution. Instead, be rigorous and look for true struggle. With the chotuKool, Godrej, Christensen, and Innosight jumped to a solution too quickly. Instead, they should have spent some time investigating if customers were really struggling and how intensely. But it turned out that there wasn’t enough of a struggle for customers to buy a low-end refrigerator.

    也许对创新者来说最大的挑战是知道如何确定是否存在创新机会。了解挣扎中的客户和仅仅是不方便的客户之间的区别是至关重要的。有抱负的企业家和创新者往往过快地从观察问题转向假设解决方案。相反，要严谨，寻找真正的奋斗。有了 chotuKool，Godrej，Christensen 和 Innosight 很快就找到了解决方案。相反，他们应该花些时间调查客户是否真的在苦苦挣扎，以及挣扎的程度有多深。但事实证明，对于消费者来说，购买一台低端冰箱的竞争还不够激烈。


    Great advertising comes from speaking to the customers’ struggling moment. The promotional page that Justin created for Product People Club was simple. It didn’t need lots of bells and whistles. All it had to do was to speak to the customers’ struggle and show them how things would be better once they found a solution for it—that is, once they were able to get the Job Done.
