Justin met these targets so well that he sold out his product in thirty minutes. By the end of the week, he had a waiting list of four hundred people.

    伟大的广告来自于对顾客苦苦挣扎的时刻的演讲。Justin 为 Product People Club 创建的促销页面很简单。不需要很多花里胡哨的东西。它所要做的就是向客户讲述他们的挣扎，告诉他们一旦他们找到了解决方案，事情会变得更好ーー也就是说，一旦他们能够完成工作。贾斯汀实现了这些目标，他的产品在三十分钟内就卖光了。到了周末，他的候补名单上已经有400人了。


    Digging deep into customer motivation reveals innovation opportunities. Don’t be satisfied with superficial facts about the customers’ struggle. Dig deep until you understand the struggle, its context(s), and how customers hope life will be better when they have a solution for their JTBD. You’ll see as you read on that a better understanding of the context of a struggle helps you understand how to grow your product.

    深入挖掘客户动机揭示创新机会。不要满足于关于顾客挣扎的肤浅事实。深入挖掘，直到你理解这场斗争，它的背景，以及当客户有了 JTBD 的解决方案时，他们是如何希望生活变得更好的。当你阅读的时候，你会发现更好地理解一场斗争的背景有助于你理解如何发展你的产品。


    Justin didn’t stop when he believed he had solved a struggle. Even when he had Product People Club up and running, he wanted to learn more about the struggle. As we’ve seen, he did this by asking a number of specific questions, and that helped him develop new features and grow his business through offering additional products.

    贾斯汀相信自己解决了一场斗争，但他没有停下来。甚至当他有了产品人员俱乐部和运行，他想了解更多的斗争。正如我们所看到的，他通过提出一些具体的问题来做到这一点，这些问题帮助他开发了新的特性，并通过提供额外的产品来发展他的业务。


    You can deliver progress to your customers’ JTBD by offering a set of products that work together as a system. Perhaps the most powerful JTBD principle is that the study of the customers’ JTBD is the study of a system. We’ll look into that more later, but for now, notice two things that Justin did: (1) he created a product (Marketing for Developers) that customers would buy after using a different product (Product People Club), and (2) he designed Marketing for Developers as a collection of videos, reading material, worksheets, and audio material. Justin’s combination of products works together to deliver customer progress. This is an important distinction of JTBD theory: it avoids the problem of unfocused “Swiss Army knife” products that try to solve too many Jobs.

    通过提供一组作为系统一起工作的产品，您可以向客户的 JTBD 交付进度。也许最强大的 JTBD 原则就是对客户 JTBD 的研究就是对系统的研究。我们将在后面进一步研究，但是现在，请注意贾斯汀做了两件事: (1)他创建了一个产品(开发者营销) ，客户使用不同的产品后会购买(产品人员俱乐部) ，和(2)他设计的开发者营销作为一个视频，阅读材料，工作表和音频材料的集合。贾斯汀的产品组合一起工作，以交付客户的进展。这是 JTBD 理论的一个重要区别: 它避免了试图解决太多就业问题的无重点的“瑞士军刀”产品的问题。

  9. Case Study: Ash and Lean Stack

    案例研究: 灰堆和瘦堆

    What’s the JTBD? Put it to work

    - JTBD 是什么?-让它发挥作用


    I met Ash Maurya at the 2013 Lean Startup Conference in San Francisco. As a presentation was about to start, I took a seat near the front of the room. Ash soon sat next to me, and we chatted a bit.

    我在旧金山举行的2013精益创业大会上遇到了 Ash Maurya。当演讲即将开始时，我在会议室前面的座位上坐了下来。阿什很快坐在我旁边，我们聊了一会儿。


    I learned a bit about his experience as an engineer and entrepreneur. In 2002, he had started WiredReach—a software product that simplified file sharing over the Internet. Eight years later, he sold it. He began blogging about his experiences starting and running a company, and he came across early writing from lean startup pioneers. This philosophy suggests that innovations should be designed in small, low-risk steps that are tested along the way. It struck a chord with Ash because a lot of its ideas about innovation matched his own experiences. Inspired, he self-published his first book, Running Lean (later republished by O’Reilly Media).

    我对他作为工程师和企业家的经历有了一些了解。2002年，他创办了 WiredReach，这是一款简化了互联网文件共享的软件产品。八年后，他把它卖了。他开始写博客，讲述自己创办和经营一家公司的经历，他偶然发现了一些精益创业先驱的早期作品。这种哲学认为，创新应该设计在小，低风险的步骤，并在这个过程中进行测试。这引起了阿什的共鸣，因为它的许多创新思想与他自己的经验相符。受到启发，他自助出版了他的第一本书《精益运作》(后来由奥赖利传媒重新出版)。


    Now he’s building another company: Spark 59. It offers a collection of books and tools for entrepreneurs. In June 2014, on a podcast, I heard him share his thoughts on Customer Jobs and how he had been combining it with lean business principles. I wanted to know more about Ash’s thoughts on Customer Jobs and if he had applied its principles to his most successful product, the Lean Canvas.

    现在他正在建立另一家公司: Spark 59。它为企业家提供了一系列的书籍和工具。2014年6月，在一个播客中，我听到他分享了他对客户工作的看法，以及他是如何将其与精益商业原则相结合的。我想知道更多关于 Ash 对客户工作的看法，以及他是否把这些原则应用到了他最成功的产品——精益帆布(Lean Canvas)上。


    Ash used Customer Jobs to help him learn about why customers were churning from his product, about how he could deliver customers more value with new products and services, and about the benefits of interviewing customers who use his product in novel ways.

    Ash 利用“客户工作”来帮助他了解为什么客户对他的产品感兴趣，他如何通过新的产品和服务为客户提供更多的价值，以及采访以新颖的方式使用他的产品的客户的好处。


    What is Ash’s latest product for getting a Job Done? Most recently, Ash has focused on helping entrepreneurs get started on the right track and avoid what he calls the “innovator’s bias.” He said,

    Ash 的最新产品是什么？最近，阿什致力于帮助企业家走上正确的道路，避免他所说的“创新者的偏见”他说,


    It’s when people get hit with an idea and then get carried away with it. They lock themselves up, and they start building the solution. They feel like they need to get it all out. They tend to be perfectionists. They spend a long time building a product, exhausting all their resources—and then end up building something no one wants.

    就是人们被一个想法击中，然后被它冲昏了头脑。他们把自己关起来，然后开始构建解决方案。他们觉得他们需要把一切都说出来。他们往往是完美主义者。他们花了很长时间开发一个产品，耗尽了所有的资源ーー最终却开发出了一些没有人想要的东西。


    Ash is describing a scenario that happens all too often: innovators think they have a brilliant idea for a product, they spend time and money building it, but when they

    Ash 描述了一个经常发生的场景: 创新者认为他们对一个产品有一个绝妙的想法，他们花费时间和金钱来构建它，但是当他们


    release it, no one buys it. At this point, they either give up or scramble to recover. Ash said, “Because [innovation is] such a long and hard process, many people also spend time trying to find the investors, or the stakeholders, that will give them the resources to continue building their product.”

    发行，没人买。在这一点上，他们要么放弃，要么争先恐后地恢复。阿什说: “因为(创新)是一个漫长而艰难的过程，许多人还花时间寻找投资者或利益相关者，让他们有资源继续开发自己的产品。”


    Ash helps innovators be more successful by helping them avoid the pitfalls associated with the innovator’s bias. A popular tool he has developed for this Job is the Lean Canvas. It’s a diagram you use instead of writing a long-winded business plan— most of which is speculative anyway. Instead, the Lean Canvas asks innovators to answer a set of important questions about how their businesses will deliver value to customers. They then go on to build the first version of their products.

    火山灰帮助创新者更加成功，帮助他们避免与创新者偏见相关的陷阱。一个流行的工具，他已经开发了这个工作是精益画布。这是一个图表，你可以用它来代替冗长的商业计划书ーー无论如何，其中大部分都是推测性的。相反，精益画布要求创新者回答一系列关于他们的企业如何为客户提供价值的重要问题。然后他们继续构建他们产品的第一个版本。


    Another problem that the Lean Canvas helps with is building consensus and a shared understanding around the business model for a product or company. But what about other struggles for progress? Has Ash found them all?

    精益画布帮助解决的另一个问题是围绕产品或公司的业务模型建立共识和共享理解。但是，其他争取进步的斗争又如何呢？Ash 都找到了吗？


    Can studying atypical customers reveal other innovation opportunities? Even though Ash had known about JTBD for a few years, he had never thought about applying any of its concepts to his own product, the Lean Canvas. This changed when he got an e-mail from Franco, a salmon fisher from Chile, who was having trouble using his site. Ash said, “We have the Lean Canvas as an online product. Every day, there are lots of people coming to the site and using it. When I read that e-mail from the salmon fisher, my first reaction was, ‘How the heck did he find us?’”

    研究非典型客户能否揭示其他创新机会？尽管 Ash 已经知道 JTBD 好几年了，但是他从来没有想过将 JTBD 的任何概念应用到他自己的产品 Lean Canvas 中。当他收到来自智利鲑鱼渔民 Franco 的电子邮件时，情况发生了变化，Franco 在使用他的网站时遇到了麻烦。Ash 说: “我们的精益画布是一个在线产品。每天都有很多人来到这个网站并使用它。当我读到这封来自鲑鱼渔夫的电子邮件时，我的第一反应是，‘他到底是怎么找到我们的?’？”


    Most of the customers who use the Lean Canvas come from the lean start-up community. Ash knew the product’s audience had been broadening, but a salmon fisher from Chile was a dramatic outlier. This is the moment when Ash thought that a Customer Jobs approach could be helpful to him. Ash set up a call with Franco, asking him to describe what made navigating the Lean Canvas website difficult for him.

    大多数使用精益画布的客户来自精益创业社区。Ash 知道这个产品的受众正在扩大，但是一个来自智利的鲑鱼渔夫是一个戏剧性的例外。这是阿什认为客户工作方法可能对他有帮助的时刻。Ash 给 Franco 打了个电话，问他是什么让他在 Lean Canvas 网站上导航变得困难。


    He was lost. At the time, the website assumed customers knew about the lean start-up community. He didn’t know anything about that. Instead, he told me that he had been at a networking event a few nights before. He was talking about wanting to get a loan from the bank for his business. He thought he had to put together a business plan for the bank. The person he was talking with said, “Don’t bother writing a whole business plan. Instead, go to leancanvas.com and create a one-page version of it.”

    他迷路了。当时，该网站假设客户知道精益创业社区。他对此一无所知。相反，他告诉我，几天前的晚上他参加了一个社交活动。他说想从银行贷款做生意。他认为他必须为银行制定一个商业计划。和他谈话的人说: “不用费心写一整个商业计划书了。相反，你可以访问 leancanvas 网站，创建一个单页版本。”


    Ash began to understand Franco’s struggle: Franco wasn’t sure how to convince the bank that his business would be profitable and that it was safe for the bank to invest in him. This proved to be a tremendous insight for Ash and his team—but not the way you might think. The value wasn’t so much in that Ash had discovered a new Job; rather, it made him revisit a question that had lingered in the back of his mind: “Are we sure we know why people are coming to our website and trying out the Lean Canvas?”

    阿什开始理解弗兰科的挣扎: 弗兰科不知道如何说服银行相信他的业务会盈利，而且银行对他的投资是安全的。事实证明，这对阿什和他的团队来说是一个了不起的洞察力ーー但不是你可能想象的那样。价值并不在于阿什发现了一个新职业，而是让他重新思考了一个在脑海中挥之不去的问题: “我们确定我们知道为什么人们会来我们的网站尝试精益画布吗?”


    You can gather JTBD data from customers who stop using your product. Ash and his team decided to do a new round of customer interviews to discover what Jobs customers were using the Lean Canvas for. They would talk with those who had recently signed up and those who had canceled their subscriptions.

    您可以从停止使用您的产品的客户那里收集 JTBD 数据。Ash 和他的团队决定进行新一轮的客户访谈，以了解乔布斯的客户使用 Lean Canvas 的目的。他们会与那些最近注册的人和那些取消订阅的人交谈。


    They wanted to know the emotional motivations and expectations of the first group, and the second group’s answers would help the team learn how, or if, the Lean Canvas was failing to make customers’ lives better in the way they expected it to.

    他们想知道第一组人的情绪动机和期望，第二组人的答案将帮助团队了解精益画布是如何，或者是否未能以他们期望的方式让客户生活得更好。


    Ash crafted two e-mails. One was a thank-you to new subscribers, and it also conveyed that Ash’s team wanted to hear more about what they hoped to achieve with the Lean Canvas. The message to those who had canceled offered an Amazon.com gift card in exchange for a conversation about why they had canceled. Though Ash got valuable information from both groups, the most useful was from those who had canceled:

    Ash 伪造了两封邮件。其中一个是对新订阅者的感谢，同时也传达了 Ash 的团队想要听到更多关于他们希望通过精益画布实现的东西。这条信息是发给那些取消预约的人的，他们提供了一张亚马逊网站的礼品卡，以换取一段关于他们为什么取消预约的对话。虽然 Ash 从两个组织都得到了有价值的信息，但最有用的是那些取消了会议的人:


    One unexpected thing that we learned was that customers weren’t leaving because we were doing a bad job. They were actually leaving because they felt like they had been satisfied. They had created their initial business model. They had, in some cases, invalidated it and moved on. They didn’t really see any other purpose to stick around and continue using the Lean Canvas.

    我们意想不到的是，顾客并没有因为我们的工作不好而离开。实际上，他们离开是因为他们觉得自己已经满足了。他们已经建立了最初的商业模式。在某些情况下，他们宣布该法案无效，然后继续前进。他们真的没有看到任何其他目的留下来继续使用精益画布。


    It appeared that the Lean Canvas was, in a way, a victim of its own success. Innovators would sign up to use the Lean Canvas, get a lot of value from it, and then move on. But that wasn’t how Ash had envisioned the product. The Lean Canvas had been designed for long-term use, but clearly, many customers saw it as a short-term product. What should Ash and his team do? Should they accept a moderate churn rate for customers?

    在某种程度上，瘦帆布似乎是它自身成功的受害者。创新者会签约使用精益画布，从中获得很多价值，然后继续前进。但是这并不是阿什设想的产品。精益帆布是为长期使用而设计的，但很明显，许多客户将其视为短期产品。Ash 和他的团队该怎么做？他们是否应该接受适度的客户流失率？


    You may discover that your product is being used for very different Jobs.

    您可能会发现，您的产品正在用于非常不同的工作

    If Ash and his team wanted to keep their customers, they needed a better picture

    如果 Ash 和他的团队想留住他们的客户，他们需要一张更好的照片


    of what Job(s) they were hiring the Lean Canvas for. More interviews brought insight.

    他们雇用精益帆布的原因。更多的面试带来了洞察力。


    One group of customers took the Lean Canvas as a starting point and then began integrating it into their own product-development processes, altering the Lean Canvas to connect to things like bug-tracking systems and company documentation. Ash found this particularly interesting. He had designed the Lean Canvas as a tool for entrepreneurs to develop business models for start-ups. Yet these particular customers were using the Lean Canvas to help them design features for an existing product.

    一组客户以精益画布为起点，然后开始将其集成到他们自己的产品开发过程中，改变精益画布以连接到诸如 bug 跟踪系统和公司文档之类的东西。Ash 觉得这个特别有趣。他设计了“精益画布”(Lean Canvas) ，作为企业家为初创企业开发商业模式的工具。然而，这些特殊的客户正在使用精益画布来帮助他们为现有产品设计特性。


    Ash and his team were at a turning point. Which opportunity would they pursue? Should they address the high churn among the original audience (entrepreneurs)? Or should they extend the Lean Canvas to include customers who were using the Lean Canvas in novel ways?

    Ash 和他的团队正处于一个转折点。他们会追求什么样的机会？他们是否应该解决原始观众(企业家)中的高流失问题？或者他们应该扩展精益画布，以包括那些以新颖的方式使用精益画布的客户？


    Narrowing what Job(s) your product should be used for has benefits. After some discussion with this team, Ash decided to focus on their core audience: innovators who needed help creating and iterating on a business model.

    缩小您的产品应该用于哪些工作的范围是有好处的。在与这个团队进行了一些讨论后，Ash 决定把重点放在他们的核心受众上: 那些需要帮助来创造和迭代商业模式的创新者。


    Our audience was already broadening on one end [more entrepreneurs were using the Lean Canvas], and if we went down that path of extending the Lean Canvas in all these ways [supporting corporations], we’d be catering to smaller segments. That is the point where you have to decide where your product starts and stops. For us, we said, “That’s out of scope. If they want to do those kinds of things, there are many other options.” We’re not going to bloat our software with extra features. Instead, we decided to focus on what we do best.

    我们的受众已经在一端扩大(更多的企业家正在使用精益画布) ，如果我们沿着这条道路扩展精益画布，以所有这些方式(支持企业) ，我们将迎合更小的细分市场。这就是你必须决定你的产品在哪里开始和结束的时候。对我们来说，我们说，“这是范围之外。如果他们想做这些事情，还有很多其它选择。”我们不会用额外的功能来膨胀我们的软件。相反，我们决定专注于我们最擅长的事情。


    Ash is doing something important here. Instead of trying to grow revenue by serving many different Jobs, he’s choosing to focus on the few Jobs that he and his team can deliver the most value for. Instead of turning the Lean Canvas into a Swiss Army knife—a tool that does a lot of things OK but not any one thing great—he was going to evolve it into a scalpel—a specialized tool that is invaluable for a select group of people. The decision was made. Now it was time to figure out exactly how to grow the business.

    Ash 在这里做一些重要的事情。他没有试图通过为许多不同的乔布斯提供服务来增加收入，而是选择专注于他和他的团队能够提供最大价值的为数不多的几个乔布斯。他没有把“瘦帆布”变成一把瑞士军刀(一种可以做很多事情，但不是任何一件伟大事情的工具) ，而是把它改造成一把手术刀(一种专门的工具，对特定的一群人来说是无价之宝)。已经决定了。现在是时候弄清楚如何发展业务了。


    How does thinking about delivering progress help you discover innovation opportunities? To figure out where to take his business next, Ash asked a simple but powerful question:

    思考如何交付进步帮助你发现创新机会？为了弄清楚下一步该把生意做到哪里，阿什提出了一个简单而有力的问题:


    To help us figure out what path to take, we asked ourselves, “What comes after that initial canvas?” Our answer was to develop two additional boards that would be used with the Lean Canvas. We wanted to extend the customer’s story in a way that emphasized more than just capturing your idea for a start-up. It’s really about creating a valid business model through experimentation and research.

    为了帮助我们找到走哪条路，我们问自己，“在最初的画布之后是什么?”我们的答案是开发两个额外的董事会，将与精益画布使用。我们希望扩展客户的故事，强调不仅仅是捕捉你的创业点子。它实际上是通过实验和研究创建一个有效的商业模式。


    Once again, Ash is doing something very smart here. His team had a question: “How can we increase revenue by getting customers to use the Lean Canvas longer (i.e., reduce churn)?” Many innovators in this position would be tempted to make changes to their existing product, usually by adding more features. But Ash didn’t do that. The Lean Canvas was great the way it was. Changing it would waste time and money in overengineering a solution and risk upsetting the habits of existing customers.

    又一次，阿什做了一件非常聪明的事。他的团队有一个问题: “我们如何通过让客户更长时间地使用精益画布来增加收入(即，减少流失) ?”许多处于这个位置的创新者会试图改变他们现有的产品，通常是通过增加更多的功能。但是 Ash 没有这么做。精益帆布的方式是伟大的。改变它将浪费时间和金钱过度设计一个解决方案，并有可能打乱现有客户的习惯。


    Instead, he made his original product more valuable to customers—not by changing it but by developing new, complementary products. This is when he developed two more boards: an Experiment Report and a Validation Plan. In this new vision, entrepreneurs would first hypothesize and document their business models using the Lean Canvas. Next, they would formulate a strategy for validating their hypotheses, using Ash’s Validation Plan to structure and document that. Then, they could run experiments that would either validate or invalidate parts of that business model; the results of these experiments would be documented on the Experiment Report. Finally, they would update the Lean Canvas and form new hypotheses as needed.

    相反，他让自己的原始产品对客户更有价值ーー不是通过改变产品，而是通过开发新的补充产品。这时他又开发了两个板子: 一个实验报告和一个验证计划。在这个新的愿景中，企业家们将首先使用精益画布来假设和记录他们的商业模式。接下来，他们将制定一个策略来验证他们的假设，使用 Ash 的验证计划来构建和记录。然后，他们可以进行实验，验证或失效的部分业务模式; 这些实验的结果将文件化的实验报告。最后，他们将更新精益画布，并根据需要形成新的假设。


    Ash both helped his customers be more successful and kept them using his products longer by extending his business with additional products. Customers stopped seeing the Lean Canvas as an end but rather as an ongoing companion.

    Ash 帮助他的客户获得更大的成功，并通过增加产品来扩展他的业务，使他们使用他的产品的时间更长。客户不再将精益画布视为终点，而是将其视为一个持续的伙伴。


    Shift from selling one product to selling a combination of products that work together as a system. Now that Ash had added complementary products, he decided to rebrand his business. The Lean Canvas became the Lean Stack. This change represented the extended value that Ash’s business now offered.

    从销售一种产品转向销售作为一个系统协同工作的产品组合。既然阿什已经添加了补充产品，他决定重塑自己的企业品牌。精益画布变成了精益堆栈。这种变化代表了 Ash 的业务现在提供的扩展价值。


    In the beginning, there was the Lean Canvas and the various Jobs that people hired it for, such as the following:

    起初，有精益画布和各种各样的工作，人们雇用它，如下:


    Cofounders starting companies use the Lean Canvas’s structured approach to help them overcome doubt and uncertainty.

    创业公司的联合创始人使用精益画布的结构化方法来帮助他们克服疑虑和不确定性。


    Entrepreneurs use it to avoid the mistake of wasting time and money building a product no one wants.

    企业家们用它来避免浪费时间和金钱去创造一个没有人想要的产品。


    Some entrepreneurs, like Franco the salmon fisher, want help “selling” themselves and their businesses as investment opportunities.

    一些企业家，比如三文鱼渔夫弗兰科，希望有人帮助他们“出售”自己和他们的企业作为投资机会。


    The Lean Canvas is brilliant at these Jobs. The downside is that not a lot of people experience them, and there is a lot of competition among solutions for these Jobs. This means that the Lean Canvas, by itself, had limited growth potential. But Ash extended his business by serving up a collection of products that work together, as a system, to help customers make progress. This was how he was able to activate much more revenue potential. He said,

    精益帆布在这些工作方面非常出色。缺点是没有多少人体验过这些工作，而且这些工作的解决方案之间存在很大的竞争。这意味着“精益画布”本身的增长潜力有限。但阿什扩大了他的业务，提供了一系列的产品，作为一个系统，一起工作，以帮助客户取得进展。这就是他如何能够激活更多的收入潜力。他说,


    Going back to the salmon fisher, yes, he will create a canvas, but what if he wants to raise money afterward? We could help him down a particular path. We might actually show him how to pitch the canvas to investors. There could be additional products that tie him together with people who can look at his pitch and maybe help him raise money. We’re even developing features that help entrepreneurs run effective board and adviser meetings.

    回到三文鱼渔夫，是的，他会创造一个画布，但如果他想筹集资金以后呢？我们可以帮助他走上一条特定的道路。我们可以教他如何向投资者推销。可能会有额外的产品把他和那些可以看到他的推销的人联系在一起，也许可以帮助他筹集资金。我们甚至正在开发一些功能，帮助企业家管理有效的董事会和顾问会议。


    Ash’s switch from the Lean Canvas to the Lean Stack puts him in a better position to help his customers with a larger JTBD: Help me become a better and more successful entrepreneur.

    Ash 从 Lean Canvas 到 Lean Stack 的转变使他处于一个更好的位置来帮助他的客户更大的 JTBD: 帮助我成为一个更好更成功的企业家。


    What is the future of Lean Stack? Ash continues to help entrepreneurs become successful. He is in the process of releasing his next book, Scaling Lean—a followup to Running Lean. He’s also just released his BOOTSTART Manifesto—a rallying call for entrepreneurs, reminding them that there has never been a better time to start one’s own business.

    精益堆栈的未来是什么？火山灰继续帮助企业家成功。他正准备出版他的下一本书《精益生产》(Scaling Lean) ，这是《精益生产》的续集。他还刚刚发布了自己的“启动创业宣言”(BOOTSTART Manifesto)ーー这是对企业家的号召，提醒他们，现在是创业的最佳时机。


    For the Lean Stack itself, Ash is looking at more Jobs that entrepreneurs struggle with:

    对于 Lean Stack 本身，Ash 正在寻找更多企业家难以找到的工作:


    We’ve learned about many different struggles that people face: starting projects, big companies sustaining innovation, and even release management. As a result, we’ve discovered many different Jobs. We want to continue to learn more about those Jobs and decide which ones we’d like to help customers accomplish.

    我们已经了解了人们面临的许多不同的困难: 启动项目，大公司维持创新，甚至发布管理。因此，我们发现了许多不同的工作。我们希望继续了解更多关于这些工作的信息，并决定我们希望帮助客户完成哪些工作。


    What’s the JTBD?

    JTBD 是什么？

    Ash’s case study doesn’t offer much data about one JTBD. Instead, it offers a lot of data about delivering progress for a higher-level struggle. You become better at seeing the big picture when understanding the high-level progress your customers are struggling to make. In Ash’s case, his customers are struggling to become successful entrepreneurs. Along the way, however, they run into various challenges. A good example comes from the salmon fisher who wanted help persuading bankers that his business was worth investing in. Once he secured financing, he could get back to growing his business.

    Ash 的案例研究没有提供太多关于 JTBD 的数据。相反，它提供了大量关于为更高层次的斗争取得进展的数据。当你理解你的客户正在努力取得的高层次的进步时，你会变得更善于看到全局。在阿什的例子中，他的客户正在努力成为成功的企业家。然而，在这个过程中，他们遇到了各种各样的挑战。一个很好的例子来自一位鲑鱼渔夫，他希望得到帮助，说服银行家相信自己的业务值得投资。一旦他获得了融资，他就可以重新开始发展自己的生意。


    Ash’s case study is also interesting because he understood that his Lean Canvas was great at helping people get their Jobs Done. So, instead of trying to make it better— which would most likely only make it worse—he focused on future products. He chose to offer progress with a collection of products that work together as a system:

    Ash 的案例研究也很有趣，因为他知道他的精益画布在帮助人们完成他们的工作方面做得很好。因此，他没有试图改善现状(这很可能只会让情况变得更糟) ，而是把重点放在了未来的产品上。他选择通过一系列产品提供进展，这些产品作为一个系统协同工作:


    Tools: Lean Canvas, Validation Plan, Experiment Report. Books: Running Lean, Scaling Lean.

    工具: 精益画布，验证计划，实验报告。书籍: 运行精益，缩放精益。

    Training: Online courses, workshops, boot camps.

    培训: 在线课程，研讨会，新兵训练营。


    Each product is serving one or more Jobs to be Done. Collectively, they work together to help people become better entrepreneurs.

    每个产品都服务于一个或多个待完成的工作。他们共同努力，帮助人们成为更好的企业家。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Ash’s Lean Canvas (now Lean Stack) is a great finale for our case studies on applying Customer Jobs theory. Let’s review some specific lessons.

    Ash’s Lean Canvas (现在的 Lean Stack)是我们应用客户工作理论的案例研究的一个很好的结尾。让我们复习一些具体的课程。


    Grow your business, reduce churn, and capture more profits by delivering progress to customers. Nowhere is the Customer Job principle of favoring progress over outcomes and goals clearer than in this case study. Ash began his business by delivering well-defined, static outcomes: better business plans and/or consensus among founders. The Lean Canvas does these tasks beautifully—so well, in fact, that some customers don’t need to use the Lean Canvas for long. In this way, the Lean Canvas was a victim of its own success.

    通过向客户提供进展来增长你的业务，减少流失，并获得更多的利润。没有什么地方比这个案例研究更清楚地表明了客户工作的原则，即优先于结果和目标的进展。Ash 通过交付定义良好的静态结果开始了他的事业: 更好的商业计划和/或创始人之间的共识。Lean Canvas 完美地完成了这些任务ーー事实上，它做得非常好，以至于一些客户不需要长时间使用 Lean Canvas。在这方面，精益画布是其自身成功的受害者。


    Ash fixed his high-churn problem by changing his business from one that delivered a static outcome to one that delivers progress. Instead of solely focusing on helping

    Ash 通过将他的业务从一个交付静态结果的业务转变为一个交付进步的业务，解决了他的高流量问题。而不是仅仅专注于帮助别人


    customers create better business plans, he also began helping them become better entrepreneurs. This strategy creates more touch points between his business and his customers’ lives, making it more relevant and valuable to them.

    客户创造更好的商业计划，他也开始帮助他们成为更好的企业家。这种策略在他的业务和客户的生活之间创造了更多的接触点，使之对他们来说更加相关和有价值。


    When you design a product for a specific outcome, customers leave when the outcome is realized. However, improving a customer’s life never ends. As long as Ash helps customers become better entrepreneurs, he’ll retain them.

    当您为特定的结果设计产品时，当结果实现时，客户就会离开。然而，改善客户的生活永远不会结束。只要 Ash 帮助客户成为更好的企业家，他就会留住他们。


    Avoid overengineering your product; develop complementary products. If you sell a software product, offer different versions of it that tailor to different vectors of progress. Ash made a brilliant move that far too few innovators do: he made the Lean Canvas more valuable to customers not by changing the product but by adding complementary ones. Ash knew that the Lean Canvas was great the way it was, so changing it would neither make it more valuable to customers nor bring any new ones to his business. At best, nothing would improve; at worst, time and money would be lost in development, and the changes would upset existing customers.

    避免过度设计你的产品; 开发互补产品。如果你销售一个软件产品，提供不同版本的产品，以适应不同的发展方向。Ash 做了一个很少有创新者做到的明智之举: 他不是通过改变产品，而是通过增加补充产品，使精益帆布对客户更有价值。阿什知道精益帆布是伟大的方式，因此改变它既不会使它更有价值的客户，也没有带来任何新的业务。在最好的情况下，什么都不会改善; 在最坏的情况下，时间和金钱将在开发中流失，而且这些变化将使现有客户感到不安。


    As I keep pointing out (it’s important), adding features to a product doesn’t mean customers will realize more value from it. Remember when we discussed that a technology and innovation can be pushed only so far and deliver customers a finite amount of progress. This is because customers realize value only when they make progress with your product. Unless you can directly connect a change to your product with how it helps make customers’ lives better, you’re likely overengineering your product and wasting money.

    正如我一直指出的(这很重要) ，向产品中添加功能并不意味着客户会从中获得更多价值。还记得我们曾经讨论过，技术和创新只能推进到一定程度，并且只能给客户带来有限的进步。这是因为客户只有在他们的产品取得进展的时候才会意识到价值。除非你可以直接将产品的变化与它如何帮助客户生活得更好联系起来，否则你很可能过度设计你的产品并且浪费金钱。


    Unlock your innovation creativity by asking, “What comes after?” This is a question every innovator should ask about his or her innovations. After your customers use your product, then what? Do any new challenges arise when customers successfully incorporate your innovation into their lives? Learning these things from your customers will keep your innovation efforts relevant and profitable.

    通过询问“接下来会发生什么?”来释放你的创新创造力这是每个创新者都应该问自己的创新问题。当你的客户使用你的产品后，然后呢？当客户成功地将你的创新融入他们的生活时，是否会出现新的挑战？从你的客户那里学习这些东西将使你的创新努力保持相关性和盈利性。

  10. The System of Progress

    进步系统

    Why study systems and the system of progress?

    为什么要研究系统和进步系统？

    The interdependencies between customer demand and the producer The system’s four main parts

    客户需求与生产者之间的相互依存关系系统的四个主要部分

    The forces of progress that power the system of progress The system of progress is continuous

    推动进步系统的进步力量进步系统是连续的

    Is the system of progress new? Put it to work

    进步系统是新的吗? 让它发挥作用


    As I’ve noted, a customer’s JTBD is part of a system. We call it the system of progress. Customers themselves, the products they buy, and the producers who create the products are all parts of this system. Understanding this is very important. It will help you find out what customers want, why they want changes, the relationship between customer motivation and the solutions they choose, and how demand is generated.

    如前所述，客户的 JTBD 是系统的一部分。我们称之为进步系统。客户本身、他们购买的产品以及创造产品的生产者都是这个系统的组成部分。理解这一点非常重要。它将帮助您了解客户想要什么，为什么他们想要改变，客户动机和他们选择的解决方案之间的关系，以及需求是如何产生的。


    Why Study Systems and The System of Progress?

    为什么是学习系统和进步系统？

    Systems thinking empowered the managers, designers, and engineers of Japan to create successful products that transformed the country from economic ruin to a global powerhouse. In the 1980s, equivalent teams at Ford Motor Company adopted systems thinking, thereby reviving the company, and created one of the most successful cars of all time: the Ford Taurus. Anyone who views innovation and customer motivation through the lens of systems thinking will gain a better understanding of how great products are created and sold.51

    系统思维赋予日本的管理者、设计者和工程师创造成功产品的能力，使日本从经济崩溃转变为全球强国。上世纪80年代，福特汽车公司(Ford Motor Company)的相应团队采用了系统思维，从而重振了公司，并创造了有史以来最成功的汽车之一: 福特金牛座(Ford Taurus)。任何通过系统思维的视角来看待创新和客户动机的人，都会更好地理解伟大的产品是如何创造和销售的。51


    Interdependence defines a system. An important principle of systems is the idea that many, and perhaps all, parts have some degree of connectedness with each other. Something happening over “here” affects something way over “there.” This connectedness is called interdependence.

    相互依赖定义了一个系统。系统的一个重要原则是，许多部分，也许是所有部分，彼此之间有某种程度的连通性。“这里”发生的事情会影响到“那里”的某些事情这种联系被称为相互依赖。


    An example of interdependence is what happened when farmers within the United States began spraying DDT—an insecticide—on their crops. Unknown at the time, DDT would get washed off crops and into rivers, fish would swallow it, birds ate the fish, the chemical caused these birds to lay eggs with weak shells, and weak shells prevented baby birds from hatching. The result was a decline in the populations of bald eagles, peregrine falcons, and brown pelicans.52

    相互依存的一个例子是，当美国农民开始向他们的作物喷洒杀虫剂 DDT 时发生的情况。当时还不知道，滴滴涕会从农作物上冲到河里，鱼会把它吞下去，鸟会吃掉鱼，这种化学物质会使这些鸟产下外壳薄弱的蛋，而外壳薄弱的蛋会阻止小鸟孵化。结果是秃鹰、游隼和褐鹈鹕的数量减少了。52


    Studying interdependencies is an important part of innovation and JTBD. For example, Dan Martell recognized that Clarity was taking away profits from hotels, restaurants, and airlines. Anthony Francavilla realized that a theater production could increase profits by selectively offering discounts. Morgan Ranieri realized that he could reduce churn not by changing how his grocery-delivery service worked but by helping customers become better meal planners.

    研究相互依存关系是创新和 JTBD 的重要组成部分。例如，丹•马特尔(Dan Martell)意识到 Clarity 正在从酒店、餐馆和航空公司那里攫取利润。安东尼 · 弗兰卡维拉意识到剧院制作可以通过有选择地提供折扣来增加利润。摩根拉涅利意识到，他可以通过帮助顾客成为更好的膳食计划者，而不是通过改变食品杂货配送服务的工作方式来减少流失。


    The system of progress is a way to understand the interdependencies between customers, their JTBD, and the producer. Once innovators understand the interdependencies that exist between the various parts of a system of progress, they can inform the producer—who may also be the innovator—how to create and sell solutions for today’s demand and to predict future demand.

    进度系统是理解客户、其 JTBD 和生产者之间相互依赖关系的一种方法。一旦创新者理解了进步系统各部分之间存在的相互依赖关系，他们就可以告诉生产者ーー也可能是创新者ーー如何为当前的需求创造和销售解决方案，并预测未来的需求。


    You do not help customers make progress by optimizing parts of the system of progress individually. You improve the system by optimizing how those parts work together. For example, a mediocre product that customers know about, can buy, and can use will beat out a perfect product that customers don’t know about, can’t buy, or can’t use.

    你不能通过单独优化进步系统的各个部分来帮助客户取得进步。您可以通过优化这些部分的协同工作来改进系统。例如，一个普通的产品，客户知道，可以购买，可以使用，将击败一个完美的产品，客户不知道，不能购买，或不能使用。


    Interdependencies Between Customers and Producers

    顾客与生产者之间的相互依赖

    The two most important interdependencies within the system of progress are between customer demand and the producer.

    进度系统中两个最重要的相互依赖关系是客户需求和生产者之间的相互依赖关系。


    The first thing to notice in this diagram (figure 18) is that the system is split into hemispheres. The two parts in the top hemisphere describe customer demand as a JTBD, whereas the two parts in the bottom describe the producer interacting with that demand.

    在这个图(图18)中首先要注意的是，系统被分成了两个半球。上半球的两个部分将客户需求描述为 JTBD，而下半球的两个部分将生产者与需求相互作用描述为 JTBD。


    The top parts of the system exist in the mind of the customer, who is the only person who can define their struggle to transform their existing life-situation into a preferred one. Yes, the producer can influence these two parts (as I’ll discuss later in the chapter), but innovators cannot define the JTBD. Innovators may introduce new ways of living to customers, but it doesn’t mean customers will accept them.

    系统的最高部分存在于客户的头脑中，客户是唯一能够定义他们的斗争，将他们现有的生活状况转变为首选的人。是的，生产者可以影响这两个部分(我将在本章后面讨论) ，但是创新者不能定义 JTBD。创新者可能会向消费者介绍新的生活方式，但这并不意味着消费者会接受它们。




    Figure 18. The System of Progress.

    图18进步系统



    The bottom parts of the system describe the interdependencies between the customer and the producer. Yes, customers act when they search for, choose, and use a product, but these actions are possible only when producers can create and meet demand, and helps customers evolve themselves.

    系统的底部描述了客户和生产者之间的相互依赖关系。是的，客户在搜索、选择和使用产品时会采取行动，但只有当生产者能够创造和满足需求，并帮助客户自我发展时，这些行动才有可能实现。


    The System’s Four Main Parts

    系统的四个主要部分

    The customer imagines a better life-salutation (a new me). It all begins with the idea of a new me. Customers can be attracted to a new me because it offers them an opportunity to get away from something they don’t like, or because it offers them an opportunity to grow in a new way. In terms of the forces of progress, these are respectively the push and pull forces. The JTBD arises when customers realize they don’t have what it takes to make that new me happen on their own.

    顾客想象一个更好的人生称呼(一个全新的我)。一切都始于一个全新的我。客户会被一个全新的我所吸引，因为这给了他们一个机会，让他们远离他们不喜欢的东西，或者因为这给了他们一个机会，让他们以一种新的方式成长。就进步的力量而言，它们分别是推力和拉力。当客户意识到他们没有能力让新的我自己发生时，JTBD 就出现了。


    Your responsibility as an innovator, advertiser, or marketer is to understand this desire for change. How, when, and why did customers realize that they needed to change? If they are struggling, why today but weren’t last month? Was there a change in what they valued? Was there a change in lifestyle? What was wrong with the solution they had been using up to that point?

    作为创新者、广告商或营销人员，你的责任就是理解这种改变的愿望。客户是如何、何时以及为什么意识到他们需要改变的？如果他们正在苦苦挣扎，为什么今天没有，而上个月没有呢？他们的价值观有变化吗？生活方式有变化吗？到目前为止他们使用的解决方案有什么问题吗？


    The customer searches for and chooses a solution. After customers believe there is an opportunity to change, they need to search for and choose a solution for their JTBD. This is where producers—businesses that make and sell products—first make contact with prospective customers.

    客户搜索并选择解决方案。在客户相信有机会改变之后，他们需要为他们的 JTBD 寻找并选择一个解决方案。这是生产商ーー生产和销售产品的企业ーー首先与潜在客户接触的地方。


    This part of the system is also where the richest data about customers’ JTBD are found. Why? (1) Customers have their idea of a new me at the top of mind, (2) they are working hard to imagine how life will be better when they can find the correct solution, (3) they visualize themselves using various solutions, and (4) they calculate how or if a solution will carry them from how they are today to the better me they want.

    系统的这一部分也是关于客户 JTBD 数据最丰富的地方。为什么？(1)客户头脑中有一个全新的我的想法; (2)他们努力想象当他们找到正确的解决方案时，生活会变得更好; (3)他们用各种各样的解决方案来形象化自己; (4)他们计算出一个解决方案如何或是否能把他们从今天的样子带到他们想要的更好的我。


    For innovators, data at this part reveal what customers value in a solution and the priority of their values. For example, are parents willing to accept lower quality food if it makes shopping more convenient? For advertisers and marketers, these data help them know when, where, and how the producer should connect with customers. Then, advertisers and marketers are responsible for helping customers become aware of and choose the product.

    对于创新者来说，这一部分的数据揭示了客户在解决方案中的价值以及他们价值观的优先级。例如，父母是否愿意接受低质量的食物，如果它使购物更方便？对于广告商和营销人员来说，这些数据有助于他们了解生产商应该在何时、何地以及如何与客户建立联系。然后，广告商和营销人员负责帮助客户了解和选择产品。


    Your goal regarding this part of the system should be to understand why customers are searching for and buying a solution now instead of a month ago. How did customers find and choose (hire) a solution for their desire to change? What were their hiring criteria? What trade-offs are they willing to make—that is, what are they willing to give up, and what are they not willing to give up? Did they try anything else besides the solution they ended up with? Why didn’t those other solutions work?53

    关于系统的这一部分，您的目标应该是理解客户为什么现在而不是一个月前搜索和购买解决方案。客户是如何找到并选择(雇佣)一个解决方案来满足他们的改变欲望的？他们的招聘标准是什么？他们愿意做出什么样的权衡ーー也就是说，他们愿意放弃什么，不愿意放弃什么？除了最后的解决方案，他们还做了其他尝试吗？为什么其他的解决方案不起作用？53


    The customer uses a solution to start making progress. Customers have designed a new me in their mind and have chosen a solution. Now it is time to think about how customers use the solution.

    客户使用解决方案开始取得进展。客户在他们的头脑中设计了一个全新的我，并选择了一个解决方案。现在是考虑客户如何使用解决方案的时候了。


    This is the part where engineers and designers take over from advertisers and marketers and create product(s) for customers to use. They must apply their understanding of the customers’ desire to change (the customer’s Job), what customers value in a solution, and how customers expect to make their lives better

    这是工程师和设计师从广告商和营销人员手中接管的部分，他们为客户创造产品供他们使用。他们必须应用他们对客户的改变欲望(客户的工作)的理解，客户在解决方案中的价值，以及客户期望如何使他们的生活更好




    Figure 19. The forces of progress increase or decrease how quickly the customer moves through the system.

    图19. 进度的力量增加或减少客户在系统中移动的速度


    once they incorporate that product into their lives. After a solution is created, the producer should continue to monitor—and possibly improve—that solution by studying how customers use it.

    一旦他们把那个产品融入他们的生活。在创建了解决方案之后，生产者应该通过研究客户如何使用该解决方案来继续监视(甚至可能改进)该解决方案。


    Gather data at this stage. How do customers use the solution they’ve chosen (even if it’s a solution created by another producer)? Are they using all of it or just parts of it? Are they using it in ways other than what it was designed for? Do they need to combine it with other solutions to get the effect they want?

    在此阶段收集数据。客户如何使用他们选择的解决方案(即使它是由另一个生产商创建的解决方案) ？他们是全部还是只用了一部分？他们有没有用其他的方式来使用它？他们是否需要将其与其他解决方案结合起来以获得他们想要的效果？


    The customer realizes a new me. Finally, customers realize that new me they’ve imagined all this time—or they don’t. When they do, their Job is Done. If those better lives don’t happen, they continue to struggle. They might be forced to combine your product with others to gain the desired effect, or they might put up with your product until something better comes along.

    顾客认识到一个全新的我。最终，顾客们意识到他们一直以来想象的全新的我ーー或者他们并没有。当他们这样做时，他们的工作就完成了。如果那些更好的生活没有发生，他们将继续挣扎。他们可能会被迫把你的产品和其他产品结合起来以获得预期的效果，或者他们可能会忍受你的产品直到有更好的产品出现。


    The Forces of Progress That Power the System Of Progress

    推动进步系统的进步力量

    Another interdependency part to the system of progress consists of the forces of progress that customers experience as they move through the systems they belong to. These forces are the engine that speed up—or slow down—customers as they move through the system of progress. They are represented by the dotted lines in our diagram (figure 19).

    进展系统的另一个相互依赖部分包括客户在其所属系统中移动时所体验到的进展力量。这些力量是客户在整个进步体系中加速(或减速)的引擎。它们由图中的虚线表示(图19)。




    Figure 20. When customers make progress (get a job done), new aspirations are often revealed.

    图20。当客户取得进展(完成一项工作) ，新的愿望往往会显现出来


    The System of Progress Is Continuous

    进步系统是连续的

    There’s one last part to mention: how the cycle starts again (figure 20). It deserves special attention.

    还有最后一部分要提到: 这个循环是如何重新开始的(图20)。


    Customers’ ability to continue evolving depends on how successful they were at overcoming previous Jobs. Have you ever used a solution to improve your life, only to realize that you face new aspirations? The following are some examples:

    客户继续进化的能力取决于他们在克服之前的乔布斯方面有多成功。你是否曾经用一个解决方案来改善你的生活，却意识到你面临着新的愿望？以下是一些例子:


    You buy your first car and enjoy your newfound independence. But now you want some help planning road trips, choosing car insurance, and finding a mechanic whom you can trust.

    你买了你的第一辆车，享受你新发现的独立。但是现在你需要一些帮助来计划公路旅行，选择汽车保险，以及找到一个你可以信任的机械师。


    You buy professional pans and enjoy your increased cooking control. But now you’re curious about new techniques and recipes. You also need to figure out where to store those new pans and how to clean them properly.

    你购买专业的平底锅，并享受您增加的烹饪控制。但是现在你对新的技术和食谱很好奇。您还需要弄清楚在哪里存储这些新的平底锅，以及如何正确地清洁它们。


    You’ve finally switched from a film camera and physical photo prints to a smartphone. Now you’re curious about sharing your photos on social networks. And you’re taking so many pictures that you need a better way to store and organize them.

    你终于从胶片相机和实体照片转向了智能手机。现在你对在社交网络上分享你的照片感到好奇。你拍了这么多照片，你需要一个更好的方式来存储和组织它们。


    As we can see, improvement in one part of life often has effects elsewhere. Often, when customers evolve themselves, even more aspirations arise.

    正如我们所看到的，生活中某一方面的改善往往会对其他方面产生影响。通常情况下，当消费者自我发展时，会产生更多的愿望。


    The system of progress allows customers to evolve. When we add this idea of an evolving customer who continues to want and make progress, we end up with a helical structure like in figure 21 (imagine that the spiral builds up on itself).

    进步系统允许客户进化。当我们添加一个不断发展的客户的想法谁继续想要并取得进展，我们结束了螺旋结构，如图21(想象螺旋本身建立)。


    The top part of the diagram illustrates how the forces of progress perpetually generate demand. The bottom part represents the interdependencies between producers and customers. Through these interdependencies, customers can make progress. The degree of success that customers make depends on how well the producer meets their demands.

    图表的顶部说明了进步的力量如何不断地产生需求。底部表示生产者和客户之间的相互依赖关系。通过这些相互依赖，客户可以取得进展。顾客取得成功的程度取决于生产者满足他们需求的程度。


    The expanding radius of the spiral movement represents the customers making progress. This system demonstrates how one or more solutions can work together, or in sequence, to deliver ongoing progress to customers. The following is an example:

    螺旋运动的扩展半径代表了客户的进步。该系统演示了一个或多个解决方案如何协同工作，或按顺序向客户提供持续进展。下面是一个例子:


    A customer aspires to become a successful entrepreneur but struggles to get started. He turns to Product People Club to jump-start motivation.

    一个顾客渴望成为一个成功的企业家，但却难以起步。他转向产品人员俱乐部来激发动力。




    Figure 21. Demand is generated as customers make progress.

    图21。需求随着客户的进步而产生



    Product People Club is helpful, but the customer has some doubts about the validity of his business model. He turns to Clarity for some advice from someone whom he respects.

    产品人员俱乐部是有帮助的，但客户有一些疑问，他的商业模式的有效性。他向 Clarity 寻求一些他尊敬的人的建议。


    The advice obtained through Clarity gives a motivation boost and helps the entrepreneur realize that his business model is questionable. This is when he turns to the Lean Stack, using the Lean Canvas to retool the business model, increase his confidence in the business, and develop a shared vision with a new cofounder.

    通过 Clarity 获得的建议可以激励创业者，帮助他们意识到自己的商业模式存在问题。这时他转向精益堆栈，使用精益画布来重组业务模式，增加他对业务的信心，并与新的共同创始人形成共同愿景。


    Next, it is time to release the new product. But how can the entrepreneur make sure it’s a successful launch? This is when he turns to Justin Jackson’s Marketing for Developers book.

    接下来，是发布新产品的时候了。但是企业家如何才能确保这是一次成功的发布呢？这是当他转向贾斯汀杰克逊的开发营销的书。


    Justin’s book helps this entrepreneur become a better marketer. Now he wants help with improving the company’s product with little waste. This is when he puts to use the Lean Stack’s Validation Plan and Experiment Report.

    贾斯汀的书帮助这个企业家成为一个更好的营销人员。现在他希望得到帮助，以减少浪费的方式改进公司的产品。这就是他使用精益堆栈的验证计划和实验报告的时候。


    And so on.

    诸如此类。


    Our example shows how someone who strives to become a successful entrepreneur evolves because he or she exists within a system that perpetually propels customers forward.

    我们的例子展示了一个努力成为成功企业家的人是如何进化的，因为他或她存在于一个永远推动客户前进的系统中。


    New Jobs arise as customers make progress. They will use some combination of different products, so they can continue making progress.

    随着客户的进步，新的工作岗位不断涌现。他们将使用一些不同产品的组合，以便他们能够继续取得进展。


    The system of progress also illustrates why some customers experience demand differently from others. For example, some entrepreneurs may struggle with motivation but not with marketing newly created solutions. Conversely, an aspiring entrepreneur who fails to create a product because he or she cannot sustain motivation will never face the struggle of how to market it.

    进度系统还说明了为什么一些客户的需求体验与其他客户不同。例如，一些企业家可能会与动机斗争，但不会与营销新创造的解决方案。相反，一个有抱负的企业家如果因为他或她不能保持动力而不能创造出一个产品，那么他将永远不会面对如何营销这个产品的困难。


    Another example of an evolving customer comes from BananaDesk founder Tim Zenderman. His product offers a complete front-desk solution (project management system + content management system + more) built for hostels. Over time, he has learned how the progress customers want changes as they move through the system. He told me, “At a high level, we found that hostels go through four stages of growth. The stages can take six months or five years. If some hostels don’t make progress, they’ll stay only at a certain level.” Tim identified these stages as follows:

    另一个客户不断发展的例子来自 BananaDesk 创始人 Tim Zenderman。他的产品提供了一个完整的前台解决方案(项目管理系统 + 内容管理系统 + 更多)建立的宿舍。随着时间的推移，他已经了解了当客户在系统中移动时，他们希望如何改变进度。他告诉我，“在高水平上，我们发现招待所经历了四个发展阶段。这些阶段可能需要6个月或5年。如果一些招待所不能取得进展，它们只会停留在一定的水平上。”蒂姆认为这些阶段如下:


    Survive. This is the initial stage a recently launched hostel finds itself in. Owners need to drive enough guests to survive, and there are many ways (or hires) for resolving this Job. Some owners put posters up in the bus terminal, build a direct marketing strategy, or make alliances with hostels in other cities. Eventually, though, most owners find that posting simple photos and availabilities—by hand—on hostel booking websites, gets them the traction they are looking for and makes it the most effective hire for this JTBD (Survive).

    活下去。这是一家最近开业的旅馆发现自己所处的初始阶段。业主需要驾驶足够的客人生存，并有许多方式(或雇佣)来解决这项工作。一些业主在公交车站张贴海报，制定直接营销策略，或者与其他城市的青年旅社结成联盟。不过，大多数业主最终发现，在旅馆预订网站上发布简单的照片和手动预订服务，可以让他们获得他们想要的吸引力，成为这个 JTBD (Survive)项目最有效的雇佣对象。



    Figure 22. New challenges are revealed as a hostel owner makes progress.

    图22。新的挑战揭示了宿舍业主取得的进展



    Control:Reservations. Once hostels start receiving reservations and managing the front desk more frequently, new problems arise. In particular, overbooking becomes a problem. This is when owners need basic reservation management. This is also when BananaDesk first starts becoming relevant to them.

    控制: 预订。一旦旅馆开始接收预订并更频繁地管理前台，就会出现新的问题。特别是，超额预订成为一个问题。这是业主需要基本预订管理的时候。这也是 BananaDesk 首次开始与他们相关联的时候。


    Control:Finance. Once reservation management is under control, they are able to handle a steady stream of customers. They’re making good money. Owners now face new problems. How much cash is at the front desk? How much money did they make last month?

    控制: 财务。一旦预订管理得到控制，他们就能够处理稳定的客户流。他们赚了不少钱。业主现在面临新的问题。前台有多少现金？他们上个月赚了多少钱？


    Scale. The business is humming along without much intervention. The owners have good reviews and a good occupancy. But how can they sell better? Revenue management, launching a franchise, or developing a direct marketing strategy (to lower customer acquisition costs) are all good potential hires for this new JTBD (Scale).

    比例尺。生意兴隆，没有太多干预。业主的评价很好，入住率也很高。但他们怎样才能卖得更好呢？收入管理，发起一个特许经营，或开发一个直接营销战略(以降低客户获取成本)都是这个新的 JTBD (规模)很好的潜在雇用。


    If we were to put these struggles into a system, it could look like figure 22. Tim also told me how the same product might be a bad fit for one stage of progress but then becomes relevant later when the customer does make progress. He told me:

    如果我们将这些挣扎放入一个系统中，它可以看起来像图22。蒂姆还告诉我，同样的产品可能不适合某个阶段的进展，但是当客户确实取得进展时，这个产品就变得相关了。他告诉我:


    At the survive stage, hiring a direct marketing strategy is a bad fit because it takes a lot of time to correctly position a business. Moreover, the benefits from a direct marketing strategy take a long time. The hostel might be out of business before it realizes any gains.

    在生存阶段，雇佣直接营销策略是不合适的，因为它需要很多时间来正确定位一个企业。此外，直接营销策略的好处需要很长时间。这家旅馆可能在实现任何收益之前就关门大吉了。


    However, a direct marketing strategy is a great hire for the scale stage. The owners have the flexibility and time to invest in a longer-term strategy. This is also when improving margins starts to become relevant and is part of that new JTBD—something that wasn’t important during the survive stage.

    然而，一个直接的营销策略是一个伟大的雇佣规模阶段。所有者有灵活性和时间投资于长期战略。也正是在这个时候，提高利润率开始变得重要起来，成为新的 JTBD 的一部分，而这在生存阶段并不重要。


    The same is true for promoting their business on hostel booking websites. Such promotions are a good hire for survive, not necessarily for scale. If you look at just the functional need of these two stages, they seem similar: “I need to sell beds.” But in both cases, the context around that “need” is quite different, and that is what determines the best hires for the Job.

    同样的道理也适用于在旅馆预订网站上推广他们的业务。这样的晋升对于生存来说是很好的雇佣，但对于规模来说却不一定。如果你只看这两个阶段的功能需求，它们看起来很相似: “我需要卖床。”但是，在这两种情况下，围绕“需求”的环境是完全不同的，这就是决定最好的招聘工作。


    Is the System of Progress New?

    进步制度是新制度吗？

    As novel as this cycle and helix concept may seem, it’s not. In 1939, Walter A. Shewhart introduced the idea that the production of products should be seen as a system and that the aim is to improve that system continually. In 1951, W. Edwards Deming modified it and coined it the “Shewhart cycle” when he taught it to the Japanese. Over the next fifty years, Deming evolved the Shewhart cycle to describe the improvement of any system, from health services to management to innovation. The Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) and Shewhart cycles were the genesis for improvement processes such as the Toyota production system, Lean Manufacturing, Six Sigma, and the Lean Startup (build-measure-learn).54

    尽管这个循环和螺旋概念看起来很新颖，但事实并非如此。1939年，沃特·阿曼德·休哈特引入了这样一种观点，即产品的生产应被视为一个系统，其目的是不断改进这个系统。1951年，爱德华兹·戴明修改了它，并在教日本人的时候创造了“休哈特循环”。在接下来的五十年里，戴明发展了休哈特周期来描述任何系统的改进，从卫生服务到管理到创新。计划-做-研究-行动(PDSA)和休哈特周期是丰田生产系统、精益生产、六西格玛和精益创业(build-meter-learn)等改进过程的起源


    People mostly remember Deming’s introduction of the PDSA cycle. What is often overlooked is Deming’s introduction of the PDSA cycle as a helix. He wanted to emphasize that the ultimate intent is to improve the system continually with the intent of evolving it.

    人们大多还记得戴明对 PDSA 循环的介绍。人们经常忽视的是戴明将 PDSA 循环作为螺旋结构的介绍。他想强调的是，最终的目的是不断改进这个系统，使之不断发展。



    Figure 23. Different approaches to how a system evolves.

    图23. 系统如何演化的不同方法



    What is the difference between Shewhart’s cycle and Deming’s PDSA cycle and the system of progress? Shewhart and Deming studied a system that continually improves product quality through increasing knowledge of the process, materials, labor, and so on. We study a system that continually improves customers’ lives through an increase in knowledge of their desires to evolve themselves, how they find solutions, how they use solutions, and how they make their lives better.

    休哈特循环和戴明的 PDSA 循环和进步系统有什么不同？Shewhart 和 Deming 研究了一个系统，该系统通过增加工艺、材料、劳动力等方面的知识来不断提高产品质量。我们研究一个系统，这个系统通过增加客户对自我发展的渴望、他们如何找到解决方案、他们如何使用解决方案以及他们如何使自己的生活更美好的知识，不断地改善客户的生活。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Studying the system of progress—which includes customers’ JTBD—helps you understand that your business needs to account for the interdependencies between the parts of the system. Here are some ways to think about applying the system of progress.

    研究进展系统(包括客户的 JTBD)有助于您理解您的业务需要考虑系统各部分之间的相互依赖性。以下是一些应用进步系统的方法。


    Grow your business by unlocking new aspirations and offering products for them. Justin Jackson’s and Ash Maurya’s case studies provide examples of innovators recognizing the new aspirations that their customers unlock when they make progress. Justin’s Product People Club helps entrepreneurs overcome the struggle of maintaining their motivation long enough to ship their product. After that, they face a new challenge—promoting their newly released product. This is when Justin’s book, Marketing for Developers, becomes relevant for them.

    通过释放新的抱负和为他们提供产品来发展你的业务。贾斯汀 · 杰克逊和阿什 · 莫里亚的案例研究提供了创新者认识到他们的客户在取得进展时释放出的新愿望的例子。贾斯汀的产品人员俱乐部帮助企业家克服困难，保持足够长的时间运送他们的产品的动力。在那之后，他们面临着一个新的挑战ーー推广他们最新发布的产品。这时贾斯汀的书，营销开发者，成为相关的他们。


    Ash’s Lean Canvas helps entrepreneurs become more successful by giving them a way to create a business model that is flexible and adaptable. After that, they face a new challenge: how to iterate on, validate, and improve the business model. This is when Ash’s Validation Plan and Experiment Report become relevant.

    Ash’s Lean Canvas 帮助企业家通过创造一种灵活和适应性强的商业模式而变得更加成功。之后，他们面临一个新的挑战: 如何迭代、验证和改进业务模型。这是当 Ash 的验证计划和实验报告变得相关的时候。


    Get ahead of your customers. When they make progress, how will their interactions with the system of progress change? What new challenges will they face? Maybe you create a new product that meets the new demand. Maybe you add an extension that helps integrate your product with other innovators’ products. Adding a hole at the end of your pan’s handle does not help customers cook better, but it does help them hang your pan on a rack made by you or someone else. Either way, customers will realize more value in your product.

    抢在顾客前面。当他们取得进步时，他们与进步系统的互动将如何改变？他们将面临什么新的挑战？也许你创造了一个新的产品来满足新的需求。也许你可以添加一个扩展，帮助你的产品与其他创新者的产品整合。在平底锅的把手末端加一个洞不会帮助顾客做得更好，但它确实能帮助他们把你的平底锅挂在你或别人做的架子上。无论哪种方式，客户将实现更多的价值在您的产品。


    Think of your business as delivering a combination of products that work together to forward the system of progress. Your products are touch points between your business and customers. The iPhone is one of the most successful products of all time, but it didn’t do it alone. Many people don’t realize that the iPhone took off only after the App Store was introduced. The App Store and iPhone are separate products (units of output). But when they operate together, they help propel the customer through the system of progress.55

    可以将您的业务看作是交付产品的组合，这些产品协同工作以推进进度系统。您的产品是您的企业和客户之间的接触点。IPhone 是有史以来最成功的产品之一，但它并不是独立完成的。许多人没有意识到 iPhone 是在 App Store 推出之后才开始流行的。App Store 和 iPhone 是独立的产品(输出单位)。但是当他们一起运作时，他们帮助推动客户通过系统的进步。55




    Figure 24. Demand is generated as someone makes progress as a contractor.

    图24。需求产生于某人作为承包商取得的进展



    Moreover, as Apple’s hardware sales slowdown—because sales for every product will eventually slow—Apple shifts to offering complementary products that build on the progress that the iPhone has unlocked. Apple CEO Tim Cook said in 2016, “In the last twelve months our services revenue [revenue from products other than the iPhone] is up almost $4 billion year-on-year to $23.1 billion, and we expect it to be the size of a Fortune 100 company next year.”56

    此外，随着苹果的硬件销售放缓ーー因为每种产品的销售最终都会放缓ーー苹果转而提供补充产品，这些产品是建立在 iPhone 取得的进步基础上的。苹果首席执行官蒂姆 · 库克(Tim Cook)在2016年表示: “在过去的12个月里，我们的服务收入(来自 iPhone 以外产品的收入)同比增长了近40亿美元，达到231亿美元，我们预计明年的收入将达到财富100强公司的规模。”56


    Another example is DeWalt—a company that makes tools such as laser specs, compressors, generators, myriad power tools, and contractor-training products. All these work together as a system to help DeWalt’s contractor customers maintain successful careers.

    另一个例子是 DeWalt ーー这家公司生产激光规格、压缩机、发电机、无数电动工具和承包商培训产品等工具。所有这些作为一个系统一起工作，以帮助德华特的承包商客户保持成功的职业生涯。


    Remember that the system of progress represents the interdependencies between the producer and customer demand. Innovation success comes from studying those interdependencies and understanding how they work together to help customers realize progress.

    请记住，进度系统代表了生产者和客户需求之间的相互依赖关系。创新的成功来自于研究这些相互依赖关系，并理解它们如何协同工作，以帮助客户实现进步。


    Identify parts of the system that your business hasn’t considered or is overvaluing. Fill in missing gaps with data from the system of progress. Almost every off-the-shelf innovation or design process focuses on only one or a few parts of the system of progress. That isn’t necessarily a problem, but it does create two risks: (1) innovators and producers are not aware that they are omitting necessary data, and

    识别出你的企业没有考虑到或者高估了系统的某些部分。用进度系统中的数据填补缺失的空白。几乎每一个现成的创新或设计过程都只关注进步系统的一个或几个部分。这不一定是个问题，但它确实带来了两个风险: (1)创新者和生产者没有意识到他们遗漏了必要的数据;

    (2) innovators and producers overvalue and overanalyze the data they do have access to.

    (2)创新者和生产者高估和过度分析他们能够获得的数据。


    For example, a company that has a customer- or user-centric process tries to fill knowledge gaps with ever-increasing data about customers. Therefore, over time, innovation efforts have created ever-larger reports that contain a great deal of irrelevant data about customers—reports that no one ends up reading.

    例如，一个拥有以客户或用户为中心的流程的公司试图用不断增加的客户数据来填补知识空白。因此，随着时间的推移，创新努力创造出了越来越大的报告，其中包含了大量与客户无关的数据ーー最终没有人会去读这些报告。


    Here’s another example: a company that focuses on goals or desired outcomes tries to fill knowledge gaps by identifying an ever-increasing number of them. Yesterday, the innovator needed to identify a few goals or outcomes; today, the innovator believes it needs to identify dozens or even hundreds.

    这里还有另一个例子: 一个专注于目标或期望结果的公司试图通过识别不断增加的目标或期望结果来填补知识空白。昨天，创新者需要确定一些目标或结果; 今天，创新者认为它需要确定几十个甚至几百个。


    But you don’t need to throw out your current design or innovation process just because it doesn’t fit with the system of progress. Instead, learn to appreciate what data you are or are not missing and what you may be overvaluing. Adjust as needed. You might learn that the data you used to think were important aren’t.

    但是你不需要仅仅因为当前的设计或创新过程不符合进步的体系就抛弃它们。相反，学会欣赏你正在或没有丢失的数据，以及你可能高估的数据。根据需要调整。你可能会发现你过去认为重要的数据并不重要。


    Find product opportunities by looking forward and backward on the system of progress. You can also deliver solutions for the system segments before or after any given segment. Most people focus on only one segment; we saw some examples of this in our first batch of case studies. Moving forward a segment is what Justin’s and Ash’s case studies show. They did that when they asked, “What comes next?” From my own experience, I’ll give a simple and brief example of moving back a segment.

    通过前瞻和回顾进步系统来发现产品机会。您还可以在任何给定的段之前或之后为系统段交付解决方案。大多数人只关注一个部分; 我们在第一批案例研究中看到了一些这方面的例子。贾斯汀和阿什的案例研究表明，向前推进一个部分。当他们问“接下来会发生什么?”根据我自己的经验，我将给出一个简单而简短的例子来说明如何回到一个片段。


    Before I created Aim—my advertising marketplace for real estate brokers and bankers—my cofounder and I had worked on another business. It would have been based on a product for mortgage bankers to process applications. Our initial investigation went very well, but during discovery, we learned of a bigger aspiration that mortgage bankers face: to find people who were looking for loans. Mortgage bankers first have to find those who need loans before they can process an application.

    在我创建 AIM 之前，我和我的联合创始人曾经做过另一项业务。 AIM 是我为房地产经纪人和银行家开设的广告市场。它将基于一种供抵押贷款银行家处理申请的产品。我们最初的调查进行得非常顺利，但在调查过程中，我们了解到抵押贷款银行家面临着一个更大的抱负: 找到那些寻找贷款的人。抵押贷款银行家首先必须找到那些需要贷款的人，然后才能处理申请。


    In fact, this desire is so great that some bankers spend hundreds of thousands of dollars trying to find people who are looking for loans. Our new information

    事实上，这种欲望是如此强烈，以至于一些银行家花费数十万美元试图找到寻找贷款的人。我们的新情报


    prompted us to change our business model and discontinue developing a solution for processing mortgages. As you know, we then focused on helping brokers remove the time and stress involved in finding leads so they can spend more time closing deals.

    促使我们改变业务模式，停止开发处理抵押贷款的解决方案。如你所知，我们之后专注于帮助经纪人消除寻找线索所需的时间和压力，这样他们就可以花更多的时间来完成交易。


    Here, my cofounder and I did the inverse of what Justin and Ash did. Instead of asking, “What comes after?” we asked, “What comes before?” It turned out that there was a much greater profit potential in solving for the latter struggle.

    在这里，我和我的联合创始人做了与贾斯汀和阿什相反的事。而不是问“接下来会发生什么?”我们问，“什么在前面?”事实证明，解决后一个问题的利润潜力要大得多。

  11. Innovation and the System of Progress

    创新与进步制度

    The customer does not understand the system Improving interdependencies within the system When a system’s interdependencies change JTBD empowers us to innovate

    客户不理解系统改善系统内部的相互依赖当系统的相互依赖性改变时 JTBD 赋予我们创新的能力

    Put it to work

    让它发挥作用


    Any innovative company struggles with how much to listen to customers. Most realize that you cannot trust them to tell you what your next new product will be.

    任何有创新精神的公司都会在多大程度上听取顾客的意见方面遇到困难。大多数人意识到你不能相信他们会告诉你下一个新产品是什么。


    How can people tell you what they want if they haven’t seen it before? If we ask them what they want, we’ll end up doing Swan Lake every year!

    如果人们以前没见过他们想要什么，他们怎么能告诉你他们想要什么？如果我们问他们想要什么，我们每年都会演《天鹅湖》 ！


    —Mario D’Amico, senior VP of marketing at Cirque du Soleil

    ー马里奥•德阿米科(Mario d’amico) ，太阳剧团营销高级副总裁


    An innovator’s responsibility is to study and improve the system. Appreciating the system helps you find innovation opportunities and gives you the right mind-set to understand whether, when, where, and how to improve it.

    创新者的责任是研究和完善系统。欣赏这个系统可以帮助你发现创新的机会，并且给你正确的思维模式去理解是否、何时、何地以及如何改进它。


    This chapter will give you an understanding of what it is like to innovate for the system as a whole instead of innovating for only one part of it.

    本章将让您了解为整个系统进行创新是什么感觉，而不是仅仅为系统的一部分进行创新。


    The Customer Does Not Understand the System

    顾客不理解系统

    Spirit Airlines is the fastest-growing, most profitable airline in America. Its 2016 Q1 profit margin was a staggering 21.3 percent. Its net income grew 315 percent between 2011 and 2015. How did it achieve such explosive growth and profit? It combines rock-bottom prices with a terrible customer experience. Since it began, customers have ranked Spirit Airlines as the most-hated airline in the United States. If customers hate it so much, why do they keep buying it?57

    精神航空公司是美国增长最快、利润最高的航空公司。该公司2016年第一季度的利润率达到了惊人的21.3% 。2011年至2015年间，其净利润增长了315% 。它是如何实现如此爆炸性的增长和利润的？它结合了最低的价格和糟糕的客户体验。自从这家航空公司成立以来，乘客们就把精神航空公司列为美国最令人讨厌的航空公司。如果消费者这么讨厌它，为什么还要继续购买呢？57


    Another airline, Ryanair, is similar. Customers also rank it as one of worst airlines in the world. It has even been ranked as the second-worst brand in the world. Nevertheless, its growth and profits are consistently staggering. In 2011, its net profit after taxes was €374.6 million; in 2015, it was €866.7 million. Which voice of the customer should we listen to—what customers say, or what customers do? 58

    另一家航空公司瑞安航空(Ryanair)也是如此。客户也把它列为世界上最差的航空公司之一。它甚至被评为世界上第二糟糕的品牌。尽管如此，它的增长和利润一直惊人。2011年税后净利润为3.746亿美元，2015年为8.667亿美元。我们应该听从顾客的哪一种声音ーー顾客说什么，还是顾客做什么？58


    When Apple announced the iPhone in 2007, Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer famously dismissed it. Here’s how he described the “problem” with the iPhone: “Five hundred dollars! Fully subsidized! That is the most expensive phone in the world! And it doesn’t appeal to business customers because it doesn’t have a keyboard—which makes it not a very good e-mail machine.” 59

    当苹果公司在2007年发布 iPhone 时，微软 CEO 史蒂夫 · 鲍尔默(SteveBallmer)曾对其不屑一顾。他是这样描述 iPhone 的“问题”的: “500美元！全额补贴！这是世界上最贵的手机！而且它对企业客户没有吸引力，因为它没有键盘ーー这使它不是一台非常好的电子邮件机器。”59


    Many criticize Mr. Ballmer as being out of touch with what customers wanted, but they are wrong to do so. At that moment, Mr. Ballmer knew exactly what customers wanted; they valued low cost and a physical keyboard. Mr. Ballmer was doing what he thought innovators were supposed to do: empathize with customers, and then design solutions that serve their needs, wants, goals, and desired outcomes. And what was the result of Mr. Ballmer’s empathy? Since making that comment, Microsoft’s smartphone market share went from 12 percent to less than 1 percent in 2016.60

    许多人批评鲍尔默先生与客户的需求脱节，但他们这样做是错误的。在那一刻，鲍尔默先生确切地知道顾客想要什么; 他们看重低成本和实体键盘。鲍尔默先生正在做他认为创新者应该做的事情: 与客户产生共鸣，然后设计出满足他们需求、愿望、目标和期望结果的解决方案。鲍尔默先生的移情作用是什么？自从发表上述言论以来，微软的智能手机市场份额在2016.60年从12% 降至不到1%


    Then, consider Steve Jobs of Apple, a “monk without empathy.” He changed the world with three massively successful innovations: the Macintosh, the iPod, and the iPhone. He also revived Apple from near bankruptcy to the most valuable company in the world. What was his opinion of customers? He said, “It isn’t the consumer’s job to know what they want.” He also said, “A lot of times, people don’t know what they want until you show it to them.” 61

    然后，想想苹果公司的史蒂夫 · 乔布斯，一个“没有同情心的和尚”他用三项巨大的成功创新改变了世界: Macintosh、 iPod 和 iPhone。他还使苹果公司从濒临破产的边缘重新成为世界上最有价值的公司。他对顾客有什么看法？他说: “消费者的工作不是知道他们想要什么。”他还说，“很多时候，人们不知道他们想要什么，直到你展示给他们看。”61


    Steve Jobs was notorious for being dismissive of customer input—and he was not the only one. Dr. Deming said, “The customer is the one who supports us.” But he also said, “The customer invents nothing. The customer does not contribute to the design of the product. He takes what he gets. Customer expectations? Nonsense.”62

    史蒂夫•乔布斯(Steve Jobs)以对客户投入不屑一顾而臭名昭著，而且他不是唯一一个这样做的人。戴明博士说: “顾客是支持我们的人。”但是他也说，“顾客没有发明任何东西。客户对产品的设计没有贡献。他得到什么就拿什么。顾客期望？一派胡言”62


    Why would Steve Jobs, Dr. Deming, and Mario D’Amico—some of the most important innovators of our time—make these comments about innovation, customer input, and expectations? What did they understand that people like Steve Ballmer don’t?

    为什么史蒂夫•乔布斯(Steve Jobs)、戴明博士(Dr。 Deming)和马里奥•达米科(Mario D’Amico)——我们这个时代最重要的创新者之一——会就创新、客户投入和期望发表这样的评论？他们了解史蒂夫 · 鲍尔默这样的人不了解的东西是什么？


    Customers know only what the system tells them. How does a doctor best serve a patient? When a patient tells a doctor she has a fever and stomachache, does the doctor automatically treat the fever and stomachache separately? Will he offer the patient an Advil for the headache and Pepto-Bismol for the stomachache? How about empathy? Will a doctor know how to help a patient once he imagines what it is like to have a fever and stomachache?

    客户只知道系统告诉他们什么。医生如何最好地为病人服务？当病人告诉医生她有发烧和胃痛时，医生会自动将发烧和胃痛分开治疗吗？他会给病人用止痛药治疗头痛，胃药治疗胃痛吗？换位思考怎么样？一个医生一旦想象到发烧和胃痛是什么感觉，他会知道如何帮助病人吗？


    Or does the doctor best serve the patient by understanding that the fever and stomachache are not the patient’s problem but only symptoms of the problem? The doctor studies the body, as a system, and recognizes that the patient’s problem is an intestinal infection. An antibiotic should be administered to kill the bacteria, eliminating the infection. The body will heal, and then the fever and stomachache will go away.

    或者医生最好是通过了解发烧和胃痛不是病人的问题，而只是问题的症状来为病人服务？医生研究身体，作为一个系统，并认识到病人的问题是肠道感染。应该使用抗生素来杀死细菌，消除感染。身体会痊愈，然后发烧和胃痛就会消失。


    Doctors treat patients successfully because they understand that the pains and discomforts that patients express are not the problems; they represent the patients’ interactions with their own bodies. Similarly, the needs, wants, and desired outcomes that customers express do not represent their problem; they represent interactions between the customer and the system of progress. Therefore, customers’ stated preferences are unreliable and why customers’ “needs” and “wants” keep changing.

    医生之所以能够成功地治疗病人，是因为他们知道病人所表达的痛苦和不适并不是问题所在，而是代表了病人与自己身体的相互作用。类似地，客户表达的需求、需求和期望的结果并不代表他们的问题; 它们代表客户和进度系统之间的交互。因此，顾客陈述的偏好是不可靠的，为什么顾客的“需要”和“想要”不断变化。


    The customers of Spirit Airlines and Ryanair do not understand why management chooses to offer terrible customer service. They think, every other airline gives me free sodas. Why won’t Spirit Airlines? Customers of 2007 expected a $99 smartphone with a keyboard. They were shocked by and did not understand the idea of a $500 keyboard-less smartphone. But fast-forward ten years, and that same customer accepts a $500 keyboard-less smartphone as “just the way things are.”

    精神航空(Spirit Airlines)和瑞安航空(Ryanair)的客户不明白，为什么管理层选择提供糟糕的客户服务。他们以为其他航空公司都会给我免费汽水。为什么精神航空公司不愿意呢？2007年的消费者期待一款99美元的带键盘的智能手机。他们对500美元的无键盘智能手机感到震惊和不理解。但是十年过去了，同一个消费者接受了一部500美元的无键盘智能手机，认为它“就是这样”


    If Spirit Airlines empathized with customers’ needs, it might be tempted to increase legroom, add reclining seats, offer free drinks, fly to more convenient airports, or stop charging customers $10 to print their boarding passes. However, such changes would increase costs of production, and Spirit Airlines could no longer offer rock-bottom prices. Likewise, if Apple had listened to customers’ insistence on a cheaper, low-end smartphone, it would have missed the opportunity to create a high-end smartphone that delivered progress in a way customers never imagined.

    如果精神航空公司同情客户的需求，它可能会忍不住增加腿部空间，增加躺椅，提供免费饮料，飞往更方便的机场，或停止向客户收取10美元打印登机牌。然而，这样的变化将增加生产成本，精神航空公司不能再提供最低的价格。同样，如果苹果听取了消费者对廉价低端智能手机的坚持，它将错过创造高端智能手机的机会，这种手机以消费者从未想象过的方式带来了进步。


    The needs, wants, and desired outcomes that customers express will change when the system changes. And there are countless ways a system can change. Keep in mind the dynamic of interdependence: a change over here can affect something way over there.

    当系统发生变化时，客户表达的需求、需求和期望的结果将发生变化。一个系统有无数种方式可以改变。请记住相互依赖的动态: 这里的变化可以影响那里的某些东西。


    When you study customers’ stated preferences—wants, needs, or desired outcomes—you are studying the interactions between customers and the system only at that moment. All those wants, needs, and desired outcomes will change when the systems that customers belong to change. Yesterday, customers wanted gaslight mantles that wouldn’t set their houses on fire, cheap meat, and somewhere to get their film developed. Today, those same customers want environmentally

    当你研究客户的陈述偏好ーー想要的、需要的或期望的结果ーー时，你只是在研究客户与系统之间的交互作用。当客户所属的系统发生变化时，所有这些想要的、需要的和期望的结果都将发生变化。昨天，顾客们想要的是不会让他们的房子着火的煤气灯罩，廉价的肉，以及可以冲洗胶卷的地方。如今，这些消费者也想要环保


    friendly compact fluorescent lightbulbs, organic kale salads, and accumulating likes on Instagram. Why did those needs change? The systems that customers belong to had changed.63

    友好的紧凑型荧光灯泡，有机甘蓝沙拉，以及在 Instagram 上积累点赞。为什么这些需求会改变？客户所属的系统发生了变化。63


    These complex and ever-changing interdependencies within systems are why Steve Jobs said, “It isn’t the consumer’s job to know what they want.” It’s what Deming meant when he said, “All customer expectations are only what you and your competitor have led him to expect.”64

    系统内部这些复杂的、不断变化的相互依存关系正是史蒂夫•乔布斯(Steve Jobs)说“消费者的工作不是知道他们想要什么”的原因这就是戴明所说的: “所有客户的期望都是你和你的竞争对手让他期望的。”64


    Innovators must understand what the customer does and doesn’t know. We must abandon the idea that customers have a laundry list of “needs.” Instead, we should see customers as having only one need: to make progress within the systems they belong to. Any discomfort or frustrations they experience in making that progress should not be thought of as needs but rather descriptions of interactions between customers, their JTBD, and the product they’ve currently hired for their JTBD. For example, a car owner might claim that he “needs” more parking options in New York City. But is that really the problem? Or is the problem an expectation that it’s a good idea to own and drive a car in a population-dense area like New York City? Perhaps the best way to help this person make progress isn’t to solve the “needs” associated with owning a car; rather, it’s to make car ownership obsolete. At the time of this writing, this is the progress that products such as Uber and Lyft are trying to make happen.

    创新者必须了解客户知道什么和不知道什么。我们必须放弃客户有一长串“需求”的想法相反，我们应该看到客户只有一个需求: 在他们所属的系统内取得进展。他们在取得进展过程中遇到的任何不适或挫折都不应该被看作是需求，而应该被看作是对客户、他们的 JTBD 以及他们目前为 JTBD 雇佣的产品之间的互动的描述。例如，一个车主可能声称他“需要”纽约市更多的停车选择。但这真的是问题所在吗？或者这个问题只是一种期望，认为在纽约这样一个人口密集的地区拥有并驾驶一辆汽车是个好主意？也许帮助这个人取得进步的最好方法不是解决与拥有一辆汽车相关的“需求”，而是让拥有汽车变得过时。在撰写本文时，Uber 和 Lyft 等产品正试图取得这样的进展。


    Customers can tell you of their struggles, how they expect life to be better, and how they interact with the products they use. But they cannot tell you what to do about it. This isn’t because customers aren’t smart enough. It’s because they don’t have access to the appropriate knowledge and theory. Customers do not understand marketing, design, sales, engineering, costs of production, systems thinking, psychology, and statistics all at once. They cannot anticipate all the ways in which their lives will change when they overcome one group of struggles and then face another. They do not understand the system of progress or why they can or cannot move through it.

    客户可以告诉你他们的挣扎，他们如何期望生活变得更好，以及他们如何与他们使用的产品互动。但他们不能告诉你该怎么做。这并不是因为顾客不够聪明。这是因为他们没有获得适当的知识和理论。客户不能同时理解市场营销、设计、销售、工程、生产成本、系统思维、心理学和统计学。当他们克服一组斗争，然后面对另一组斗争时，他们无法预料他们的生活会发生怎样的变化。他们不理解进步的制度，也不理解为什么他们能够或不能够通过它。



    Figure 25. Joanna increased revenue by helping customers find and choose a solution for a JTBD.

    图25. Joanna 通过帮助客户找到并选择 JTBD 的解决方案来增加收入



    In other words, customers know only what the system tells them. This is something the customer does not understand, but you must.

    换句话说，客户只知道系统告诉他们什么。这是客户不理解的东西，但是你必须理解。


    Improving Interdependencies Within the System

    改善系统内部的相互依存关系

    It is the innovator’s responsibility to study and understand the interdependencies within the system of progress. The system should be studied as a whole, and improvements to the parts should be done with the intent of making the whole better. Far too often, innovators believe that they can improve the system by studying one part—for example, the customer’s stated preferences—and then making a corollary change to the product. Unfortunately, they often end up only increasing costs of production with no improvement of the system. The result is diminished profits.

    研究和理解进步系统中的相互依存关系是创新者的责任。系统应作为一个整体进行研究，对各个部分进行改进，使整体更加完善。很多时候，创新者认为，他们可以通过研究一个部分(例如，顾客陈述的偏好) ，然后对产品做出必然的改变，来改进这个系统。不幸的是，它们最终往往只是增加了生产成本，而没有对系统进行任何改进。结果是利润减少。


    I’ll give you some brief examples of innovators who increased profits not by studying customers’ stated preferences but by improving how the product interacted with the system it belonged to.

    我将给你们举一些简单的例子，说明创新者不是通过研究客户陈述的偏好来增加利润，而是通过改进产品与其所属系统的互动方式来增加利润。


    Joanna Wiebe: increase profits with new copywriting. Beachway Therapy Center offers a product that helps people overcome addiction. The center knows its customers’ JTBD, and it has a great product for it. However, it was not happy with its sales. What could be done? Joanna made several copywriting changes. One

    Joanna Wiebe: 通过新的文案增加利润。海滩疗法中心提供了一个产品，可以帮助人们克服成瘾。该中心了解其客户的 JTBD，并为它提供了一个伟大的产品。然而，它对自己的销售额并不满意。我们能做什么？乔安娜对文案做了几处修改。一


    was a new headline for the company website: “If you think you need rehab, you do.” Another was changing the call-to-action button from “Sign up today” to “Does my insurance cover this?” The result was 26 percent more leads, each valued at $20,000 per month.65

    是该公司网站的一个新标题: “如果你认为你需要康复，那么你就需要。”另一个是将“呼吁行动”按钮从“今天注册”改为“我的保险是否包括这个?”结果是多了26% 的线索，每条线索每月价值20,000美元。65


    Joanna improved the interaction between Beachway’s clinic and the system of progress by creating a promotional copy that helped customers recognize that the clinic’s product represented an appropriate solution for their JTBD. The new headline spoke directly to a lingering question that many people with addiction struggle with. The new call-to-action button was directly aimed at reducing customers’ anxieties.

    乔安娜改善了 Beachway 诊所和进展系统之间的互动，创建了一个促销副本，帮助客户认识到诊所的产品代表了他们的 jtBD 的适当解决方案。这个新标题直接回答了一个挥之不去的问题，这个问题困扰着许多瘾君子。新的行动号召按钮直接旨在减少顾客的焦虑。


    Me: helping new customers use a product. For a long time, FDT—a software program for engineers—had low adoption among some customers. I learned that these customers weren’t accustomed to such a feature-rich, high-end product. What did we do? My team and I didn’t change the core product. Instead, we created a video-training platform and integrated it at various touch points between customers and us. This was meant to help reduce the anxiety and inertia forces that blocked customers from switching to the product. Sales increased.

    我: 帮助新客户使用产品。长期以来，FDT ーー一个面向工程师的软件程序ーー在一些客户中的采用率很低。我了解到这些客户并不习惯这种功能丰富的高端产品。我们做了什么？我和我的团队没有改变核心产品。相反，我们创建了一个视频培训平台，并将其集成在客户和我们之间的各种接触点上。这是为了帮助减少焦虑和惰性的力量，阻止客户转换到产品。销售额增加了。


    Even though no customers asked for this video platform, they instantly loved it. In this case, we improved our product’s interaction with the system of progress by minimizing the demand-reducing forces—that is, anxiety and inertia—that some customers faced when first using the product. This was done without changing the core product at all; rather, we created additional products—a training platform— that would help customers move through the system of progress.

    尽管没有顾客要求使用这个视频平台，他们还是立刻喜欢上了它。在这种情况下，我们通过最小化一些客户在首次使用产品时所面临的减少需求的力量(即焦虑和惰性) ，改善了我们的产品与进度系统的互动。这样做完全没有改变核心产品; 相反，我们创造了额外的产品ーー一个培训平台ーー来帮助客户完成进度系统。


    Bob Moesta: increase profits by designing for the system, not for customers’ stated preferences. Bob led marketing and sales at a business that designed, built, and sold homes. The business wanted to offer a home that would appeal to empty nesters—parents who wanted to downsize their home after their children had grown and moved away. Two stated preferences from prospective customers were (1) a smaller dining room because they no longer had big family meals and (2) an expanded second bedroom so their children could visit. Bob’s company delivered on what customers wanted. The result? Tepid sales.

    鲍勃 · 莫斯塔: 通过为系统设计来增加利润，而不是按照顾客所陈述的偏好来设计。鲍勃在一家设计、建造和销售房屋的公司领导市场营销和销售工作。该公司希望提供一个能吸引空巢老人的房子，这些父母希望在孩子长大并搬走后缩小自己的房子面积。来自潜在客户的两个明确的偏好是(1)一个较小的餐厅，因为他们不再有大的家庭聚餐和(2)一个扩大的第二卧室，以便他们的孩子可以访问。鲍勃的公司满足顾客的需求。结果呢？销售不景气。


    Bob figured out the problem. These empty nesters were willing to change almost everything to accommodate living in a smaller home—except for getting rid of their existing, family-size dining room table. It had tremendous sentimental value because it reminded them of countless family meals. When it came to get rid of it so that

    鲍勃发现了问题所在。这些空巢老人愿意改变几乎所有的东西，以适应住在较小的房子里ーー除了摆脱现有的家庭用餐大小的餐桌。它具有巨大的情感价值，因为它使他们想起了无数的家庭聚餐。当它来摆脱它，以便


    they could move into one of Bob’s homes, they couldn’t do it. At a result, many ended up not moving at all.

    他们可以搬进鲍勃的家，但他们做不到。结果，许多人最终一动不动。


    To fix this, Bob did the opposite of what his customers claimed they wanted: he shrunk the second bedroom and expanded the dining room so that it could accommodate their existing family-size dining room table. Moreover, Bob added a big, old-looking dining room table to the demonstration home, for it would help customers visualize themselves living in this unit. The result? A 23 percent increase in sales.

    为了解决这个问题，鲍勃采取了与客户所说的相反的做法: 他缩小了第二间卧室，扩大了餐厅，以便能够容纳他们现有的家庭餐桌。此外，鲍勃增加了一个大，看起来很旧的餐桌示范家庭，因为它将有助于客户形象化自己生活在这个单位。结果呢？销售额增长了23% 。


    These empty nesters thought that a small dining room and larger second bedroom would be best for them, but they were wrong. Why? They did not anticipate how hard it would be to give away their dining room table. How could they? Customers cannot see into the future. They cannot know all the ways in which their lives will change as they move through the system of progress.

    这些空巢老人认为，一个小餐厅和较大的第二卧室将是他们最好的，但他们错了。为什么？他们没有预料到把餐桌送人会有多么困难。他们怎么能这样？顾客不能预见未来。他们不可能知道他们的生活在进步的过程中会发生什么样的变化。


    Bob won because he understood that customers’ stated preferences are unreliable, and that customers’ needs will change as they move through the system of progress. Instead, he studied interactions within the system as customers moved through it, and he made a change with the intent of improving the system as a whole instead of focusing on just one part of it.

    鲍勃之所以获胜，是因为他明白顾客陈述的偏好是不可靠的，而且顾客的需求会随着他们在整个系统中的进步而改变。相反，他研究了当客户通过系统时系统内部的交互，并且他做了一个改变，目的是改进整个系统，而不是仅仅关注其中的一部分。


    When A System’s Interdependencies Change

    当系统的相互依赖性发生变化时

    All systems change. Some change slowly; others change quickly. How much and how fast the system changes depends on which interdependencies change and how many. A producer might be able to respond to changes within the system by making a small change of its own—for example, adding a new feature to its product. Sometimes, a big change requires the producer to respond with a bigger change, such as creating a brand-new product. Let’s look at these responses in more detail.

    所有系统都会改变。有些变化缓慢，有些变化迅速。系统变化的程度和速度取决于哪些相互依赖关系发生了变化以及变化的数量。生产商也许能够对系统内部的变化作出反应，做出自己的一些小改变ーー例如，在产品中增加一个新功能。有时候，一个大的变化需要生产者以一个更大的变化来回应，比如创造一个全新的产品。让我们更详细地看看这些反应。


    Adapting an existing product to match a change in the system. For many years, customers used the FDT software I mentioned above to create games that were played on websites. Customers were happy with it because a healthy sync existed between our solution and our customers’ JTBD. The system of progress operated smoothly.

    调整现有产品以匹配系统中的更改。多年来，客户使用我上面提到的 FDT 软件来创建在网站上玩的游戏。客户对此很满意，因为我们的解决方案和客户的 JTBD 之间存在健康的同步。进度系统运行平稳。




    Figure 26. A disruption in the system of progress can force the customer to start all over again.

    图26。进度系统中的中断可以迫使客户重新开始
