    Then, smartphones came along. This affected the system of progress that our customers and our product belonged to. Now customers wanted help with publishing their games on smartphones, but our product couldn’t help them do that. This frustrated them—and us! Our product could not deliver the progress that they now desired. If we didn’t act quickly, a competitor would take advantage of this opportunity and steal our customers.

    然后，智能手机出现了。这影响了我们的客户和产品所属的进步体系。现在，客户希望在智能手机上发布他们的游戏，但我们的产品无法帮助他们做到这一点。这使他们和我们都感到沮丧！我们的产品无法实现他们现在所期望的进步。如果我们不迅速行动，竞争对手就会利用这个机会抢走我们的客户。


    Fortunately, my team was able to adjust our product to meet this change in the system and fit our customers’ JTBD. The system once again operated smoothly.

    幸运的是，我的团队能够调整我们的产品以满足系统中的这种变化，并适合我们客户的 JTBD。该系统再次顺利运行。


    When customers can’t get their preferred solution for a JTBD. You’ll remember that a cofounder and I created Aim in 2013. But our product was relevant to our customers only because of what had happened three years earlier.

    当客户无法得到他们首选的 JTBD 解决方案时。你应该还记得，我和一位共同创始人在2013年创建了 AIM。但是，我们的产品之所以与客户相关，仅仅是因为三年前发生的事情。


    For many years, real estate agents and mortgage bankers had worked closely together to sell houses. The real estate broker would find people who wanted mortgages and send them to a mortgage banker whom the broker knew personally. This was how mortgage bankers used to get their leads.

    多年来，房地产经纪人和抵押贷款银行家一直密切合作，出售房屋。地产代理会找到想要抵押贷款的人，把他们送到经纪人认识的抵押贷款银行家那里。抵押贷款银行家过去就是这样获得生意的。


    But in 2010, US federal law made the traditional relationship between real estate brokers and mortgage bankers illegal. Just like that, the solution that mortgage bankers preferred for their JTBD was gone. That’s why my cofounder and I created our Aim online advertising platform, which was like Google’s AdSense. It allowed real estate brokers to pass leads to mortgage bankers legally. At first, our prospective customers were apprehensive about using our product because it was very different from what they were used to. However, when they were confronted with either engaging in potentially illegal relationships or using previous solutions they didn’t like, we began to win customers over.

    但在2010年，美国联邦法律将房地产经纪人与抵押贷款银行家之间的传统关系定为非法。就这样，抵押贷款银行家青睐的 JTBD 解决方案消失了。这就是为什么我和我的共同创始人创建了我们的 AIM 在线广告平台，就像 Google 的 AdSense 一样。它允许房地产经纪人合法地向抵押贷款银行家传递信息。起初，我们的潜在客户对使用我们的产品感到担忧，因为它与他们习惯使用的产品非常不同。然而，当他们面对潜在的非法关系或使用他们不喜欢的解决方案时，我们开始赢得客户。


    In this example, a disruption arose in the system of progress, and it prevented customers from making progress. They were sent back to the beginning, had to reevaluate their struggle, and had to begin searching for and choosing a solution for their JTBD.

    在这个例子中，进度系统中出现了一个中断，它阻止了客户取得进展。他们被送回到最初，不得不重新评估他们的斗争，不得不开始为他们的 JTBD 寻找和选择一个解决方案。


    Fragile Interdependencies and Cascade Effects

    脆弱的相互依赖和级联效应

    We’ve looked at examples of innovators generating profits not by changing the product based on customers’ stated preferences but by improving the system that the product belonged to. We’ve also seen examples of responding to changes within the system. Now let’s look at two characteristics of systems that make products vulnerable to creative destruction: (1) fragile interdependencies and (2) cascade effects. Understanding these will help you plan and adapt for changes in the system.

    我们已经看到了一些创新者创造利润的例子，他们不是通过根据顾客所陈述的偏好改变产品，而是通过改进产品所属的系统。我们还看到了响应系统内部变化的例子。现在让我们看看使产品容易遭受创造性破坏的系统的两个特征: (1)脆弱的相互依赖性和(2)级联效应。理解这些将帮助您计划和适应系统中的变化。


    Space travel makes for fragile interdependencies and cascade effects. The plot for the movie Gravity kicks off when a missile destroys a satellite. The debris from that satellite then destroys other satellites, whose debris goes on to destroy still more satellites. This cascade effect continues, eventually destroying the transportation that the main character had relied on to get home. If the main character is unable to adapt to all the changes, she will die.

    太空旅行造成了脆弱的相互依赖和级联效应。电影《地心引力》的情节开始于一枚导弹摧毁了一颗卫星。这颗卫星的碎片随后会摧毁其他卫星，这些卫星的碎片继续摧毁更多的卫星。这种级联效应持续不断，最终摧毁了主人公回家所依赖的交通工具。如果主角不能适应所有的变化，她就会死。


    In this example, the main character has fragile interdependency with the system she is a part of. In addition, a cascade effect dramatically changes her relationship with the system. In fact, the system changes so much, and her vulnerability is so high, that her chances of survival are almost zero.

    在这个例子中，主人公与她所属的系统之间有着脆弱的相互依赖关系。此外，级联效应极大地改变了她与系统的关系。事实上，这个系统变化如此之大，她的脆弱性如此之高，她的生存机会几乎为零。


    What happens in Gravity can happen to products. A product’s exposure to creative destruction goes up when it has fragile interdependencies with the system it is a part of or when innovators are unable or unwilling to respond to cascade effects within the system.

    引力中发生的事情也可能发生在产品上。当一个产品与其所属的系统之间存在脆弱的相互依赖关系，或者当创新者不能或不愿对系统内的级联效应作出反应时，该产品遭受创造性破坏的风险就会上升。


    Some fragile interdependencies expose system parts to creative destruction. Every system is unique. Moreover, each system has countless, unique interdependencies. Some interdependencies are robust; some are fragile. For example, if you were to remove a strand of hair from my head, the rest of my body is barely affected. But if you were to remove my arm, heart, or brain, the rest of my body would be severely affected.

    一些脆弱的相互依赖性使系统部件遭受创造性破坏。每个系统都是独一无二的。此外，每个系统都有无数独特的相互依赖关系。有些相互依赖性很强，有些则很脆弱。例如，如果你要从我头上取下一根头发，我身体的其他部分几乎不会受到影响。但如果你切除我的手臂，心脏或大脑，我身体的其他部分会受到严重影响。


    This idea of interdependencies and fragility also applies to the system of progress. In 2012, I left my job as FDT’s product manager and once again became an entrepreneur; however, my departure wasn’t hasty. Several months earlier, I had recommended to the CEO that the team be downsized and shifted to other products, that FDT be sold as a subscription instead of through major releases, and that advertising costs be eliminated or reduced. When I got the cost of production down as much as I could, I made one more cost-cutting decision: I fired myself.

    这种相互依存和脆弱性的思想也适用于进步系统。2012年，我辞去了 FDT 产品经理的工作，再次成为了一名企业家; 然而，我的离开并不草率。几个月前，我曾建议 CEO 缩小团队规模，转向其他产品，FDT 以订阅方式销售，而不是通过主要发行版销售，广告成本被消除或降低。当我尽可能地降低生产成本时，我又做了一个削减成本的决定: 我解雇了自己。


    Why did I do that? I understood that no matter what my team did, future demand for our product would diminish, causing a decline in revenue. And my job was to make sure that the product continued to deliver profits despite the decline in revenue. For that to work, costs had to be reduced.

    我为什么要这么做？我明白，无论我的团队做什么，未来对我们产品的需求将会减少，导致收入下降。我的工作就是确保产品在收入下降的情况下仍能继续带来利润。为了达到这个目的，必须降低成本。


    How did I know that revenue would decline? I understood that the product had a fragile interdependency that would drag down future demand: it had a tight coupling with a technology called Adobe Flash. Any changes to Adobe Flash also affected our product. When demand for Flash engineers went up, more of our product sold. When demand for Flash engineers went down, we sold less. Therefore, when I saw that the demand for Flash engineers was on an irreversible decline and would eventually extinguish, I knew demand for the product would disappear as well. In other words, a fragile interdependency made our product more vulnerable to creative destruction.

    我怎么知道收入会下降？我知道这个产品有一个脆弱的相互依赖关系，这会拖累未来的需求: 它与一个叫做 Adobe Flash 的技术有一个紧密的耦合。AdobeFlash 的任何改动都会影响我们的产品。当对 Flash 工程师的需求上升时，我们的产品卖出了更多。当对 Flash 工程师的需求下降时，我们的销量就下降了。因此，当我看到对 Flash 工程师的需求正在不可逆转地下降并最终消失时，我知道对该产品的需求也将消失。换句话说，脆弱的相互依赖性使我们的产品更容易受到创造性破坏。


    Another example of a fragile interdependency is when smartphone makers use the Android operating system. At first, smartphone makers jumped at the idea that they wouldn’t have to create their own operating system; they could just use Android. However, when they did this, they bound their smartphone’s success to Android. This can cause big problems. Just recently (August 9, 2016), a critical flaw was found in the Android operating system, affecting nine-hundred million phones! This

    智能手机制造商使用 Android 操作系统时，这种脆弱的相互依存关系就是另一个例子。一开始，智能手机制造商认为他们不需要创建自己的操作系统，他们只需要使用安卓系统就可以了。然而，当他们这样做的时候，他们把他们的智能手机的成功与 Android 绑定在一起。这可能会造成大问题。就在最近(2016年8月9日) ，Android 操作系统发现了一个严重的缺陷，影响了9亿部手机！这个


    means that these smartphone makers and all their customers have to wait until someone, somewhere, fixes the problem.66

    这意味着这些智能手机制造商和他们的所有客户必须等待，直到有人，在某个地方，解决了这个问题。66


    Cascade effects can affect the system. A cascade effect within a system is when one change in a system causes another change, triggering still others, and so on. A cascade effect contributes to the main character of Gravity being stranded in space. It’s also important to note that the magnitude (and speed) of these effects is often nonlinear. They start out small, but over time, they gain momentum.

    级联效应可以影响系统。系统中的级联效应是指系统中的一个更改导致另一个更改，从而触发其他更改，等等。级联效应是重力滞留在空间中的主要特征。同样需要注意的是，这些影响的程度(和速度)通常是非线性的。它们起初很小，但随着时间的推移，它们获得了动力。


    How Kodak succumbed to creative destruction is an example of how a business was at first unwilling—and then unable—to respond to a cascade effect. Kodak’s decline wasn’t just because of the shift from film to digital cameras; it was also because of all the downstream effects in the system of progress: (1) digital cameras began replacing film cameras for people’s JTBD; (2) customers switched from stand-alone digital cameras to the cameras in smartphones; (3) digital cameras began to affect other solutions for other jobs—for instance, people switched from using physical prints and snail mail to using digital images, e-mail, text messaging, and online social networks; and (4) a decline in the cost of mobile data, matched with changes in online social networks, encouraged many people to switch from sharing images to sharing video.

    柯达是如何屈服于创造性破坏的，这个例子说明了一家企业最初是如何不愿——然后又是如何无法——对一连串效应做出反应。柯达的衰落不仅仅是因为从胶片相机到数码相机的转变，还因为进步体系中的所有下游效应: (1)数码相机开始取代胶片相机，用于人们的 JTBD; (2)消费者从独立的数码相机转向智能手机中的相机; (3)数码相机开始影响其他工作的解决方案ーー例如，人们从使用物理打印和普通邮件转向使用数码图像、电子邮件、短信和在线社交网络; 以及(4)移动数据成本的下降，与在线社交网络的变化相一致，促使许多人从分享图像转向分享视频。


    Another example of a significant cascade effect is smartphones. Smartphones didn’t affect only those systems that included phones as a solution; they also affected systems that included gaming devices, navigation devices, fitness trackers, calculators, flashlights, scanners, bar-code scanners, video cameras, alarm clocks, and so on.

    另一个显著级联效应的例子是智能手机。智能手机不仅仅影响了那些包括手机在内的系统，它们还影响了那些包括游戏设备、导航设备、健身追踪器、计算器、手电筒、扫描仪、条形码扫描仪、摄像头、闹钟等等的系统。


    The introduction of smartphones created a cascade effect that affected how customers made progress across many different systems. At the time of this writing, smartphones are having a tremendous effect across multiple systems of progress in India. Because so many Indians live on only a few dollars a day, they are forced to make trade-offs on the things they buy. Lakshmi Kumari, who earns $100 a month washing kitchenware in rich homes, says, “[I’ve stopped buying hair-conditioner sachets.] It was an added expense. Shampoo works just fine. I can do without conditioner. But I can’t do anything without my phone. I can’t hear songs, I can’t surf the net, and I can’t chat with friends.” Venkatesh Kini, the president of Coca-Cola in India and southwest Asia, says, “We are competing for the consumer’s wallet not just with beverages and other impulse categories, but also with data services on smartphones.” 67

    智能手机的引入产生了一种级联效应，影响了客户在许多不同系统上取得进展的方式。在撰写本文时，智能手机正在印度的多个进步系统中产生巨大的影响。因为许多印度人每天的生活费只有几美元，他们不得不在他们购买的东西上做出权衡。拉克希米 · 库马里(Lakshmi Kumari)每月在富人家里洗厨具挣100美元，她说: “(我已经不再购买护发素香包了。)这是额外的开支。洗发水挺好用的。我可以不用护发素。但是没有手机我什么都做不了。我不能听歌，不能上网，也不能和朋友聊天。”印度和西南亚的可口可乐公司总裁 Venkatesh Kini 表示: “我们不仅在与饮料和其他冲动类产品竞争消费者的钱包，还在与智能手机上的数据服务竞争。”67


    Admittedly, cascade effects are not always that dramatic. We saw a small one happen with Clarity. When customers switched from attending a conference to Clarity, downstream products such as airlines, hotels, and restaurants lost customers as well. Yes, the effect on those products is barely noticeable; however, it demonstrates the complexity of systems. A change in a seemingly distant part of the system can affect the whole.

    不可否认，级联效应并不总是那么引人注目。我们看到 Clarity 身上发生了一个小问题。当客户从参加会议转向 Clarity 时，航空公司、酒店和餐厅等下游产品也失去了客户。是的，对这些产品的影响几乎不明显; 然而，它展示了系统的复杂性。系统中一个看似遥远的部分发生的变化可能会影响整个系统。


    Big things have small beginnings. Thinking about the fragile interdependencies within a system helps me become a better innovator. It even helps me as a customer. Should I buy a new speaker system that I plug my smartphone into? What happens when the smartphone manufacturer changes its inputs? Will I have to get an adapter?

    大事物都有小的开端。思考一个系统内部脆弱的相互依赖性有助于我成为一个更好的创新者。它甚至帮助我作为一个顾客。我应该买一个新的扬声器系统，我把我的智能手机插入？当智能手机制造商改变输入时会发生什么？我得买个适配器吗？


    Cascade effects are impossible to predict. You can predict a first-order effect. For example, when cars appeared, you might have been able to predict that nearly everyone would use one. But could you also have predicted nth-order effects, such as urban sprawl, Walmart, and car collecting? Probably not. In fact, I would have bet you couldn’t.

    级联效应是无法预测的。你可以预测一级效应。例如，当汽车出现的时候，你可能已经能够预测几乎每个人都会使用它。但是，你是否也能预测到 N 级效应，比如城市扩张、沃尔玛(Walmart)和汽车收藏？也许不会。事实上，我打赌你做不到。


    JTBD Empowers Us to Innovate

    JTBD 赋予我们创新的能力

    JTBD empowers us to innovate in a world filled with variation and complexity. It does this not by offering us strategies on what our innovation should or shouldn’t do but through equipping us with language and principles of customer motivation so that we can become better at creating our own strategies for innovation success. The following are some example scenarios:

    JTBD 使我们能够在一个充满变化和复杂性的世界中进行创新。它不是为我们提供创新应该做什么或不应该做什么的策略，而是让我们掌握客户激励的语言和原则，这样我们就能更好地创造我们自己的创新成功策略。以下是一些示例场景:


    Sometimes, success comes from continual improvement of existing high-margin products that serve the most-demanding customers, such as IBM and the mainframe over the past seventy years. Or maybe you go the other way and create a feature-minimal product that offers rock-bottom prices and a terrible user experience, akin to what Spirit Airlines does.

    有时候，成功来自现有的高利润产品的持续改进，这些产品服务于最苛刻的客户，比如 IBM 和过去七十年的大型机。或者你可以反其道而行之，创造一个功能最少的产品，提供最低的价格和糟糕的用户体验，就像精神航空公司所做的那样。


    Sometimes, an innovation simultaneously replaces products that cost considerably more and those that cost less. An accounting firm saves a great deal of money when it buys a PC to do the work of five accountants. At the same time, a PC is considerably more expensive than a typewriter or an Atari game system.

    有时，一项创新同时取代了成本高得多和成本低得多的产品。一家会计师事务所买一台个人计算机来做五个会计师的工作，可以省下一大笔钱。同时，个人电脑要比打字机或雅达利游戏机贵得多。


    Sometimes, all it takes is a few tweaks that help customers use a product, such as what I did with FDT. And sometimes the product is fine the way it is, and all that is needed is to help customers find and choose it, such as what Joanna Wiebe did.

    有时候，所需要的只是一些帮助客户使用产品的调整，就像我在 FDT 中所做的那样。有时候产品本身就很好，所需要做的就是帮助客户找到并选择它，就像 Joanna Wiebe 做的那样。


    Perhaps the best thing to do, though, is to develop new products that help customers evolve themselves in ways they might not be aware of yet—such as what Ash Maurya and Justin Jackson did.

    不过，或许最好的办法是开发新产品，帮助客户以他们可能尚未意识到的方式发展自己ーー比如阿什•毛里亚(Ash Maurya)和贾斯汀•杰克逊(Justin Jackson)的做法。


    It all comes down to four points: (1) all customers want to make progress within the systems they belong to; (2) customers, producers, innovators, and products are all parts of a system; (3) understanding the system comes from studying the interdependencies between the parts, not from studying the parts; and (4) each system is complex and one of a kind, so solutions that improve them must also be one of a kind.

    这一切归结为四点: (1)所有客户都希望在他们所属的系统内取得进展; (2)客户、生产者、创新者和产品都是系统的一部分; (3)理解系统来自于研究各部分之间的相互依赖，而不是来自于研究各部分; (4)每个系统都是复杂的、独一无二的，因此改进它们的解决方案也必须是独一无二的。


    Let’s go forth and become great at creating and selling products that people will buy.

    让我们勇往直前，在创造和销售人们愿意购买的产品方面做得更好。


    Put It to Work

    让它发挥作用

    Here are some points that may help you apply systems thinking to JTBD.

    以下几点可以帮助您将系统思维应用于 JTBD。


    Persuade customers to reject their current products by changing their JTBD. A great salesperson understands that customer “wants” come from the system, not the customer. So, if you want to change “what customers want,” all you have to do is convince them of a Job that is worth getting Done.

    通过更改 JTBD 来说服客户拒绝他们当前的产品。一个伟大的销售人员明白顾客的“需求”来自于系统，而不是顾客。所以，如果你想改变“顾客想要什么”，你所要做的就是让他们相信一份值得完成的工作。


    Imagine you make outdoor grills. You want to persuade customers to upgrade from small grills to larger, more expensive ones. How do you do that? Well, you won’t have much success if you just pepper customers with messages about how great your larger grill is or try to convince them that an existing grill is inferior. Why? These customers are fine with the way things are. A healthy sync exists between their JTBD and the small grill they’ve hired for it. Customers are making the kind of progress they want.

    想象一下你做室外烤架。你想说服顾客从小型烧烤架升级到更大、更昂贵的烧烤架。你是怎么做到的？如果你只是向顾客灌输你的大烤架有多棒或者试图说服他们现有的烤架是劣质的，那么你就不会取得多大的成功。为什么？这些顾客对现状很满意。一个健康的同步存在于他们的 JTBD 和他们雇佣的小烤架之间。客户正在取得他们想要的进步。


    However, you will have a shot at selling a larger grill if you can convince customers how rewarding it is to host a large party and grill food for everyone. If customers agree to that idea of progress, they realize that their current grills can’t get them there.

    然而，如果你能说服顾客举办一个大型聚会并为每个人烧烤食物是多么值得，那么你将有机会卖出一个更大的烧烤架。如果消费者同意这种进步的想法，他们就会意识到他们目前的烧烤架不能把他们带到那里。


    In that moment, you’ve changed the customers’ JTBD and changed the system of progress they interact with. If they want to restore sync to the system, then they need a new solution. That’s when you pull the curtain back on the larger grill and casually point out that they can cook food for twenty people.

    在那一刻，您已经改变了客户的 JTBD，并且改变了与他们交互的进度系统。如果他们想要恢复到系统的同步，那么他们需要一个新的解决方案。这时你拉开大烤架上的窗帘，漫不经心地指出他们可以为20个人做饭。


    Bring focus to which system of progress you’re solving for by splitting up products that deliver different types of progress. For many years, DeWalt made radial arm saws that woodworkers used to customize shapes. In 1960, Black+Decker (B&D), the tool company that invented the portable electric drill, acquired DeWalt. In the early 1990s, B&D decided that its DeWalt division would serve a different system of progress.

    通过拆分产品来提供不同类型的进度，将焦点集中在你正在解决的进度系统上。多年来，DeWalt 制造了木工用来定制形状的径向臂锯。1960年，发明便携式电钻的工具公司 Black + Decker (B & D)收购了 DeWalt。20世纪90年代初，B & D 决定，其德华特(DeWalt)部门将服务于一种不同的进步体系。


    B&D would continue to focus on giving homeowners the power to do small-scale home maintenance and fabrication work without the need for professionals. B&D’s products include items for lawn care, preselected power-tool kits, and DIY books. Conversely, DeWalt focuses on helping professional construction contractors have successful careers. Its line includes laser specs, compressors, generators, robust drills, and myriad other power tools and contractor-training products.

    B & D 将继续致力于赋予房主无需专业人士就能进行小规模房屋维护和制造的权力。B & D 的产品包括草坪护理项目，预先选定的电动工具包，和 DIY 书籍。相反，DeWalt 专注于帮助专业建筑承包商获得成功。其产品线包括激光规格，压缩机，发电机，强力钻头，以及无数其他电动工具和承包商培训产品。


    When done correctly, splitting up products—or sometimes companies—to address different systems of progress is a good answer to the question “Which jobs should our product or business focus on?” Remember that a product that tries to solve many Jobs at once ends up not being able to solve any one Job well. When this happens, your innovation exposure goes up, and your business becomes vulnerable to creative destruction.

    如果处理得当，将产品(有时是公司)拆分，以解决不同的进度体系，就是对“我们的产品或业务应该关注哪些工作”这个问题的一个很好的回答请记住，一个产品试图同时解决许多工作，结果却不能很好地解决任何一个工作。当这种情况发生时，你的创新曝光率就会上升，你的企业就会变得容易受到创造性破坏的影响。

  12. How Might We Describe a Job to be Done?

    我们如何描述一项要完成的工作？

    Try it yourself Describing a JTBD

    你自己试试描述一个 JTBD


    The Job to be Done is the big picture. It encapsulates why customers buy your product(s). Here are two ways this big-picture approach helps me:

    要完成的工作是大局。它概括了客户购买你的产品的原因。以下是这种全局方法对我的两种帮助:


    It’s portable throughout an organization. Everyone from marketing to design to engineering can use it. It helps them work together.

    从市场营销到设计再到工程设计，每个人都可以使用它，它可以帮助他们一起工作。


    It’s a good balance between high and low levels. It’s abstract enough to give room for creativity while also offering boundaries where a product starts and stops.

    这是高水平和低水平之间的良好平衡。它的抽象性足以给予创造性的空间，同时也提供了产品开始和结束的界限。


    This section describes how I like to describe a specific Job to be Done. It’s not the “right” way because I don’t believe there is one “right” way. What’s important are

    本节描述我如何描述要完成的具体工作。这不是“正确”的方式，因为我不相信有一个“正确”的方式。重要的是

    (1) does it help you and your team work together? (2) does it describe a “better me” for the customer; and (3) does it help you avoid describing a product or how someone uses it?

    (1)它有助于你和你的团队一起工作吗？(2)它是否为顾客描述了一个“更好的我”; (3)它是否帮助你避免描述一个产品或者别人如何使用它？


    Try It Yourself

    你自己试试

    If you want to know how I like to phrase a JTBD, jump to the next section. However, I recommend you try to describe one yourself. In this section, I’ll offer you some data I gathered from an investigation I did on why people were buying products from Honest. Honest is a company that sells products ranging from household cleaners to baby supplies. As you read through it, think about how you would describe these customers’ JTBD. The hint I offer you is to think about a JTBD in two parts—where they are today and where they want to be.

    如果您想知道我喜欢如何表达 JTBD，请跳到下一节。然而，我建议你试着自己描述一个。在本节中，我将向您提供一些数据，这些数据是我从一项关于人们为什么购买 Honest 产品的调查中收集到的。Honest 是一家销售从家用清洁剂到婴儿用品等各种产品的公司。在您阅读本文时，请考虑如何描述这些客户的 JTBD。我给您的提示是，将 JTBD 分为两部分考虑ーー它们现在处于什么位置以及它们希望处于什么位置。


    Honest’s products. Honest offers a wide range of all-natural household and childcare products, including soaps and detergents, moisturizers, sanitizer sprays, cleaners, diapers, baby wipes, baby food, and vitamin supplements, to name just a few. Collectively, they are marketed as giving a family what they need to create a safe, clean, nutritious, toxin-free environment for their children.

    诚实的产品。Honest 提供各种纯天然的家庭和儿童护理产品，包括肥皂和洗涤剂、保湿剂、消毒喷雾剂、清洁剂、尿布、婴儿湿巾、婴儿食品和维生素补充剂等等。总的来说，它们的营销目的是为了给一个家庭提供他们所需要的东西，为他们的孩子创造一个安全、清洁、有营养、无毒的环境。


    Besides the products, Honest also offers their products through a by-mail subscription. However, their version is different. The customer chooses

    除了产品，Honest 还通过电子邮件订阅提供他们的产品。但是，他们的版本是不同的。客户选择


    subscriptions to specific product bundles ranging from “diapers and wipes” to an “essentials” bundle that includes cleaners and bathing products.

    订购特定产品包，从“尿布和湿巾”到包括清洁剂和沐浴用品在内的“必需品”包。


    Understand the customer’s current life-situation. Next, it’s time to focus on the forces of progress that pushed and pulled customers toward buying these products. In this investigation, I found two groups of customers who were struggling the most: (1) parents who had recently had their first child and (2) parents who have children with various environmental sensitivities.

    了解客户当前的生活状况。接下来，是时候关注推动和拉动消费者购买这些产品的进步力量了。在这项调查中，我发现有两类顾客最为挣扎: (1)刚刚生下第一个孩子的父母; (2)有不同环境敏感性孩子的父母。


    Both groups described this struggle: The search for child-safe products left them feeling overwhelmed, tired, and scared. They’d ask for advice from their own parents, friends, doctors, community support groups, and the Internet. To them, it seemed that the more they “learned,” the more confused they would become. Their own parents would say one thing, the doctor would say another, and the Internet…well, the Internet says that everything is both fine and dangerous. Everyone had his or her own opinions. Disagreements and arguments between couples were aplenty. These groups of customers also described similar struggling moments. Here are a few:

    两组人都描述了这种挣扎: 寻找儿童安全产品让他们感到不知所措、疲惫和害怕。他们会向自己的父母、朋友、医生、社区支持团体和互联网寻求建议。对他们来说，似乎他们“学到”的越多，他们就会变得越困惑。他们自己的父母会说一套，医生会说另一套，而互联网... 嗯，互联网上说一切都很好，也很危险。每个人都有自己的观点。夫妻之间的分歧和争吵很多。这些顾客群体也描述了类似的挣扎时刻。这里有一些:


    Are there any chemicals in this baby formula that will harm my child? Is my child getting all the necessary nutrients for healthy brain development?

    这婴儿配方奶粉里有什么化学物质会伤害我的孩子吗？我的孩子是否获得了健康大脑发育所需的所有营养素？


    Does my floor cleaner have chemicals in it that will give my baby a rash? This cleaner looks like it’s OK, but it doesn’t specifically say it’s safe for babies.

    我的地板清洁剂里有会让宝宝起疹子的化学物质吗？这个清洁剂看起来还可以，但是没有明确说明它对婴儿是安全的。


    I finally found a safe household cleaner, but what about soap, shampoo, and baby wipes?

    我终于找到了一个安全的家用清洁剂，但是肥皂，洗发水和婴儿湿巾呢？


    My baby touches everything and puts everything in his/her mouth. What germs and chemicals do I need to worry about?

    我的宝宝接触所有的东西，把所有的东西放进他/她的嘴里。我需要担心什么细菌和化学物质？


    I see hives and redness on my child. Is the sunscreen not working, or is this an allergic reaction? My information sources all give different answers.

    我看到我的孩子身上有荨麻疹和红肿。是防晒霜不起作用，还是过敏反应？我的信息来源给出了不同的答案。


    Discovering how life should be. As I talked with parents who were struggling, I also asked them how they imagined life being better once they did find the right solution. The data were consistent and generally fell into two categories.

    发现生活应该是怎样的。当我与挣扎的父母交谈时，我也问他们，一旦他们找到了正确的解决办法，他们如何想象生活会变得更好。数据是一致的，一般分为两类。


    Some parents felt as if the joy of parenthood were being taken away or reduced. They imagined that if they found the right solution for their struggle, they would have the energy to enjoy being parents and experience the picture of parenthood they had had in their minds when they first decided to have children.

    一些父母感到，为人父母的快乐似乎正在被剥夺或减少。他们想象着，如果他们找到了正确的解决办法，他们就会有精力享受为人父母的感觉，体验当他们第一次决定要孩子的时候，他们脑海中的为人父母的景象。


    Parents felt they would get along better with their spouses. Some couples argued over which products were safe and which issues mattered. Did they need special soaps and shampoos? Wasn’t it good enough that their multipurpose household cleaner was labeled “organic”? Preventing disagreements like these would enable parents to enjoy parenting together instead of them working against each other.

    父母觉得他们会和配偶相处得更好。一些夫妇争论哪些产品是安全的，哪些问题是重要的。他们需要特殊的肥皂和洗发水吗？他们的多功能家用清洁剂被贴上“有机”的标签还不够好吗？预防这样的分歧将使父母能够一起享受养育子女的乐趣，而不是彼此对立。


    What was fired? The last piece of the puzzle is to learn what customers stopped doing when they started using Honest products. The results were consistent. These parents were combining multiple solutions together:

    什么被开除了？最后一个难题是了解客户在开始使用 Honest 产品时停止了哪些操作。结果是一致的。这些家长将多种解决方案结合在一起:


    Competing brands ranged from Huggies to Earth’s Best to Seventh Generation.

    竞争品牌从好奇到地球上最好的第七代。


    If they could, they bought multiple products from one manufacturer.

    如果可以的话，他们会从一家制造商购买多种产品。


    They were asking advice and input from family, friends, doctors, parent communities, and the Internet.

    他们向家人、朋友、医生、家长社区和互联网征求意见和建议。


    Based on these data, how would you describe this JTBD? Do you think there are more than one JTBD?

    根据这些数据，您如何描述这个 JTBD? 您认为有不止一个 JTBD 吗？


    Describing A JTBD

    描述一个 JTBD

    Here is how I described one JTBD that I discovered:

    我是这样描述我发现的一个 JTBD 的:


    Free me from the stress I deal with when figuring out what products won’t harm my children, so I can have more time to enjoy being a parent.

    当我发现什么产品不会伤害我的孩子的时候，把我从压力中解放出来，这样我就可以有更多的时间享受为人父母的乐趣。



    Figure 27. A possible description for a JTBD. Note the two parts: (1) the job, (2) when the job is done – i.e. when the “new me” is created.

    图27。JTBD 的可能描述。注意这两个部分: (1)作业，(2)作业完成的时间——也就是“新的我”被创建的时间



    When I put people’s JTBD into words, I prefer to keep it simple. I create a statement that combines the forces that generate demand (push and pull) with the Job and when it’s Done.

    当我把人们的 JTBD 用语言表达时，我更喜欢保持简单。我创建了一个声明，结合生成需求(推和拉)的力量与工作，当它完成。


    In this Honest example, you can see two parts: (1) free me from the stress I deal with when figuring out what products won’t harm my children, and (2) so I can have more time to enjoy being a parent.

    在这个诚实的例子中，你可以看到两个部分: (1)当我弄清楚什么产品不会伤害我的孩子时，把我从压力中解放出来; (2)这样我可以有更多的时间享受为人父母的乐趣。


    he emphasis on a struggle for progress is why this JTBD model often makes use of phrases such as give me, help me, make the, take away, free me, or equip me. These phrases remind us that success comes from the customers using the product to make progress. It also helps you think about how your product fits in between where they are now and where they want to be.

    他强调为进步而奋斗，这就是为什么这个 JTBD 模式经常使用诸如给我、帮助我、让我、带走我、解放我或装备我这样的短语。这些短语提醒我们，成功来自于消费者使用产品来取得进步。它还可以帮助你思考你的产品如何适应他们现在所处的位置和他们想要达到的位置。


    Variations of wording. I’ve used two other wordings. When you describe a JTBD, try a few different ways to say something, and use whichever you and your team prefer.

    措辞的变化。我还用了另外两个词。当您描述 JTBD 时，请尝试几种不同的表达方式，并使用您和您的团队喜欢的任何方式。


    Reverse it: “Help me have more time to enjoy being a parent, by taking away the stress I deal with when figuring out what products won’t harm my children.”

    反过来说: “帮助我有更多的时间享受为人父母的乐趣，当我弄清楚什么产品不会伤害我的孩子时，通过消除我所处理的压力。”


    Put it in third person: “Free parents from the stress they deal with when figuring out what products won’t harm their children, so they can have more time to enjoy being parents.”

    用第三人称来说: “当父母们发现什么产品不会伤害他们的孩子时，他们可以从压力中解脱出来，这样他们就有更多的时间享受为人父母的乐趣。”


    Testing the JTBD. The most important test of wording a JTBD is whether it also describes the solution(s) it replaced. Remember our lessons on creative destruction and JTBD principles: when customers start using a solution for a JTBD, they stop

    测试 JTBD。对 JTBD 措辞最重要的测试是它是否也描述了它所替代的解决方案。请记住我们关于创造性破坏和 JTBD 原则的教训: 当客户开始使用 JTBD 解决方案时，他们就停止了


    using something else. When applying this principle, we see that this description works.

    当应用这个原理时，我们看到这个描述是有效的。


    When parents started buying multiple products from Honest, they stopped behaviors such as asking friends, family, doctors, and the Internet. The only time when they would go back to any of these previous solutions was when their expectations were violated. For example, one parent described how she bought a sunscreen from Honest without considering any other options. However, her daughter broke out in hives when the sunscreen was applied. This prompted the parent to go search the Internet and talk with people about what sunscreen(s) weren’t safe. She also talked with her doctor to figure out if her daughter had an unknown allergy.

    当父母开始从 Honest 购买多种产品时，他们停止了询问朋友、家人、医生和互联网等行为。只有当他们的期望被打破时，他们才会回到以前的任何一种解决方案。例如，一位家长描述了她是如何在没有考虑任何其他选择的情况下从 Honest 公司购买防晒霜的。然而，当涂抹防晒霜时，她的女儿出现了荨麻疹。这促使父母去搜索互联网，并与人们谈论什么防晒霜是不安全的。她还与她的医生交谈，以确定她的女儿是否患有不明原因的过敏症。


    A JTBD to note. I chose to share this JTBD because it presents an interesting situation: I believe that many parents are hiring Honest—the brand—more than any individual product. When parents realized they needed a sunblock, they automatically bought one from Honest. This is important because it shows how fatigued parents were in their decision-making process. It also explains why the bundles are a great idea. With these bundles, Honest is telling parents that they don’t need to think about what they need; Honest will take care of it. This delivery service also helps customers develop and maintain a habit of using Honest products.

    需要注意的 JTBD。我之所以选择分享这个 JTBD，是因为它呈现了一个有趣的情况: 我相信，许多家长聘用 Honest ーー这个品牌ーー的次数超过了任何一个单独的产品。当父母意识到他们需要防晒霜时，他们自动从 Honest 买了一个。这一点很重要，因为它显示了父母在决策过程中是多么疲惫。这也解释了为什么捆绑销售是个好主意。有了这些捆绑，诚实告诉父母，他们不需要考虑他们需要什么，诚实会照顾它。这种送货服务还可以帮助客户培养和保持使用诚信产品的习惯。


    I also like how Honest is offering a collection of products that work together—as a system—to deliver customers progress. These products act as touch points between Honest and various parenting aspirations. It’s as though Honest is a software product that customers subscribe to, and each product is an individual feature.

    我还喜欢 Honest 提供的一系列产品，它们作为一个系统一起工作，为客户带来进步。这些产品充当了诚实和各种育儿愿望之间的接触点。就好像 Honest 是客户订阅的软件产品，每个产品都是一个独立的特性。


    Finally, this example shows a high-level JTBD. How high or low you choose to describe a JTBD is a design and business decision.

    最后，这个示例展示了一个高级 JTBD。您选择多高或多低来描述 JTBD 是一个设计和业务决策。


    How you describe a JTBD is a competitive advantage. As mentioned before, I don’t believe that there’s any “right” way to phrase a JTBD. Such a claim would mean that there is no creativity in innovation—that we can just outsource our thinking to some model created by someone else. Every system is one of a kind, and every effort to improve a system should likewise be one of a kind.

    如何描述 JTBD 是一个竞争优势。正如前面提到的，我不认为有任何“正确”的方式来表达 JTBD。这种说法意味着创新中没有创造力ーー我们可以将自己的思维外包给别人创造的某种模式。每一个系统都是独一无二的，每一个改进系统的努力也应该是独一无二的。

  13. Get Started Today

    今天就开始

    Influencing others

    影响他人

    Learning Customer Jobs from others jtbd.info

    从别人那里学习客户工作

    Customer Jobs Meetups Contacting me

    客户工作会议联系我


    How you apply Customer Jobs depends on your situation. How much influence do you wield in your team or organization? Are you a designer who needs to persuade a product manager? Are you an entrepreneur or CEO who wields influence over employees? Are you a venture capitalist who wants to make better investments on behalf of your limited partners? How are your leadership and persuasion skills? Do you have access to customers? Do you have a product now, or are your creating a new one from scratch?

    如何应用客户工作取决于你的情况。你对你的团队或组织有多大的影响力？你是一个需要说服产品经理的设计师吗？你是一个对员工有影响力的企业家或者 CEO 吗？你是一个风险投资家，想代表你的有限合伙人进行更好的投资吗？你的领导能力和说服技巧如何？你能接触到顾客吗？你现在有产品了吗? 或者你正在从头开始创造一个新的产品？


    Each of these circumstances requires a different approach. Without knowing your JTBD—and why you hired this book—it would be wrong of me to tell you what to do next. What I can do is arm you with ideas on choices you can make. I can tell you how other people have solved something and what problems might arise for you as you engage in a course of action.

    每种情况都需要不同的方法。在不知道你的 JTBD 以及你为什么雇用这本书的情况下，我不应该告诉你接下来该做什么。我能做的就是给你提供你可以做出的选择。我可以告诉你其他人是如何解决问题的，当你采取行动的时候，你可能会遇到什么问题。


    Regardless of what you do next, remember that everyone desires progress, even you. Understand that first, and then figure out the best way to make that progress happen.

    不管你接下来做什么，记住每个人都渴望进步，即使是你。首先要理解这一点，然后找出实现这一进程的最佳方法。


    Finally, this can be your last chapter if you intended to learn just the theory of Customer Jobs. If you want to apply Customer Jobs to discover innovation opportunities, please read on.

    最后，如果你只想学习客户工作的理论，这可能是你的最后一章。如果你想应用客户工作来发现创新机会，请继续阅读。


    Influencing Others: Customer Jobs Top Down

    影响他人: 客户工作自上而下

    I’ve introduced Customer Jobs thinking to teammates as a founder and as a product manager. Dan Martell from Clarity introduced Customer Jobs thinking to his team. Morgan Ranieri’s cofounder at YourGrocer insisted on applying Customer Jobs thinking before getting started. Here are some recommendations for you if you want to build Customer Jobs thinking into your endeavor.

    作为创始人和产品经理，我已经向队友们介绍了客户工作思想。Clarity 的丹•马特尔(Dan Martell)向他的团队介绍了客户工作的思路。YourGrocer 的联合创始人摩根•拉涅利(Morgan Ranieri)坚持在开始工作之前应用客户工作的思想。这里有一些建议给你，如果你想建立客户工作的思想进入你的努力。


    Be a practitioner first. Then, tell everyone about the benefits and some practices. Dan from Clarity began by first being a practitioner himself. He introduced

    先做个医生。然后，告诉大家有关的好处和一些做法。来自 Clarity 的 Dan 一开始也是个实践者。他介绍


    Customer Jobs to his employees only after he had successfully interviewed customers and understood their JTBD. When he was ready to involve everyone else, he explained the high-level concept to them, he gave them tools and techniques on how to interview customers, and then all of them interviewed customers together.

    只有在他成功地面试了客户并理解了他们的 JTBD 之后，才能向他的员工提供客户工作。当他准备好让每个人都参与进来时，他向他们解释高层次的概念，给他们提供如何采访客户的工具和技巧，然后所有人一起采访客户。


    Are you being asked to start a company? Insist on Customer Jobs research. When Morgan invited Frankie Trindade to join YourGrocer as technical cofounder, Frankie insisted that they understand their customers’ JTBD before moving ahead with anything. Frankie wanted to make sure an opportunity existed before he left his current job and would be spending his time building the right product since he would be engineering it. Not only did this approach bring the team members together, but it also helped them get started on the right foot.

    你是否被要求创办一家公司？坚持客户工作研究。当摩根邀请弗兰基 · 特林达德(Frankie Trindade)加入 YourGrocer 成为技术联合创始人时，弗兰基坚持要求他们在推进任何事情之前了解客户的 JTBD。弗兰基想要确保在他离开现在的工作之前有一个机会，而且他会花时间来开发正确的产品，因为他会设计这个产品。这种方法不仅把团队成员聚集在一起，而且还帮助他们有了一个良好的开端。


    Just do it. But separate the data from your synthesis of them. When I was product manager for FDT, I was responsible only to the CEO. He supported whatever I did as long as I got results. I didn’t ask for permission to apply JTBD thinking; I just did it. I interviewed customers and gathered data, distilled their JTBD, discovered Job Stories, and presented my data and insights to the rest of the team.

    照做就是了。但要把数据和综合数据分开。当我是 FDT 的产品经理时，我只对 CEO 负责。只要我有结果，他就支持我做的一切。我并没有请求许可来应用 JTBD 思维，我只是这样做了。我采访了客户，收集了数据，提炼了他们的 JTBD，发现了工作故事，并向团队的其他成员展示了我的数据和见解。


    The catch is that I made sure not to commingle my data with my synthesis of them. This gave the team the opportunity to debate my findings and offer their own interpretations of those data. I also never explicitly claimed that I was applying JTBD principles. I just used the language when presenting the data. Everyone felt involved, and they caught on. They applied Customer Jobs theory without knowing it.

    问题在于，我确保了不把我的数据和我的综合数据混在一起。这使研究小组有机会对我的研究结果进行辩论，并对这些数据提出自己的解释。我也从未明确声称我正在应用 JTBD 原则。我只是在展示数据时使用了这种语言。每个人都觉得自己被卷进来了，他们也明白了。他们在不知情的情况下应用了客户工作理论。


    Influencing Others: Customer Jobs Bottom Up

    影响他人: 客户工作自下而上

    Other Customer Jobs practitioners have kindly shared their experiences in influencing coworkers about Customer Jobs thinking. Create a Customer Jobs theme Meetup, by David Wu:

    其他客户工作从业人员已经友好地分享了他们的经验，影响同事对客户工作的想法。创建一个客户工作主题会议，作者: David Wu:


    I first applied Customer Jobs theory and practices while leading product management at Meetup. Meetup is a product you can use to organize a local group or find one that you can join. I began applying Customer Jobs principles in my own work and then introduced it to the rest of my team. Once we had made a few successes, we introduced our results in a presentation with the rest of the company.

    我第一次应用客户工作理论和实践是在 Meetup 领导产品管理的时候。Meetup 是一个产品，您可以使用它来组织本地小组，或者找到一个您可以加入的小组。我开始在自己的工作中应用客户工作原则，然后将其介绍给团队的其他成员。一旦我们取得了一些成功，我们就会向公司的其他人介绍我们的成果。


    I began by interviewing customers myself. Our company had a usability lab that brought in customers almost every day of the week for tests. It wasn’t hard for me to talk with customers after they had completed a usability test.

    我开始亲自采访客户。我们公司有一个可用性实验室，几乎每周每天都带来客户进行测试。在客户完成可用性测试之后，我和他们交谈并不困难。


    I would talk with them about the first time they had used our product, the last time they used it, and what other products they had used in the past before using Meetup. Once I was comfortable running interviews, I began inviting members of my team to join me. They immediately began seeing the value in talking with customers about their desire for self-betterment and how they were expecting [their lives] to be better with Meetup. We were getting data about specific moments of struggle that would help us design new features and find the right messaging that would connect with customers.

    我会和他们谈论他们第一次使用我们的产品，最后一次使用它，以及在使用 Meetup 之前他们还使用过哪些其他产品。一旦我适应了进行面试，我就开始邀请我的团队成员加入我。他们立即开始看到与客户谈论他们对自我提升的渴望以及他们如何期望(他们的生活)通过 Meetup 变得更好的价值。我们正在获取关于特定挣扎时刻的数据，这些数据将帮助我们设计新功能，并找到与客户建立联系的正确信息。


    My team and I had found value in applying Customer Jobs principles to our work. We wanted to introduce it to the rest of the company, but we had to do it in a way that wouldn’t put people off. We decided to give a short presentation, at lunchtime, about what we had learned about our customers’ struggles.

    我和我的团队发现了将客户工作原则应用到我们的工作中的价值。我们想把它介绍给公司的其他人，但是我们必须以一种不会让人们反感的方式来做。我们决定在午餐时间做一个简短的介绍，说说我们从客户的挣扎中学到了什么。


    I created a catchy title for the presentation: “Why People Fire Meetup.” The presentation focused on customers who had churned. I showed pictures of customers who had stopped using our product. Next to those pictures, I displayed quotes about the anxieties they had experienced while using our product. Most of the quotes were related to attending a Meetup for the first time or organizers not knowing how to plan a successful Meetup.

    我为这个演讲创建了一个吸引人的标题: “为什么人们要开会”演讲的重点是那些遭遇困境的客户。我给那些已经停止使用我们产品的顾客看照片。在这些图片旁边，我展示了他们在使用我们的产品时所经历的焦虑。大多数引用都与第一次参加聚会有关，或者组织者不知道如何计划一次成功的聚会。


    Showing the picture of [the customers] who had churned, along with a quote from them about their struggle, had a big impact. Right away, people in the audience started volunteering ideas on how we could fix these problems. There was a lot of positive energy in the room. When the time was right, I explained that I had gathered these data through applying some JTBD principles and practices. This got the JTBD ball rolling at our company.

    展示那些被搅得天翻地覆的顾客的照片，以及他们关于自己斗争的一段话，产生了巨大的影响。很快，观众中的人们开始主动提出解决这些问题的想法。房间里充满了正能量。当时机成熟时，我解释说，我通过应用一些 JTBD 原则和实践收集了这些数据。这让我们公司的 JTBD 运转起来了。


    Customer Jobs thinking starts with ideas you can test, by Dan Ritzenthaler:

    返回文章页面客户译者:


    Great designers will want to understand their customer’s struggle before they design a solution for it. Unfortunately, getting this directly

    伟大的设计师在为客户设计解决方案之前，会希望了解他们的客户的困境


    from the customer can be hard. You’re eager to go out and talk with customers about their struggles. Your teammates, on the other hand, might try to legitimize design decisions through their own intuition and anecdotal data. This puts you in a tough spot.

    从顾客那里得到好处是很难的。你渴望走出去和客户谈论他们的困难。另一方面，您的队友可能会试图通过他们自己的直觉和轶事数据来使设计决策合法化。这让你很为难。


    People are averse to change. You’re more likely to put people off— instead of winning their support—if you try to directly sell them on a new way of doing things. Instead, let them explore their prejudices, anecdotal guesses, and intuition. Then, reframe and massage their stories into a format that everyone can verify.

    人们反对改变。如果你试图直接向人们推销一种新的做事方式，那么你更有可能让他们反感，而不是赢得他们的支持。相反，让他们探索自己的偏见、轶事猜测和直觉。然后，将他们的故事重新组合并按摩成每个人都可以验证的格式。


    Here is a way you can put your teammates’ hypothesis into a format that you can all test: (1) How are customers currently struggling? (2) What is pushing customers to need a new solution? (3) Without describing the feature, how will the customer’s life be better once the feature exists? (4) What is preventing customers from adopting a new solution?

    这里有一个方法，你可以把你的队友的假设变成一个格式，你可以全部测试: (1)客户目前如何挣扎？(2)是什么促使客户需要新的解决方案？(3)在不描述特征的情况下，一旦特征存在，客户的生活将如何变得更好？(4)是什么阻止客户采用新的解决方案？


    Now you have something that your team can verify. You’ll be in a better position to ask your teammates, “Can I go check this out with a few customers?” Perhaps you can get some customers on to a quick phone call or send a survey.

    现在你有你的团队可以证实的东西了。你会处于一个更好的位置去问你的队友，“我能和几个顾客一起去看看吗?”也许你可以让一些客户快速打电话或者发送一份调查。


    It’s easier to sell “consumer research” as due diligence and verification of existing assumptions. It’s hard to sell a new process framework. Plus, for people who haven’t yet discovered the value of research, it’s less likely to seem like wasted energy.

    把“消费者研究”作为尽职调查和对现有假设的验证更容易推销。很难推销新的流程框架。另外，对于那些还没有发现研究价值的人来说，它不太可能看起来像是浪费能源。


    Over time, your teammates will see the value in understanding the customer’s desire to improve themselves. Then, you’re in a stronger position to request JTBD-style interviews before flushing out a potential feature.

    随着时间的推移，你的团队成员将看到理解客户改进自己的愿望的价值。然后，您就处于一个更有利的位置，可以在充实潜在特性之前申请 JTBD 风格的面试。


    Learning Customer Jobs from Others

    向他人学习客户工作

    You may want to learn more about JTBD theory from others and about how others have applied it. This is good, but it has challenges.

    您可能希望从其他人那里了解更多关于 JTBD 理论以及其他人是如何应用它的。这很好，但也有挑战。


    Customer Jobs has been around for a while, but it’s currently fragmented.

    客户工作已经存在了一段时间，但目前它是分散的

    Customer Jobs began with Bob Moesta, John Palmer, and Richard Pedi. For many

    客户工作从鲍勃 · 莫斯塔、约翰 · 帕尔默和理查德 · 佩迪开始


    years, it was only a nascent theory with rough edges. These men evolved it as they applied it, and they taught parts of it to clients, friends, coworkers, and academics. The spread of Customer Jobs has been similar to the spread of information in the telephone game; every time it passed from one person to another, it changed a little bit.

    多年来，这只是一个有着粗糙边缘的新兴理论。这些人在应用的过程中不断进化，他们将其中的一部分传授给客户、朋友、同事和学者。客户工作的传播类似于电话游戏中的信息传播，每次从一个人传到另一个人，都会有一点点改变。


    This is a trade-off when a message is spread quickly, but the result is frustrating for newcomers who want to know which version is “right” or “the best.” Even Pedi’s, Moesta’s, and Palmer’s ideas on Customer Jobs have diverged. Today, you might think they are talking about completely different things.

    当一条信息传播得很快时，这是一种权衡，但对于想知道哪个版本是“正确的”或“最好的”的新手来说，结果是令人沮丧的甚至连佩迪、莫斯塔和帕尔默对客户工作的看法也存在分歧。今天，你可能认为他们在谈论完全不同的事情。


    I, myself, don’t have an allegiance to any single “correct” version of Customer Jobs. I don’t want Customer Jobs; I want the progress the theory can deliver me. My advice is not to worry about which way is the correct one to apply Customer Jobs thinking. Pick and choose whatever parts help you; however, I do stick very close to the principles and theory outlined in this book. They have been proven, through practice, to be reliable. I recommend you do the same.

    我个人并不忠于任何一个“正确”的客户工作版本。我不想要客户工作，我想要理论带给我的进步。我的建议是，不要担心应用客户工作思维的正确方式。挑选任何能帮助你的部分，然而，我坚持非常接近的原则和理论在这本书中概述。实践证明，它们是可靠的。我建议你也这么做。


    JTBD.INFO

    I maintain a collection of Customer Jobs-related articles at jtbd.info. I invite you to read them. I also encourage you, the reader, to submit articles for publication. How have you applied Customer Jobs? Have you created any tools that might help others? Do you have a story to tell? Do you have an idea on how to improve Customer Jobs theory? You can submit an article via jtbd.info by clicking the email or Twitter icons on the front page.

    我在 jtbd.info 上维护了一系列与客户工作相关的文章。我邀请你读一读。我也鼓励你，读者，提交文章发表。你是如何应用客户工作的？你是否创造了任何可以帮助他人的工具？你有故事要讲吗？你对如何改进客户工作理论有什么想法吗？您可以通过 jtbd.info 提交文章，只需点击首页上的电子邮件或 Twitter 图标即可。


    My rules for publishing are straightforward. First, the content must be mostly original. It doesn’t help anyone to rephrase what someone else has already said elsewhere. Second, contrary opinions are welcome and encouraged but need to be well formed and supported. Perhaps you disagree with the theory I suggest in this book. That’s great! Just make sure your argument is solid and backed up.

    我的出版规则很简单。首先，内容必须大部分是原创的。重新措辞别人在别处已经说过的话，对任何人都没有帮助。第二，反对意见是受欢迎和鼓励的，但需要良好的形式和支持。也许你不同意我在这本书中提出的理论。太棒了！只要确保你的论点是站得住脚的。


    Customer Jobs Meetups. A Customer Jobs Meetup (meetup.com) is a great place to discuss Customer Jobs principles and practices and to share stories. David Wu began the JTBD (abbreviated from Customer Jobs) Meetup in New York City, and now I cohost it with him.

    客户工作聚会。客户工作聚会(Meetup. com)是一个讨论客户工作原则和实践并分享故事的好地方。David Wu 在纽约开始了 JTBD (客户工作的缩写)会议，现在我和他一起主持。


    Running a Meetup. A great way to run a Meetup is to introduce Customer Jobs briefly to anyone new. Then, introduce a product and invite everyone to think

    开会。运行 Meetup 的一个很好的方法是向任何新人简要介绍客户工作。然后，介绍一个产品，并邀请大家思考


    about what Job(s) it might be used for—that is, how it helps people improve themselves, and how it makes people’s lives better.

    关于它可能被用来做什么ーー也就是说，它如何帮助人们提高自己，以及它如何使人们的生活更美好。


    A Customer Jobs Meetup will be most successful when you have at least four attendees. Or, before starting a Customer Jobs Meetup in your area, you may want to have informal get-togethers in your community. The following are some possible ideas.

    客户工作会议将是最成功的，当你有至少四个与会者。或者，在你所在地区开始一个客户工作聚会之前，你可能想在你的社区里举行一个非正式的聚会。以下是一些可能的想法。


    Begin as an advocate within your company. Perhaps you can convince a few coworkers to meet after work or during lunch to talk about applying Customer Jobs principles to your business. When you become comfortable with this, invite people from other companies to join in. Exchange ideas and challenges.

    从公司内部的一名律师开始。也许你可以说服一些同事在下班后或午餐时间见面，讨论如何将客户工作原则应用到你的业务中。当你对此感到满意时，邀请其他公司的人加入进来。交流想法和挑战。


    Meet other entrepreneurs and innovators at other Meetups. Talk with them about Customer Jobs. If you can drum up interest, ask if they’d be interested in getting together for a Meetup specifically about Customer Jobs.

    在其他聚会上与其他企业家和创新者见面。与他们讨论客户工作。如果你能激起他们的兴趣，问问他们是否有兴趣一起参加一个关于客户工作的聚会。


    Contacting Me

    联系我

    I try to help anyone I can, however I can. As time permits, I enjoy doing calls and sharing e-mails with entrepreneurs and innovators. I encourage you to contact me via my website with your questions or comments or if you want help. If I can’t help you, I’m sure I know someone who can.

    我尽我所能帮助任何人。在时间允许的情况下，我喜欢与企业家和创新者打电话、分享电子邮件。我鼓励你通过我的网站与我联系，提出你的问题或意见，或者如果你需要帮助。如果我帮不了你，我知道有人能帮你。


    I also enjoy learning how others apply Customer Jobs. If you have a story or insight to share, feel free to contact me. The best ways to contact me are through my website, alanklement.com; Twitter, @alanklement; or the jtbd.info site.

    我也喜欢学习其他人如何应用客户工作。如果你有故事或见解要分享，请随时与我联系。联系我的最好方式是通过我的网站 alanklement.com、 Twitter@alanklement 或者 jtbd.info。

  14. Appendix: Know the Two — Very — Different

    附录: 认识两者ーー非常ーー不同

    Interpretations of Jobs to be Done

    对待完成工作的解读

    Two Models: Jobs-As-Progress; Jobs-As-Activities Do Goals vs. Be Goals

    两种模式: 工作即进步; 工作即活动: 实现目标与成为目标

    Jobs-As-Activities Jobs-As-Progress

    作为活动的工作作为进步的工作

    Two different, incompatible models

    两种不同的，互不相容的模式

    The Future? Use What’s Helpful. Don’t Assume Anything

    未来? 使用有用的东西。不要假设任何东西


    Note: the content in this chapter originally appeared as a blog post on JTBD.info. It has been added to this second edition because many people find it helpful.

    注意: 本章的内容最初是以博客文章的形式出现在 JTBD.info 上的。它被添加到这第二版，因为许多人发现它有帮助。


    The popularity of Jobs to be Done has exploded in recent years. This has been both good and bad.

    最近几年，《待完成的工作》的受欢迎程度呈爆炸式增长，这既有好的一面，也有坏的一面。


    On the benefit side, powerful concepts like “progress” are disseminating throughout design and innovation communities. On the downside, because the phrase “Jobs to be Done” has evolved publicly and openly for quite some time, numerous problems have popped up:

    在利益方面，像“进步”这样强大的概念正在整个设计和创新社区传播。不利的一面是，由于“待完成的工作”这个短语已经公开演变了相当长一段时间，许多问题出现了:


    After Clayton Christensen loosely introduced the phrase in his book, The Innovator’s Solution (2003), many people have offered different interpretations of Jobs to be Done.

    克莱顿•克里斯滕森(Clayton Christensen)在其著作《创新者的解决方案》(The Innovator’s Solution，2003年出版)中松散地介绍了这个短语之后，许多人对待完成工作提出了不同的解释。


    Newcomers are unaware of the different interpretations. This confuses them and/or discourages them from participating.

    新来的人没有意识到不同的解释，这使他们感到困惑和/或不愿意参加。


    Criticisms against one interpretation are mistakenly applied to both. This dissuades people from investigating it further.

    对一种解释的批评被错误地应用于两种解释，这阻止了人们进一步的调查。


    The aim of this chapter will help you:

    本章的目的是帮助你:


    Know the two main interpretations of Jobs to be Done.

    了解工作待完成的两种主要解释。


    Be able to quickly find JTBD content that is relevant to you. Understand why people claim why one interpretation is nothing new. Contribute and evolve Jobs theory in a positive, open-source way.

    能够快速找到与您相关的 JTBD 内容。理解为什么人们声称一种解释并不新鲜。以积极、开源的方式贡献和发展乔布斯理论。


    Two Models: Jobs-As-Progress; Jobs-As-Activities

    两种模式: 工作即进步，工作即活动

    This chapter will focus on the two, main interpretation of Jobs to be Done. Each has evolved in different ways. And as you will learn, they are also incompatible with each other.

    本章将重点介绍两个主要的工作要做的解释。每一个都以不同的方式进化。你会发现，它们也是互不相容的。


    The two versions of Job to be Done are:

    工作待完成的两个版本是:


    Jobs-As-Progress: a theory that is promoted by Clayton Christensen, Bob Moesta, and myself.

    作为进步的工作: 一个由克莱顿 · 克里斯滕森，鲍勃 · 莫斯塔和我提出的理论。


    Jobs-As-Activities: an ideology and typology promoted by Anthony Ulwick and licensees of his patented Outcome Driven Innovation.

    作为活动的工作: 一种意识形态和类型学，由安东尼 · 乌尔维克和他的专利成果驱动创新的许可证推广。


    In an odd coincidence, these two different ideas can be represented side by side in an excerpt from Levitt’s 1983 book, The Marketing Imagination:

    奇怪的巧合是，这两种不同的想法可以并排出现在莱维特1983年出版的《营销想象力:


    [The marketing imagination] resides in its implied suggestion as to what to do— in this case, find out what problems people are trying to solve. It is represented by Charles Revson’s famous distinction regarding the business of Revlon, Inc.: “In the factories we make cosmetics. In the drugs stores we sell hope.” It is characterized by Leo McGinneva’s famous clarification about why people buy quarter-inch drill bits:” They don’t want quarter-inch bits. They want quarter-inch holes.”

    (市场营销的想象力)存在于对于该做什么的暗示之中ーー在这种情况下，找出人们试图解决的问题。查尔斯•雷夫森(Charles Revson)对露华浓公司(Revlon，Inc。)业务的著名评价代表了这一点: “在工厂里，我们生产化妆品。在药店里，我们卖的是希望。”拥有属性里奥 · 麦克吉尼瓦对人们为什么购买四分之一英寸的钻头做出了著名的澄清: “他们不想要四分之一英寸的钻头。他们想要四分之一英寸的洞”


    While Levitt wasn’t talking about JTBD, his two examples match the two different interpretations of Job to be Done. Each offers a different opinion on why people buy products.

    虽然莱维特没有谈论 JTBD，但他的两个例子与对待完成工作的两种不同解释相吻合。对于人们为什么购买产品，每个人都有不同的看法。


    Revson’s customers-want-hope is about results from a change. I buy and use makeup for the first time because I want to change how others perceive me and how I perceive myself.

    Revson 的客户需要希望是关于改变带来的结果。我第一次购买和使用化妆品是因为我想改变别人对我的看法和我对自己的看法。


    McGinneva’s customers-want-quarter-inch-holes is about results from a use-case. I buy a particular drill bit because I want to make a particular hole.

    McGinneva 的“客户想要四分之一英寸的洞”是关于一个用例的结果。我买一个特别的钻头是因为我想钻一个特别的孔。





    Figure 28. Powers’ hierarchy of goals as represented in “on the self-regulation of behavior” (carver 2001). Also see “means-ends” analysis (Newell & Simon 1972).

    图28。权力的目标等级表现在“对行为的自我调节”(卡弗2001年)。另见“手段-目的”分析(Newell & Simon 1972)



    Before we get into the details of these two interpretations, we need some background on the difference between “Be” goals and “Do” goals.

    在我们进入这两种解释的细节之前，我们需要了解一些关于“ Be”目标和“ Do”目标之间区别的背景知识。


    Do Goals Vs. Be Goals

    目标 VS 成为目标

    Even if you forget everything else in this chapter, make sure you remember figure 28.

    即使您忘记了本章中的其他内容，也一定要记住图28。


    William Powers’ hierarchy of goals (1973a, 1973b) is a widely accepted model of the relationship between the things we do, and why we do them. Not only does this help with understanding Jobs to be Done, it also helps in understanding other approaches to design and innovation.

    威廉 · 鲍尔斯(William Powers)的目标层次理论(1973a，1973b)是一个被广泛接受的关于我们所做的事情和我们为什么做这些事情之间关系的模型。这不仅有助于理解工作待完成，也有助于理解其他方法的设计和创新。


    With regards to JTBD, this model is a typology that describes a few important concepts:

    关于 JTBD，该模型是一种类型学，描述了几个重要概念:


    The types of goals humans have.

    人类的目标类型。



    Figure 29. A dependency inversion exists within our goal system.

    图29。依赖性反转存在于我们的目标系统中



    The priority order amongst the different types of goals. How the goal types influence each other.

    不同目标类型之间的优先顺序。目标类型如何相互影响。

    The dependency between goal types.

    目标类型之间的依赖关系。


    Here’s how it works.

    事情是这样的。


    Different goals. Your ideal self is a synthesis of various Principles or “Be” goals. For example, you think of yourself as a particular type of parent or friend and having a particular set of personal freedoms. These Be goals are what motivate you to choose and carry out one or more Programs or “Do” goals. These Do goals are then fulfilled by Sequences or Motor control goals.

    不同的目标。你的理想自我是各种原则或“存在”目标的综合体。例如，你认为自己是一个特殊类型的父母或朋友，有一套特殊的个人自由。这些是目标是什么激励你选择和执行一个或多个计划或“做”的目标。这些“执行”目标随后通过序列或运动控制目标来实现。


    Be goals have the highest priority; Motor control goals have the lowest. Be goals are the core drivers of all our actions and decisions. This also means that, no matter how well a Do or Motor Control goal is fulfilled, it’s a failure if the higher Be goal is not satisfied. It also means that a Do goal doesn’t have to be successfully executed to fulfill a Be goal.

    目标具有最高的优先级; 运动控制目标具有最低的优先级。目标是我们所有行动和决定的核心驱动力。这也意味着，无论“做”或“运动控制”目标实现得多么好，如果更高的 Be 目标没有得到满足，那么这个目标就是失败的。它还意味着，要实现 Be 目标，不一定非要成功地执行 Do 目标。


    A fancy way of saying this, is to say that a dependency inversion exists in our goal systems (figure 29). High level goals don’t need low level goals, but low-level goals need high level goals.

    说这话的一种花哨的方式是说依赖性反转存在于我们的目标系统中(图29)。高层次的目标不需要低层次的目标，但是低层次的目标需要高层次的目标。


    For example, suppose your goal is to be thoughtful for your family. To fulfill this goal, you choose the activity cook.

    例如，假设你的目标是为家人着想。为了实现这个目标，您可以选择活动炊事器。


    However, the fulfillment of be thoughtful isn’t dependent on the success or failure of cook dinner.

    然而，体贴的实现并不取决于做饭的成败。


    It’s possible that you brilliantly cook dinner, but if your family would have preferred going to a restaurant, you failed. On the other hand, you could be totally unsuccessful at the cook dinner activity, but if your family finds the gesture endearing and thinks of you as being thoughtful anyway, then the activity was a success.

    也许你做饭做得很棒，但是如果你的家人更喜欢去餐馆吃饭，你就失败了。另一方面，你可能在晚餐烹饪活动中完全失败，但是如果你的家人觉得这个姿势很可爱，并且认为你很体贴，那么这个活动就是成功的。


    Taken even further, Be goals can be fulfilled without even needing to engage in any activity (Carver 2001). For example, suppose you live in a neighborhood that has high crime. This high crime made you feel unsafe (an unattained Be goal). Then, without any action on your part, the local police start 24/7 patrolling. Immediately, you start feeling safer. Over time, crime reduces, and you become safe. Your life-situation (your collection of Be goals) has changed even though you didn’t carry out any activities or tasks (Do or Motor control goals).

    更进一步说，Be 的目标甚至不需要参与任何活动就可以实现(Carver2001)。例如，假设你住在一个犯罪率很高的社区。这种高犯罪率使你感到不安全(一个未达到的目标)。然后，如果你不采取任何行动，当地警察就会开始全天候巡逻。马上，你就会觉得更安全了。随着时间的推移，犯罪率下降，你变得安全。你的生活状况(你收集的 Be 目标)已经改变，即使你没有进行任何活动或任务(做或运动控制目标)。


    Be goals are the most stable; Do and Motor control goals are transitory. Be goals are states of self-perception. They are entirely emotional (or psychological if you prefer that word). Do and Motor control goals are purely functional and are technology dependent. They are things you do to fulfill a Be goal.

    目标是最稳定的; 行动和运动控制目标是短暂的。目标是自我认知的状态。它们完全是情感上的(或者说心理上的，如果你喜欢这个词的话)。“做”和“运动”的控制目标纯粹是功能性的，并且是技术性的。它们是你为了实现目标而做的事情。


    Stated another way: You don’t ultimately want to achieve the Do and Motor goals; you want the Be goals.

    换一种说法: 你并不想最终实现“做”和“动力”的目标，你想要的是“成为”的目标。





    Figure 30. Ulwick sees jobs as activities and tasks (Ulwick 2005).

    图30. Ulwick 将工作视为活动和任务(Ulwick 2005)



    This reason— along with the fact that our self-perception changes slowly — means that Be goals are more stable than Do and Motor control goals. As illustrated by Powers and Carver, humans switch between and even combine multiple Do and Motor control goals as they aim to fulfill Be goals. For example, in my pursuit to “be thoughtful”, I might cook dinner, buy wine, write a poem, and make a home video. A real example of this behavior appears later in the article.

    这个原因ーー再加上我们的自我认知变化缓慢的事实ーー意味着 Be 目标比 Do 目标和 Motor 控制目标更稳定。正如异能和卡佛所说明的，人类在多个执行和运动控制目标之间切换，甚至结合，因为他们的目标是实现 Be 目标。例如，在我追求“体贴周到”的过程中，我可能会做饭、买酒、写诗、制作家庭录像。这种行为的一个真实例子将在本文后面出现。


    Now we’re ready to get into the two interpretations of JTBD.

    现在，我们准备进入 JTBD 的两种解释。


    Jobs-As-Activities

    作为活动的工作

    Determining how Jobs came to be associated with tasks and activities is tricky. The phrase Jobs to be Done, with regards to an innovation ideology, was first used by Clayton Christensen (Christensen 2003). In it he references:

    确定乔布斯是如何与任务和活动联系在一起的是一个棘手的问题。克莱顿 · 克里斯滕森(ClaytonChristensen，2003年出版)首先使用了“乔布斯待完成”这个短语来描述创新意识形态。他在书中提到:


    Rick Pedi as having “coined for us the language Jobs to be Done” (this account is expanded in Christensen’s 2016 book).

    里克•佩迪(Rick Pedi)“为我们创造了‘工作待完成’这种语言”(这一说法在克里斯滕森2016年出版的书中得到了扩展)。


    Anthony Ulwick of Strategyn as having “used a very similar concept in his consulting work, using the phrase outcomes that customers are seeking.”

    Strategyn 的安东尼•乌尔维克(Anthony Ulwick)“在他的咨询工作中使用了一个非常类似的概念，使用了客户正在寻求的结果这个短语。”


    James J. Gibson’s theory of affordances as “being a concept that mirrors what we term jobs or outcomes.”

    吉布森的可供性理论是“一个反映我们称之为工作或结果的概念。”


    However, Christensen never defined what a Job to be Done was, nor used it with rigor. Christensen gives examples of Job such as make the commute more interesting, placate children, feel like loving parents, and use small snippets of time productively (Christensen 2003). If you were to put these examples against Powers’ goal hierarchy, they range from low-level Motor control goals to high level Be goals.

    然而，克里斯滕森从来没有定义什么是“要完成的工作”，也没有严格地使用它。Christensen 举了一些例子，比如让上下班路上更有趣，安抚孩子，感觉自己像慈爱的父母，有效利用一小段时间(Christensen 2003)。如果你将这些例子与异能的目标层次相对照，它们的范围从低级别的马达控制目标到高级别的 Be 目标。


    I asked Clay’s team about this discrepancy when I met with them to develop the Jobs-As-Progress model. Their answer was that, back in 2003 they were just starting to develop the theory. As a result, some ambiguity existed.

    当我与克莱的团队会面开发“工作即进步”模型时，我询问了他们关于这个差异的问题。他们的回答是，早在2003年，他们才刚刚开始发展这一理论。因此，存在一些模棱两可的地方。


    The most notable instance of interpreting Jobs-As-Activities is from Anthony Ulwick (Ulwick 2005, 2016).

    最著名的诠释“工作即活动”的例子来自 Anthony Ulwick (Ulwick 2005,2016)。


    What is it? Ulwick is the primary proponent of the idea of Jobs-As-Activities. As an example of this thinking, Ulwick cites McGinneva’s “Customers want a quarter inch hole…” quote (Ulwick 2016).

    这是什么？Ulwick 是“作为活动的工作”理念的主要支持者。作为这种想法的一个例子，Ulwick 引用了 McGinneva 的“顾客想要一个四分之一英寸的洞...”引文(Ulwick 2016)。


    In his 2005 book, Ulwick describes a Job to be Done as:

    在他2005年出版的书中，乌尔维克这样描述待完成的工作:


    [Companies] must know which jobs their customers are trying to get done (that is, the tasks or activities customers are trying to carry out).

    (公司)必须知道他们的客户想要完成哪些工作(也就是说，客户想要完成的任务或活动)。


    In his 2016 book, he defines a Job to be Done as:

    在他2016年出版的书中，他对待完成工作的定义是:


    A task, goal or objective a person is trying to accomplish or a problem they are trying to resolve. A job can be functional, emotional or associated with product consumption (consumption chain jobs).

    一个人正在努力完成的任务、目标或目的，或者他们正在努力解决的问题。一份工作可以是功能性的、情感性的或者与产品消费相关的(消费链工作)。


    A Job to be Done is then described in terms of a Job Map:

    一个待完成的工作被描述为一个工作地图:


    Analysis of hundreds of jobs has revealed that all jobs consist of some or all of the eight fundamental process steps: define, locate, prepare, confirm, execute, monitor, modify and conclude (see the universal job map).

    对数百个作业的分析表明，所有作业都包含八个基本流程步骤中的一部分或全部: 定义、定位、准备、确认、执行、监视、修改和总结(见通用作业图)。


    Ulwick defines Jobs to be Done as:

    Ulwick 对待工作的定义是:


    Jobs-to-be-Done Theory provides a framework for (i) categorizing, defining, capturing, and organizing all your customer’s needs, and (ii) tying customer-defined performance metrics (in the form of desired outcome statements) to the Job-to-be-Done.

    工作待完成理论提供了一个框架，用于(i)分类、定义、捕捉和组织所有客户的需求，(ii)将客户定义的绩效指标(以期望的结果声明的形式)与工作待完成联系起来。


    With regards to being called a “theory”, the description given is not of a theory, but of an Ideology and Typology. A theory is a hypothesis of how and why a natural or social phenomenon happens — e.g. evolution, gravity, bending of space-time. On the other hand, an ideology is a belief system (e.g. a strategy) and a typology is a categorization schema (Bacharach 1989, Bhattacherjee 2012, Colquitt 2007).

    关于被称为“理论”，所给出的描述不是一个理论，而是一种意识形态和类型学。理论是对自然或社会现象如何以及为什么发生的假设ーー例如进化、重力、时空弯曲。另一方面，意识形态是一种信仰系统(例如一种策略) ，类型学是一种分类图式(Bacharach 1989，Bhattacherjee 2012，Colquitt 2007)。


    Ulwick’s Jobs-As-Activities suggests that customers want to do these activities. Examples of Jobs in this model include listen to music, drill a quarter-inch hole, storing-retrieving music, and cutting a piece of wood. As a result, the activity becomes the fundamental unit of analysis. Any emotional considerations are secondary to this core, functional Job:

    Ulwick 的“作为活动的工作”建议客户想要做这些活动。在这个模型中，乔布斯的例子包括听音乐，钻一个四分之一英寸的洞，存储-检索音乐，以及切割一块木头。因此，活动成为分析的基本单元。任何情感上的考虑都是次要的，这个核心，功能性的工作:


    Emotional jobs define how customers want to feel or avoid feeling as a result of executing the core functional job. Social jobs define how the customer wants to be perceived by others.

    情感工作定义了客户在执行核心功能工作时想要或避免的感受。社会工作定义了顾客希望别人如何看待他。


    The core functional job is the anchor around which all other needs are defined. It is defined first, then the emotional, related and consumption chain jobs are defined relative to the core functional job.

    核心功能性工作是定义所有其他需求的锚。首先对其进行定义，然后相对于核心职能工作定义情感工作、相关工作和消费链工作。


    Within the Powers model, a Job to be Done in this interpretation is a Program made up of Sequences — or Do goals made up of Motor control goals.

    在权力模型中，按照这种解释，“要完成的工作”是一个由序列组成的程序，或者说“要完成的目标”是由电机控制目标组成的。


    What is it based upon or similar to? Those who have experience in Goal-Directed Design, Cognitive Task Analysis, Hierarchical Task Analysis, Human Computer Interaction (HCI), Use Cases, or Activity-Centered Design will

    它是基于或类似于什么？那些在目标导向设计、认知任务分析、层次任务分析、人机交互(HCI)、用例或活动中心设计方面有经验的人



    Figure 31. “Warm up furnace” is an example of task analysis. Ulwick's idea of jobs to be done is similar to task analysis.

    图31。“预热炉”是任务分析的一个例子。Ulwick 关于完成工作的想法与任务分析类似


    recognize this interpretation of JTBD as similar to what they are already doing (figure 31), and the notion of “desired outcomes” is also similar to Sayan Chatterjee’s paper, Delivering desired outcomes efficiently: the creative key to competitive strategy (Chatterjee 1998).

    认识到 JTBD 的这种解释类似于他们已经在做的事情(图31) ，“期望结果”的概念也类似于 Sayan Chatterjee 的论文，有效地提供期望的结果: 竞争战略的创造性关键(Chatterjee 1998)。


    The many similarities of Jobs-As-Activities model has with these other existing ideas is why a lot of people claim that Jobs to be Done is nothing new.

    工作即活动模式与其他现有理念有许多相似之处，这就是为什么许多人声称“工作即完成”并不是什么新鲜事。


    For example, Ulwick’s Job Map is very similar to Norman’s Seven Stages of Action (figure 32). They’re not exactly the same, but they are strikingly similar. Both are based upon the idea of a person physically interacting with a technology through three phases: planning, doing, and evaluating.

    例如，Ulwick 的工作地图非常类似于 Norman 的七个行动阶段(图32)。它们虽然不完全一样，但却惊人地相似。两者都基于一个人通过三个阶段与技术进行物理交互的想法: 计划、实施和评估。


    Both Don Norman and Anthony Ulwick even use listen to music as an example of an activity. Here’s how Norman describes the activity of listen to music in his 2013 edition of his 1988 book:

    唐 · 诺曼和安东尼 · 乌尔维克甚至把听音乐作为一项活动的例子。下面是诺曼在他1988年出版的书的2013年版中对听音乐活动的描述:


    Focusing upon tasks is too limiting. Apple’s success with its music player, the iPod, was because Apple supported the entire activity

    专注于任务太局限了。苹果公司的音乐播放器 iPod 的成功，是因为苹果公司支持整个活动




    Figure 32. Don Norman’s action model (top) is very similar to Ulwick’s job map (bottom).

    图32。唐 · 诺曼的行动模型(上图)与 Ulwick 的工作地图(下图)非常相似


    involved in listening to music: discovering it, purchasing it, getting it into the music player, developing playlists (that could be shared), and listening to the music.

    参与听音乐: 发现它，购买它，把它放进音乐播放器，开发播放列表(可以共享) ，听音乐。


    The biggest difference between Ulwick’s Jobs-As-Activities model and HCI, Activity Centered Design, Goal-Directed Design, Cognitive Tasks analysis, and Use Cases is the addition of a business strategy layer. Ulwick’s ideology suggests that businesses should focus on creating technologies that help consumers better execute tasks and activities (Ulwick 2016):

    Ulwick 的“作为活动的工作”模型与 HCI、以活动为中心的设计、目标导向的设计、认知任务分析和用例之间最大的区别是增加了一个商业战略层。Ulwick 的思想认为，企业应该专注于创造技术，帮助消费者更好地执行任务和活动(Ulwick 2016) :


    New products and services win in the marketplace if they help customers get a job done better (faster, more predictably, with higher output) and / or more cheaply.

    如果新产品和服务能帮助客户更好地完成工作(更快、更可预测、产量更高)和/或更便宜，它们就能赢得市场。


    Jobs-As-Progress

    作为进步的工作

    The first mention of Jobs as Progress is in the Jobs to be Done Handbook (Spiek & Moesta 2014). But this book was about an interview method and doesn’t get into Customer Jobs theory. Currently, there are only two books that focus on Jobs as

    第一次提到作为进步的工作是在《工作待完成手册》(Spiek & Moesta 2014)。但是这本书是关于一种面试方法，并没有涉及到客户工作的理论。目前，只有两本关于乔布斯的书


    Progress and develop it as a theory: this book and Competing Against Luck (Christensen, Dillon, Duncan, Hall 2016).

    进步和发展它作为一个理论: 这本书和竞争反对运气(克里斯坦森，狄龙，邓肯，大厅2016年)。


    In Competing Against Luck Christensen writes:

    在《与运气竞争》一书中，克里斯滕森写道:


    It was Bob and his partner Rick Pedi who first brought me the puzzle that eventually led to the Theory of Jobs to Be Done and his work in

    是鲍勃和他的搭档里克 · 佩迪第一次给我带来了这个谜题，最终导致了《完成工作理论》和他的工作


    Figure 33. A visualization of a Job to be Done and “progress”.

    图33。要完成的工作和“进度”的可视化


    the years since has helped shape it.

    之后的几年帮助塑造了它。


    No references to Gibson, Ulwick, affordances, or desired outcomes appear in Christensen’s Competing Against Luck. Instead, Christensen replaces the idea that customers want “outcomes” with customers want “progress”. This Jobs-As-Progress model is the version Christensen, Moesta, and I promote.

    在克里斯滕森的《与运气竞争》一书中，没有提到吉布森、 Ulwick、经验或期望的结果。相反，克里斯滕森用客户希望“进步”来取代客户希望“结果”的想法。这种“工作即进步”的模式是我和克里斯滕森(Moesta)推广的版本。


    What is it? Jobs-As-Progress is a theory only. Theory tells you how and why things happen, not what you should do about it. Theory is descriptive, not prescriptive. Jobs-As-Progress aims to answer several social phenomena such as:

    这是什么？“工作即进步”只是一种理论。理论告诉你事情发生的方式和原因，而不是你应该怎么做。理论是描述性的，不是规定性的。“工作即进步”旨在回答以下几种社会现象:


    What causes someone to purchase a product for the first time?

    是什么促使人们第一次购买产品？


    Why and how do consumers use markets to adapt in a changing world.

    消费者为什么以及如何利用市场来适应不断变化的世界。


    Why and how do consumers shop (search for new products, services, and technologies)?

    消费者为什么以及如何购物(寻找新的产品、服务和技术) ？


    Why and how do consumers switch between products?

    消费者为什么以及如何在产品之间切换？


    The Jobs-As-Progress model suggests (hypothesizes) that a consumer will look for, buy, and use a product for the first time when a discrepancy exists between how things are today and how they want them to be in the future (recall Revlon’s “in the drug store we sell hope…” quote and Powers’ “Be” goal). Jobs-As-Progress is about a consumer’s desire to use markets with the aim of resolving a Be goal discrepancy.

    “工作即进步”模型假设消费者会第一次寻找、购买和使用一种产品，当事物的现状与他们希望未来的样子之间存在差异时(回想一下露华浓的“在药店里我们卖希望... ...”引用和鲍尔斯的“做自己”的目标)。作为进步的工作是关于一个消费者的愿望，使用市场的目的是解决一个是目标的差异。



    Figure 34. In “the why before the why”, basecamp founder Jason Fried writes about four jobs (Be goal discrepancies) that cause people to seek out solution that would enable them to change their life-situation.

    图34。Basecamp 创始人杰森•弗里德(Jason Fried)在《为什么在为什么之前》(the why before the why)一书中写道，有四种工作(目标不一致)促使人们寻找解决方案，从而改变自己的生活状况



    Two definitions of a Job to be Done in this model are:

    在这个模型中需要完成的工作有两个定义:


    We define a “job” as the progress that a person is trying to make in a particular circumstance (Christensen 2016).

    我们将“工作”定义为一个人在特定环境下努力取得的进步(Christensen 2016)。


    A Job to be Done is the process a consumer goes through whenever she aims to transform her existing life-situation into a preferred one but cannot because constraints are stopping her (Klement 2016).

    待完成的工作是一个消费者为了将现有的生活状况转变为更喜欢的生活状况而经历的过程，但由于受到限制而无法实现(Klement 2016)。


    One key to this model is to recognize that Jobs-As-Progress is about understanding why consumers change their historical purchase patterns — i.e. why they would stop using product X and start using product Y. Understanding what conditions must exist for this behavior change is important. If you want people to start using your

    这个模型的一个关键是要认识到，Jobs-As-Progress 是关于理解消费者为什么要改变他们的历史购买模式ーー也就是为什么他们不再使用产品 X 而开始使用产品 Y。理解这种行为改变必须存在什么条件是很重要的。如果你想让人们开始使用你的



    Figure 35. Dan Martell of clarity (clarity.fm) applied a jobs-as-progress model to grow and eventually sell his business. He understood that consumers were trying to resolve a be goal discrepancy, and that various solutions could be used to resolve it.

    图35。Clarity.fm 的丹•马特尔(Dan Martell)应用了“工作即进展”的模式来发展并最终出售自己的企业。他理解消费者正在试图解决目标差异，并且可以使用各种解决方案来解决这个问题


    product (i.e. create growth), then you’re gonna have to persuade them to stop using the products they use today and start using your product.

    产品(即创造增长) ，然后你必须说服他们停止使用他们现在使用的产品，开始使用你的产品。


    The other key to this model is to recognize that it’s about unattained Be goals (Figure 34). It’s not about Do or Motor control goals. Jobs-As-

    这个模型的另一个关键是认识到它是关于未实现的 Be 目标(图34)。这与行动或运动控制目标无关。工作


    Progress recognizes that tasks and activities are a means to an end only. They do not represent what consumers want.

    进步认识到任务和活动只是达到目的的一种手段，它们并不代表消费者想要什么。


    This realization helps us understand how consumers see and use markets. Until the Jobs-As-Progress model came along, most companies restricted competition to products that shared functionality (e.g. products that “cut a straight line”). However, because customers see tasks and activities as a means to end only, consumers end up considering products and services that vary greatly on functionality.

    这种认识有助于我们理解消费者如何看待和使用市场。在 Jobs-As-Progress 模式出现之前，大多数公司将竞争限制在共享功能的产品上(例如“直线切割”的产品)。然而，由于客户只将任务和活动视为结束的手段，因此客户最终考虑的产品和服务在功能上差异很大。


    This is clear in the Clarity case study from this book. In this example, Clarity founder Dan Martell learned that a lot of his customers were coming to Clarity because they had a Be goal discrepancy around being motivated and inspired. This discrepancy caused them to investigate and evaluate activities that ranged from “attend to a conference” to “video chat with a famous person”. Even though these

    这一点在本书的 Clarity 案例研究中很明显。在这个例子中，Clarity 的创始人 Dan Martell 了解到，他的许多客户之所以来到 Clarity，是因为他们在被激励和鼓舞方面存在着“ Be”目标差异。这种差异导致他们调查和评估从“参加会议”到“与名人视频聊天”的各种活动。即使这些


    solutions offer wildly different activities and are functionally different, they all competed in helping the consumer attain a particular set of Be goals (figure 34).

    解决方案提供了完全不同的活动，功能也不同，它们都在帮助消费者实现一组特定的 Be 目标(图34)。


    The Jobs-as-Progress model suggests that a great deal of innovation is about eliminating tasks and activities — not designing for them. IKEA’s innovation was to create furniture that you could order and assemble yourself without needing to “cut a straight line”, “drill a quarter inch hole”, or even “want a quarter inch hole”.

    “工作即进步”(Jobs-as-Progress)模式表明，大量创新都是关于消除任务和活动ーー而不是为它们设计。宜家的创新之处在于，你可以自己订购和组装家具，而不需要“切割直线”、“钻四分之一英寸的洞”，甚至“想要四分之一英寸的洞”。


    Moreover, in 2017, IKEA bought Task Rabbit. Why? Because they also understand that people don’t want to “assemble/build furniture” either.

    此外，在2017年，宜家收购了任务兔。为什么? 因为他们也明白，人们也不想“组装/制造家具”。


    Rather, they want to be organized, express their individuality, and feel comfortable in their home.

    相反，他们希望被组织起来，表达他们的个性，在家里感到舒适。


    What is it based upon or similar to? The theoretical basis of Jobs-As-Progress draws from many sources — too many to list here. The most import parts (humans as goal-directed organisms that self-regulate discrepancies via feedback loops) stems from people such as Norbert Wiener (1961), Herbert Simon (1996), Albert Bandura (1997), Charles S. Carver (2001), and William Powers (1972).

    它是基于或类似于什么？“作为进步的工作”的理论基础来自许多方面ーー太多了，无法在此列举。最重要的部分(人类作为目标导向的有机体，通过反馈回路自我调节差异)源于人类，如诺伯特 · 维纳(1961) ，赫伯特 · 西蒙(1996) ，阿尔伯特 · 班杜拉(1997) ，查尔斯 · S · 卡弗(2001)和威廉 · 鲍尔斯(1972)。


    I am not aware of these ideas as having been used within the context of innovation or design. The closest thing to it would be Cooper’s Goal-Directed Design and Hassenzahl’s Experience Design (Hassenzahl 2010). However, even these are different. Goal-Directed Design is a method while Experience Design is an ideology. Neither of these aims to explain why or how any natural or social phenomena happen.

    我没有意识到这些想法已经被用在创新或设计的背景下。最接近它的是 Cooper 的目标导向设计和 Hassenzahl 的体验设计(Hassenzahl 2010)。然而，即使是这些也是不同的。目标导向设计是一种方法，体验设计是一种意识形态。这些都不是为了解释为什么或如何发生任何自然或社会现象。


    Two Different, Incompatible Models

    两种不同的，不相容的模式

    If it isn’t clear, these are two different, and incompatible, interpretations of why we buy and use products.

    如果还不清楚的话，这就是对我们为什么购买和使用产品的两种不同的、互不相容的解释。


    The Jobs-As-Activities model suggests that customers want to engage in the activity; therefore, your efforts should be to improve that activity.

    Jobs-As-Activity 模型表明，客户希望参与该活动; 因此，您的努力应该是改进该活动。



    Figure 36. The Jobs-as-Progress model suggests that we create technologies, so we can skip having to “do things” and have more time to enjoy a particular life-situation.

    图36。“工作即进步”模式建议我们创造技术，这样我们就可以跳过“做事情”的步骤，有更多的时间享受特定的生活环境



    Whereas the Jobs-As-Progress model suggests that there’s nothing functional or activity related about a JTBD. Why? Because it is technologies that function, not our desires. Don Norman (1988) also offers his opinion about focusing on tasks or activities only:

    然而 Jobs-As-Progress 模型表明 JTBD 没有任何功能或活动相关。为什么？因为起作用的是技术，而不是我们的欲望。唐 · 诺曼(1988)也提出了他的观点，关于专注于任务或活动:


    Most innovation is done as an incremental enhancement of existing products. What about radical ideas, ones that introduce new product categories to the marketplace? These come about by reconsidering the goals, and always asking why the real goal is: what is called root cause analysis.

    大多数创新都是作为对现有产品的渐进增强而进行的。那些激进的想法呢? 那些将新产品类别引入市场的想法？这些都是通过重新考虑目标，并总是问为什么真正的目标是: 什么是所谓的根本原因分析。


    Harvard Business School marketing professor Theodore Levitt once pointed out, “People don’t want to buy a quarter-inch drill. They want a quarter-inch hole!” Levitt’s example of the drill implying that the goal is really a hole is only partially correct, however. When people go to a store to buy a drill, that is not their real goal. But why would anyone want a quarter-inch hole? Clearly that is an intermediate goal. Perhaps they wanted to hang shelves on the wall. Levitt stopped too soon.

    哈佛商学院市场营销学教授西奥多•莱维特(Theodore Levitt)曾指出: “人们不想买四分之一英寸的钻头。他们想要一个四分之一英寸的洞!”然而，莱维特关于钻孔的例子暗示目标实际上是一个洞，这只是部分正确。当人们去商店买钻头时，那并不是他们真正的目的。但为什么会有人想要四分之一英寸的洞呢？显然，这是一个中间目标。也许他们想把架子挂在墙上。莱维特停得太早了。


    Once you realize that they don’t really want the drill, you realize that perhaps they don’t really want the hole, either: they want to install their bookshelves. Why not develop methods that don’t require holes?

    一旦你意识到他们不是真的想要钻孔机，你就会意识到他们可能也不是真的想要那个洞: 他们想要安装他们的书架。为什么不开发不需要漏洞的方法呢？


    Or perhaps books that don’t require bookshelves. (Yes, I know: electronic books, e-books.)

    或者是不需要书架的书(是的，我知道: 电子书，电子书。)


    Rather, a consumer’s ultimate motivation is to regulate a discrepancy they have amongst Be goals. e.g. help me become financially stable, make me confident and impress others. In their pursuit of this goal, consumers may engage in one or more activities…or maybe they don’t engage in any activity at all.

    相反，消费者的最终动机是调节他们在 Be 目标之间的差异。帮助我在经济上变得稳定，使我自信，给别人留下深刻印象。在他们追求这个目标的过程中，消费者可能会参与一个或多个活动... ... 或者他们可能根本不参与任何活动。


    For example, the Jobs-As-Progress models suggest that people don’t want to mow the lawn. They do so only because they own grass and grass grows (and dies). Avoiding having to “mow the lawn” is why innovations such as lawn-care services, automated lawn mowers, and field turf (fake grass) exist. Perhaps one day GMO grass will be created that won’t ever have to be cut.

    例如，“工作即进步”(Jobs-As-Progress)模式表明，人们不想修剪草坪。他们这样做只是因为他们拥有草和草生长(和死亡)。避免“割草”是为什么创新，如草坪护理服务，自动割草机，和草坪(假草)存在。也许有一天转基因草将被创造出来，而且永远不需要被修剪。


    Challenges in Understanding a Tangled Mess

    理解一团乱麻的挑战
