    It’s impossible to predict the future of Customer Jobs theory; however, one thing is for sure: a lot of people are confused. Moreover, there’s little reason to think that will change in the future. Two reasons are:

    预测客户工作理论的未来是不可能的; 然而，有一件事是肯定的: 许多人感到困惑。此外，几乎没有理由认为这种情况会在未来发生改变。两个原因是:


    Misattributions. One challenge with advancing Customer Jobs theory, is how many people repeat what others have written or said without investigating sources. For example, Alex Osterwalder wrote (2014):

    错误的归属。推进客户工作理论面临的一个挑战是，有多少人在没有调查消息来源的情况下重复别人写过或说过的东西。例如，亚历克斯 · 奥斯特瓦尔德(Alex Osterwalder)在2014年写道:


    The jobs to be done concept was developed independently by several business thinkers including Anthony Ulwick of the consulting firm Strategyn, consultants Rick Pedi and Bob Moesta, and Professor Denise Nitterhouse of DePaul University. It was popularized by Clay Christensen and his consulting firm Innosight and Anthony Ulwick’s Strategyn.

    待完成工作的概念是由多位商业思想家独立提出的，其中包括咨询公司 Strategyn 的安东尼•乌尔维克(Anthony Ulwick)、咨询顾问里克•佩迪(Rick Pedi)和鲍勃•莫斯塔(Bob Moesta) ，以及德保罗大学学教授丹尼斯•尼特豪斯(Denise Nitterhouse)。克莱•克里斯滕森(Clay Christensen)和他的咨询公司 Innosight 以及安东尼•乌尔维克(Anthony Ulwick)的《 Strategyn 》使该书流行起来。


    Here Osterwalder is trying to give due credit, but accidentally adds to the confusion:

    在这一点上，奥斯特瓦尔德试图给予应有的赞扬，但不小心加剧了混乱:


    The citation makes it seem like Christensen, Nitterhouse, Moesta, Ulwick, and Pedi are talking about the same thing— while they are discussing wildly different things

    引文让人觉得克里斯滕森、尼特豪斯、 Moesta、 Ulwick 和佩迪在谈论同一件事ーー而他们却在讨论截然不同的事情


    Christensen (2017) writes that Pedi and Moesta (not Ulwick and Nitterhouse) were the originators of Customer Jobs thinking

    Christensen (2017)写道 Pedi 和 Moesta (不是 Ulwick 和 Nitterhouse)是客户工作思想的创始人


    While Denise Nitterhouse was cited as a co-author of the article “Finding the Right Job For Your Product” (Christensen et al 2007), she’s a proponent of Customer Case Research (Berstell, Nitterhouse 1997) which isn’t about JTBD. Moreover, a comment by “Denise Nitterhouse” claims that Nitterhouse is mistakenly attributed with the milkshake story (see article by Derek Christensen).

    当 Denise Nitterhouse 被引用为“为你的产品找到合适的工作”(Christensen et al 2007)这篇文章的合著者时，她是客户案例研究的支持者(Berstell，Nitterhouse 1997) ，这与 JTBD 无关。此外，“丹尼斯 · 尼特豪斯”的评论声称，尼特豪斯被错误地归咎于奶昔故事(见德里克 · 克里斯滕森的文章)。


    Repeating nascent, or passing, ideas as if they are well researched. Here’s another challenge facing the future of JTBD: ideas are repeated without any proof or investigation of it’s sources. For example, the idea that there are functional, social, and emotional jobs originates from just one line (Christensen 2003):

    重复新生的或传递的想法，好像它们是经过深入研究的。JTBD 的未来还面临着另一个挑战: 在没有任何证据或对其来源进行调查的情况下重复思想。例如，功能性、社会性和情感性工作的概念只源于一句话(Christensen 2003) :


    The functional, emotional, and social dimensions of the jobs that customers need to get done constitute the circumstances in which they buy.

    客户需要完成的工作的功能、情感和社会维度构成了他们购买的环境。


    That’s it! Just one line. No evidence, citation, or further clarification is given.

    就这样! 只有一句话。没有证据，引证，或进一步的澄清。


    Over the years, many people have repeated and expanded upon this ontology of Jobs…but there’s no experimental data or theoretical basis to support it. It’s a textbook example of Argumentum ad Populum (i.e. “If many believe so, it is so”).

    多年来，许多人重复并扩展了乔布斯的这个本体论... ... 但是没有实验数据或理论基础来支持它。这是诉诸群众的一个典型例子(比如“如果很多人这么认为，那么事实就是如此”)。


    The Future? Use What’s Helpful. Don’t Assume Anything

    未来? 使用有用的东西。不要假设任何东西

    If you choose to get deeper into JTBD, know that it is quite the rabbit hole — for better or worse. My advice is to remain pragmatic, use what you feel is helpful, and be skeptical of what other people write and talk about.

    如果你选择深入 JTBD，要知道这是一个兔子洞ーー不管是好是坏。我的建议是保持务实，利用你觉得有帮助的东西，并对其他人写的和谈论的东西保持怀疑。


    The ultimate goal is to be great at making products that people will buy. The rest is just a means to that end.

    最终目标是做出人们愿意购买的产品。剩下的只是达到目的的手段。

    参考文献

    霍恩斯比，P。(2010)层次任务分析

  15. Appendix: A Summary of Customer Jobs

    附录: 客户工作摘要

    What Is Customer Jobs (The Theory)?

    什么是客户工作(理论) ？


    A Job to be Done is a process: it starts, it runs, and it ends. The key difference, however, is that a JTBD describes how a customer changes or wishes to change. With this in mind, we define a JTBD as follows:

    待完成的工作是一个过程: 它开始、运行和结束。但是，关键的区别在于 JTBD 描述了客户如何更改或希望更改。考虑到这一点，我们将 JTBD 定义如下:


    A Job to be Done is the process a consumer goes through whenever she aims to transform her existing life-situation into a preferred one but cannot because there are constraints that stop her.

    待完成的工作是一个消费者想要将现有的生活环境转变为自己喜欢的生活环境时所经历的一个过程，但是由于受到限制而无法实现。


    What Isn’t A Customer Job?

    什么不是顾客工作？


    If you are in doubt whether someone is describing a customer’s JTBD, ask these questions:

    如果你不确定某人是否在描述客户的 JTBD，那么问下面这些问题:


    Does this describe an action?

    这是否描述了一种行为？


    Can I visualize someone doing this?

    我能想象有人这么做吗？


    If you answer “yes” to these questions, you’re probably describing a solution for a JTBD and not a JTBD itself. Remember, a JTBD is not a task, activity, or has any functional characteristic. It describes a customer’s desire to improve him-/herself— something that can neither be seen nor can be described in terms of actions or functional qualities.

    如果您对这些问题的回答是肯定的，那么您可能描述的是 JTBD 的解决方案，而不是 JTBD 本身。请记住，JTBD 不是任务、活动或具有任何功能特征。它描述了一个客户想要提高自己的欲望ーー这种欲望既不能被看到，也不能用行动或功能特性来描述。


    What About Different Types of Jobs?

    不同类型的工作呢？


    It is best to avoid coming up with different types of Jobs or stratifying them. Any attempt to do so will lead to logical inconsistencies and overlaps. It’s best to keep it simple: each Job is a combination of various emotional forces.

    最好避免提出不同类型的工作或将它们分层。任何这样做的尝试都会导致逻辑上的不一致和重叠。最好保持简单: 每份工作都是各种情感力量的结合。


    What Are JTBD Principles?

    什么是 JTBD 原则？


    Customers don’t want your product or what it does; they want help making their lives better (i.e., they want progress).

    客户不想要你的产品或者它能做什么; 他们想要的是帮助他们生活得更好(也就是说，他们想要进步)。


    People have Jobs; things don’t.

    人们有工作，事情没有。

    A Summary of Customer Jobs

    客户工作综述


    Competition is defined in the minds of customers, and they use progress as their criterion.

    竞争在顾客心目中是有定义的，他们用进步作为他们的标准。


    When customers start using a solution for a JTBD, they stop using something else. Innovation opportunities exist when customers exhibit compensatory behaviors. Favor progress over outcomes and goals.

    当客户开始使用 JTBD 的解决方案时，他们停止使用其他解决方案。当顾客表现出补偿行为时，就存在创新机会。支持取得进展而不是结果和目标。

    Progress defines value; contrast reveals value.

    进步定义价值，对比揭示价值。


    Solutions for Jobs deliver value beyond the moment of use.

    乔布斯的解决方案提供超越使用时刻的价值。


    Producers, consumers, solutions, and Jobs should be thought of as parts of a system that work together to evolve markets.

    生产者、消费者、解决方案和乔布斯应该被看作是一个系统的一部分，它们共同努力促进市场的发展。

  16. Appendix: Summary of Putting Customer Jobs to Work

    附录: 将客户工作付诸实施的摘要

    Chapter 4

    第四章


    Ask customers about what they’ve done, not just what they want. Confirm it if you can.

    询问客户他们做了什么，而不仅仅是他们想要什么。如果可以的话，确认一下。


    Ask the right questions to learn how your customers view competition.

    提出正确的问题来了解你的客户是如何看待竞争的。


    Learn what kind of progress customers are seeking. What’s their emotional motivation (JTBD)? Use that to segment competition.

    了解客户需要什么样的进步。他们的情感动机是什么? 利用这一点来细分竞争对手。


    Ask yourself, “From which budget will my product take away money?” Create better marketing material by speaking to your customers’ JTBD.

    问问你自己，“我的产品会从哪个预算中拿走钱?”通过与客户的 JTBD 对话来创建更好的营销材料。

    Focus on delivering emotional progress (getting a Job Done). Don’t focus solely on functionality.

    专注于实现情感上的进步(完成工作)。不要只关注功能性。


    Chapter 5

    第五章


    How do you convince teammates or management to change a product? Frame design challenges as a JTBD.

    如何说服团队成员或管理层更改产品? 框架设计作为 JTBD 面临的挑战。


    Dig deeper when you tap into a struggle or aspiration. How have customers tried to solve it before?

    当你陷入挣扎或渴望时，再深入挖掘一下。以前客户是如何尝试解决这个问题的？


    Determine if anxiety is a competitor. If it is, find ways of reducing it.

    确定焦虑是否是竞争对手，如果是，找到减少焦虑的方法。


    Be suspicious of the “impulse purchase” concept. No purchase is random.

    要怀疑“冲动购物”的概念。没有任何购物是随机的。


    Chapter 6

    第六章


    Don’t depend on demographics.

    不要依赖人口统计学。


    Create better advertising and promotional material by speaking to what customers value.

    通过谈论客户的价值来创造更好的广告和促销材料。


    Teams become more motivated, build consensus, and share a vision when they do JTBD research together.

    当团队一起进行 JTBD 研究时，他们会变得更有动力，建立共识，并分享愿景。


    First, study the push and pull.

    首先，学习推拉。


    Dig into inertia and anxiety after identifying push and pull.

    在分辨推拉之后深入研究惰性和焦虑。


    Fight anxiety and generate pull by helping customers visualize the progress they will make by using your product.

    通过帮助客户想象他们使用你的产品所取得的进步来战胜焦虑并产生吸引力。


    Reduce anxiety-in-choice with trials, refunds, and discounts.

    通过试用、退款和折扣减少选择中的焦虑。


    Identify any habits-in-use that keep customers from using your product. Adjust your product to help them along.

    找出任何阻止客户使用你的产品的使用习惯。调整你的产品来帮助他们。


    Chapter 8

    第八章


    Create a constancy of purpose to innovate for your organization. Discover the customers’ JTBD by focusing on what doesn’t change.

    为你的组织创造一个不变的目标，通过关注不变的东西来发现客户的 JTBD。

    Before you make anything, have a clear picture in your mind of what customers will stop doing.

    在你做任何事情之前，在你的头脑中有一个清晰的画面，客户将停止做什么。


    Chapter 9

    第九章


    Don’t restrict competition to products with similar functionality or physical characteristics.

    不要将竞争局限于功能或物理特性相似的产品。


    Talk with your customers!

    和你的顾客谈谈！


    Confirm that competition exists between products by finding customers who switched.

    通过寻找转换的客户来确认产品之间存在竞争。


    Do you think you’re creating a new market? Think again. Know what budget you’re taking away from.

    你认为你正在创造一个新的市场吗? 再想一想。知道你从哪个预算中拿走了什么。

    Continually refresh the competitive landscape with ongoing feedback from customers.

    不断刷新竞争格局与持续的反馈从客户。


    Remember that not every JTBD needs to be solved with a product that customers buy.

    请记住，并不是每个 JTBD 都需要用客户购买的产品来解决。


    Chapter 10

    第十章


    Begin by identifying a struggle or aspiration. Start wide and get progressively narrow.

    从确定一个斗争或抱负开始，从广泛的开始，逐步缩小范围。


    Find innovation opportunities when customers exhibit compensatory behaviors.

    当顾客表现出补偿行为时，寻找创新机会。


    Chapter 11

    第11章


    Innovation opportunities are found through looking for specific data.

    创新机会是通过寻找具体的数据找到的。


    Know the difference between a struggling customer and a merely inconvenienced customer.

    了解苦苦挣扎的客户和仅仅是不方便的客户之间的区别。


    Great advertising comes from speaking to the customers’ struggling moment. Digging deep into customer motivation reveals innovation opportunities.

    伟大的广告来自于对消费者挣扎的时刻的演讲。深入挖掘消费者的动机揭示了创新的机会。

    You can deliver progress to your customers’ JTBD by offering a set of products that work together as a system.

    通过提供一组作为系统一起工作的产品，您可以向客户的 JTBD 交付进度。


    Chapter 12

    第12章


    Grow your business, reduce churn, and capture more profits by delivering progress to customers.

    通过向客户提供进展来增长你的业务，减少流失，并获得更多的利润。


    Unlock your innovation creativity by asking, “What comes after?”

    通过询问“接下来会发生什么?”来释放你的创新创造力


    Chapter 13

    第13章


    Grow your business by unlocking new aspirations and offering products for them.

    通过释放新的抱负和为他们提供产品来发展你的业务。


    Think of your business as delivering a combination of products that work together to forward the system of progress.

    可以将您的业务看作是交付产品的组合，这些产品协同工作以推进进度系统。


    Find product opportunities by looking forward and backward on the system of progress.

    通过前瞻和回顾进步系统来发现产品机会。


    Chapter 14

    第14章


    Persuade customers to reject their current products by changing their JTBD.

    通过更改 JTBD 来说服客户拒绝他们当前的产品。


    Bring focus to which system of progress you’re solving for by splitting up products that deliver different types of progress.

    通过拆分产品来提供不同类型的进度，将焦点集中在你正在解决的进度系统上。


  17. Notes

    笔记

21 Look for “WYSIATI”. Kahneman, D. (2011). Thinking, fast and slow. Macmillan.

寻找“ WYSIATI”。卡尼曼，D。(2011)。思考，快速和缓慢。麦克米伦。


22 Learn about revealed preference vs. stated preference from Paul Samuelson’s “A Note on the Pure Theory of Consumer’s Behavior,” Economica, 1938. H. S. Houthakker’s “Revealed Preference and the Utility Function,” Economica, 1950. M. K. Richter’s “Revealed Preference Theory,” Econometrica: Journal of the Econometric Society, 1966.

从保罗 · 萨缪尔森的《消费者行为的纯理论》一书中了解显示性偏好与陈述偏好，《经济学人》 ，1938年。胡萨克的《显示性偏好与效用函数》 ，《经济学》 ，1950年。里希特的《显示性偏好理论》 ，《计量经济学: 经济计量学会杂志》 ，1966年。


23 Preference reversal is explained in The Causes of Preference Reversal by Amos Tversky, Paul Slovic, and Daniel Kahneman, https://goo.gl/uv88iz.

23《偏好逆转的原因》一书解释了偏好逆转的原因，作者是阿莫斯 · 特沃斯基、保罗 · 斯洛维奇和丹尼尔 · 卡尼曼， https://goo.gl/uv88iz。


24 Read about expectations being violated in Gary Klein’s Sources of Power: How People Make Decisions, https://goo.gl/LVvRkf.

读读加里 · 克莱因的《权力的来源: 人们如何做决定》一书中关于期望被违背的 https://goo.gl/lvvrkf。

32 How the chotuKool started from Innosight’s Innovation Case Study, http://goo.gl/IeZwXL. Also see “Godrej Chotukool: A Cooling Solution for Mass Markets” by C. Dhanraj, B. Suram, and P. Vemuri from Harvard Business Review, https://goo.gl/HfnKRs.

32 chootukool 是如何从 Innosight 的创新案例研究开始的， http://goo.gl/iezwxl。另见《哈佛商业评论》的 c. Dhanraj，b. Suram 和 p. Vemuri 的《 Godrej Chotukool: 大众市场降温解决方案》 ， https://goo.gl/hfnkrs。


33 George Meneze’s quote about selling millions of chotuKools from Fundamentals of Management: Asia Pacific Edition, https://goo.gl/z14cWj. chotuKool wins Edison Award from Innosight, http://goo.gl/hF3IXh and http://goo.gl/wpfvGn. Dr. Christensen praising the chotuKool, http://goo.gl/ioRFAK. Harvard Business School praising the chotuKool “Godrej Chotukool: A Cooling Solution for Mass Markets,” http://goo.gl/75UmXn. Harvard Business School case study “Little Cool, Big Opportunity” by Rory McDonald, Derek van Bever, and Efosa Ojomo, https://goo.gl/W0niu3. 33乔治•梅内兹(George Meneze)关于销售《管理基础: 亚太版》(Asia Pacific Edition， https://goo.gl/z14cwj )中数以百万计的 chotuKools 产品的评论。Chutkool 赢得了来自 Innosight、 http://goo.gl/hf3ixh 和 http://goo.gl/wpfvgn 的爱迪生奖。克里斯坦森博士赞扬了 http://goo.gl/iorfak。哈佛商学院称赞 chotuKool“ Godrej chotuKool: 为大众市场降温的解决方案”， http://goo.gl/75umxn。哈佛商学院案例研究“小酷，大机遇”，罗里麦克唐纳，德里克范贝弗，和埃弗萨奥霍莫， https://goo.gl/w0niu3。参考净水器和 chotuWash“在 Godrej，ChotuKool 催生了主要的商业战略”， http://goo.gl/hlk5l1和“跨国公司正在成为印度: Godrej 的乔治 · 梅内塞斯”， http://goo.gl/mgygor。更多关于 chotuWash， http://goo.gl/s57eu9和“一个小小的创新引领下一个大事件”的 http://goo.gl/bgb226。


34 Only fifteen thousand chotuKools from S. Sharma’s article in DNA India, “At Godrej, ChotuKool Spawns Major Business Strategy,” http://goo.gl/4oxFQ1. Also in Engineering Applications in Sustainable Design and Development by Bradley Striebig, Adebayo A. Ogundipe, and Maria Papadakis (Nelson Education, 2015), p. 664. The chotuKool was first released in the state of Maharashtra: population 114.2 million. In “Back to Business Fundamentals: Making “Bottom of the Pyramid” Relevant to Core Business,” E. Simanis,

沙玛在《脱氧核糖核酸印度》上发表的文章《在戈德雷吉，乔图库尔产生了重大的商业战略》中，只有一万五千个乔图库尔 http://goo.gl/4oxfq1。也在工程应用在可持续设计和发展布拉德利 Striebig，阿德巴约 A. 奥贡迪佩，和玛丽亚帕帕达基斯(纳尔逊教育，2015年) ，第664页。Chootukool 首次发布于 Maharashtra，人口1.142亿。在《回到商业基础: 使金字塔底部与核心业务相关》一文中，E,

M. Milstein, and D. Ménascé point out that the chotuKool was celebrated by Godrej before any units were sold, https://goo.gl/gfFiL3. Comments about the chotuKool’s failure, as well as the general flaw with disruptive innovations are echoed here: P. Soni (2014), “Why Corporate Frugal Innovations Fail and Grassroots Frugal Innovations Succeed,” http://goo.gl/rqcX0w.

米尔斯坦先生和 D · 梅纳斯切先生指出，chootukool 在出售之前就已经被戈德雷伊 https://goo.gl/gffil3庆祝过了。关于 chotuKool 的失败，以及破坏性创新的普遍缺陷的评论在这里得到了回应: P.Soni (2014) ，《为什么企业节俭创新失败，而草根节俭创新成功》 http://goo.gl/rqcx0w。

51 Read about Deming and Ford, http://goo.gl/khzdpt and http://goo.gl/sS4WJa.

阅读有关戴明和福特、 http://goo.gl/khzdpt 和 http://goo.gl/ss4wja 的文章。

53 This is another example of Gary Klein’s mental simulation, https://goo.gl/0GjEji.

53这是加里 · 克莱因心理模拟的另一个例子， https://goo.gl/0gjeji。


54 Shewhart Cycle: Walter Andrew Shewhart, Economic Control of Quality of Manufactured Product (ASQ Quality Press, 1931). Walter Andrew Shewhart and William Edwards Deming, Statistical Method from the Viewpoint of Quality Control (Courier Corporation, 1939). More history of the Shewhart Cycle and PDSA from Ronald Moen’s Foundation and History of the PDSA Cycle, http://goo.gl/cm6fNN.

54休哈特周期: 沃尔特安德鲁休哈特，制成品质量的经济控制(ASQ 质量出版社，1931年)。沃尔特安德鲁休哈特和爱德华兹·戴明，从质量控制的观点统计方法(快递公司，1939年)。更多关于休哈特周期和 PDSA 的历史，来自 Ronald Moen 的基金会和 PDSA 周期的历史， http://goo.gl/cm6fnn。


55 Apple’s iPhone numbers from statista, http://goo.gl/5TiRmr. Applications in App Store, http://goo.gl/wqL8Lm. Service vs. system: Instead of calling a collection of products a service, you could call them a system—a smaller system that contributes to the larger system of progress. Use whatever language is most comfortable for you.

返回文章页面苹果 iPhone http://goo.gl/5tirmr :。应用程序商店中的应用程序， http://goo.gl/wql8lm。服务 VS 系统: 与其把一组产品称为服务，不如把它们称为系统ーー一个更小的系统，它有助于形成更大的进步系统。使用你觉得最舒服的语言。


56 Read Tim Cook’s statement during an earnings report by R. Ritchie, “This Is Tim: Apple’s CEO on the Company’s 2016 Q3 Earnings,” http://goo.gl/ujQtqX.

56. 阅读里奇在一份收益报告中的陈述，“这是蒂姆: 苹果公司2016年第三季度收益的首席执行官,”http://goo.gl/ujqtqx。

63 “Context-Dependent Preferences,” by Amos Tversky and Itamar Simonson, https://goo.gl/MK4Hfv. Kahneman, “The Causes of Preference Reversal,”

https://goo.gl/23A0sc. Learn about intransitivity of preference: Amos Tversky, “Intransitivity of Preferences,” https://goo.gl/6r9K0X.
